questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to breast changes. During the past few months, she has noticed skin dimpling over the right breast which has slowly increased. She has previously been in good health, eats a balanced diet and exercises regularly. Family history is negative for breast cancer. She does not smoke or use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, skin dimpling is noticed on the right upper quadrant of the right breast. A firm, fixed mass is palpated at the same location. Mammography reveals a 2 cm, dense mass with spiculated margins. A core-needle biopsy is obtained and shows sheets of anaplastic cells with an extensive desmoplastic response. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has an invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC), the most common type of breast cancer, accounting for up to 80% of invasive cancers. It is important to note that the term IDC is used for all carcinomas that are not subclassified into specialized types (e.g., mucinous, tubular). The tumor usually arises from ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and crosses the basement membrane. Ductal carcinoma typically produces an extensive desmoplastic response, which is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue that surrounds the tumor and replaces the normal breast tissue. This reaction leads to an identifiable mammographic and sonographic density, and a hard, palpable irregular mass upon examination. On histology, its appearance ranges from tumors with well-developed tubules to sheets of anaplastic cells. About 60% of the tumors are ER-positive, 20% HER2 positive, and 15% are negative for both.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), it is rarely associated with calcifications on mammography. On histology, the tumor has a homogeneous appearance. The cells are monomorphic with round nuclei and are found in clusters within the lobules. LCIS is not associated with an extensive desmoplastic response and is unlikely to be observed on mammography.   
❌ Comedo carcinoma:
Incorrect: A comedocarcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is characterized by extensive necrosis, aggressive behavior, and increased risk for recurrence. On histology, the lesion plugs the lactiferous duct and exhibits necrosis. Transected ducts produce toothpaste-like necrotic tissue that extrudes when gentle pressure is applied to the breast.  
❌ Tubular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Tubular carcinoma is a rare type of ER-positive/HER2- negative cancer accounting for up to 2% of invasive breast cancers. The majority of cases are detected on mammography as a small irregular mass. On histology, cells are arranged in well-formed tubules. Metastases to the lymph nodes are rare, and the prognosis is excellent. In about 3/4 of the cases, a low grade associated ductal carcinoma in situ is present.   
✅ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mucinous carcinoma:
Incorrect: Mucinous (colloid) carcinoma is an ER-positive/HER2- negative tumor that constitutes up to 2% of invasive breast cancers. On gross examination, it has a gelatinous appearance and is well-circumscribed. On histology, nests of tumor cells dispersed in extracellular mucin can be seen. It is considered a prognostically favorable variant among invasive breast cancers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for the past few hours. A week ago, she had an upper respiratory infection, and since then, she has not recovered completely. Medical history is significant for smoking half-a-pack of cigarettes daily and drinking 3 beers a week but is otherwise unremarkable. Medications include oral contraceptives and ibuprofen for occasional migraine headaches. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension. When the patient inhales, the radial pulse suddenly becomes undetectable. The lungs are clear to auscultation, and no wheezes are heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, jugular venous distension, and pulsus paradoxus following a viral illness is consistent with cardiac tamponade.   

Cardiac tamponade occurs when large amounts of fluid accumulate between the layers of the pericardium (pericardial effusion), resulting in compression of the heart. Common etiologies include infectious, trauma, metabolic, autoimmune, cancer or idiopathic. The presentation may be acute and develop over minutes (e.g. trauma) or subacute, which develops over hours to days (e.g., uremia, post-viral) when enough fluid accumulates. The classic triad of symptoms, known as the Beck triad, consists of hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. Other signs and symptoms include syncope, chest pain, and pulsus paradoxus.  

Pulsus paradoxus refers to an abnormal decrease in the systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) observed during inspiration. It is important to note, however, that pulsus paradoxus can also be seen in some cases of hypovolemic shock and acute and chronic pulmonary obstructive disease. Pulsus paradoxus occurs as a result of the limited outward expansion of the right ventricle as the preload is increased during inspiration. This leads to bulging of the interventricular septum into the left ventricle with reduction in left ventricular filling, which decreases the stroke volume. The reduced stroke volume manifests as a drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.  

Patients suspected of cardiac tamponade should be promptly evaluated with an electrocardiogram, chest radiograph, and echocardiography. Electrocardiogram typically shows normal sinus tachycardia and electrical alternans, which is characterized by beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complex. Echocardiography plays a major role in identification of pericardial effusion. Definitive treatment includes drainage by needle (pericardiocentesis) or surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Viral myocarditis:
Incorrect: The clinical presentation of myocarditis is highly variable, ranging from subclinical disease to fatigue, chest pain, heart failure, arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and sudden death. Weak pulses may be observed in patients with myocarditis, as the dilated heart cannot efficiently pump out the blood; however, pulsus paradoxus is not observed.   
❌ Myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Acute myocardial infarction typically presents with chest pain that radiates to the jaw and left shoulder, diaphoresis, and dyspnea. It may progress to cardiogenic shock, which is characterized by tachycardia, hypotension, jugular venous distention, and pulmonary edema. However, it does not cause pulsus paradoxus, and this patient's age favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Cardiac tamponade:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism can present with shortness of breath, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. Although pulsus paradoxus can also rarely be seen, patients typically have hypoxemia, which is not seen in this patient.   
❌ Constrictive pericarditis:
Incorrect: Constrictive pericarditis shares many common features with cardiac tamponade, including pulsus paradoxus, jugular venous distension, and diastolic dysfunction. Constrictive pericarditis can occur as a result of viral, post-cardiac surgery, post-radiation therapy, connective tissue disorder or idiopathic. However, it is unlikely to develop after 1 week of viral illness, and other features would be expected (ascites, pulsatile hepatomegaly).

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of burning epigastric pain approximately 3 hours after eating. The patient reports he is often woken up at night with abdominal discomfort and nausea. He does not have any previous medical problems and does not take any medications. The patient undergoes endoscopy, which demonstrates the following pathologic lesion.  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia   

Which of the following is the most likely complication of this disease process?

choices.text: Gastric outlet obstruction due to scarring
Diffuse lesion with raised margins and distant metastasis

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with chronic abdominal pain and an endoscopy that demonstrates an ulcer in the duodenum of the small intestine. If left untreated, duodenal ulcers can progress to scarring, fibrous deposition and ultimately gastric outlet obstruction.  

Duodenal ulcers are the most common type of ulcer and are almost exclusively due to infection with H. pylori. Associated clinical features often include weight gain, as well as pain relieved with eating. Other rare causes of the disease include a gastrin-producing tumor referred to as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Duodenal ulcers are caused by decrease in the mucosal barrier leads to increased permeability to gastric acid secretion or increased gastric acid secretion.  

In contrast to duodenal ulcers, gastric ulcers have a tendency to have worsening pain with eating, are associated with weight loss, and are associated with an increased risk of gastric cancer. All gastric ulcers must undergo biopsy, whereas duodenal ulcers are only biopsied if they have characteristic malignant features.  



Option Analysis

✅ Gastric outlet obstruction due to scarring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse lesion with raised margins and distant metastasis :
Incorrect: Gastric cancer is uncommon with duodenal ulcers. For this reason most duodenal ulcers do not require biopsy unless the lesion has features concerning for malignancy.   
❌ Postprandial pain:
Incorrect: Postprandial pain is a complication that occurs due to gastric ulcers. Based on the image, this ulcer is located in the duodenum, which is associated with relief of pain after eating.    
❌ Weight loss :
Incorrect: Weight loss is a complication associated with gastric ulcers; however, weight gain is associated with duodenal ulcers.   
❌ Grossly thickened stomach wall:
Incorrect: Linitis plastica is the characteristic term for diffuse gastric cancer, which appears as signet ring cells on histologic examination. Duodenal ulcers do not predispose to the formation of diffuse gastric cancer.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up appointment after hospitalization for pyelonephritis. The patient has had multiple episodes of urinary tract infections over the past few years. She is otherwise healthy. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit substances. Family history is unremarkable. The patient’s physical exam is normal. A CT of the abdomen obtained during hospitalization is shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Failure of neural crest cell migration

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent urinary tract infections, which raises suspicion for an underlying cause. The abdominal CT reveals the presence of a horseshoe kidney. Horseshoe kidney is the most common fusion anomaly and usually occurs due to fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys.  

Normally, during fetal development, the future kidneys develop in the pelvis as a structure called the metanephros and subsequently migrate upward to their normal position in the retroperitoneal renal fossa. In horseshoe kidney, however, the fused kidneys are lodged under the inferior mesenteric artery. This prevents their ascent into the abdomen and results in ectopy.  

Most patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally, but some may present with pain and hematuria due to obstruction or infection. Horseshoe kidney is associated with hydronephrosis, vesicoureteral reflux, renal stones, infection, and chromosomal aneuploidy syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, trisomies 13, 18, 21). In addition, the condition increases the risk of kidney cancer, especially Wilms tumor and carcinoid tumors. The prognosis is generally excellent, and most patients do not require special intervention.    



Option Analysis

❌ Defective tissue differentiation:
Incorrect: An example of defective tissue differentiation would be multicystic dysplastic kidney disease, which occurs due to failure of the ureteric bud to induce differentiation of the metanephric mesoderm during embryonic development. This condition results in a nonfunctional kidney consisting of cysts and connective tissue. However, this patient's imaging findings favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Failure of neural crest cell migration:
Incorrect: An example of failed neural crest cell migration would be Hirschsprung disease, a form of congenital megacolon caused by a lack of ganglion cells in the rectum. Patients typically present with constipation, abdominal distention, and explosive expulsion of feces. In contrast, this patient has no history of gastrointestinal symptoms.  
❌ Impaired tissue obliteration:
Incorrect: Failure of the vitelline duct to obliterate would cause a Meckel diverticulum. The diverticulum may contain ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue. Patients are usually young children and may present with hematochezia, abdominal pain, and intussusception. In contrast, this patient’s imaging findings show a renal abnormality.  
✅ Fusion anomaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abnormal ureteral bifurcation:
Incorrect: Bifurcation of the ureteric bud before it enters the metanephric blastema during embryonic development would result in a duplex collecting system. The condition is associated with vesicoureteral reflux, ureteral obstruction, and increased risk for UTIs. However, this patient's imaging findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 20 minutes of crushing chest pain and diaphoresis that began suddenly while watching television. According to the patient’s partner, lately he has had occasional chest pain occurring during rest that resolved after a few minutes. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient has not been taking medications as prescribed. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. The patient appears to be in acute distress and in pain. Cardiac examination shows an additional sound just prior to S1 on auscultation. ECG demonstrates ST segment elevation in leads V1-V5. While being prepared for percutaneous coronary intervention, the patient suddenly dies. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple cardiac risk factors (e.g. hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a history of unstable angina) and is now presenting with acute onset of chest pain and diaphoresis. In addition, his ECG findings show ST-elevation in leads V1-V5, supporting the diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) affecting the anterior wall (left anterior descending artery).  



Symptoms of MI may include severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm and/or jaw, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, and fatigue. The additional heart sound S4 represents the stiffening of the wall during diastole, and although nonspecific, it is often correlated with an acute MI. Diagnosis involves measurement of cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponins) and an ECG to look for ST changes and the presence of Q waves.   

Myocardial infarction can be complicated by a variety of conditions depending on the location of injury and timeline since the initial insult. During the first 24 hours, the most common cause of death is ventricular tachycardia/ventricular fibrillation leading to sudden cardiac death (SCD). SCD refers to a sudden stop of cardiac activity followed by hemodynamic collapse.  

Option Analysis

❌ Papillary muscle rupture:
Incorrect: Papillary muscle rupture is a possible life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI), but it usually occurs after 2–7 days, not immediately after an MI. Papillary muscle dysfunction results in acute mitral regurgitation. The posteromedial papillary muscle receives its blood supply from the posterior descending artery and is the most commonly affected papillary muscle.   
✅ Ventricular arrhythmia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Free wall rupture is a possible complication of MI that can lead to cardiac tamponade progressing to pulseless electrical activity and death. However, this complication usually occurs 5-14 days post MI.  
❌ Thromboembolic stroke:
Incorrect: Thromboembolic stroke can occur as a result of a mural thrombus following MI. Hypokinesis of the involved myocardium leads to blood stasis and thrombus formation. However, mural thrombi usually take a few days (average of 6 days) to develop and are not a cause of sudden cardiac death.   
❌ Interventricular septal rupture:
Incorrect: Interventricular septal rupture is a possible complication following MI. This complication can occur when the left anterior descending artery, which provides the main blood supply for the septum, is involved. Interventricular septal rupture occurs 3-5 days post infarction, not on the first day. Interventricular septal rupture leads to hemodynamic compromise, which is characterized by hypotension, biventricular failure, and a new harsh holosystolic murmur.  
❌ Fibrinous pericarditis  :
Incorrect: Fibrinous pericarditis, also known as Dressler Syndrome, is a late complication of MI seen several weeks post-MI. Dressler Syndrome is caused by an autoimmune reaction against cardiac antigens released during the cardiac injury.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation can occur in association with MI and is a predictor of poor outcome. The atrial fibrillation itself is not the cause of death. However, the associated symptoms, such as heart failure and cardiogenic shock, contribute to mortality. Sudden cardiac death post-MI is most frequently the result of a ventricular tachyarrhythmia, not atrial.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male currently experiencing homelessness presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, shortness of breath and cough of 4-days duration. The patient reports he has also noticed several new skin lesions that were not present before, some of which are painful to the touch. The patient uses intravenous heroin and reports he last used heroin yesterday. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. On physical examination the patient appears disheveled. Erythematous lesions are noted on the chest, arms, and hands bilaterally, some of which are painful to palpation. An image of the non-tender lesions is demonstrated below. Nail examination is notable for small ecchymotic lesions of the upper nail beds bilaterally. Rales are appreciated in the lungs bilaterally, and a holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the left lower sternal border. Which of the following clinical features is required for the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
A new murmur that provides evidence of valvular regurgitation is the strongest clinical finding for bacterial endocarditis according to the modified Duke criteria, which is used in the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. This set of clinical and radiographic criteria has been used as the primary diagnostic criteria for endocarditis since its publication in 2000. Of all the clinical factors listed, a new regurgitant murmur is the only major clinical criteria suggestive of bacterial endocarditis.   

All of the other clinical features of endocarditis are listed as minor criteria, including fever, vascular phenomena like Janeway lesions, or immunologic phenomena like Osler nodes, which are the painful erythematous lesions seen in this patient. Subungual nail bed hemorrhage, also referred to as splinter hemorrhages, can also be seen in bacterial endocarditis; however, neither their presence nor location are diagnostic of infective endocarditis, as they are commonly found in otherwise healthy patients or in patients with underlying malignancy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Non-painful erythematous lesions:
Incorrect: Janeway lesions are relatively uncommon lesions found in endocarditis and are classified as minor Duke criteria when assessing a patient for signs of endocarditis.  
❌ Painful erythematous lesions:
Incorrect: Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules mostly on the pads of the fingers and toes that are classified as minor Duke criteria when assessing a patient for signs of endocarditis.  
✅ Evidence of valvular regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: While fever is the most common symptom in endocarditis (found in >90% of cases), it is nonspecific and therefore does not fall under the major Duke criteria when assessing for features of endocarditis.   
❌ Nail bed hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Splinter hemorrhages, while found in endocarditis, are relatively non-specific for this disease process and are also found in patients with underlying malignancy and hypercoagulable disorders. Therefore, they are not included in the major Duke criteria.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to a follow-up appointment following hospitalization due to diverticulitis. Since then, she has been recovering well and has no complaints. Medical history is significant for cholelithiasis, hypercholesterolemia, diverticulitis and constipation. Medications include statins, multivitamins, and supplemental fiber. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and nontender, and bowel sounds are present. A CT obtained at the recent hospitalization is shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This woman who is currently asymptomatic has an incidental finding on CT scan showing calcification of the gallbladder (indicated by the red arrow), suggestive of porcelain gallbladder.  

Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder from chronic gallbladder inflammation. Approximately 95% of patients have associated gallstones. Patients with a porcelain gallbladder are usually asymptomatic, and the diagnosis is made incidentally on abdominal imaging. Occasionally patients can present with symptoms related to gallstones, including right upper quadrant/epigastric abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. On physical examination, the gallbladder may be palpable as a firm, non-tender mass in the right upper quadrant. Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a relatively increased risk for gallbladder cancer, mostly adenocarcinoma. However, since the absolute risk of developing cancer is low, some experts prefer observation, while others recommended elective cholecystectomy.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the liver in adults. It is associated with hepatitis B or hepatitis C chronic infection, other conditions of cirrhosis (e.g., alcoholic and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, autoimmune diseases), and certain carcinogens (e.g., Aspergillus aflatoxin). Clinical findings include jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, ascites, polycythemia (due to excessive erythropoietin production), and anorexia. This patient has no history of these risk factors or presence of these clinical findings on examination.  
❌ Budd-Chiari syndrome:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome is caused by thrombosis or compression of hepatic veins followed by centrilobular congestion and necrosis. Patients present with symptoms of congestive liver disease, such as hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, varices, ascites, and liver failure. It is associated with hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia vera, pregnancy, hepatocellular carcinoma). This patient has no history of these risk factors or presence of these clinical findings on examination.  
❌ Liver cirrhosis:
Incorrect: Liver cirrhosis is a condition in which the liver loses its normal function due to long term damage and scarring (fibrosis). This damage is characterized by the replacement of healthy liver tissue with scar tissue. Etiologies include nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, chronic alcohol use, chronic viral hepatitis, biliary disease, autoimmune hepatitis, and genetic/metabolic disorders. This patient has none of these risk factors.  
✅ Gallbladder adenocarcinoma  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Primary biliary cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune chronic liver disease resulting from progressive destruction of the intrahepatic bile ducts of the liver. It is associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, Hashimoto thyroiditis, celiac disease). Common symptoms are fatigue, itching, and jaundice. This patient has no history of these risk factors or presence of these clinical findings on examination.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to complaints of weakness and numbness in the lower extremities. The patient has sprained both ankles on multiple occasions over the past year while playing soccer due to difficulty running, which has progressively worsened. The patient has not had any recent infections or diarrhea. The patient's family lives in a new home built 3 years ago. The patient’s mother reports the patient was adopted at the age of 3, and she is unsure of his biological family’s history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Distal calf muscle atrophy is noted. There is loss of proprioception and vibratory sensation in both feet. Ankle reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. An image of the patient’s foot is shown below. This patient’s neurological dysfunction is most likely caused by which of the following?  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) is a spectrum of inherited disorders caused by mutations in genes that are expressed in peripheral nerve myelin. Most are inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, and therefore, a family history of the disorder is usually present. CMT affects the peripheral nervous system and is characterized by defective protein production in Schwann cells or the peripheral neuron’s axon. The most common form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is CMT1. CMT1 is caused by mutations in the PMP22 and MPZ genes, which encode proteins that are part of the myelin sheath.  

Individuals with CMT typically have distal lower extremity weakness, which is similar to Guillain-Barré syndrome. The difference is that CMT also causes sensory symptoms such as pain or numbness. Early physical exam findings include distal calf muscle atrophy and loss of reflexes. Motor symptoms are also common and occur due to damage to the common peroneal nerve, which can lead to foot drop. Weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the foot can result in pes cavus, as characterized by a high arching foot that does not flatten with weight bearing (seen in the image). Weakness of the back muscles can result in scoliosis.   

Diagnosis for CMT usually begins with nerve conduction studies that show a significantly decreased conduction velocity. Genetic testing is necessary to obtain a definitive diagnosis and determine which subtype of CMT the patient has.  





Option Analysis

✅ Mutation in myelin protein gene :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyalinization of endoneurial arterioles:
Incorrect: In diabetic neuropathy, there is nonenzymatic glycosylation of tissue proteins that results in hyalinization of endoneurial arterioles. This occlusion of blood supply to the nerve results in ischemic nerve damage. However, this patient has no history of diabetes mellitus.
❌ Autoreactive T-lymphocytes attacking oligodendrocytes:
Incorrect: Lesions in multiple sclerosis (MS) are caused by a type IV hypersensitivity (cell-mediated reaction) in which Th1 and Th17 T cells react against oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system. This patient’s condition is likely affecting the peripheral nervous system, not the central nervous system as seen in MS.
❌ Heavy metal exposure :
Incorrect: Lead poisoning in children is a serious public health issue that can result in permanent neurological dysfunction. Lead has a direct effect on neurons resulting in neurotoxicity and neuronal death. This child lives in a modern home where lead-based paints were likely not used, and he lacks other clinical features seen in children with lead poisoning, such as abdominal pain, cognitive decline, and constipation.
❌ Autoantibodies attacking peripheral nerve endoneurium  :
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is seen in patients following an upper respiratory infection or gastroenteritis. Molecular mimicry results in the production of cross-reactive antibodies against myelin found on peripheral Schwann cells, resulting in endoneurial inflammation. Individuals with GBS present with a bilateral, symmetric ascending paralysis, but typically lack the sensory deficits seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with a history of hypertension and congestive heart failure presents to the primary care physician with muscle cramps, weakness, and fatigue. The patient has had multiple admissions to the hospital over the past several months and has been on escalating doses of bumetanide and hydrochlorothiazide. He was recently ill with food poisoning. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 143/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam the patient is not in acute distress, has 1+ peripheral edema in the lower extremities bilaterally, and has faint bibasilar rales. ECG is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with heart failure presents with muscle cramps, weakness, and fatigue in the setting of escalating doses of diuretic therapy and recent gastroenteritis. The ECG demonstrates flattened T-waves and the appearance of U-waves which are consistent with hypokalemia.  

Hypokalemia is a common electrolyte disturbance and is divided by etiology: 1) decreased intake, 2) increased translocation into cells, or 3) increased losses via urine, the gastrointestinal tract, or sweat. Of these etiologies, increased losses via urine, GI tract, or sweat is the most common.    

Decreased intake is relatively rare and is caused by severe anorexia, prolonged fasting, or diets low in potassium containing foods. Etiologies that promote increased entry into cells include alkalosis, as well as insulin and beta adrenergic activity due to stimulation of the sodium potassium ATPase.  

Common gastrointestinal losses include diarrhea or laxative abuse. Increased renal losses are commonly caused by loop and thiazide diuretics, which induce increased distal delivery of potassium and volume depletion, hence activating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. If potassium intake does not match urinary losses, or if a concomitant process such as diarrhea occurs, hypokalemia may ensue. Less common but important causes of hypokalemia include hyperaldosteronism and renal tubular acidosis type I and II.    

Regardless of the etiology, the symptoms include muscle weakness, fatigue, cramps, cardiac arrhythmias, renal abnormalities, and glucose intolerance. Treatment is directed at correcting the underlying cause and careful repletion of potassium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hypokalemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypophosphatemia:
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia can be caused by acetazolamide but is not commonly observed in patients taking thiazide or loop diuretics. Conditions associated with hypophosphatemia include chronic alcohol use, urinary phosphate wasting syndromes (e.g. Fanconi syndrome), and chronic ingestion of antacids or phosphate binders.
❌ Hypocalcemia :
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia can present with muscle weakness and fatigue but more commonly causes numbness, muscle spasms, and tetany. Loop diuretics, such as bumetanide, can induce hypocalcemia. However, ECG would typically show prolonged QT intervals. In contrast, the above ECG demonstrates flattened T-waves and U-waves, which are nearly pathognomonic for hypokalemia.
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Diuretics and dehydration can precipitate hyponatremia; however acute hyponatremia tends to present with nausea, headache, malaise, and seizures. In addition, hyponatremia typically manifests with non-specific ECG findings. 
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are associated with hyperglycemia due to their effect on suppressing insulin secretion. Hyperglycemia in and of itself is not associated with ECG changes.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of fatigue and shortness of breath for the past several weeks. He lives in a 2nd floor apartment and has difficulty catching his breath after climbing the stairs. He also reports feeling tingling in his hands and feet during this same time period. The patient recently immigrated from India and was being treated for a disease with a daily medication, but cannot recall its name. He has no cognitive impairment, abnormal bleeding episodes, or depression. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. There is diminished sensation bilaterally on the hands and feets. Laboratory investigations show a hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL. Bone marrow biopsy reveals numerous hypochromic erythrocytes with coarse basophilic granules, which are positive for Prussian blue staining. Reduced activity of which of the following enzymes is likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has fatigue, dyspnea, and a peripheral blood smear exhibiting sideroblasts. Given the patient recently immigrated from India (a tuberculosis endemic country) and has peripheral neuropathy, he was likely taking isoniazid, which can cause pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency. As a result, the patient’s symptoms are likely due to sideroblastic anemia caused by reduced activity of δ-aminolevulinate (ALA) synthase (which uses vitamin B6 as a cofactor).  

Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia wherein sideroblasts, or erythrocytes with abnormal mitochondrial iron deposition that form a perinuclear ring, are found in bone marrow biopsies. Due to the elevated iron content of these cells, they appear blue with Prussian blue staining.    

Sideroblastic anemia can be congenital or acquired. An X-linked defect in the ALA synthase gene is a congenital cause. Lead exposure, myelodysplastic syndromes, alcohol use, and isoniazid treatment are acquired causes.  

Isoniazid interferes with the metabolism of pyridoxine. Therefore, patients taking this medication are at increased risk of peripheral neuropathy due to S-adenosylmethionine accumulation, as well as sideroblastic anemia, since pyridoxine is an essential coenzyme used in the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis by ALA synthase. To prevent these complications, patients being treated with isoniazid should also receive supplemental pyridoxine.    






Option Analysis

✅ δ-aminolevulinate synthase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase:
Incorrect: δ-aminolevulinate (ALA) dehydratase is the second enzyme involved in heme synthesis. This enzyme can be inhibited in patients with lead poisoning. 
❌ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase   :
Incorrect: In patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, there is impaired regeneration of reduced glutathione, which is an important antioxidant. Patients typically develop hemolytic anemia after being exposed to an oxidative stressor (e.g., infection, fava beans, certain antibiotics). Although this condition can present with anemia, it also causes jaundice and dark urine, which are absent in this patient. As a result, it is unlikely this patient has G6PD deficiency.
❌ Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase :
Incorrect: Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is an enzyme involved in metabolism of methylmalonyl-CoA and requires vitamin B12 as a cofactor. In patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, elevated methylmalonic acid can damage myelin, resulting in subacute combined degeneration, which commonly presents with peripheral neuropathy. However, vitamin B12 deficiency would not account for the sideroblasts seen on bone marrow aspiration.
❌ Porphobilinogen deaminase :
Incorrect: Porphobilinogen deaminase deficiency is seen in patients with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP typically presents as severe abdominal pain, neurologic abnormalities, and red-purple urine. Although this patient also has neurologic abnormalities (e.g. peripheral neuropathy), the presence of sideroblasts on bone marrow aspiration makes another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, presents to the office for evaluation of an abnormal routine Pap smear. She has been healthy and has no vaginal spotting or bleeding. The cervical cytology showed atypical glandular cells. Menarche was at age 14, and she had a regular menstrual cycle until menopause at the age of 47. Past medical history is significant for osteoporosis treated with raloxifene. She also took hormone replacement therapy for hot flashes for two years after menopause. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 31.5 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows loss of labial fullness and an atrophic vagina. Bimanual examination is significant for a small uterus. Endometrial sampling is performed, and histology shows complex papillary architecture with the presence of round calcific collections and marked nuclear atypia. Which of the following risk factors in this patient’s history is the most significant in the development of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of low estrogen (loss of labial fullness, atrophic vagina), small uterus (suggestive of endometrial atrophy), together with histopathological findings of complex papillary architecture, psammoma bodies and nuclear atypia (high nucleus-to-cytoplasmic ratio, hyperchromasia and prominent nucleoli), is consistent with the diagnosis of type II (serous) endometrial carcinoma.

 

 Endometrial carcinoma is the most common gynecological cancer in the developed countries. It is classified into 2 subtypes on the basis of histopathology:  

  •  Type I carcinoma: also known as endometrioid carcinoma due to its histologic resemblance to endometrial glands. It is known to arise from endometrial hyperplasia usually in the setting of increased estrogen exposure. 
  •  Type II carcinoma: a rare and more aggressive tumor which is not estrogen dependent. It presents as postmenopausal vaginal bleeding or as an incidental finding of abnormal cervical cytology (as seen in this patient). The most common type is serous, arising from an atrophic endometrium. Advanced age is a major risk factor. A mutation in p53 is commonly observed in early carcinogenesis. This tumor has a high tendency for lymphovascular invasion as well as intraperitoneal and extra-abdominal spread.

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: A history of endometrial cancer (not breast cancer) in a first-degree relative is considered a risk factor in the development of endometrial cancer. Germline mutations of BRCA genes are associated with the cancers of breast and ovary (not endometrium). Lynch syndrome, in contrast, is associated with an increased risk of colonic, endometrial, and ovarian cancers. 
✅ Age of the patient:
Incorrect: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of hormone replacement therapy:
Incorrect: Increased estrogen exposure (as a result of hormone replacement, early menopause or tamoxifen) is considered a risk factor in the development of type I (endometrioid) endometrial carcinoma. The presence of psammoma bodies (round calcific collections) on histopathology and endometrial atrophy (small uterus) in this patient makes type II endometrial cancer more likely.  
❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: Although early age of menarche is considered a significant risk factor for the development of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma, this patient’s age of menarche is appropriate.
❌ Raloxifene use:
Incorrect: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is sometimes used for the prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. Unlike tamoxifen and estrogens, raloxifene does not increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to the office because of vaginal spotting, abdominal distention and constipation for the past 3 months. She is also having difficulty defecating and often has to put her index and middle finger in her vagina to aid in pushing the stools out. Menopause was at age 48. Past history is significant for breast cancer treated by breast-sparing mastectomy and tamoxifen. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows an enlarged irregular uterus and normal rectal tone. Transvaginal doppler ultrasound shows mixed echogenic masses with increased vascularity and central necrosis, bulging into the uterine cavity. Hysterectomy is performed which reveals a poorly-demarcated large yellow soft mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Histology of the specimen is shown.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with postmenopausal bleeding, bulk-related symptoms (constipation) and abdominal distention, in combination with histopathology showing smooth muscle cells of irregular size and hyperchromatic nuclei, is consistent with uterine leiomyosarcoma.  

Leiomyosarcoma is a rare tumor and usually arises in women after the age of 40. Common risk factors include tamoxifen use, history of pelvic irradiation and some hereditary syndromes (e.g. hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma [HLRCC] syndrome). It is important to note that leiomyosarcomas arise de novo and not from benign leiomyomas or from myometrial or endometrial stromal cells.  

The increasing size of the mass can sometimes put pressure on adjacent organs, leading to bulk-related symptoms (e.g. constipation). Patients usually report relieving of pressure by “splinting”, which helps in defecation by manually deflecting the obstruction. Although the clinical presentation is somewhat similar to leiomyoma, the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma is considered when the symptoms occur after menopause and doppler ultrasound shows a poorly-demarcated mass with increased vascularity and mixed echogenicity suggestive of hemorrhage and necrosis. Grossly, it appears as a soft yellow-colored mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Histopathology shows smooth muscle cells of irregular size and nuclear atypia (hyperchromatic nuclei).  


Courtesy of Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease (9th ed.)  



Option Analysis

❌ Uterine polyps:
Incorrect: Uterine polyps are the hyperplastic growths of tissue from the endometrial surface which usually present with intermenstrual bleeding. Bulk-related symptoms with an irregularly enlarged uterus as seen in this patient would be atypical.
❌ Uterine leiomyoma:
Incorrect: Although the clinical presentation of this patient is similar to that of leiomyoma, soft yellow masses with hemorrhagic areas and irregular smooth muscle cells on histology are consistent with a more malignant process, such as leiomyosarcoma.
✅ Uterine leiomyosarcoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endometrial cancer:
Incorrect: Endometrial cancer may present with postmenopausal bleeding, but it is usually associated with a thick endometrial stripe on ultrasound. Histology shows glandular architecture mixed with solid areas, not irregular smooth muscle cells.
❌ Adenomyosis:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis may also present with abnormal uterine bleeding, but a uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus is usually seen on physical examination. Histopathology shows ectopic endometrial tissue in the myometrium.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of decreased concentration for the last 5 months. He is no longer able to complete his daily crossword puzzles due to lack of focus and a persistent feeling of fatigue. His partner states that he has been more forgetful recently, oftentimes misplacing common objects such as his glasses and wallet. The patient has gained 12-lb in the last 4 months without a change in diet or activity level. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, which is being treated with lisinopril. The patient has had no changes in vision, headaches, or loss of peripheral sensation. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg, and BMI is 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows dry skin and a slightly distended abdomen. Deep tendon reflexes are delayed in the upper and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show the following:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   137 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride   99 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.6 mg/dL 
 Glucose  89 mEq/L 
 ESR  73 mm/h 
 TSH  8.8 μU/mL 
 Hemoglobin  12.6 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  42% 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fatigue, lack of focus, weight gain, delayed deep tendon reflexes, and elevated TSH levels. He most likely has primary hypothyroidism. In the United States, Hashimoto thyroiditis, a chronic autoimmune condition, is the most common cause. Hashimoto thyroiditis is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland, ultimately causing destruction and fibrosis of the gland, as well as impaired production of thyroid hormone. In an attempt to induce production of thyroid hormones, the anterior pituitary secretes more TSH, resulting in elevated serum TSH levels.  

Secondary hypothyroidism, in contrast, is caused by damage to the pituitary (e.g. pituitary adenoma) and tertiary hypothyroidism is caused by damage to the hypothalamus. In both of these cases, there would be decreased production of TSH that results in the decreased thyroid hormone production.

   





Option Analysis

✅ Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease has an insidious onset that more gradually impairs memory, ultimately progressing to impairment of daily functioning. This patient’s symptoms started 5 months ago, making this diagnosis less likely. In addition, the physical exam and laboratory values point to another diagnosis. 
❌ Pituitary adenoma:
Incorrect: A pituitary adenoma can compress nearby structures, resulting in a hypothyroid state; however, the compression would inhibit thyrotropes from releasing TSH. In contrast, this patient has an elevated TSH level.
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect: This patient’s age and hypertension puts him at risk for vascular dementia. Vascular dementia results in a stepwise cognitive decline secondary to small or large vessel disease. However, vascular dementia would not account for this patient’s weight gain, distended abdomen, delayed reflexes, or abnormal lab values.  
❌ Vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause fatigue and neuropathy and may cause pseudodementia in elderly patients. The condition can also cause anemia. In contrast, this patient has a normal hemoglobin level. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency would not explain the patient’s elevated TSH level.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to behavior problems and declining academic performance. He used to do well in school but during the past year and a half, he started receiving Cs and Ds in his classes and having social problems. The patient’s teachers report he disrupts classmates, cannot sit still, and makes “funny noises.” The parents mention that he used to have a lot of friends but now constantly gets into fights because his classmates make fun of his behavior. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the child blinks constantly, shrugs the shoulders, and occasionally grunts. When the child is asked to stop these movements, he can suppress them for a few moments, then recommences. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with academic decline, vocal tics (grunting), and motor tics (blinking and shoulder shrugging) that have been present for more than 1 year, all favoring the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome. The disruptive behavior is most likely due to concurrent attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, present in up to 60% of the cases.  

Tourette syndrome (TS) is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics that occur during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to disturbances in the cortico-striatal-thalamic (mesolimbic) circuit, which results in disinhibition of the limbic and motor systems. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition and are defined as sudden, brief, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical presentation with onset before age 18.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Provisional tic disorder :
Incorrect:  Provisional tic disorder, also known as transient tics, is a type of motor disorder in which a child experiences involuntary motor and/or verbal tics for less than one year. This occurs in otherwise healthy children and spontaneously remits in a few weeks or months. This child has been experiencing symptoms for more than 1 year. 
❌ Persistent Tic Disorder:
Incorrect: Persistent tic disorder, also known as chronic tic disorder, is characterized by either motor tics OR vocal tics, but not both, for more than 1 year and before 18 years of age. This patient is exhibiting both vocal and motor tics. 
✅ Tourette syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Epileptic automatisms:
Incorrect: Automatisms are nonpurposeful, brief, unconscious, stereotyped behaviors that often accompany certain types of epilepsy, such as complex partial seizures. These include finger rubbing, lip-smacking, chewing, etc.. Patients are amnestic to their automatisms. This child has vocal and motor tics that he can suppress when asked, making this diagnosis very unlikely. 
❌ Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia is a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by brief (less than one minute) attacks of choreoathetosis, dystonia, or both that occur with sudden changes in movement, such as getting up from a seated position. Movements are often unilateral and consciousness is retained. This child’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to the acute onset of diffuse headache, blurry vision, and nausea that started 2 hours ago. His partner states that the patient has not visited a physician in several years. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 189/130 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is confused and dyspneic. No neck pain or stiffness is noted. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles without wheezing. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral blurring of the optic disc margins. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hypertension now presenting with acute onset of headache, extremely high blood pressure, blurry vision, confusion, and pulmonary edema is most likely experiencing hypertensive emergency.    

When the elevation of blood pressure reaches a critical level (typically around 180/120 mm Hg), the vascular myogenic response increases vascular resistance. In response to an increase in intravascular pressure, the myogenic response is vascular vasoconstriction. The relative peripheral hypoperfusion causes an increase in vasoactive hormones, such as angiotensin II, norepinephrine, and antidiuretic hormone; this maladaptive response worsens the peripheral resistance and leads to a vicious cycle of worsening hypertension and damage to organs. In this case of hypertensive emergency, the patient’s pulmonary edema is most likely caused by left ventricular dysfunction due to elevated high blood pressure, resulting in backup of blood into the pulmonary vasculature.  

Hypertensive urgency is defined as systolic and diastolic blood pressures ≥180/≥120 mmHg respectively without acute end-organ damage. In contrast, hypertensive emergency is defined as very high blood pressure with signs of acute end-organ damage. These include:

  •  Neurologic: Encephalopathy, stroke, retinal hemorrhages and exudates, papilledema 
  •  Cardiopulmonary: Myocardial infarction, heart failure with pulmonary edema 
  •  Vascular: Aortic dissection, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia 
  •  Renal: Acute hypertensive nephrosclerosis 
Diagnosis is based upon history and physical examination in patients with significantly elevated blood pressure, whether or not they have a history of hypertension. Further diagnostic testing should be performed to evaluate the presence of target-organ damage including ECG, urinalysis, chest x-ray, serum electrolytes, serum creatinine, cardiac biomarkers and head imaging. Treatment consists of pharmacological blood pressure reduction (e.g., nitroprusside, hydralazine); however, this should be done gradually to prevent ischemic complications.    


Option Analysis

❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm. Classically, SAH presents as a sudden onset of severe headache, often described as "worst headache of my life" or "thunderclap headache." Other common signs and symptoms include a brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain or stiffness, elevated intracranial pressure, and retinal hemorrhages. Although imaging is required to exclude the condition, SAH does not present with dyspnea or crackles on lung auscultation.  
❌ Intracranial tumor :
Incorrect: Brain tumors may present with generalized and/or focal signs and symptoms, though in some cases they may be asymptomatic. Common presenting symptoms of brain tumors include headache, seizures, focal neurological deficit, aphasia, cognitive dysfunction and signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema, vomiting). Although this patient has signs of increased intracranial pressure, an intracranial mass will not evolve over a few hours but rather manifests over days, weeks and months. Additionally, this patient’s elevated blood pressure and pulmonary findings suggests a different etiology. 
✅ Hypertensive emergency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meningitis :
Incorrect: Meningitis typically presents with the classic triad of fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status. Patients often complain of photophobia. The majority of patients have high fevers. This patient is afebrile, and meningitis will not explain this patient’s pulmonary findings. 
❌ Pheochromocytoma:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that arises from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. Patients may present with the classic triad of episodic headaches, sweating, and tachycardia. Although this patient’s hypertension may be explained by an underlying pheochromocytoma, the history of chronic, uncontrolled hypertension suggests another, more likely etiology.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue, easy bruising, and 7 kg (15 lb) weight gain over the past three months. Past medical history is notable recurrent multiple sclerosis flare-ups. She is currently being treated with oral prednisone. The patient is not taking any other medications. On the physical examination, there is symmetric muscle weakness in the upper and lower extremities. The patient also has wide reddish-purple streaks most prominent on the abdomen. Examination of the patient’s face reveals the following findings:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Laboratory testing reveals a fasting serum glucose of 147 mg/dL. Which of the following sets of additional findings would most likely be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Cushing syndrome secondary to exogenous corticosteroid use. The most common cause of Cushing syndrome is chronic corticosteroid use, often for the treatment of autoimmune/inflammatory conditions.  

Normally, the hypothalamus secretes corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which stimulates the pituitary gland to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH travels to the adrenal glands where it targets cells in the adrenal cortex to induce cortisol production. In particular, ACTH targets the zona fasciculata, the layer of the adrenal cortex responsible for cortisol production. Cortisol production is regulated via negative feedback. This means that high levels of cortisol inhibit hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH, respectively.

In this scenario, the oral prednisone that the patient is taking can cause negative feedback on the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland. This leads to a decrease in CRH and ACTH levels, which in turn shuts down cortisol production from the zona fasciculata. Over time, this lack of stimulation can cause the zona fasciculata of both adrenal glands to shrink and become atrophic.   

Option Analysis

❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Elevated  Hyperplasia :
Incorrect: These findings are observed in patients with secondary hypercortisolism. The most common cause of secondary hypercortisolism is an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. However this patient has an autoimmune condition that is being treated with oral steroids. This makes exogenous hypercortisolism a more likely cause of her symptoms.
❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Elevated Atrophy:
Incorrect: This is seen in patients with hypocortisolism secondary to adrenal gland atrophy. The body will increase ACTH levels in an attempt to produce more cortisol. However, hypocortisolism would not present with weight gain, round faces, muscle atrophy, and abdominal striae. Instead, these symptoms are seen in hypercortisolism. 
❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Unchanged Unchanged:
Incorrect: These findings are found in healthy individuals and patients with intermittent steroid use. For example, patients who use corticosteroid inhalers or topical creams on an infrequent basis will have serum cortisol levels within normal range. As a result, ACTH secretion will remain unchanged and the adrenal glands would undergo neither hyperplasia or atrophy.
❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Decreased Hyperplasia :
Incorrect: This is observed in patients with primary hypercortisolism, which is most often due to adrenal adenomas. In response to corticosteroid overproduction, the body reduces ACTH secretion. However this patient has an autoimmune condition that is being treated with oral steroids. This makes exogenous hypercortisolism the most likely cause of her symptoms.
✅   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland Decreased Atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 3, comes to the labor and delivery unit at the 38 weeks gestation due to vaginal bleeding. She did not receive any prenatal care during this pregnancy. The patient’s first 2 children were born through normal vaginal delivery, while her last child was delivered through C-section due to second stage arrest. She is in good health and takes no medications other than prenatal vitamins. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Fetal heart rate is 85/min and fetal heart rate tracing shows a sinusoidal pattern. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. The uterus is non-tender on palpation. Speculum examination reveals ruptured membranes, closed cervix, and profuse bleeding from the cervical os. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who did not receive prenatal care, is presenting with painless vaginal bleeding upon rupture of the membranes, which is accompanied by fetal heart rate tracing showing a sinusoidal pattern and bradycardia; she most likely suffered from ruptured vasa previa.    

Vasa previa is a condition in which the fetal blood vessels are found in the membranes that cover the internal cervical os. Patients often present with painless vaginal bleeding upon rupture of membranes, accompanied by fetal heart rate abnormalities such as bradycardia or sinusoidal pattern. Fetal exsanguination can occur within minutes. The exact pathogenesis of vasa previa is unknown. Risk factors for developing vasa previa include velamentous cord insertion, umbilical cord insertion in the lower uterus, placenta previa or low-lying placenta, succenturiate placental lobe or bilobed placenta, in vitro fertilization, and multiple gestations. Diagnosis of vasa previa is made by demonstrating the fetal vessels passing across the internal cervical os by transvaginal ultrasound examination with color Doppler. Delivery is usually made via planned cesarean delivery at 34 to 35 weeks of gestation or by emergency cesarean delivery if a rupture occurred. Vasa previa is often associated with velamentous umbilical cord insertion, in which the umbilical inserts to the chorioamniotic membranes instead of the placenta and therefore is not protected by Wharton's jelly.  



Option Analysis

❌ Placenta accreta:
Incorrect: Placenta accreta refers to a placenta that attaches to the myometrium without penetrating it. Placenta accreta presents as a life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs after delivery when manual placental separation is attempted. This patient has not yet delivered, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Placental abruption :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness. 
✅ Vasa previa :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ​Placenta previa :
Incorrect: Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implementation over or in proximity to the cervical os. Placenta previa should be suspected in any pregnant woman who presents with painless vaginal bleeding after 20 weeks gestation. Diagnosis is made via ultrasound, and a cesarean section is usually indicated. Although this patient has risk factors for placenta previa (e.g., multiparity, prior C-section), the fetal heart rate pattern and low heart rate suggest that the bleeding occurred from the fetal side (vasa previa). Since placenta previa involves maternal vessels, it would more likely result in maternal instability, which is not seen in this patient. 
❌ Uterine rupture:
Incorrect: Uterine rupture typically presents with severe abdominal and uterine pain with/without hemodynamic changes, vaginal bleeding, and fetal heart rate changes (most commonly bradycardia). However, loss of fetal station (station refers to the stage of the presenting fetal part; therefore, loss of station means regression of the fetus back into the uterus), cessation of contractions, and changes in uterine contour are also expected. Risk factors are previous classical uterine incision and myomectomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a progressive cough accompanied by mild hemoptysis. During the past 2 weeks, she has been experiencing non-productive cough, pelvic pressure, and mild vaginal bleeding. Six weeks ago, the patient had an abortion at 15 weeks gestation, and since then, her menstrual period had not yet returned. She is in good health, and she does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. She is sexually active with her male partner and currently does not use contraception. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the uterus is soft and mildly enlarged. Vaginal examination shows minimal blood at the vaginal vault. The cervix is closed, non-erythematous. An x-ray of the chest is obtained and shows multiple, rounded nodules of variable size scattered throughout the lungs. Which of the following findings is most specific for this patient’s conditions?

choices.text: Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies on immunofluorescence
Positive acid-fast bacilli on sputum analysis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with vaginal bleeding, enlarged uterus, cough, and hemoptysis following a recent abortion. Along with the x-ray findings showing a cannonball pattern (lung metastases), the most likely diagnosis is choriocarcinoma. It is associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).    

Choriocarcinoma is a type of invasive gestational trophoblastic neoplasia characterized by abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue. Choriocarcinoma is highly vascular and composed of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts without villi. Choriocarcinoma can follow any type of pregnancy but more commonly occurs after molar pregnancy. Patients often present with vaginal bleeding or amenorrhea, pelvic pain or pressure, and an enlarged soft uterus. Dyspnea, chest pain, cough, or hemoptysis may occur from lung metastases, as seen in this patient. Cannonball appearance on chest x-ray is characteristic. Metastases to the liver and central nervous system may also occur; metastatic disease to the brain typically presents with headaches, dizziness, nausea, slurred speech or visual disturbances. On ultrasound, choriocarcinoma appears as a heterogeneous mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Color doppler will show a markedly hypervascular lesion.    

Choriocarcinoma is uniquely sensitive to chemotherapy, and therefore, management involves treatment with chemotherapeutic agents, namely, methotrexate. Women with choriocarcinoma should be monitored with serial measurements of serum hCG at the start of treatment and then at weekly intervals during therapy. After remission is achieved, serum hCG should be measured monthly until monitoring has shown one year of normal hCG levels.  

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
Pulmonary metastases - “cannonball” appearance on chest x-ray

Option Analysis

❌ Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies on immunofluorescence :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Goodpasture disease, a small vessel vasculitis characterized by antibodies directed against the glomerular basement membrane and alveolar basement membrane, resulting in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and/or alveolar hemorrhage. The absence of renal symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, it would not explain the patient's vaginal bleeding. 
❌ Anti-proteinase 3 antibodies on immunofluorescence :
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is a type of granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis that is associated with antinuclear antibodies and specifically with anti-proteinase 3 antibodies. Patients typically present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., elevated ESR and CRP), asthma, sinusitis, palpable purpura, renal involvement, and neurologic deficits. The absence of atopic history or other symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Positive acid-fast bacilli on sputum analysis :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) infection. While TB infection can present with hemoptysis, the absence of fever and the presence of vaginal bleeding is not consistent with the diagnosis. Moreover, an x-ray of active tuberculosis will likely show an upper lobe lesion rather than multiple scattered nodules. 
✅ Elevated serum hCG levels :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated d-dimer:
Incorrect: D-dimer is not specific and is often elevated in many conditions including pulmonary embolism (PE) and malignancy. While PE can present with cough and hemoptysis, other findings such as tachycardia, dyspnea, and mild fever are also expected. PE would not explain the patient’s x-ray and vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 3-week-old boy presents to the emergency department due to worsening vomiting at home. The vomiting began suddenly today, and the patient has been more sleepy than usual. He was born full-term at home to a mother who has a history of epilepsy but is otherwise healthy. The patient has not received any vaccines since the mother is concerned they will increase his risk of developing “behavioral disorders.” Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 104/54 mmHg. On physical examination the infant begins seizing with tonic-clonic movements in the upper and lower extremities. He is noted to have a bulging anterior fontanelle and downward displacement of the eyes. No pain is elicited with flexion of the neck. Point of care glucose is 60 mg/dL. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Low stores of a fat soluble vitamin
Delayed development of the germinal matrix

questions.solution:
This full-term neonate presents with vomiting, a bulging anterior fontanelle, altered mental status, and new-onset seizure. Given the patient was born at home and did not receive vaccinations or routine postnatal care, these findings are concerning for spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage secondary to vitamin K deficiency.  

Neonates who are born to mothers taking anticonvulsants, did not receive prophylactic vitamin K administration after birth, and are exclusively breastfed are at increased risk of developing vitamin K deficiency. Without adequate vitamin K stores, γ-carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, and X is impaired, resulting in prolongation of the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time. As such, vitamin K deficiency leads to an increased risk of bleeding (e.g., intracerebral hemorrhage, gastrointestinal bleeding, severe bruising, surgical site bleeding).  

In older children and adults, vitamin K deficiency is rare. However, individuals with conditions causing fat malabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease) or those taking certain medications (e.g. cephalosporin) that eradicate intestinal bacteria are at risk.  

Diagnosis of vitamin K deficiency is made by clinical history and coagulation studies showing a prolonged PT and PTT. Of note, the PT tends to elevate first since factor VII has the shortest half life. The diagnosis is confirmed when PT and PTT correct after administration of vitamin K.

Option Analysis

✅ Low stores of a fat soluble vitamin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meningeal irritation by gram-positive bacteria:
Incorrect: Meningitis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of a neonate presenting with seizures and a bulging fontanelle. However, it is unlikely this patient has meningitis given the absence of fever or nuchal rigidity.
❌ Seizure disorder :
Incorrect: A seizure disorder is formally diagnosed via electroencephalography (EEG). This patient first presented with vomiting and lethargy before developing seizures, making a primary seizure unlikely. Instead, the patient more likely had a seizure secondary to an acute intracranial pathology.
❌ Gestational diabetes:
Incorrect: Individuals born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at risk of developing hypoglycemia. This complication occurs because hyperinsulinemia persists in the newborn even after the intrauterine glucose supply from the mother is interrupted after delivery. Hypoglycemia can result in seizures. However, this patient had a blood glucose of 60 mg/dL, making hypoglycemia from gestational diabetes unlikely. 
❌ Delayed development of the germinal matrix:
Incorrect: Germinal matrix hemorrhage is a common cause of seizure and altered mental status in premature infants. However, this infant was born full term, making this diagnosis is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to acute onset of abdominal pain, intense sweating, and vomiting. The pain is sharp, constant, 8/10 in intensity and radiates to the right shoulder blade. The patient has 2 children who were both delivered by cesarean section. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and obesity. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 37 kg/m2. ECG shows no abnormalities. An abdominal ultrasound is inconclusive due to body habitus. Further testing is performed, and the laboratory results are shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  8000 mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  85 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.6 g/dL 
 BUN  10 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  15 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  17 U/L 
 Amylase  50 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   60 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with abdominal pain that radiates to the right shoulder, vomiting and normal laboratory values most likely has biliary colic. Note that this patient has multiple risk factors for developing gallstones, including female sex, age, multiparity, and obesity.  

Biliary colic refers to episodic pain caused by temporary obstruction of the cystic duct by stone during gallbladder contraction. Common presentations include epigastric/right upper quadrant pain which may radiate to the right shoulder. The pain is often associated with diaphoresis, nausea, and vomiting. Following a fatty meal (although it can happen after any meal), neurohormonal activation with cholecystokinin triggers the contraction of the gallbladder, forcing the stone into the cystic duct. When the contractions subside, the stone is displaced from the duct, relieving the obstruction. Biliary colic is a misnomer because the pain is usually constant and not colicky. The pain of biliary colic usually lasts less than 6 hours, compared to cholecystitis which is usually longer. Note that a fever will not be present in biliary colic, since there is no inflammatory process occurring, unlike in cholecystitis.  

During an episode of biliary colic, laboratory values should demonstrate normal values; this is because there is no inflammatory process occurring (unlike in cholecystitis), and therefore, no enzymatic markers should be elevated. Diagnosis is usually clinical and abdominal ultrasound may show stones within the gallbladder. Patients with repeated bouts of biliary colic are candidates for elective cholecystectomy after the pain subsides.    



Option Analysis

❌ Cholangitis:
Incorrect: Acute cholangitis is an inflammation of the biliary system secondary to partial obstruction of the bile duct by gallstones. Patients typically present with systemic signs, such as fever. Laboratory tests typically reveal leukocytosis and a cholestatic pattern of liver test abnormalities (i.e., elevations in the serum alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and mainly, conjugated bilirubin). This patient has no fever and has normal laboratory values, suggesting a different diagnosis.   
❌ Gallstone pancreatitis :
Incorrect: Gallstones lodged in the biliary tract can trigger acute pancreatitis by obstruction of the flow from the pancreatic duct or by obstructing the ampulla of Vater. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient has normal enzyme levels, favoring another diagnosis.   
✅ Biliary colic :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acalculous cholecystitis :
Incorrect: Acalculous cholecystitis is defined as inflammation of the gallbladder without evidence of gallstones or cystic duct obstruction. It is typically seen in critically ill patients due to gallbladder stasis. This patient is relatively healthy and has normal enzyme levels. 
❌ Calculous cholecystitis :
Incorrect: Calculous cholecystitis refers to the inflammation of the gallbladder due to cystic duct obstruction by stone. Typical presentation includes steady, severe epigastric or right upper quadrant pain which may radiate to the right shoulder or back. The pain is often associated with fever, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Laboratory findings include leukocytosis but normal total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels, if the disease is limited to the gallbladder (uncomplicated cholecystitis).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest pain that started suddenly 15 minutes ago while playing with his grandchildren. The patient describes the pain as “pressure and tightness” located in the center of his chest. The patient reports that he occasionally experiences mild chest discomfort when going up the stairs. Medical history is significant for a 30-pack-year smoking history, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. The patient is given a sublingual medication while in the emergency department, and the symptoms resolve within a few minutes. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely to be seen in this patient following the administration of this medication?  

*(-) decrease, (0) no effect, (+) increase
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors (smoking, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension), who now presents with substernal chest pain with exertion that resolves with nitroglycerin, most likely has stable angina. Stable angina most commonly occurs secondary to atherosclerosis. The onset of stable angina symptoms typically occurs when there is ≥70% coronary artery occlusion. Atherosclerosis leads to mismatch between oxygen demand and consumption, which becomes more pronounced during exertion.  

Nitrates (nitroglycerin) work by increasing nitric oxide (NO) release in vascular smooth muscle cells, which causes elevation of cGMP and smooth muscle relaxation. This process results in vasodilation of veins and arteries, leading to increased peripheral venous capacitance and decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR), respectively. When blood pools in the venous system, less blood flows back to the heart (decreased preload), which reduces myocardial wall stress and oxygen consumption.
