This mechanism is believed to be responsible for the antianginal effects of nitrates. The reduction in SVR also decreases cardiac wall stress, since the heart has to overcome less resistance to pump blood out (decreased afterload). In addition, nitrates also mildly vasodilate the coronary arteries, leading to increased oxygen delivery to the myocardium. However, the vasodilation of arteries only has a minor contribution, because nitrates affect veins more than arteries. The heart rate is increased due to barorecptors induced reflex tachycardia in response to reduced blood pressure.  



Option Analysis

❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  +  0  ++ :
Incorrect: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive medication that preferentially reduces afterload. The increased heart rate is due to reflex tachycardia in response to reduced blood pressure. The exact mechanism of action is unknown, but arterial dilation is thought to occur via blockage of calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and inhibition of myosin phosphorylation in arterial smooth muscle cells.
✅   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  + ++ + :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction 0++ ++ :
Incorrect: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI, e.g. enalapril) is a class of antihypertensive medications that work by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor. In addition, it reduces aldosterone secretion, which further reduces the blood pressure. ACEI reduces preload and afterload but has no effect on the heart rate. 
❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  - 0  +:
Incorrect: Carvedilol is a beta-blocker class medication with a nonselective beta-adrenoreceptor and alpha-adrenergic blocking activity. As a result, there is a decrease in heart rate, cardiac output, and peripheral vascular resistance.  
❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  0 0  ++ :
Incorrect: Dihydropyridines (e.g. amlodipine) are a type of calcium channel blockers that act on vascular smooth muscle. It works by blocking voltage-dependent L-type calcium channels of cardiac and smooth muscle, thereby reducing muscle contractility. Non-dihydropyridines (e.g. diltiazem) also work on the cardiac nodal tissue and reduce the heart rate.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with 3 days of difficulty urinating, right flank pain, malaise, and nausea. Medical history includes chronic migraines for the last 10 years, for which she has been taking ibuprofen multiple times daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg. Laboratory testing is obtained and the results are shown below.



Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has urinary symptoms, history of analgesic overuse, hypokalemia, urine pH above 5.5, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. She most likely has a distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and symptoms due to a calcium phosphate kidney stone. 



Distal RTA is caused by a genetic or acquired defect of α-intercalated cells in the distal tubule and collecting duct, which prevents them from secreting hydrogen. This defect leads to a buildup of hydrogen in the blood, resulting in acidemia and metabolic acidosis. To maintain electroneutrality, there is increased excretion of potassium in the renal tubules and hypokalemia. Patients with distal RTA have alkaline urine pH, usually above 5.5, and increased calcium excretion without increased calcium absorption. This mismatch leads to increased bone turnover and predisposition to developing calcium phosphate kidney stones.  





Genetic causes of distal RTA include mutations in the H+ ATPase or H+/K+ ATPase pump of α-intercalated cells. Acquired distal RTA may be due to adverse medication reactions (e.g., amphotericin B, analgesics), congenital urinary tract anomalies, or autoimmune diseases (e.g. SLE), all which can damage the distal and collecting tubules and decrease hydrogen secretion.   

Option Analysis

❌ Reduced aldosterone release :
Incorrect: Reduced aldosterone release would cause a hyperkalemic (type 4) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). The condition presents with a urine pH < 5.5 and hyperkalemia. In contrast, this patient has a urine pH > 5.5 and hypokalemia, which is more consistent with a type 1 RTA.  
❌ Respiratory muscle fatigue:
Incorrect: Respiratory muscle fatigue can develop over time due to hyperventilation. It would result in respiratory acidosis, which presents with an elevated pCO2. In contrast, this patient has findings more consistent with a metabolic acidosis. 
✅ Decreased hydrogen secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased cystine excretion :
Incorrect: Increased excretion of cystine into the urine can cause cystine stone formation. This patient has laboratory findings consistent with a type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which increases urine calcium and leads to calcium phosphate stone formation. 
❌ Increased bicarbonate excretion:
Incorrect: Increased excretion of bicarbonate would cause a type 2 renal tubular acidosis (RTA). This patient has a high urine pH and hypokalemia, which is more consistent with type 1 RTA.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parent due to excessive bleeding with menstruation, lightheadedness, and headaches. The patient states the symptoms started 6 months ago with her first menstrual period. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg. Physical exam reveals conjunctival pallor. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below.  
 
Laboratory value  Results
 Hematologic  
 Platelet count  180,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin  9.7 g/dL 
Coagulation studies  
 Prothrombin time (PT)  12 seconds 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  30 seconds 
 Bleeding time*  12 minutes 
*Reference Range: 2-7 minutes  
 
A sample of the patient’s blood is collected. Administration of risotectin to the sample fails to induce platelet aggregation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has excessive menstrual bleeding and anemia in the setting of a prolonged bleeding time and abnormal ristocetin test. She most likely has Bernard-Soulier syndrome.   

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive platelet adhesion defect caused by an abnormal Gp1b platelet receptor. Normally, the Gp1b receptor binds to von Willebrand factor, which in turn allows platelets to adhere to the damaged endothelium. In contrast, in the setting of defective Gp1b receptors, platelets are unable to adhere to damaged blood vessels, and platelet plug formation cannot occur. Laboratory testing will reveal an elevated bleeding time and abnormal ristocetin test, meaning that addition of ristocetin to the patient’s blood sample would not promote platelet aggregation.  

Most patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome do not require any particular treatment except preventative measures and therapies to mitigate the frequency bleeding episodes. However, those with more severe bleeding may need antifibrinolytic therapy or platelet transfusions.   



Option Analysis

❌ Platelet aggregation defect:
Incorrect: Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a platelet aggregation disorder caused by a defect in the platelet Gp2b3a receptor. Patients with this condition have a normal ristocetin test, wherein platelet aggregation occurs after ristocetin is added to the blood sample. 
❌ Combined platelet and coagulation defect :
Incorrect: Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is a combined platelet and coagulation defect. On one hand, the defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF) impairs platelet adhesion to the endothelial lining. On the other hand, since not enough vWF is available to carry and protect factor VIII, a coagulation defect also arises. The condition would cause an elevation in both activated partial thromboplastin time and bleeding time.
❌ General coagulation defect :
Incorrect: Vitamin K deficiency is a general coagulation defect and leads to decreased activity of factors II, VII, IV, X, protein C, and protein S in the coagulation cascade. Patients have an increased prothrombin time and increased activated partial thromboplastin time, but a normal bleeding time.
✅ Platelet adhesion defect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired hemoglobin synthesis:
Incorrect: Many conditions, ranging from thalassemias to sickle cell disease, impair hemoglobin synthesis and can result in anemia. However, this patient has an elevated bleeding time. As a result, she most likely has a platelet disorder and anemia secondary to excess menstrual bleeding.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a three month history of pain and swelling in both wrists. She states that the pain is worse in the morning and is characterized by stiffness that takes approximately one hour to improve. Upon questioning, the patient notes that she had one episode last month where red patches over her cheeks and nose appeared after spending a day at the park with her nephew. She is sexually active with one partner and takes oral contraceptive pills. She drinks approximately four alcoholic beverages per week and does not smoke cigarettes. The patient’s temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows flat, fixed erythema over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds. The wrists are visibly swollen bilaterally and are tender on palpation. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.0 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  3,800/mm3 
 Platelet count  160,000/mm3 

Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). She exhibits the classic symptoms of arthralgias, rash, and fever. The malar (butterfly) rash, the most common skin lesion that characterizes acute SLE, was likely triggered by ultraviolet light exposure at the park. Combined with the inflammatory arthritis and laboratory abnormalities (leukopenia), SLE should be suspected.  


SLE is caused by a combination of factors that predispose to an abnormal immune response leading to autoantibody immune complex deposition, inflammation, and end-organ damage. Pathogenesis begins when environmental triggers cause cell damage and apoptosis, exposing nuclear material to the immune system. Genetic susceptibility can lead to poor clearance of these nuclear antigens and to recognition of their moieties as foreign. Dendritic cells present these antigens to B-cells, which then start producing autoimmune antibodies, known as antinuclear antibodies (ANA). These antibodies spread through the bloodstream, forming immune complexes with antigens encountered in the blood, and deposit within various organs.  

These deposited immune complexes activate the complement cascade, leading to enzyme-mediated cell damage, referred to as a type III hypersensitivity reaction. End-organ damage (e.g., rash, nephritis, synovitis) occurs as a result. When complement is activated and used up, serum complement levels (C3 and C4) fall. Another high-yield fact is that because early complement proteins like C1q, C2 and C4 are all involved in removing immune complexes, individuals that lack any of these proteins are predisposed to developing SLE.    

Patients can also develop antibodies to antigens found on hematologic cells, including erythrocytes and leukocytes, and certain molecules, like phospholipids. Binding of these antibodies triggers complement activation via the classical complement pathway, leading to cell lysis and death. This process represents a type II hypersensitivity reaction and can cause hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased erythrocyte sedimentation rate:
Incorrect: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) refers to the speed at which red blood cells drop to the bottom of a test tube. Inflammatory antibodies clump up on the cells and increase the ESR in the case of lupus, though elevated ESR is not specific for lupus. A decreased ESR would not be consistent with this patient’s diagnosis.  
✅ Decreased complement C4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased interleukin-6:
Incorrect: Interleukin-6 (IL-6) causes fever and stimulates the production of acute-phase proteins. IL-6 levels are instead increased in lupus, contributing to B-cell hyperactivity and tissue damage.
❌ Decreased haptoglobin:
Incorrect: Haptoglobin is a protein that binds to free hemoglobin from ruptured blood cells, forming a complex that is removed by the spleen; therefore, haptoglobin levels are low in hemolytic anemia. Lupus can cause hemolytic anemia, but this patient’s hemoglobin level is normal.
❌ Decreased C-reactive protein:
Incorrect: C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute-phase protein whose levels rise in response to inflammation. CRP would generally be elevated in active lupus, but it is not specific for the disease and is not part of the diagnostic criteria for lupus. A decrease in CRP would not be consistent with this patient’s diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal results of a routine blood count. The patient does not have any symptoms of fatigue, malaise, fever, or shortness of breath. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged, firm, mobile cervical lymph nodes on both sides. Fecal occult blood is negative. Laboratory results are shown.  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   90,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   20,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils  20% 
 Lymphocytes  75% 
 Eosinophils  2% 
 Basophils  1% 
 Monocytes  1% 
After appropriate workup, flow cytometry is indicated which shows the following results.
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis, and flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation (CD20 and CD5) is strongly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL).  

CLL/SLL arises from oncogenic mutations that cause inhibition of apoptosis and monoclonal expansion of B cells, resulting in their accumulation in the peripheral blood and bone marrow. It is the most common leukemia in adults in the Western world, and it is almost always seen in the elderly (median age of diagnosis is 70). It is usually asymptomatic (as in this patient) but can present with “B symptoms” (fever, weight loss, night sweats and fatigue). Lymphadenopathy (cervical, supraclavicular and/or axillary), hepatomegaly and splenomegaly are common findings on examination. Lymph nodes appear as round, firm, mobile and nontender masses on palpation.  

 Proliferation centers in lymph nodes, which are loose aggregates of large lymphocytes, are pathognomonic of CLL/SLL. On laboratory evaluation, lymphocytosis (>5000/mL) is present in association with anemia, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and a few cells disrupted in the process of making smear, called smudge (smear) cells (mnemonic: CLL = Crushed Little Lymphocytes). Immunophenotype analysis by using flow cytometry is key to make a definitive diagnosis, which shows clonal expansion of B-cells expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23.  

A small fraction of patients with CLL/SLL can develop transformation to aggressive tumors resembling diffuse large B cell lymphoma (Richter transformation). This should be suspected in patients with CLL/SLL who develop rapidly progressive lymphadenopathy or extranodal sites of disease, systemic symptoms, or elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase, indicative of a rapidly proliferating tumor.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Hairy cell leukemia:
Incorrect: Although hairy cell leukemia is also a mature B cell neoplasm, it usually presents with pancytopenia and massive splenomegaly. Additionally, lymphadenopathy is atypical and should prompt investigation for a different underlying condition.
✅ Chronic lymphocytic leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Chronic myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Chronic myeloid leukemia is a myeloproliferative (not lymphoproliferative) neoplasm characterized by uncontrolled production of mature granulocytes. Lymphocyte count is usually not affected, and blood count usually reveals elevated myelocytes and basophils. Moreover, CD20 cells on flow cytometry are indicative of a B-cell neoplasm.
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with asymptomatic lymphadenopathy or a mediastinal mass and constitutional symptoms (fever, night sweats and weight loss). It does not usually cause anemia or lymphocytosis.
❌ Aplastic anemia:
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure causing pancytopenia, not lymphocytosis. A clonal B cell proliferation, as demonstrated by this patient's flow cytometry, is not typical.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman comes to the office with joint pain and fatigue. For the past three months, she has felt excessive fatigue with normal activity, associated with poor appetite, and a 5 lb (2.3 kg) weight loss. The joint pain is characterized by stiffness in her fingers and wrists that lasts an hour after waking up and usually improves throughout the day. She has no significant past medical history. The patient’s temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg. She appears tired. Physical examination shows symmetrically swollen and tender wrists bilaterally, and abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Examination of the patient’s face is shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons    

Follow-up laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.0 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  3,800/mm3 
 Platelet count  125,000/mm3 
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) based on the systemic features of fatigue, weight loss, and fever; the presence of inflammatory arthritis; and the photosensitive malar rash (flat, fixed erythema over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds).  

SLE results from a combination of predisposing factors causing an abnormal immune response leading to autoantibody immune complex deposition, inflammation, and end-organ damage. Pathogenesis begins when environmental triggers cause cell damage and apoptosis, exposing nuclear material to the immune system. Genetic susceptibility can lead to poor clearance of these nuclear antigens and to the recognition of their moieties as foreign. Dendritic cells present these antigens to B-cells which then produce autoimmune antibodies, known as antinuclear antibodies (ANA). These antibodies spread through the bloodstream, forming immune complexes with antigens encountered in the blood, and deposit within various organs. There, these immune complexes cause complement cascade activation, leading to enzyme-mediated cell damage, referred to as a type III hypersensitivity reaction. End-organ damage (e.g., rash, nephritis, synovitis) occurs as a result.  

In addition, non-complexed auto-antibodies can directly bind to antigens recognized on the cell membranes of circulating hematologic cells, activating the complement pathway on the cell surface and causing cellular destruction. This type II hypersensitivity reaction causes the hematologic manifestation of SLE, including anemia (usually chronic, less often hemolytic), leukopenia (specifically lymphopenia), and thrombocytopenia (rarely less than 50,000/mm3). Processing of these antibody-covered cells may lead to lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Although most patients with SLE will have one or two cytopenias, they can also have pancytopenia, as in this patient.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Type I hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are caused by antigenic cross linking of IgE on mast cells and basophils, causing the release of vasoactive biomolecules and the immediate allergic or anaphylactic response. SLE is not associated with Type I hypersensitivity reactions.
✅ Type II hypersensitivity reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Type III hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type III hypersensitivity reactions occur when antibodies (IgG) bind to soluble antigens, forming circulating immune complexes that deposit and cause a local inflammatory reaction. Although this is the primary mechanism of organ damage in SLE, it is not the mechanism of blood cell destruction in SLE, and therefore it does not explain this patient’s laboratory values.  
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions occur when T helper cells are activated by antigen presenting cells, developing memory and causing macrophage activation and inflammation when that antigen is encountered again. This is not a primary reaction caused by SLE.  
❌ Type V hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type V hypersensitivity reaction is sometimes used to describe activating antibody presence (e.g. Graves disease), but the concept is not generally accepted as a true hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy comes to the emergency department complaining of 2 days of fatigue, large purple spots on his legs, and bleeding in his mouth from the gums. He has no significant past medical history, and family history is unremarkable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/66 mmHg. Upon physical exam, he is found to have pale skin, large purpura on his legs bilaterally, and bleeding mucosal petechiae. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below. Direct Coombs test is positive.    

Laboratory value  Result
 Hematologic 
 Hemoglobin  8.1 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   86 fL 
 Platelet count  80,000/mm3  
 Reticulocyte count   4.6% 
 Haptoglobin  100 mg/dL (N = 50-220) 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  1080 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with signs and symptoms consistent with extravascular hemolytic anemia (normal haptoglobin and fatigue), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count, purpura, and mucosal petechiae), and a direct Coombs test most likely has Evan’s syndrome. Evan’s syndrome is a rare disease that is defined as a combination of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is a disorder in which autoantibodies bind to platelets and mark them for destruction in the spleen, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a disorder in which autoantibodies bind to erythrocytes and mark them for destruction in the spleen. Diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory findings, which would show positive direct Coombs test as well as markers of hemolysis (e.g., elevated LDH, elevated unconjugated bilirubin).  



Option Analysis

❌ Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura:
Incorrect: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is a type of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and patients present with signs and symptoms consistent with thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia as in this patient. However, the direct Coombs test would be negative.   
❌ Valve-associated hemolysis:
Incorrect: Valve-associated hemolytic anemia is a type of macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia most commonly associated with aortic stenosis or a prosthetic mitral valve. The patient would have signs and symptoms consistent with extrinsic hemolytic anemia, such as elevated LDH (which is seen in this patient), as well as decreased haptoglobin (which is normal in this patient), but not thrombocytopenia. The direct Coombs test would be negative.   
✅ Evan’s syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a type of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, in which patients present with signs and symptoms consistent with thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia, as in this patient. However, the direct Coombs test would be negative, and the patient would also have renal failure.   
❌ Autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a type of extrinsic hemolytic anemia associated with a positive direct Coombs test but not thrombocytopenia. Therefore, this diagnosis would not explain all of the symptoms present in this patient, specifically the purpura and mucosal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parent due to repeated episodes of jaundice, pallor, and fatigue for the last 8 months and new-onset abdominal pain for the last 3 days. She is at the 35th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. The parent reports no pregnancy or birth-related complications and states that the patient had been relatively healthy previously. The parent states that the girl’s biological father had been hospitalized with similar symptoms as a child and had abdominal surgery, but the details of the surgery are unknown. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing pale child with scleral icterus and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below. The patient most likely has a defect in which of the following?

Laboratory ValueResult
Hematologic
Leukocyte count6,500/mm3
Platelet count250,000/mm3
Hemoglobin9.6 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)84 fL
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)42 g/dL (normal 32-36 g/dL)
Red cell distribution width (RDW)15%
Reticulocyte count9.1%

choices.text: Single amino acid in the beta chain of hemoglobin

questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain, growth delay, scleral icterus, splenomegaly, anemia, and increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) has hereditary spherocytosis. Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant condition that commonly presents for the first time in children near the age of 5. It is caused by an inherited defect of the erythrocyte cytoskeleton-membrane tethering proteins: ankyrin, spectrin, or band 3. Loss of membrane integrity leads to the formation of membrane blebs, and erythrocytes assume a round shape (spherocytes). These spherocytes are unable to maneuver through splenic sinusoids and are consumed by macrophages in the spleen.

Peripheral Blood Smear Showing Spherocytes


Reproduced from:

Characteristic laboratory findings include increased RDW and MCHC. Definitive diagnosis is made via osmotic fragility test, which demonstrates spherocyte fragility in a hypotonic solution. Eosin-5-maleimide (EMA) binding is another test that can be performed. EMA is an eosin-based fluorescent dye that binds to RBC membrane proteins; since patients with HS lack these proteins, there will be decreased fluorescence of EMA-labeled RBCs in a flow cytometry-based assay. Treatment includes splenectomy (which is likely the abdominal surgery this child’s father previously had).  

Option Analysis

✅ Erythrocyte cytoskeleton-membrane tethering proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GPI anchor glycolipid:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is associated with impaired synthesis of the GPI anchor glycolipids for decay-accelerating factor (DAF/CD55) and membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL/CD59). This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.
❌ Single amino acid in the beta chain of hemoglobin:
Incorrect: A single amino acid point mutation from glutamic acid to valine in the beta chain of hemoglobin  is associated with sickle cell anemia. This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.
❌ Ferroportin-mediated intestinal iron transport:
Incorrect: Impaired ferroportin-mediated intestinal iron transport is associated with anemia of chronic disease. This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.
❌ Glutathione-mediated protection from oxidative stress:
Incorrect: Glutathione-mediated protection from oxidative stress is impaired in glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD). This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe right flank pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The pain is 7/10 in severity and radiates to the groin. Medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is unable to lay still and is agonizing with pain. A urine dipstick is positive for blood. She is treated with IV fluids and analgesia. Further evaluation will most likely reveal which of the following set of findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with the classic signs and symptoms of nephrolithiasis, including flank pain radiating to the groin, nausea and vomiting, hematuria, and inability to lay still. In the absence of underlying conditions or additional clues, it is reasonable to deduce that the patient’s symptoms are due to the most common type of renal stone, calcium oxalate stones.  

Calcium oxalate stones account for 80% of all stones. Idiopathic hypercalciuria is the most common metabolic abnormality in patients with calcium kidney stones. Idiopathic hypercalciuria is characterized by normocalcemia and hypercalciuria that cannot be explained by another medical condition (e.g. hyperparathyroidism). Calcium oxalate stones are not pH-dependent, unlike other stone types. Additional risk factors for developing calcium oxalate stones are listed in the table below.



Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with hereditary cystinuria, an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in the proximal convoluted tubule cystine-reabsorbing transporter. This defect also results in poor reabsorption of the amino acids ornithine, lysine, and arginine (COLA). Hexagonal-shaped cystine crystals can be found on urinalysis. Cystine stones account for approximately 1% of all stones. Patients often have a positive family history and present during childhood with recurrent kidney stones.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) stones, which account for 15% of all stones. Struvite stones can be found in the setting of infection by urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter. Urease breaks urea into ammonia and alkalizes urine (high pH). This patient has no history of urinary tract infections.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with uric acid stones, which account for 5-10% of all stones. Dehydration, acidic urine, and increased uric acid levels, such as in the setting of myeloproliferative disorders, promote their formation. They can also form in the setting of chronic diarrhea, in which bicarbonate is lost via stool; the subsequent decrease in urine pH facilitates the formation of insoluble uric acid crystals. This patient has none of these conditions.
❌ :
Incorrect: Calcium phosphate stones, which are associated with a high urinary pH (>6.5), are the second most common type of kidney stone. In contrast, calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone and the most likely diagnosis in this patient. These stones are associated with hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hypocitraturia.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse is admitted for acute pancreatitis, and he becomes acutely short of breath on day two of his hospitalization. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 110/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. He is given supplemental O2 via non-invasive ventilation, but he later requires intubation due to persistent hypoxemia and concern for airway compromise. Chest x-ray demonstrates new bilateral opacities. His arterial blood gas on 100% FiO2 shows the following:  

 
Laboratory value  Result
Blood Gases, Serum 
pH  7.51 
 PCO2  23 mmHg 
 PO2  54 mm Hg 
Cardiac Enzymes, Serum 
Brain Natriuretic Peptide  (BNP)  <100 ng/dL (N = <100) 
 Troponin  <.03 ng/dL 
Which of the following physiologic parameters best confirms the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) based on the Berlin criteria, with findings of new bilateral infiltrates on his chest x ray, a PO2:FiO2 ratio < 300, an identifiable clinical insult of pancreatitis, and a brain natriuretic peptide <100 ng/dL. ARDS most commonly occurs due to sepsis but can also occur as a complication of acute pancreatitis, major trauma, shock, drug overdose, severe burns, pneumonia and massive hemorrhage. Patients with severe acute pancreatitis have systemic circulation of activated pancreatic enzymes and cytokines (tumor necrosis factor, platelet activating factor). ARDS can then be the result of microvascular thrombosis (a result of the inflammatory environment) and systemic active phospholipase A (lecithinase) digesting lecithin, a major component of surfactant, which then results in alveolar capillary damage. The injury to the alveolar epithelium and endothelium results in pulmonary edema and a protein-rich infiltrate, leading to acute respiratory failure.    

The diagnostic criteria for ARDS follows the Berlin criteria, which entails ruling out a cardiac etiology causing volume overload. This step in diagnosis can be accomplished via an echocardiogram or a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), or low brain natriuretic peptide levels, which are reflective of a normal left atrial pressure.   



Option Analysis

❌ Increased FEV1/FVC ratio:
Incorrect: An increased FEV1/FVC ratio describes the restrictive pattern of lung physiology often seen in patients with sarcoidosis, asbestosis, or pulmonary fibrosis. Patients with ARDS may have an increased FEV1/FVC ratio in the latter part of the disease process or a normal ratio. However, this finding is relatively non-specific in these patients.   
❌ Increased airway compliance :
Incorrect: Patients with ARDS are more likely to have decreased airway compliance due to hyaline membrane formation and subsequent collapse of alveoli. The thickening of alveolar membranes with hyaline formation results in decreased lung distensibility and compliance.   
✅ Normal left atrial pressure :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Respiratory acidosis :
Incorrect: ARDS typically presents with hypoxemic respiratory alkalosis during the initial insult of ARDS, but it is a nonspecific finding. If the initial insult is due to an anion-gap metabolic acidosis such as sepsis, patients can present with a mixed anion gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.  
❌ Increased right ventricular pressure :
Incorrect: Increased right ventricular pressures can be seen in the setting of cor pulmonale, pulmonary embolism, COPD, and pulmonary hypertension. While right ventricular pressure can become elevated in the later stages of ARDS, it is unlikely to do so during the initial stages.

questions.text:
A 5-month-old female is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of jaundice that began after a viral upper respiratory tract infection. She was born at 39 weeks gestation to a 27-year-old, gravida 1 para 1, woman via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The patient has been meeting developmental milestones. Family history is noncontributory. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse jaundice. Abdominal and neurological exams are unremarkable. Blood testing is performed and reveals the following:  
Laboratory value  Result 
Hemoglobin  13.9 mg.dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,800/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  12.7 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Alanine  aminotransferase  15 U/L 
 Aspartate  aminotransferase  16 U/L 
Phenobarbital is administered, and repeat total serum bilirubin is measured at 7 mg/dL. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces

questions.solution:
This patient has Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, a condition characterized by reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. It is less severe than Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. Patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II develop unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but the total bilirubin is usually below 20 mg/dL. In contrast, individuals with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I often have total bilirubin exceeding 20 mg/dL.  

Patients with this condition can develop jaundice and, in rare cases, neurological deficits secondary to kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II have good response to treatment with phenobarbital, which increases UDPGT synthesis and subsequently increases conjugation of unconjugated bilirubin. In contrast, patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I do not respond to phenobarbital therapy, because there is a complete absence of UDPGT enzyme activity.    

Option Analysis

❌ Absent UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Incorrect: This answer describes Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. However, patients with this condition would not respond to phenobarbital, and thus no decline in total serum bilirubin would occur after administration.  
✅ Reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defective multidrug resistance protein 2:
Incorrect: This answer describes Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2) is involved in the transport of conjugated bilirubin out of hepatocytes and into the bile canaliculi. Patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome have conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, whereas this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 
❌ Imapired replenishment of glutathione:
Incorrect: This answer describes glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. The condition can predispose patients to hemolysis after exposure to oxidative stress, causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, phenobarbital would not reduce unconjugated bilirubin levels in patients with G6PD deficiency.  
❌ Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces:
Incorrect: Breastfeeding failure jaundice typically occurs during the first week of life and is due to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces. However, it would be atypical for breastfeeding failure jaundice to present in a 5 month old child with no signs of malnutrition or dehydration.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office with a 3-week history of dark brown urine. He also complains of a cough productive of pinkish sputum that started around the same time. Review of systems reveals loss of appetite, fatigue, and 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the last month. He has had no oral ulcers, joint pain, or rashes. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral wheezing. There is 2+ peripheral pitting edema. Serum creatinine is 1.3 mg/dL. Complete blood count and urinalysis results are shown below. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral nodular densities. Serum c-ANCA is positive. Renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following additional findings are most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: History of allergic rhinitis and asthma
Blanching lesions on skin and mucous membranes

questions.solution:
This patient has nephritic syndrome, characterized by hematuria, mild proteinuria, edema, red blood cell (RBC) casts and dysmorphic RBCs. The presence of constitutional symptoms (fatigue, loss of appetite, fever and weight loss), together with hemoptysis, nodular densities on chest x-ray, and crescent formation on renal biopsy, confirms the diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).  

GPA, formerly called Wegener granulomatosis, is an immune-mediated vasculitis associated with the formation of proteinase 3 antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA). These autoantibodies against neutrophil granule proteins are the hallmark of GPA, though their exact role in causing disease remains unclear. The condition usually manifests in older adults with constitutional symptoms, recurrent sinusitis, cough, hemoptysis and nephritic syndrome. Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia, leukocytosis and positive c-ANCA on serology. Chest x-ray reveals nodular densities suggestive of necrosis and cavitation.  

Definitive diagnosis requires biopsy of the involved organs. Common findings include leukocytoclastic vasculitis (cutaneous), deposition of fibrin and C3 in glomeruli in the form of a crescent as indicated by the black arrows (renal), and granulomatous inflammation (lungs).  



Treatment involves immunosuppression, often involving glucocorticoids combined with either cyclophosphamide or rituximab.

Option Analysis

✅ History of recurrent sinopulmonary infections:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive hepatitis C virus serology:
Incorrect: Positive hepatitis C virus serology is associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome, which is a small-vessel vasculitis that usually presents with palpable purpura, arthralgias, and peripheral neuropathy. Though immune complex deposition can lead to nephritic syndrome, biopsy findings usually show glomerular basement membrane thickening and subendothelial deposits, not crescent formation.
❌ History of allergic rhinitis and asthma:
Incorrect: History of atopy (asthma) is usually seen in patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome), which usually presents with nephritic syndrome, skin nodules, purpura, and/or wrist drop (peripheral neuropathy). Laboratory findings include eosinophilia and p-ANCA seropositivity. This diagnosis is unlikely given this patient's normal eosinophil count and c-ANCA seropositivity.
❌ History of recurrent genital ulcerations:
Incorrect: Recurrent genital ulcerations are usually seen in Behçet syndrome, which is also a small-vessel vasculitis. However, it usually presents with recurrent aphthous ulcers, ocular pain (uveitis) and tender bumps on the shin (erythema nodosum), which are not seen in this patient.
❌ Blanching lesions on skin and mucous membranes:
Incorrect: Blanching lesions on the skin and mucous membranes can be seen in hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (also called Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome). The condition usually presents with recurrent epistaxis or hemorrhagic stroke (due to arteriovenous malformations). Although hematuria can be seen, dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs), RBC casts, and nodular densities on chest x-ray would be atypical.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain that started two hours ago. He reports that the pain radiates to the back and is 8 out of 10 in severity. The patient eats a well-balanced diet, consumes 1-2 beers per week, and denies recent abdominal trauma. Family history is notable for hypertension in his father. Physical examination shows pain on light palpation of the epigastric region. Hepatosplenomegaly is noted. Multiple small red-yellow papules are present on the patient’s buttocks and shoulders. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
Laboratory value Result 
Sodium  139 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Calcium  7.9 mg/dL 
 Triglyceride  860 mg/dL 
 Serum Cholesterol (Total)  190 mg/dL 
 Lipase  310 U/L 

A deficiency in which of the following proteins is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has type I hyperlipidemia (also termed hyperchylomicronemia), an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by elevation of chylomicrons in the blood. It occurs most often due to lipoprotein lipase deficiency. A rarer cause is a defect in apolipoprotein C-II, a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase. Without a functional lipoprotein lipase, the breakdown of chylomicrons and their triglyceride content is prevented, resulting in massive triglyceride accumulation within the blood.  

The massive triglyceride content in the blood results in cutaneous deposition and rapid development of xanthomas on the back and buttocks that can be pruritic. Due to the rapid nature of their development, they are called eruptive xanthomas. In addition, the high concentration of serum triglycerides can lead to acute pancreatitis. This is because when pancreatic cells encounter triglycerides, they release lipase to break the triglycerides down into free fatty acids; excess free fatty acids can injure the pancreas. Lastly, patients can develop hepatosplenomegaly.  

Of note, patients with type I hyperlipidemia are not at increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. This is because the development of atherosclerotic plaques is related to the elevation of other lipoproteins such as low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and not related to the elevation of chylomicrons.  

Laboratory testing will show markedly elevated triglyceride levels and normal/mildly elevated cholesterol levels. Another important sign is that when fasting serum is chilled, the chylomicrons will form a white, creamy layer at the top of the test tube, as seen in the image below.  


Image reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   

Option Analysis

❌ Apolipoprotein C-II:
Incorrect: A defect in apolipoprotein C-II can result in familial hyperlipidemia type I. The condition presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pancreatitis, and eruptive xanthomas. However, a deficiency in apolipoprotein C-II accounts for less than 20% of cases. The vast majority of cases (80%) are caused by defects in lipoprotein lipase.  
❌ Apolipoprotein E:
Incorrect: Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is involved in lipoprotein remnant uptake. A defect with ApoE presents with premature atherosclerosis, increased risk of acute coronary syndrome, and palmar xanthomas. However, it would be atypical for an ApoE defect to present with pancreatitis or eruptive xanthomas.
✅ Lipoprotein lipase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pancreatic lipase:
Incorrect: A defect in this enzyme can cause poor fat absorption and a deficiency in fat-soluble vitamins. As a result, patients with pancreatic lipase deficiency have low serum triglyceride levels. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has markedly elevated serum triglyceride levels, favoring another diagnosis.
❌ Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase helps break down fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. A defect in this protein can cause hypoketotic hypoglycemia, which presents with seizures, vomiting, and coma. The condition is usually diagnosed shortly after birth and would not present with eruptive xanthomas and pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic with worsening abdominal pain and associated fatigue, intermittent nausea and vomiting, and dark urine. He reports his symptoms started three weeks ago and have not improved. He uses intravenous heroin and reports drinking approximately 4-6 beers daily. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a disheveled male with track marks noted in the antecubital fossa of the arms bilaterally. There is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory findings are as follows:  


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, malaise, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. The liver function tests demonstrate a marked elevation in ALT and AST concerning for acute hepatitis. Given the history of intravenous drug use and the relative increase in ALT compared to AST, this presentation is most consistent with acute infection due to hepatitis B.  

Viral hepatitis refers to either an acute or chronic infection of the liver caused by hepatitis viruses A, B, C, D, or E. Acute viral hepatitis is almost exclusively caused by hepatitis A or B, but it can be caused by the other hepatitis viruses as well. Acute viral hepatitis manifests with malaise, fever, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and dark urine within six months of infection. It will typically present with significant elevations in ALT and AST, usually on the order of >15 times the upper limit of normal with associated indirect hyperbilirubinemia.  

In contrast, chronic hepatitis is associated with hepatitis B and C and is most often asymptomatic but can progress to cirrhosis and end-stage liver disease. When symptoms do develop they are often constitutional and include features such as malaise or fatigue. Sometimes, the only features of infection may be cirrhotic liver disease, manifesting with jaundice, ascites, or spider angioma. Chronic hepatitis will also have elevations in liver enzymes, usually on the order of ~15 times the upper limit of normal.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acute hepatitis B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HIV:
Incorrect: Early HIV infection can manifest with non-specific viral symptoms including fatigue, malaise and low-grade fevers. It does not typically cause marked elevations in liver function tests or right upper quadrant tenderness.
❌ Biliary colic:
Incorrect: Biliary colic results from intermittent obstructing cholelithiasis. It can cause episodic right upper quadrant pain but does not typically cause elevation in liver enzymes.
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess:
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscess is a rare entity associated with underlying liver disease or recent biliary tract manipulation. In developing countries, pyogenic liver abscesses are more commonly caused by parasitic infections, whereas in the United States they are commonly caused by bacterial infections.
❌ Acute alcoholic hepatitis:
Incorrect: While this patient is a heavy user of alcohol, his liver function tests demonstrate an ALT>AST, consistent with a viral hepatitis pattern. Alcohol, as a mitochondrial poison, tends to generate an AST:ALT of approximately 2:1.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations. He states he drank his morning coffee, went out for a jog, but he suddenly became lightheaded and noted a fluttering sensation in his chest. He had a similar episode in the past, which self-resolved without intervention. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 175/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable, and initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Based on this patient's clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
This young, otherwise healthy patient presents with sudden onset palpitations and an electrocardiogram that demonstrates a regular, narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves. These findings are most consistent with the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.   

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia refers to any supraventricular tachycardia (arising above the bundle of His) with abrupt onset and offset. While there are multiple subsets, this arrhythmia is most commonly caused by atrio-ventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), which results in a reentrant circuit that loops within the AV node. Patients with this disorder are typically symptomatic and may notice subtle palpitations, dizziness, and lightheadedness. Patients with underlying heart disease may also experience chest pain and shortness of breath. This arrhythmia commonly occurs in patients without any history of cardiac disease, although alcohol and coffee can trigger the arrhythmia via inhibition of adenosine reuptake.  

On an electrocardiogram, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is defined as a regular rhythm with a rate between 150 to 250 beats per minute, a narrow QRS complex, and absence of normal P-waves. Sometimes, retrograde P-waves can be seen after the QRS complex; however, these are usually buried. First-line treatment consists of vagal maneuvers (e.g., placing an ice pack on the face, having the patient bear down or blow into a straw). If these maneuvers fail, adenosine should be administered. This medication terminates the arrhythmia by decreasing AV nodal conduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrial flutter:
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves," which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Multifocal atrial tachycardia :
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying R-R intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Individuals with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. However, this patient’s rhythm is regular and P-waves are absent.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) will manifest on electrocardiography with an abnormally fast heart rate, irregularly spaced QRS complexes, and absent P-waves. In contrast, the QRS complexes on this patient’s electrocardiography are equally spaced. 
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia is defined as a fast heart rate (>100 beats per minutes), regular rhythm, and an identifiable P-wave before every QRS complex. In contrast, no P-waves can be seen on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to lightheadedness. The patient was drinking coffee this morning, noticed a “fluttering” sensation in his chest, and subsequently felt lightheaded. He is otherwise asymptomatic and has not seen a physician in many years. He smokes one to two cigarettes per day and drinks a glass of wine with dinner nightly. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 134/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 142/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination is notable for an obese male in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary exam is without evidence of gallops, rubs, murmurs, or rales. Initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s electrocardiographic findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, lightheadedness, and an electrocardiogram demonstrating an irregularly irregular fast rhythm without identifiable P-waves. These findings are consistent with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Of the risk factors listed, a history of untreated hypertensive heart disease is the most common underlying risk factor for the development of this arrhythmia.  

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia in clinical practice and results from unpatterned depolarization of atrial tissues caused by multiple micro-reentry circuits. These reentry circuits are most commonly the result of progressive fibrosis and atrial dilation. Electrocardiographically, atrial fibrillation is characterized by irregularly irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves. When rapid ventricular response occurs, with rates >100 beats per minute, diastolic filling and subsequent cardiac output may decrease. These changes result in symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and lightheadedness.  

Atrial fibrillation has multiple etiologies and risk factors, but the most common ones are hypertensive heart disease and coronary artery disease. Other causes include hyperthyroidism, excess alcohol consumption, valvular heart disease, and congestive heart failure.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertensive heart disease :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperthyroidism :
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism is associated with new-onset atrial fibrillation. However, this patient does not have a history consistent with this diagnosis (e.g., presence of goiter, history of Graves disease, history of autoimmune disorders).
❌ Obstructive sleep apnea:
Incorrect: To date, studies are inconclusive regarding the association between obstructive sleep apnea and atrial fibrillation. 
❌ Caffeine consumption:
Incorrect: Caffeine consumption may be associated with certain arrhythmias, such as paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. However, it is not associated with atrial fibrillation.
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism can cause new-onset atrial fibrillation. However, this patient lacks risk factors for pulmonary embolism, such as recent surgery, long distance travel, or active malignancy.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. Per emergency medical services, she was found at home surrounded by several empty bottles of vodka. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder, cirrhosis, and heart failure. Temperature is 35.5°C (96.0°F), pulse is 141/min, respirations are 36/min, blood pressure is 75/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, she is unresponsive and dried blood is observed at the mouth and nares. The patient is jaundiced with clammy and cool extremities. Cardiopulmonary exam is otherwise unremarkable. Electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia. Which of the following best describes the physiological parameters of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of alcohol use disorder and cirrhosis presents with altered mental status and signs of hemodynamic instability. On physical exam, the patient has cold and clammy extremities with dried blood at the mouth and nares, an ominous sign for ongoing hemorrhagic shock due to variceal bleeding. Of the physiologic parameters listed, decreased PCWP, decreased CO, increased SVR, and decreased SvO2 are consistent with hypovolemic shock.  

Hypovolemic shock refers to impaired end-organ perfusion due to decreased intravascular volume. There are two types of hypovolemic shock: hemorrhagic and nonhemorrhagic. Hemorrhagic shock occurs due to blood loss from gastrointestinal bleeding, trauma, postpartum complications, surgical complications, or aneurysmal rupture. Non-hemorrhagic shock occurs due to fluid losses including massive diarrhea, vomiting, or severe burns.  

In either case, decreased circulating intravascular volume leads to decreased venous return, decreased cardiac output, and decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (which is reflective of left atrial pressure). As a compensatory mechanism, heart rate increases and the peripheral vasculature vasoconstricts to shunt blood towards vital organs. Due to this shift in vascular flow, patients develop cold peripheral extremities, pallor, and clammy skin. Additionally, decreased intravascular volume and decreased oxygen carrying capacity decreases the mixed venous oxygen saturation. Treatment includes providing volume replacement: blood in the case of hemorrhage shock and intravenous fluids in the setting of non-hemorrhagic shock.  


Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with cardiogenic shock, which is also a type of “cold shock” that presents with cool and clammy extremities. Unlike hypovolemic shock, cardiogenic shock demonstrates an increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure due to impaired cardiac contractility. Although this patient has a history of heart failure, the physical exam fails to demonstrate evidence of new murmur or pulmonary edema, making cardiogenic shock less likely.
❌ :
Incorrect: These physiologic parameters reflect shock that has been treated with intravenous fluids, blood products, or inotropic medications. This patient has not yet received any treatment.
❌ :
Incorrect: Distributive shock refers to shock from anaphylaxis or sepsis. Unlike hypovolemic shock, distributive shock is a type of “warm shock” (e.g. warm extremities) and presents with a large decrease in systemic vascular resistance due to release of inflammatory mediators.
❌ :
Incorrect: Neurogenic shock falls under the category of “warm shock” and presents clinically after severe head or spinal cord trauma or intracerebral hemorrhage. Autonomic instability ensues, resulting in decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, cardiac output, and systemic vascular resistance.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of fatigue, which began six months ago. He has felt more tired than usual and has had decreased libido over the same time period. The patient attributes these symptoms to recent stress at work as an attorney. Past medical history is noncontributory and he does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse hyperpigmentation of the skin. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Mild testicular atrophy is noted. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  



If untreated, this patient’s condition would most likely give rise to which of the following liver findings?

choices.text: Liver nodule and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels
Iron-deficiency anemia and altered stooling habits
Multiple pulmonary nodules on chest CT scan
Demyelination of the dorsal columns and personality changes

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fatigue, hepatomegaly, hypothyroidism, skin hyperpigmentation, and elevated glucose levels. He likely has underlying hemochromatosis. If untreated, the condition can give rise to hepatocellular carcinoma, which manifests as a liver nodule and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels.  

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the HFE gene that lead to increased iron absorption in the small intestine. Hemochromatosis is mostly asymptomatic early in life, but as toxic levels of iron accumulate in the body, it can become symptomatic, usually between the 3rd and 5th decade of life.  

The various organs that iron deposits in correlate with the clinical features of the disease: pancreatic accumulation leads to diabetes mellitus, dermal deposition results in hyperpigmented and bronze skin, pituitary damage causes decreased libido and testicular atrophy, joint deposition leads to arthralgias, thyroid deposition leads to hypothyroidism, and hepatic deposition results in hepatomegaly with eventual cirrhosis. The risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with hemochromatosis is up to 200 times higher than the general population. In fact, HCC causes nearly 50% of deaths in patients with hemochromatosis. HCC typically presents as weight loss, cachexia, a liver nodule, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Liver nodule and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Iron-deficiency anemia and altered stooling habits:
Incorrect: Iron-deficiency anemia and change in stools can result from a colonic mass (e.g. colon cancer), especially in adults over the age of 50. This patient’s underlying diagnosis, however, is more commonly associated with a different malignancy.
❌ Multiple pulmonary nodules on chest CT scan:
Incorrect: Multiple pulmonary nodules on CT scan could be indicative of a primary lung malignancy or metastases from a different organ. However, this patient does not smoke and has no symptoms of underlying pulmonary disease (e.g., dyspnea, chronic cough, hemoptysis). Instead, his symptoms of skin hyperpigmentation, hyperglycemia, and decreased libido are more concerning for hemochromatosis, which predisposes individuals to hepatocellular carcinoma.
❌ Demyelination of the dorsal columns and personality changes:
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis and cognitive impairment are commonly seen in tertiary syphilis (neurosyphilis). This patient has no risk factors for syphilis, and lacks previous symptoms associated with syphilis, such as a painless ulcer on the genitals (primary syphilis) or maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles (secondary syphilis).
❌ Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of thyroid tissue:
Incorrect: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid tissue can develop in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient has signs and laboratory values consistent with hypothyroidism, his other symptoms (e.g., hyperglycemia, skin hyperpigmentation, testicular atrophy) cannot be fully explained by autoimmune thyroiditis alone.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after a 2-day history of abdominal pain, fever, and altered mental status. He is oriented only to self and is unable to name the city in which he lives or the current year. The patient has a history of chronic alcohol use and was found to have cirrhosis several years ago. His other medical conditions include hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals jaundice and palmar erythema. The abdomen is tense, distended, and tender to palpation. Shifting dullness to percussion is present. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
This patient with alcoholic liver cirrhosis and ascites (e.g., distended abdomen, shifting dullness), is presenting acutely with abdominal pain, fever, and altered mental status. He likely has spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).  

Ascites form due to a combination of portal hypertension, splanchnic vasodilation, and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. These factors contribute to water retention and overflow into the peritoneal cavity. Intestinal Gram-negative flora (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella) are able to translocate through the intestinal wall into the ascitic fluid, thereby causing SBP.  

Diagnosis is established by paracentesis and subsequent examination of the ascitic fluid for white blood cells, especially polymorphonuclear cells (neutrophils). By definition, SBP can be diagnosed when there are >250 PMNs/µL in the ascitic fluid. Treatment is typically with 3rd generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime).  






Option Analysis

✅ Microbial infection of ascitic fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial infection of the meninges:
Incorrect: Meningitis, which is caused by bacterial infection of the meninges, can also result in fever and altered mental status. However, meningitis characteristically causes neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity), along with photophobia, which this patient lacks.
❌ Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A stroke involving the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would present as contralateral paralysis and sensory loss affecting primarily the lower extremities as well as urinary incontinence. Although this patient has the risk factors for stroke (e.g., hypertension, T2DM), he lacks the associated motor deficits.
❌ Inflammation of brain parenchyma:
Incorrect: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain parenchyma, and it typically presents with a prodromal phase of fever, headache, and altered mental status. Acute encephalitis can cause seizures and behavioral changes. However, encephalitis itself would not explain the jaundice, palmar erythema, shifting dullness to percussion, and abdominal tenderness noted on physical examination.
❌ Infection of lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: Pneumonia is due to microbial infection of lung parenchyma, and classically presents with high fevers, cough (usually productive), dyspnea, and altered mental status if severe. This patient lacks a cough, and the presence of a distended, tender abdomen with shifting dullness makes another etiology more likely.

questions.text:
A 37 year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a one-minute generalized tonic clonic seizure. The patient is confused, has difficulty answering questions, and is unable to provide additional history. Past medical records indicate that he has generalized anxiety and major depression managed with fluoxetine. Family history is notable for Addison disease in his mother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Extremities examination shows multiple healing forearm lacerations. Laboratory results are as follows:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   116 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.5 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  0.9 mg/dL 
 Calcium  9.1 mg/dL 
 Glucose  102 mg/dL 
 Serum Osmolarity   245 mOsm/kg 
 Urine Osmolality  406 mOsm/kg 

A urine toxicology is ordered, and results are negative. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the patient's seizure?

choices.text: Salt wasting secondary to inadequate aldosterone release
Inadequate antidiuretic hormone release by the posterior pituitary
Resistance of kidneys to antidiuretic hormone

questions.solution:
This patient is having severe symptomatic hyponatremia (seizure, confusion). He takes fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that can sometimes lead to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) by increasing pituitary ADH secretion as a side effect.

Patients with SIADH usually have increased pituitary or ectopic ADH secretion. A less common cause of SIADH is enhanced stimulation of kidney ADH receptors due to genetic mutations. Excess ADH increases water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules, resulting in fluid retention. The body, in turn, reduces aldosterone production, which increases urinary sodium excretion and helps eliminate some of the excess water. The net result is euvolemic hyponatremia. As a result, SIADH presents with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality. It is crucial to distinguish SIADH from similar conditions (e.g., diabetes insipidus, primary polydipsia) based on laboratory findings. Differences between these conditions are summarized in the table below.  

 

Mild and moderate hyponatremia caused by SIADH can manifest as headaches, nausea/vomiting, and muscle cramps. In cases of severe hyponatremia, patients can also present with confusion, seizures or coma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypotonic fluid overloading:
Incorrect: This answer describes primary polydipsia, a condition caused by abnormally increased thirst that leads to excessive intake of fluids. Though it is often associated with psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia or anxiety disorder, it presents with low serum sodium and low urine osmolality, which is inconsistent with this patient’s laboratory findings.
✅ Inappropriate antidiuretic hormone release:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Salt wasting secondary to inadequate aldosterone release:
Incorrect: Adrenal insufficiency can cause hyponatremia and seizures. This patient’s family history of Addison disease (autoimmune destruction of the adrenal glands) does increase his risk of developing the condition. In addition, patients often become hypovolemic, resulting in an elevated serum osmolality and rise in creatinine. However, while this patient has hyponatremia, his normal creatinine and reduced serum osmolality are suggestive of a euvolemic hyponatremia.
❌ Inadequate antidiuretic hormone release by the posterior pituitary:
Incorrect: Central diabetes insipidus (DI) occurs in patients who are unable to release adequate amount of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), resulting in significant fluid loss via urine. Laboratory findings in central DI are notable for an elevated serum osmolality and reduced urine osmolality. This patient has the exact opposite findings (i.e. reduced serum osmolality and elevated urine osmolality).
❌ Resistance of kidneys to antidiuretic hormone:
Incorrect: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) occurs in patients whose kidneys develop resistance to ADH. The condition is often seen in patients taking lithium or demeclocycline. Laboratory findings in nephrogenic DI are notable for an elevated serum osmolality and reduced urine osmolality. This is inconsistent with the patient’s laboratory findings.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the primary care physician’s office for evaluation of fatigue and muscle weakness for the past 6 months. The patient is a construction worker and reports having difficulty lifting as much as he previously could. Past medical history is notable for asthma managed with albuterol and budesonide inhalers. He consumes 3-4 glasses of beer per week and is sexually active with his spouse. Physical examination reveals 4/5 strength in the shoulders and hips and 5/5 in the rest of the body. The deltoids and quadriceps are tender to palpation. Examination of the patient’s hands reveals the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional cutaneous findings would most likely be observed on the patient’s physical exam?

choices.text: Diffuse lace-like discoloration of the skin
Scale-like papules and plaques on the elbows and knees
Wide reddish-purple streaks on the abdomen
Pruritic eruptions on the body’s skin flexures

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has dermatomyositis. It is an antibody-mediated autoimmune condition characterized by proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings. The four classic skin findings found in patients with dermatomyositis are: Gottron papules, heliotrope rash, shawl and face rash, and mechanic hands.  

 1) A heliotrope rash (Figure 1A) is characterized by a purplish-red discoloration that most often affects the upper eyelids. Periorbital edema is usually present as well. In some cases, the rash can also affect the nose and cheeks.  

2) Gottron papules (Figure 1B) are erythematous macules or patches over extensor surfaces of elbows, knuckles, knees, and ankles. The image in this vignette shows Gottron papules on the patient’s hands.  

3) The  shawl sign (Figure 1C) is a widespread, flat, reddened area that appears on the back, shoulders, and upper chest. Exposure to ultraviolet light can exacerbate the rash. Patients may have concurrent redness of the face.  

4) Mechanic hands (Figure 1D) refers to hyperkeratotic, scaling, and fissuring of the patient’s hands. It most often affects the fingers and palms. The prevalence of this finding amongst patients with dermatomyositis is low. However, it is frequently tested on board exams.  

Figure 1: Cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis

Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons (A, B, C, D)

Option Analysis

❌ Diffuse lace-like discoloration of the skin:
Incorrect: This answer describes livedo reticularis, a condition caused by swelling of the venules secondary to obstruction by clots. Livedo reticularis can be seen in many autoimmune conditions that damage the blood vessels, including polyarteritis nodosa, systemic lupus erythematosus, and dermatomyositis. This patient’s hand findings (Gotrron papules) and proximal weakness are consistent with dermatomyositis. However, the incidence of livedo reticularis is low amongst patients with dermatomyositis.
❌ Scale-like papules and plaques on the elbows and knees :
Incorrect: This answer describes psoriasis, an idiopathic chronic inflammatory condition characterized by increased keratinocyte proliferation. Individuals with psoriasis have silvery plaques found on extensor surfaces. However, individuals with psoriasis would not present with proximal muscle weakness. Moreover, the image of the patient’s hands lacks the silvery plaques that characterize psoriasis.
✅ Purplish discoloration of the eyelids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wide reddish-purple streaks on the abdomen:
Incorrect: Abdominal striae can be seen in patients with hypercortisolism. In patients with chronic hypercortisolism, the skin becomes progressively thinner and can no longer conceal the color of venous blood in the underlying dermis. Chronic hypercortisolism can also cause muscle atrophy and weakness. Although this patient is taking budesonide, inhaled corticosteroids are generally unable to cause systemic hypercortisolism and the manifestation of striae.
❌ Pruritic eruptions on the body’s skin flexures:
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in patients with atopic dermatitis, colloquially known as eczema. The condition most often affects flexural surfaces (e.g., antecubital fossa, popliteal fossa). However, it would be atypical for eczema to cause proximal muscle weakness or the lesions observed on the dorsum of the patient’s hands.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the outpatient provider for evaluation of muscle weakness that began 5 months ago. The patient reports having difficulty at work as a librarian reaching for books on the top shelves. Past medical history is notable for hypertension currently managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 148/91 mmHg, pulse is 64/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination reveals 4/5 strength in the deltoids and quadriceps. Strength is 5/5 in the rest of the body. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal examination are non-contributory. No rashes are found on examination. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Detection of anti-signal recognition particle antibodies
Perimysial infiltration pattern on muscle biopsy
Detection of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient has polymyositis, which presents with proximal muscle weakness in the absence of skin findings. The symptoms of polymyositis overlap with those of the other idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (e.g., dermatomyositis, inclusion body myositis). A combination of the patient’s history, physical examination, and laboratory testing can be used to diagnose patients with polymyositis and distinguish it from similar conditions.  

Definitive diagnosis is based on identifying autoantibodies, like anti-signal recognition particle (anti-SRP), and anti-Jo-1 antibodies. Of note, anti-SRP is most specific for polymyositis whereas anti-Mi-2 is most specific for dermatomyositis. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are non-specific and are often found in patients with either condition. All of the inflammatory myopathies can cause elevated serum levels of muscle enzymes such as aldolase or creatine kinase. Additionally, electromyography can be used to detect regions of dead muscle cells that cause abnormal electrical signals conduction.
