A muscle biopsy will show inflammation, immune cell infiltration, and varying stages of necrosis. Biopsy in a patient with polymyositis will reveal endomysial infiltration by CD8+ T-cells. In contrast, biopsy in a patient with dermatomyositis will reveal perimysial infiltration by CD4+ T-cells. 




Option Analysis

❌ Elevation of serum creatinine kinase:
Incorrect: Increased serum creatinine kinase levels would be expected in pathologies that cause muscle injury. These conditions include trauma, rhabdomyolysis, and autoimmune myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. However, this finding is non-specific and would have limited utility in distinguishing the patient’s condition (polymyositis) from other conditions with a similar presentation.
✅ Detection of anti-signal recognition particle antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Detection of anti-Mi-2 antibodies:
Incorrect: Autoantibodies targeting the Mi-2 nuclear antigen are most specific for dermatomyositis. This condition also presents with proximal muscle weakness. However, dermatomyositis presents with skin findings, whereas this patient's physical examination revealed none.
❌ Perimysial infiltration pattern on muscle biopsy:
Incorrect: A muscle biopsy can be useful in the work-up of dermatomyositis and polymyositis. A perimysial infiltration pattern, where immune cells invade the connective tissue sheath that groups muscle fibers into bundles, is found in patients with dermatomyositis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has polymyositis, which results in endomysial infiltration. 
❌ Detection of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) is found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Patients with rheumatoid arthritis can present with morning stiffness. The condition most often affects distal joints (e.g., metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, wrist, knee). In contrast, it would be atypical for rheumatoid arthritis to present with muscle tenderness and weakness at the shoulders and hips.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to her primary care provider for evaluation of skin patches that are lighter in color than the surrounding skin. Her symptoms began 4-months ago and have progressively worsened. The affected areas are non-painful and non-pruritic. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism, for which she is currently taking metformin and levothyroxine, respectively. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 116/73 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination of the patient’s skin reveals the following:

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Infection of skin by Malassezia furfur
Deposition of disorganized collagen at injury site

questions.solution:
This patient has vitiligo, an acquired condition characterized by the development of irregular patches of depigmented skin. In addition, patients can develop depigmentation of the hair and iris. Vitiligo can be subdivided into non-segmental and segmental vitiligo.

Non-segmental vitiligo tends to affect the extremities (e.g., hands, feet), neck, and head. The lesions are usually symmetrical. Segmental vitiligo tends to affect areas of skin near the spinal cord dorsal roots. The lesions are usually asymmetrical. Both types are caused by the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is associated with other autoimmune disorders, such as type I diabetes mellitus, psoriasis, Graves disease, and Hashimoto thyroiditis.

There are two main treatment approaches. When the affected area is small, cosmetic cover up and topical immune-suppressants can be applied directly to skin. When the affected area is large, systemic immune-suppressants, UV phototherapy, skin-bleaching, and in severe cases, skin grafts, can be tried. Whatever the course of therapy, sunscreen is recommended to prevent darkening of skin areas immediately surrounding the vitiligo lesions and contrasting the depigmentation areas. Moreover, sunscreen can reduce the risk of skin cancer.    

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired melanocyte tyrosinase activity:
Incorrect: Impaired melanocyte tyrosinase activity would hinder melanin production and result in albinism. The condition manifests with diffusely white skin and hair. In contrast, this patient has only patches of hypopigmentation, which is more consistent with vitiligo. Moreover, the symptoms of albinism would be present at birth.  
✅  Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Infection of skin by Malassezia furfur :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes tinea versicolor, which arises secondary to an infection of the skin by the Malassezia fungus. The fungus can degrade lipids, which produces acids that damage melanocytes, ultimately causing hypo- or hyperpigmented lesions. However, skin lesions affected by Malassezia are generally pruritic. 
❌ Deposition of disorganized collagen at injury site:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a keloid, which occurs when there is over-deposition of scar tissue at an injury site. Keloids manifest as firm, rubbery nodules that are elevated from the skin’s surface. In contrast, this patient’s lesions are at the same level as the remaining skin.   
❌ Vasospasm of small vessels :
Incorrect: This answer describes Raynaud phenomenon, which occurs when small blood vessel vasospasms reduces blood supply to the digits. The digits can turn white or blue in color. However, once the inciting trigger has been removed, episodes of Raynaud phenomenon usually resolve within 30-60 minutes. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms have persisted for several months.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl comes to her outpatient provider for a routine visit. The patient has no acute complaints but reports noticing new hyperpigmented lesions on her face. She is currently in high school and is performing well in her classes. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 110/71 mmHg, and pulse is 85/min. Physical examination reveals the following findings:

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

The remainder of the patient’s physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s skin findings?

choices.text: Infection of pores by Cutibacterium acnes

questions.solution:
This patient has ephelides (better known as freckles). It manifests with well-demarcated, light-brown macules that develop in sun exposed skin areas, such as the face, shoulders, and chest. The condition arises since UV-B radiation stimulates melanocytes to increase melanin production. Ephelides are most frequent in individuals with red or blond hair and fair skin.  

It is important to remember that individuals with ephelides have a normal melanocyte count but increased melanin production. In contrast, melanocytic nevi are caused by an increase in the actual number of melanocytes that accumulate in a small area. Moreover, ephelides have no malignant risk, whereas melanocytic nevi bear the risk of progressing to melanoma.  

Diagnosis is clinical, and since the condition has no malignant risk whatsoever, no treatment is necessary. However, for cosmetic reasons, topical depigmentation agents and laser treatment can be used to lighten the lesions.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Infection of pores by Cutibacterium acnes :
Incorrect: This answer describes acne vulgaris, which can manifest with non-inflammatory comedones and inflammatory pustules/nodules. The lesions are often red and painful. In contrast, this patient lacks any of the findings typically seen in acne vulgaris. 
❌ Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes :
Incorrect: Vitiligo is characterized by the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. The condition manifests with irregular patches of hypopigmentation. In contrast, this patient has hyperpigmented lesions on the face.  
❌  Infection of skin by Malassezia furfur :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes tinea versicolor, which arises secondary to an infection of the skin by the Malassezia fungus. The fungus can degrade lipids, which produces acids that damage melanocytes, ultimately causing hypo- or hyperpigmentation. However, Malassezia lesions tend to be pruritic and generally appear on the chest and trunk. 
❌ Benign proliferation of melanocytes :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a melanocytic nevus, which often manifests as a brownish-black lesion that is either flat or elevated. In contrast, this patient has multiple small hyperpigmented lesions that are more consistent with the presentation of ephelides (also termed freckles). The condition is characterized by a normal number of melanocytes but with increased melanin production. 
✅ Overproduction of melanin by melanocytes  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of recurrent bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence for the past several months. The patient has not had any recent illnesses. He recently started training to become a competitive bodybuilder and has been on a diet consisting of mainly protein shakes and yogurts. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient takes only a multivitamin daily. He recently traveled to China to visit his relatives. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds with no tenderness to abdominal palpation. He is administered 50 g of lactose orally. Three hours later, there is an increase in breath hydrogen content. Stool sampling reveals a decreased pH. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Genetically regulated reduction of lactase enzyme activity
Loss of intestinal brush border enzyme due to gastroenteritis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with recurrent bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence after consuming a lactose-heavy diet (e.g., yogurts, protein shakes with milk). He likely has primary lactose intolerance.

Primary lactose intolerance is caused by a decreased expression of the lactase gene and is the most common cause of lactose intolerance. The condition is heavily influenced by many genetic factors, such as race and ethnicity, and it occurs most frequently in Asian and African populations. Less common causes of lactose intolerance include secondary lactose intolerance, which can arise in the setting of inflammatory or infectious damage to the intestines, or congenital lactase deficiency, which is when the lactase enzyme is absent at birth.

Patients with lactose intolerance who continue to eat lactose-containing foods typically develop postprandial bloating, flatulence, and diarrhea (especially prominent in children and adolescents).

The hydrogen breath test can be used in the work-up of lactose intolerance. Hydrogen is produced as a result of bacterial fermentation of the undigested lactose. The hydrogen gets reabsorbed into the blood and subsequently exhaled via the lungs.  



Option Analysis

✅ Genetically regulated reduction of lactase enzyme activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth:
Incorrect: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine can occur due to blind intestinal loops, such as after surgery, or due to motility disorders. The bacteria can deconjugate bile acids, resulting in steatorrhea and malabsorption. However, this patient’s symptoms occurred after he began consuming lactose-heavy foods, which makes an alternative diagnosis more likely.
❌ Congenital lactase deficiency:
Incorrect: Congenital lactase deficiency is a severe gastrointestinal disorder that presents early in infancy with profuse watery diarrhea in infants fed with breast-milk or lactose-containing formula supplements. This patient is presenting at a much older age, which makes congenital lactase deficiency highly unlikely.
❌ Developmental lactose malabsorption:
Incorrect: Developmental lactose malabsorption occurs in premature (<34 weeks gestation) infants, and generally improves as the intestinal mucosa matures. This patient is presenting at a much older age, which makes this etiology an unlikely cause of his lactose malabsorption.
❌ Loss of intestinal brush border enzyme due to gastroenteritis:
Incorrect: Secondary (acquired) lactose malabsorption can occur in individuals who have underlying small bowel pathology (e.g. celiac disease) or recent gastroenteritis, which causes damage to the intestinal mucosa. This damage results in loss of the lactase enzyme, which is normally present in the intestinal microvilli. However, this patient has had no preceding infection, making this etiology an unlikely cause of his lactose malabsorption.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old female comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue and “diffuse pain in the bones.” Her symptoms started three months ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for asthma and two kidney stones over the past three years, both of which passed spontaneously. She is uses an albuterol inhaler. Family history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis in her mother. The patient's vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam reveals intact strength and sensation in all extremities. Laboratory testing is ordered, and the results are as follows:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum sodium  140 mEq/L 
 Serum potassium  4.5 mEq/L 
 Serum calcium  11.8 mg/dL 
 Serum phosphorus  2.5 mg/dL 

 Which of the following changes in bone structure would most likely be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Elevation of periosteum from the bone surface

questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, diffuse bone pain and history of kidney stones, together with laboratory evidence of hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia, most likely has primary hyperparathyroidism, which occurs when parathyroid hormone is produced independent of the serum calcium level. It is most often due to parathyroid adenomas and less commonly due to parathyroid hyperplasia. The autonomous production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes:

  •  Increased calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract 
  •  Increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys 
  •  Enhanced subperiosteal bone resorption and calcium release from the bones  
  •  Increased secretion of phosphate in the kidneys 
The clinical findings of primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered as “stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric overtones.” “Stones” is for calcium-based kidney stones or gallstones that can be formed. “Bones” is for diffuse bone pain that results after chronic hormone-driven demineralization. “Groans” is for constipation and muscle weakness, both of which are partly due to decreased muscle contractions. Finally, “psychiatric overtones” refers to symptoms like depressed mood, cognitive dysfunction and psychosis.

Diagnosis is based on serum PTH, calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D levels to confirm the type of hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option Analysis

❌  Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone deposition :
Incorrect: A bone biopsy performed in a patient with osteopetrosis will show deposition of lamellar bone in a mosaic pattern. Osteopetrosis is caused by defective bone resorption by osteoclasts, which leads to the creation of thick but disorganized bone. The bone is weak and prone to fracture. Serum calcium and phosphorous levels are normal in patients with osteopetrosis. 
✅  Subperiosteal bone resorption :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Elevation of periosteum from the bone surface:
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in conditions such as osteosarcoma due to rapid bone deposition. Osteosarcoma generally presents with localized pain at the site of the tumor, whereas this patient has diffuse pain. Moreover, osteosarcoma would not explain the hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia observed in this patient. 
❌ Joint space narrowing:
Incorrect: Joint space narrowing would be observed in patients with osteoarthritis. This condition presents with joint pain that worsens with movement and improves with rest. Osteoarthritis would not explain the hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia observed in this patient. 
❌  Ulnar deviation of the bilateral wrists :
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The condition presents with joint pain that is usually worse in the morning and improves with use. The patient's family history places her at increased risk of developing this condition. However, rheumatoid arthritis most often affects the distal joints and would not present with the generalized pain experienced by this patient. Moreover, serum calcium and phosphate levels are normal in rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents because of poor growth. The patient was born at 38-weeks gestational age via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient is exclusively breast fed, does not consume formula, and spends most of her time indoors. Past medical history is notable for a viral upper respiratory tract infection at 7-months-old. Family history is notable for Celiac disease in her older brother. The patient is below the 10th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination reveals bowing of the legs. Skeletal imaging is ordered, and results similar to those shown below are found:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has rickets, a condition characterized by inadequate mineralization of the cartilaginous growth plates in children. A similar condition is osteomalacia, which describes inadequate bone mineralization in adults. Both conditions can be due to a deficiency or impaired metabolism of vitamin D, phosphate, or calcium. Of note, breast milk contains low vitamin D levels, and exclusively breast-fed children are at risk of developing vitamin D deficiency. When these elements are missing, osteoblasts do not have enough calcium and phosphate to deposit into the organic matrix.

In children, since the growth plates have not closed, this leads to cartilaginous growth plates, impaired growth of bones, and bone malformations. In adults, where the epiphyseal plates have already closed, it only causes defective mineralization of osteoid, resulting in weak bones that are fracture-prone.

Both conditions can cause diffuse bone and joint pain, proximal muscle weakness, and increased risk of fragility fractures. Rickets-specific symptoms include thin and soft skull bones (termed craniotabes), delayed fontanelle closure, and bow legs (also termed genu varum). Additionally, the rachitic rosary pattern (see Figure 1) can be seen. This term describes the little bumps that appear along the chest wall due to widening of the junction between the ribs and costal cartilage in front of the rib cage.

 Figure 1: Rachitic rosary sign in patient with rickets 




Option Analysis

✅ Inadequate dietary vitamin D intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Impaired absorption of fat-soluble vitamins:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis can cause fat malabsorption and result in a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins. The condition can present with steatorrhea and recurrent pulmonary infections. However, the patient in this vignette does not have steatorrhea and only has an isolated instance of respiratory tract infection.
❌ Reduced bone resorption by osteoclasts:
Incorrect: This answer describes osteopetrosis. It can present with symptoms including cranial nerve impingement, pathological fractures, pancytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly. Radiographic imaging will reveal diffuse sclerosis. In contrast, osteopetrosis will not present with the ‘rachitic rosary’ sign found in this patient’s x-ray.
❌ Gluten-related autoimmune intestinal damage:
Incorrect: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by intestinal hypersensitivity to gluten, which is a protein found in grains. However, this patient is exclusively breast-fed and is not consuming any grain products.
❌ Congenital defect impairing chondrocyte proliferation:
Incorrect: This answer describes achondroplasia. The condition can present with short stature. However, it will not present with the ‘rachitic rosary’ pattern noted on this patient’s x-ray.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle injury. The patient was the restrained passenger in a stationary vehicle as he was rear-ended by another vehicle traveling approximately 80 miles per hour. The patient’s neck was hyperflexed during the collision and now feels stiff. He is unable to move his arms or legs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 9/min, blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Neurological exam is notable for bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation as well as bilateral loss of motor function below C6. Sensation to soft touch and vibration is unaffected. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient sustained a hyperflexion injury to his neck after a high speed motor vehicle accident. His neurologic exam is notable for bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the C6 level. Together, these findings are concerning for anterior spinal artery occlusion.  

Anterior spinal artery occlusion has numerous causes including emboli, mass effect from tumors, hematoma, traumatic dissection injury, and aortic aneurysm repair. The anterior spinal artery does not have substantial collateral flow and is thus very susceptible to ischemia, especially below the T8 level.      

Damage to the artery results in ischemia to the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, which houses the descending corticospinal tract, ascending spinothalamic tract, as well as autonomic fibers. Clinically, this ischemia manifests with bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the level of the lesion. In contrast, the dorsal columns are unaffected and hence, proprioception and vibration sense are preserved. Other associated symptoms include anal sphincter dysfunction, urinary retention, and blood pressure lability due to autonomic dysfunction.    


Option Analysis

✅  Anterior cord syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Central cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome more commonly occurs due to a forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities. In contrast, both the upper and lower extremities are equally affected in this patient. 
❌ Brown-Sequard syndrome:
Incorrect: Brown-Sequard syndrome refers to hemisection of the spinal cord that usually occurs due to a penetrating injury to the spine. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception, as well as contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. 
❌  Cauda equina syndrome :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from the compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia. The condition would not manifest with complete paralysis and loss of temperature and pain sensation below the C6 level. 
❌ Subfalcine herniation:
Incorrect: Subfalcine herniation occurs when brain tissue herniates under the falx cerebri, resulting in compression of the anterior cerebral artery. This compression leads to infarction of the medial frontal and parietal lobes, which can manifest with contralateral lower extremity weakness.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. His symptoms are most prominent in the hands, worse in the morning, and gradually improve with activity. In addition, the patient endorses malaise in spite of getting more than eight-hours of rest each evening. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 147/83 mmHg, and pulse is 71/min. Physical examination reveals the following findings in the right hand:



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Similar findings are also noted in the left hand. Which of the following additional findings will be most likely present on this patient’s physical exam?

choices.text: Silver scale-like plaques on the skin
Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine
Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints
Purulent drainage from the knee joint

questions.solution:
This patient has swan-neck deformities in the hands, malaise, and fever. His presentation is most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune condition resulting in joint destruction. As rheumatoid arthritis progresses, it can cause several joint deformities. Five notable deformities are:

1) The swan-neck deformity occurs when the distal interphalangeal joint of the affected finger is in flexion, whereas the proximal interphalangeal joint is in hyperextension.    

2) The Boutonniere deformity occurs when the proximal interphalangeal joint is in flexion, and the distal interphalangeal joint is in hyperextension.    

3) Ulnar drift occurs if the metacarpophalangeal joints are severely affected. In this condition, the fingers lean away from the thumb and toward the pinky.    

4) The Z-deformity occurs where the thumb flexes at the metacarpophalangeal joint and hyperextends at the interphalangeal joint. This finding is also termed the “hitchhiker thumb deformity.”   

5) The claw toe deformity occurs where the metatarsophalangeal joint is hyperextended, while the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints are flexed. This causes the affected toes to look like bird claws.


Option Analysis

❌ Silver scale-like plaques on the skin:
Incorrect: Patients with psoriatic arthritis will have both joint pain and skin psoriasis. Psoriatic arthritis typically presents with asymmetrical joint involvement. In contrast, this patient has symmetrical findings. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not typically cause the swan-neck deformity seen in this patient.
❌ Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in ankylosing spondylitis, a chronic inflammatory disease of the axial skeleton. The condition most often affects young males and presents with stiffness in the neck and back. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to either present in an elderly male or to not cause axial skeleton symptoms.
✅ Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Purulent drainage from the knee joint  :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis can cause fever and purulent drainage. However, this patient’s history of joint pain that improves with movement and presence of swan-neck deformities are more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis would not cause pus accumulation within affected joints.
❌ Inflammation of the conjunctiva:
Incorrect: Patients with reactive migratory arthritis classically present with joint pain, conjunctivitis, and urethritis. Reactive arthritis typically occurs after an infection. In contrast, this patient has no history of recent infection or migrating joint pain.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of joint pain that began half-a-year ago. The pain is most prominent in the left knee and right index distal interphalangeal joint. The symptoms worsen with physical activity and improve with rest. The patient is a retired construction worker. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are noncontributory. Examination of the affected knee reveals reduced range of motion. A fine gritting sound is heard on passive flexion and extension of the left knee. No erythema or warmth is noted at the joint. Examination of the patient’s fingers reveals the following:




Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

 A comprehensive musculoskeletal examination is subsequently performed. Which of the following additional joints will most likely reveal abnormal findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has pain in a weight-bearing joint that is exacerbated by activity and improves with rest. These symptoms, in combination with the physical examination finding of a Heberden node at the right index finger, are most consistent with osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage and underlying bone.

Osteoarthritis most often affects weight-bearing joints (e.g., ankle, knee, hip). Osteoarthritis can also affect the hands and manifest with pain in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints due to their high frequency of use. Unlike rheumatoid arthritis, the metacarpophalangeal are rarely affected in osteoarthritis.

Overtime, articular damage will cause a hypertrophic reaction that leads to new bone formation at the joint margins called osteophytes. If the osteophyte manifests as a subcutaneous nodule at the distal interphalangeal joint, it is called a Heberden node (blue arrows). In contrast, if the subcutaneous nodule is at the proximal interphalangeal joint, it is called a Bouchard node (yellow arrow).





Option Analysis

❌ Sacroiliac joint  :
Incorrect: The sacroiliac joint is frequently affected in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. The condition most often affects young men and manifests with limited spinal mobility, as well as morning stiffness that improves with activity. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to manifest in an older male.  
❌ Metacarpophalangeal joint:
Incorrect: The metacarpophalangeal joints are often affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis manifests with symmetrical joint pain and stiffness that worsens with rest and improves with activity. In contrast, this patient’s joint symptoms are asymmetrical and exacerbated by activity.
❌ Wrist joint:
Incorrect: The wrist joints are often affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with symmetrical joint pain/stiffness that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient’s joint pain is asymmetrical and worsens with activity. Moreover, rheumatoid arthritis would not account for the Heberden nodule (subcutaneous nodule at the distal interphalangeal joint) found at the right index finger.
✅ Hip joint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ First metatarsophalangeal joint:
Incorrect: The first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe) is often affected in gout, which is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joint. The condition causes acute-onset pain that subsequently self-resolves within a few days to few weeks. In contrast, gout would not cause pain that persists for several months.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of left-sided weakness and slurred speech that began three hours ago. She is currently taking oral contraceptives. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has a 8 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 127/81 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Physical examination shows motor strength of ⅗ on the left side. Cardiac exam reveals a systolic murmur loudest at the left upper sternal border and fixed-splitting of the S2 heart sound. Extremity examination reveals swelling and erythema in the right calf. MRI of the brain shows signs of an ischemic infarction. Which of the following best explains the finding observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of smoking, obesity and use of oral contraceptive pills is presenting with swelling and erythema in the right calf. These findings are consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Moreover, she most likely has an atrial septal defect (ASD), given the examination finding of a fixed split S2 heart sound. The clot likely travelled to the right atrium and passed through the defect into the arterial circulation, ending up in cerebral vasculature, causing a stroke. This phenomenon is termed paradoxical embolism, which is a known complication of ASD.  

A similar cardiac condition is patent foramen ovale (PFO), which occurs when the septum primum and septum secundum fail to fuse after birth. This can result in transient right-to-left shunting of blood with straining or coughing. However, a PFO would not present with the fixed-split S2 heart sound found in ASD.  

Both conditions can cause paradoxical embolus because instead of going from the right atrium to the right ventricle and to the lungs, the embolus can pass through the defect into the left atrium and, eventually, into the systemic circulation.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Factor V Leiden deficiency :
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden, the most common cause of inherited hypercoagulability, can predispose patients to develop a DVT. However, the fact that an embolus from this patient’s DVT travelled to the brain as opposed to the lungs raises concerns for a paradoxical embolism. An ASD would explain the paradoxical embolism with these cardiac examination findings.  
❌ Patent foramen ovale :
Incorrect: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) can cause a paradoxical embolus. It can cause transient right-to-left shunting of blood during straining or coughing. However, a PFO would not result in the constant left-to-right shunting that is needed to produce a fixed-split S2 heart sound. Hence, an ASD is a more likely explanation.  
❌ Ventricular septal defect :
Incorrect: A ventricular septal defect (VSD) can result in a paradoxical embolus. However, it usually causes a holosystolic murmur loudest at the left lower sternal border with or without a thrill. 
✅ Atrial septal defect :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Carotid artery stenosis :
Incorrect: Carotid artery stenosis is caused by atherosclerotic plaque deposition. If a portion of the plaque breaks off, it can travel to the brain and result in a stroke. However, this patient has a DVT and cardiac murmur, which are more consistent with the presentation of a paradoxical embolus.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of excessive fatigue and weight loss over the past 3 months. Menses occur every 28 days without heavy flow or severe pain. The patient’s mother died of endometrial cancer at the age of 48. Vital signs in the office include temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse of 98/min, respirations of 14/min, and blood pressure of 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. Rectal examination is notable for guaiac-positive brown stool. Hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, and mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. Colonoscopy shows a mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the resected mass reveals adenocarcinoma, and further genetic testing reveals a mutation in the MLH1 gene. This patient’s cancer is most likely due to a primary defect in which of the following cellular processes?

choices.text: DNA repair in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with gastrointestinal bleeding and is shown to have adenocarcinoma of the colon. Taking into account her mother’s history of endometrial cancer at a young age, as well as genetic testing revealing a mutation in the MLH1 gene, this patient likely has hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC, also termed Lynch syndrome, is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in one of four DNA mismatch repair genes: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, or PMS2. These mutations cause subsequent DNA mismatches to occur in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences (microsatellites), resulting in microsatellite instability. Microsatellite instability likely affects genes that control cell growth, and accumulation of mutations drives the process of carcinogenesis.    

Colon cancer in patients with Lynch syndrome is usually right-sided and occurs in adults under 50 years of age. Right-sided colon cancers grow as exophytic masses but do not typically cause colon obstruction because the right-sided colon has a larger diameter than the left. Instead, right-sided tumors tend to cause chronic bleeding, eventually causing iron-deficiency anemia. Lynch syndrome is also associated with extraintestinal malignancies, such as endometrial, ovarian, stomach, and skin cancers.
 

Option Analysis

✅ DNA repair in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleotide excision repair:
Incorrect: Defects in nucleotide excision repair (NER) are seen in xeroderma pigmentosum, wherein there is an inability to repair pyrimidine dimers formed by UV exposure. Patients typically present with photosensitivity and UV radiation-induced skin cancers.
❌ Homologous recombination DNA repair system:
Incorrect: BRCA1 and BRCA2 are genes involved in homologous DNA repair. Mutations in these genes can predispose patients to developing breast and ovarian cancers. Colon cancers and endometrial cancers, as seen in this patient and her mother, are much less commonly associated with BRCA mutations. 
❌ Degradation of β-catenin :
Incorrect: The APC gene encodes a cytoplasmic protein responsible for promoting the degradation of β-catenin. Mutation in the APC gene results in the development of hundreds of adenomatous polyps. This patient’s colonoscopy revealed just one colonic mass. Moreover, genetic testing revealed a mutation in the MLH1 gene, which suggests a different underlying condition.
❌ Nonhomologous recombination DNA repair system:
Incorrect: Ataxia telangiectasia is a disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene, which is involved in nonhomologous DNA repair. Patients typically present at a very young age (typically before the age of 5) with ataxia, telangiectasias in the eyes and skin, as well as recurrent infections.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man goes to his primary care physician for evaluation of hearing loss. The patient has had progressive bilateral hearing loss for several months, with hearing in the right ear worse than that of the left. He recalls, “I knew something was wrong when I was at a dinner party last week and could not hear my conversation over the other patrons.” He currently works as a band manager for a group of local rock musicians. On physical exam, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 151/83 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. An otoscopic examination is performed and demonstrates the following (with similar findings on the contralateral side):



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 

A tuning fork is struck and placed on the patient's forehead, and the patient reports localization of sound to the left ear. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient's clinical condition?

choices.text: Chronic mechanical damage to stereociliated cells in the organ of Corti
Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes
Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient has asymmetric hearing loss, a normal tympanic membrane, and Weber test consistent with sensorineural hearing loss. Given the patient’s history and occupation, his presentation is consistent with noise-induced hearing loss.

Noise-induced hearing loss is caused by mechanical trauma to stereociliated cells within the cochlea. When the ear is exposed to excessively loud sounds over a prolonged period of time, overstimulation of the inner ear structures results in production of reactive oxygen species, which leads to oxidative cell death. It most commonly occurs in patients with chronic, hazardous sound exposures (e.g., musicians, construction workers).

Clinically, this disorder presents with progressive high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The hearing loss can be symmetrical or asymmetrical, wherein hearing loss in one ear is more severe than that of the other. Less common associated symptoms include tinnitus or episodic vertigo.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic mechanical damage to stereociliated cells in the organ of Corti:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes:
Incorrect: Otosclerosis is characterized by bony remodeling and overgrowth of the middle ear ossicles. The footplate of the stapes is most commonly affected. The condition presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss. In contrast, this patient’s Weber test finding (i.e. localization to the ear with more mild hearing loss) suggests sensorineural hearing loss.
❌ Traumatic tympanic membrane perforation:
Incorrect: Tympanic membrane perforation may occur in individuals exposed to loud noises (e.g., gunshots, bomb explosions). However, this patient’s tympanic membrane is intact without evidence of perforation.
❌ Impaired reabsorption of endolymphatic fluid:
Incorrect: Meniere disease is characterized by impaired reabsorption and accumulation of endolymphatic fluid within the cochlea and vestibular organs.  The condition typically presents with episodes of unilateral hearing loss associated with tinnitus and vertigo.
❌ Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of presbycusis. Presbycusis is an age-related condition characterized by bilateral, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Symptoms of presbycusis generally become noticeable around the age of 60, whereas this patient is only in his 40s.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of muscle weakness and headaches for the past 2 months. He is a construction worker and has found it difficult to lift large objects during the job. The patient has no significant past medical history, but he states his blood pressure was “high” at a recent health fair. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Serum 
 Sodium   147 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.9 mEq/L 
 Chloride   105 mEq/L 
 HCO3-  32 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.6 mg/dL 
 Glucose  94 mg/dL 

Serum renin levels are decreased. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Tumor in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex
Tumor in the medulla of the adrenal gland
Tumor in the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with recurrent headaches, muscle weakness, and hypertension. Laboratory testing reveals a reduced renin level as well as hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. He likely has Conn syndrome (or primary aldosteronism) due to an aldosterone-secreting tumor in the zona glomerulosa.

Physiologically, aldosterone increases the activity of sodium/potassium ATPase ion pumps on the surface of cells lining the distal tubules and collecting ducts of the kidney. The result is increased sodium and water reabsorption as well as increased potassium and hydrogen excretion through urine. Thus, hyperaldosteronism can be diagnosed by observing low serum potassium levels, elevated aldosterone levels, and low plasma renin activity, and elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Of note, the aldosterone-to-renin ratio is the most sensitive screening test for primary aldosteronism. Serum sodium can be mildly elevated or normal due to the aldosterone “escape mechanism.”

Once primary aldosteronism is confirmed, an abdominal CT or MRI scan is needed to confirm and locate the aldosterone-producing tumor. Some cases may be treated by surgically resecting the tumor. In cases of bilateral tumors, treatment typically consists of administering aldosterone antagonists, such as spironolactone or eplerenone.



Option Analysis

✅ Tumor in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tumor in the medulla of the adrenal gland:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor that originates from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla, can also cause headaches and hypertension. However, this patient’s hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis cannot be explained by pheochromocytoma alone.
❌ Atherosclerosis of the renal artery:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis, which is usually due to atherosclerosis, can result in activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The condition would cause hypokalemia and hypertension, as seen in this patient. However, renin levels would be elevated, not decreased, in patients with renal artery stenosis. Additionally, physical examination would reveal an abdominal bruit that can usually be heard over the flank.
❌ Tumor in the anterior pituitary:
Incorrect: Pituitary overproduction of ACTH can result in Cushing syndrome, which can also present with hypokalemia and hypertension. However, Cushing syndrome causes significant physical alterations, such as weight gain (e.g., central obesity, moon facies, buffalo hump), bruisable skin, and hyperglycemia; none of these findings are seen in this patient.
❌ Tumor in the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex:
Incorrect: The zona fasciculata is responsible for cortisol production. Therefore, a tumor in this region of the adrenal cortex would present with hypercortisolism, weakness, and hypertension. However, Cushing syndrome also causes significant physical alterations, such as weight gain (e.g., central obesity, moon facies, buffalo hump), bruisable skin, and hyperglycemia; none of these findings are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by emergency medical services after being found face down on the sidewalk. The patient has a temperature of 36°C (96.8°F), pulse of 62/min and regular, blood pressure of 102/72 mmHg and respiratory rate of 7/min, and O2 saturation of 75% on room air. He is stuporous, and pupils are pinpoint. He is subsequently given naloxone. Repeat vital signs are temperature of 36°C (96.8°F), pulse of 72/min, blood pressure of 107/71 mmHg and respiratory rate of 14/min, and O2 saturation of 95% on room air. The patient remains stuporous following administration of this medication. The patient is subsequently intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit, and an MRI of the head reveals the following image:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Thrombi originating in the left atrium

questions.solution:
Hypoxic stroke, aka hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, or global cerebral ischemia, develops in the setting of systemic hypoperfusion or hypoxemia. This type of stroke commonly occurs during cardiac arrest, shock states, prolonged hypoventilation due to drug overdose, drowning, or during invasive procedures with significant blood loss. The pattern of injury observed with this type of stroke often includes watershed infarctions, since the areas of the brain most susceptible to ischemic injury exist at the border of blood supply between two separate cerebral arteries. As blood flows through the vessels of the brain, tissue proximal to the circulation extracts oxygen and nutrients from the blood, leaving little to no oxygen or nutrients for tissue most distal to large collateral vascular supplies. As a result, these “watershed areas'' become ischemic, with subsequent tissue damage.  The three primary watershed areas include:

  •  The area between the anterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries 
  •  The area between the posterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries 
  •  The area between the external and internal branches of the middle cerebral arteries 
MRI imaging following a watershed infarction typically reveals a linear rosary-like pattern at the aforementioned anatomic locations. This patient’s MRI demonstrates multiple left subcortical infractions located at the border zone of MCA/ACA and MCA/PCA.


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Option Analysis

❌ Middle meningeal artery tear:
Incorrect: Trauma to the middle meningeal artery may cause an epidural hematoma. Patients with epidural hematomas present with loss of consciousness following head trauma, with a lucid interval, followed by progressive decline in mental status. Head imaging typically reveals a biconvex, hyperdense lesion.
✅ Prolonged cerebral hypoperfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rupture of bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of  bridging veins refers to the etiology of subdural hematomas, which is more commonly observed in patients with fragile vasculature (e.g., infants, elderly patients). Head imaging demonstrates crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhages.
❌ Small-vessel lipohyalinosis:
Incorrect: Lacunar strokes are commonly precipitated by conditions causing arterial damage (e.g., hypertension, diabetes). This young patient is unlikely to have suffered a lacunar stroke, as his brain imaging suggests a different etiology.
❌ Thrombi originating in the left atrium:
Incorrect: Embolic strokes often occur in the setting of uncontrolled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. This patient’s pulse is regular.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to vulvar itching over the past few months. The patient reports experiencing an irritating itch that often awakens her at night. She has tried multiple lotions without relief. Medical history is remarkable for atopic dermatitis, which has been effectively managed with a steroid cream. The patient does not have any burning sensation during urination, dyschezia, or dyspareunia. The patient has no history of sexually transmitted diseases and is in a monogamous relationship with her partner. The patient’s temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Physical examination of the vulva reveals a thick, leathery lesion covering most of the left labia majora. A close up of the lesion is shown below:

Retrieved from: Wikimedia

 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has intense pruritus and a thick, leather-like lesion isolated to the labia majora, which is consistent with the diagnosis of lichen simplex chronicus.    

Lichen simplex chronicus is a skin condition caused by long-standing scratching, which results in epithelial thickening and hyperkeratosis. The exact pathogenesis is not well understood, but it is hypothesized that chronic stimulation of the cutaneous nerve results in nerve dysfunction, which accentuates the “itch-scratch” cycle. It may arise secondary to other conditions, specifically atopic dermatitis. Patients typically present with extremely pruritic, leathery, thick skin and enhanced skin markings. These lesions are common on the neck, genitals, or dorsum of the foot.    

In contrast to lichen sclerosis, lichen simplex chronicus does not increase the risk of cancer. Diagnosis is usually done clinically but a biopsy may be done to exclude other conditions. Treatment focuses on halting the itch-scratch cycle and involves topical and intralesional corticosteroids. 

Option Analysis

❌ Extramammary Paget disease:
Incorrect: Paget disease of the vulva is an intraepithelial adenocarcinoma seen usually in patients > 60 years of age. Similar to Paget disease of the breast, the lesion is eczematous-like, well-demarcated, and has raised edges. Gross examination will reveal an erythematous background dotted with pale islands. Pruritus is the most common symptom. In contrast, this patient’s lesion is thickened, white, and leathery, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Lichen sclerosis:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosis is a benign, chronic dermatologic disorder typified by inflammation, epithelial thinning, and dermal changes. It is often seen in prepubertal girls and peri/postmenopausal women and is associated with a low estrogen state. Patients often present with vulvar pruritus, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesion manifests as porcelain-white, thin paper-like plaques. This patient’s lesion is instead thickened, while lichen sclerosis leads to thinning of the skin. Also, other than pruritus, the patient is not experiencing any other symptom associated with lichen sclerosis.  
❌ Vitiligo:
Incorrect: Vitiligo is an acquired pigmentation disorder characterized by irregular patches of complete depigmentation due to destruction of melanocytes. It is believed to be an autoimmune condition and often accompanies other autoimmune conditions. Although lesions may appear anywhere on the body, they are asymptomatic and would not cause pruritus.  
✅ Lichen simplex chronicus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratoses are benign epidermal tumors arising from the proliferation of immature keratinocytes. The condition is often seen in individuals > 50 years of age. The lesions are flat, well-demarcated, greasy, and often described as having a “stuck on” appearance. Lesions occur on the head, trunk, and extremities. It would be atypical for seborrheic keratoses to manifest in the vulva.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to vaginal pruritus and eczema over the past month. She has tried multiple creams, including corticosteroids, with no relief. She is generally healthy and does not smoke or use alcohol. There is no history of sexually transmitted diseases or abnormal Pap smears. The patient has had 3-lifetime sexual partners and is currently in a monogamous relationship with her partner of 35 years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 142/86 mmHg.  Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated, eczematous lesion with raised edges that covers most of the left labia majora. A biopsy is obtained and shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an eczematous-like rash on the vulva which did not respond to topical creams, and the biopsy results show tumor cells with clear cytoplasm (clear halo) infiltrating the epidermis, a classic picture of Paget disease. Paget cells stain positive for mucin on Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) staining.    

Paget disease refers to the intraepidermal proliferation of epithelial cells in the skin of the nipple or the vulva. While virtually all cases of Paget disease of the nipple are associated with an underlying adenocarcinoma, only a minority of cases of extramammary Paget disease have an underlying tumor. Instead, Paget cells in the vulva commonly arise from proliferation of epidermal progenitor cells. The lesions of Paget disease usually appear as red, scaly, crusted plaque that may mimic the appearance of eczema, but the lack of response to steroids distinguishes the lesions from eczema.  

Option Analysis

❌ Low-estrogen physiologic states:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosis is a benign skin condition seen in prepubertal girls and peri/postmenopausal women. It is associated with low estrogen state, genetic factors, infections, and immunologic abnormalities. Patients often present with vulvar pruritus, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesion manifests as porcelain-white, thin paper-like plaques. Treatment includes topical corticosteroid cream. The condition predisposes to vulvar cancer, and a biopsy is recommended to rule-out malignancy. This patient’s histological findings suggest a different diagnosis. 
❌  Hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: Lichen simplex chronicus refers to thickening and hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium as a result of chronic scratching and irritation. Patients often present with pruritic, leathery, thick skin and enhanced skin markings on the vulva. It is not associated with an increased risk of cancer.  
❌ Infection with oncogenic virus:
Incorrect: Infection by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 16,18, and 33 is associated with increased risk for developing vaginal and vulvar cancer. The lesions are usually warty or Bowenoid type, multifocal, and tend to be poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinomas. However, this patient’s histology is consistent with extramammary Paget disease, which is not associated with HPV infection.  
✅ Proliferation of epidermal progenitor cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Proliferation of malignant basal cells:
Incorrect: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin cancer and is usually found in sun-exposed areas. The lesions are usually pink, waxy, and occasionally exhibit pearly nodules and telangiectasias. On histology, basal cell tumors show a “palisading” pattern.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic due to fever, weight loss and weakness in his right foot and left hand for the past 2 months. During this period, he lost 4.5-kg (10-lb) without intention or changes in his diet. He has no jaw pain, change in vision, or headaches. He last visited his primary care physician more than 10 years ago, and his medical history is significant for IV drug use in his 20s. He no longer uses illicit drugs and does not smoke cigarettes. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4° F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows high-stepping gait when the patient lifts the right foot and decreased strength in the extensors of the left hand. There is no pain with palpation of the scalp. Cardiopulmonary exam shows no abnormalities. Skin examination shows purpura. Laboratory studies show the following:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Leukocyte count  15,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  70 mm/h 
 C-reactive protein concentrations  30 mg/dL (N=0.08–3.1) 
 Serum 
 Hepatitis B surface antigen  Positive 
 Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies   Negative 
 Urine  
 Protein  2+ 
 Erythrocytes  5-7/hpf 
 Creatinine  2.5 mg/dL 
 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with constitutional symptoms, renal involvement, mononeuritis multiplex, and positive serology for hepatitis B infection most likely has polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).  

PAN is medium-vessel vasculitis typically seen in middle-aged men that is often associated with hepatitis B/C and hairy cell leukemia. Biopsy of the affected arteries will show transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with fibrinoid necrosis. The absence of perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA), no evidence of pulmonary involvement, and the positive serology for hepatitis B helps to narrow the diagnosis.  




Option Analysis

❌ Temporal arteritis:
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients are usually above the age of 50. Moreover, patients often present with a history of scalp/temporal pain, headaches, and jaw claudication. Temporal arteritis is often associated with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), which can present with proximal muscle pain and stiffness. 
❌ Microscopic polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Microscopic polyangiitis (MP) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP), skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, and neurologic deficits. However, ear, nose, and throat manifestations are commonly seen, and perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) is positive in the majority of the cases.  
✅ Polyarteritis nodosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) may also present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP), skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, and neurologic deficits. However, it is most often seen in atopic patients with a history of allergies or asthma. Additionally, perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) is positive in the majority of the cases. 
❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP), skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, and neurologic deficits. However, ear, nose, and throat manifestations are commonly seen, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA) is positive in the majority of the cases.  
❌ Thromboangiitis obliterans:
Incorrect: Thromboangiitis obliterans is an inflammatory disease affecting small- to medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities. It typically affects men who smoke and presents with distal signs of ischemia, ulcerations and Raynaud phenomenon. This patient does not smoke, and his presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing over the past two days. His past medical history is significant for chronic liver disease secondary to chronic alcohol use disorder. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal distention with shifting dullness. Serum creatinine concentration is 1.5 mg/dL, and serum urea nitrogen concentration is 20 mg/dL. The patient is started on furosemide, and his condition quickly improves. Three days later, repeated laboratory studies show the following:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Sodium  132 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride  95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.9 mg/dL 
 Albumin  3.2 g/dL 
 BUN/Cr  > 20 
 Urine 
 Erythrocytes  0/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)  <1% 
 Urine osmolality  600 mOsm/kg 
 Sediment  None 
 
 Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with difficulty breathing most likely due to volume overload secondary to ascites from decompensated chronic liver disease. This diagnosis is supported by the fact that treatment with furosemide improves his condition. However, laboratory results a few days later show a rising creatinine, a low fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% and a high urine osmolality of 600 mOsm/kg, which is consistent with prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) from volume depletion from the furosemide therapy.      

AKI can be divided into categories based on where the problem has occurred: prerenal AKI (e.g., bleeding, volume depletion, sepsis), intrarenal AKI (e.g., acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis, or interstitial nephritis) or post-renal AKI (e.g., BPH, stones, malignancy). To establish the cause of renal injury, it is essential to assess the urine osmolality, urine sodium, FENa, and the serum BUN/Cr.    

In prerenal AKI, the kidney detects reduced blood flow. In an attempt to conserve the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), the kidney reabsorbs more sodium (leading to a FeNa<1%) and urea. Creatinine, however, is not reabsorbed, and thus BUN/Cr ratio is >20. Because the kidney is absorbing fluids to maintain GFR, the urine is highly concentrated and usually >500 mOsm/kg.


Option Analysis

❌ Acute tubular necrosis:
Incorrect: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is a cause of intrarenal acute kidney injury due to ischemic (e.g., hypotension, shock) or cytotoxic causes (e.g., aminoglycosides, radiocontrast agents, lead, cisplatin). In ATN, the urine osmolality is usually <350 (mOsm/kg) and the FENa> 2%. Granular muddy brown casts are also seen in the urine. 
❌ Diabetic nephropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic nephropathy is a progressive chronic condition that causes a gradual decline in renal function. This patient's drastic change in renal function favors another diagnosis. Additionally, this patient laboratory findings suggest prerenal acute kidney injury. 
❌ Syndrome of increased antidiuretic hormone (SIADH):
Incorrect: SIADH can be caused by certain medications (e.g., cyclophosphamide, SSRI). This patient is not taking any of these nephrotoxic medications, and the laboratory findings favor a different diagnosis. Additionally, SIADH would lead to euvolemic hyponatremia, not hypervolemia and ascites as seen in this patient.   
❌ Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:
Incorrect: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus can be hereditary (ADH receptor mutation) or secondary to hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, lithium use, or demeclocycline use. In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality is expected to be <300 mOsm/kg. 
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis is a possible cause of prerenal acute kidney injury. However, patients usually have a history of hypertension resistant to medical treatment. Another possible manifestation is at least 30% rise in serum creatinine following ACEI or ARB use. This patient received furosemide, and the serum creatinine increased by less than 30%. 
✅ Volume depletion:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office to establish routine care. He reports intermittent diarrhea and on-and-off crampy abdominal pain for the past 2 years. The diarrhea is nonbloody and is not associated with food intake. Past medical history is significant for pain in his knee joints that partially responds to ibuprofen. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva and mild right lower quadrant tenderness. Colonoscopy later reveals focal linear ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa, along with nodular mucosal changes in the descending colon and ileum. The rectal mucosa is spared. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a long-term history of intermittent watery diarrhea, in combination with crampy abdominal pain and physical examination findings of anemia (pallor conjunctiva) and abdominal tenderness, is most likely suffering from Crohn disease (CD), an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

Crohn disease is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it can present with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Systemic findings of inflammation (low-grade fever, weight loss, anemia, fatigue) can be seen. Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Intestinal features typical of Crohn disease include:

  •  Aphthous ulcers: small, discrete superficial ulcers, usually the earliest lesions seen in Crohn disease. 
  •  Skip lesions (Fig A): Large ulcers with normal mucosa in between, typical of segmental distribution of Crohn disease. 
  •  Cobblestone appearance (Fig B): Characterized by nodular thickening, with deep linear or serpiginous ulcers. Rectal sparing is a distinct feature. 
  •  Creeping fat (Fig C):  Characterized by fibrofatty proliferation of the mesenteric tissue adjacent to chronically inflamed bowel loops.

Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure B (Retrieved from: ">Wikimedia Commons


Figure C (Retrieved from: Radiopaedia.org

Option Analysis

❌ Ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis usually presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and is characterized on colonoscopy by continuous involvement of the rectum and sigmoid colon with scattered pseudopolyps and friable mucosa. Skip lesions and cobblestoning are typical of Crohn disease.
✅ Crohn disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranous colitis is a manifestation of C. difficile infection that clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. The infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins), and typical colonoscopy findings include pseudomembranes on the inflamed colonic mucosa. Skip lesions, linear ulceration and cobblestoning of mucosa are unlikely.
❌ Ischemic colitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic colitis can be secondary to embolic or thrombotic occlusion of mesenteric vessels; it typically presents acutely with bloody diarrhea, postprandial pain, or the classic finding of abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. This patient with long-standing watery diarrhea unrelated to food intake and endoscopic evidence of skip lesions and cobblestoning of mucosa most likely has Crohn disease.
❌ Diverticulitis:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis is defined as inflammation of diverticula, which are seen on colonoscopy as small, flask-like outpouchings containing only mucosa and submucosa. Diverticulitis is common in patients with long-standing constipation, and it usually presents with fever, acute-onset left-sided abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. Long-standing intermittent watery diarrhea and episodic abdominal pain are atypical.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and flank pain. The patient was found unconscious on a sidewalk by a bystander who called EMS. The patient was provided with intravenous fluids en route, after which his mental status improved. Upon initial assessment, the patient endorses left flank pain radiating to the groin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes. The patient’s eyes open spontaneously, and he is oriented to time and place but not to person. Initial laboratory studies are shown. During the first six hours of admission, urine output is 40 mL.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.6 mEq/L 
 Chloride  99 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  18 mEq/L 
 Serum creatinine  2.8 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Sediment  Granular “muddy brown” casts and envelope shaped crystals 
 Arterial blood gas (ABG) 
 pH  7.2 
 Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2)  40 mmHg 
 Partial pressure of oxygen (pO2)  85 mmHg 

 Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Dysmorphic red blood cells on urine microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with acute renal failure (oliguria and rising creatinine) and granular casts on urine microscopy is consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). In addition, this patient’s lab work demonstrates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis and envelope shaped (oxalate) crystals on urinalysis. Together, these findings are consistent with ethylene glycol poisoning--a toxic alcohol found in antifreeze that is often ingested as a substitute for alcohol.  

Ethylene glycol is metabolized to glycolic acid, which causes direct tubular damage, and oxalic acid, which crystallizes and obstructs the renal tubules. Together, these effects result in acute tubular necrosis and intrarenal azotemia. Intrarenal azotemia is characterized by tubular dysfunction, impaired reabsorption of sodium, increased urinary sodium (>40 mEq/L) and increased FENa(>2%). Urea reabsorption is also impaired, causing BUN:Cr to fall below 15. Failure of water reabsorption dilutes the urine, decreasing osmolality to <350 mOsm/kg.  

Urinalysis demonstrates granular “muddy brown” casts of sloughed tubular cells, which are pathognomonic for ATN. Histologically, ATN is characterized by loss of tubular epithelial cells’ nuclei, tubular dilation and epithelial cell vacuolization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urine osmolality <350 mOsm/kg:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) < 1%:
Incorrect: FENa <1% is seen in prerenal azotemia, where renal tubular function remains intact, causing increased sodium reabsorption due to the activation of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Prerenal azotemia occurs secondary to any process that decreases renal perfusion. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with ethylene glycol poisoning, a type of intrarenal acute kidney injury. 
❌ Hydronephrosis:
Incorrect: Hydronephrosis occurs secondary to obstruction of urinary outflow from the kidneys. Although it can present with increased creatinine levels and oliguria, the findings of increased anion gap metabolic acidosis and granular casts make an intrarenal cause more likely. 
❌ BUN:Cr > 20:
Incorrect: BUN:Cr >20 is observed in prerenal azotemia, as the kidneys reabsorb more urea compared to creatinine. In intrarenal azotemia, however, the kidneys are unable to reabsorb urea due to damaged renal tubular cells, resulting in BUN:Cr <20.  
❌ Dysmorphic red blood cells on urine microscopy:
Incorrect: Dysmorphic red blood cells on urine microscopy are observed in glomerular pathology (e.g. nephritic syndrome). The distortion of red blood cells occurs as they pass through damaged glomeruli. This condition is accompanied by proteinuria and formation of red blood cell casts.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parent because of increased sensitivity to sunlight. His parent reports that the patient sunburns easily since birth, even with minimal sun exposure. He has been meeting all developmental milestones and just recently started riding his tricycle with no assistance. Family history is significant for cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma in his paternal grandfather.  Vitals are within normal limits for age. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection and dryness of the facial skin with rough texture and erythematous macules and freckles. A complete neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following processes of DNA repair is most likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with photosensitive skin since infancy, in combination with physical examination findings of dry and erythematous facial skin with freckles and bilateral conjunctivitis, is strongly suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum (XP).

Normally, harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation creates pyrimidine dimers commonly between two adjacent thymines on one of the DNA strands, distorting the DNA strand in that region of the molecule. Nucleotide excision repair fixes this damage in a stepwise manner as follows:

  1.  Initially, endonucleases make two incisions in the DNA strand on the 3’ side and 5’ side of the damaged bases, leaving a fragment of 12 to 24 nucleotides with free ends, exposing them to exonucleases. 
  2.  Exonucleases remove these damaged nucleotides. 
  3.  DNA polymerase inserts new nucleotides, and 
  4. DNA ligase seals the bonds once again



XP is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that results from mutations in the genes that are involved in nucleotide excision repair. It primarily manifests in childhood with pigmented skin changes (e.g. freckling), skin atrophy, dryness, telangiectasia, and ocular damage which can present as ectropion, conjunctival injection, and/or corneal scarring. Progressive neurodegeneration is also seen in some cases, and this complication may present with sensorineural hearing loss, intellectual impairment, speech delays, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. Strict sun avoidance, protection, and frequent skin examination are appropriate management options.  


Option Analysis

❌ DNA mismatch repair:
Incorrect: Defective DNA mismatch repair results in Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer), which is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder that is strongly associated with colorectal cancer. Most patients are asymptomatic, but gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain are the usual presentation. This patient’s history of photosensitivity makes this disorder unlikely.
❌ Nonhomologous end joining repair:
Incorrect: Nonhomologous end joining refers to joining the ends of DNA fragments to repair the double-stranded breaks. Failure of this repair mechanism is usually observed in ataxia-telangiectasia, due to an abnormal ATM gene. The condition usually manifests in children as cerebellar ataxia, spider angiomas and recurrent infections. Dry skin and photosensitivity is atypical.
❌ Homologous recombination:
Incorrect: Homologous recombination refers to repair of damaged DNA using a complementary DNA strand from intact homologous double-stranded DNA. Failure of this mechanism results in Fanconi anemia, which presents with short stature, café-au-lait spots, and thumb/radial defects. Dry pigmented skin with increased sensitivity to sunlight is not seen.
✅ Nucleotide excision repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Base excision repair:
Incorrect: Base excision repair plays an important role in the repair of spontaneous or toxic deamination (removal of amino groups from nitrogen bases) that results from chemicals like nitrites or nitrosamine. A defect in base excision repair can increase the risk of developing colorectal cancer but is not associated with xeroderma pigmentosum.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old healthy man comes to the office because of an evolving nevus. He states it has been present on the dorsum of his right hand for “quite a while,” but it started growing in size and changing color recently. He has been a gardener for the past 20 years and spends much of his time working outdoors. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented lesion on the dorsum of the right hand with irregular borders, measuring 8-mm in diameter. Excisional biopsy of the lesion reveals the following findings on histopathology.



Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of metastasis for this patient’s lesion?

choices.text: Diameter of the lesion >6 mm at diagnosis

questions.solution:
This patient with prolonged sunlight exposure (as a gardener) has an evolving nevus (increase in size, changing color, irregular borders). Moreover, the histopathologic findings of nests of melanin-producing atypical melanocytes with large hyperchromatic nuclei, nuclear polymorphism and a distorted architecture with dermal solar elastosis are typical of melanoma, in which vertical growth is associated with increased risk of metastatic spread.



Melanoma most commonly occurs in the skin, though it can occur anywhere there are melanocytes (e.g., eyes, gastrointestinal tract, nails). Grossly, a cutaneous lesion is characterized by asymmetric shape, irregular borders, color variegation, diameter >6 mm, and evolution in size and appearance overtime (ABCDE criteria). It exhibits radial growth in its early development, but as it progresses, a vertical growth phase ensues, which is characterized by migration of neoplastic cells downward into the deeper dermis and beyond. It significantly increases the riskof metastasis, and it roughly corresponds to a palpable nodularity of the lesion. The Breslow depth, which is a measure of distance from the epidermal granular cell layer to the deepest visible neoplastic cells, is an important prognostic indicator for melanoma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Horizontal growth:
