Incorrect: Radial growth is usually observed in melanoma in its initial stages. However, this superficial,  horizontal growth within the epidermis and superficial dermis carries a very low risk of metastatic spread.
✅ Vertical growth:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prominent nuclear atypia:
Incorrect: Nuclear atypia (e.g., hyperchromatic nuclei, nuclear polymorphism) is a typical finding of malignant melanoma on histopathology, but it is not associated with increased risk of metastatic spread of the cancer cells.
❌ Diameter of the lesion >6 mm at diagnosis:
Incorrect: Increase in size of the lesion with diameter of >6-10 mm is considered a risk factor for malignant transformation of melanocytic nevus (mole). It is, however, not considered a risk factor for metastatic disease.
❌ Color variegation:
Incorrect: Color variegation (variable mixtures of brown, tan, red and black) is a common feature of melanoma and helps to differentiate it from a benign nevus. However, it is not associated with increased risk of metastatic disease.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician’s office due to weight loss and chronic cough for the past 2 months. He also noted streaks of blood mixed in with the sputum. His medical history is significant for smoking 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The patient's records show that 1 year ago his BMI was 24 kg/m2, and now it is 18 kg/m2. He denies any changes in his diet but reports a decreased appetite. Chest radiograph shows a central nodule in the right lung field. Biopsy of the suspected lesions is performed and histopathology shows small dark cells that stain positive for chromogranin A. Which of the following is most likely to be responsible for the patient’s weight loss?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation and histopathology results are consistent with the diagnosis of small cell lung cancer. His records show that his BMI declined from a normal level to being underweight, most likely due to cancer cachexia.

Cachexia is defined as a complex metabolic syndrome related to underlying illness; it is characterized by loss of muscle with/without loss of fat mass. It is associated with increased morbidity. Anorexia, insulin resistance, inflammation, and increased muscle protein breakdown are often associated with cachexia. In patients with cancer, despite reduced food intake in most cases, the calorie expenditure remains high. Cachexia differs from age-related loss of muscle mass, starvation, malabsorption, and hyperthyroidism in that cachexia is thought to be mediated mainly by TNF-α, IFN-γ, IL-1, and IL-6. TNF-α also suppresses appetite and inhibits the action of lipoprotein lipase, preventing the release of free fatty acids from lipoproteins, which also promote additional weight loss. The only definitive treatment for cancer cachexia is removal of the underlying tumor.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decay-accelerating factor:
Incorrect: Decay-accelerating factor (DAF), also called CD55, is a protein that regulates the complement system and the complement system’s activation against self cells. It is not the cause of cancer cachexia. Deficiency in DAF is associated with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
❌ Interleukin-12:
Incorrect: Interleukin-12 is secreted by macrophages to induce differentiation of T cells into Th1 cells. It also activates natural killer cells. It is not associated with cancer cachexia.
❌ Interferon-α:
Incorrect: Interferon-α (IFN-α), together with IFN-β and IFN-γ, is secreted by cells infected by viruses to act on neighboring cells, priming them for viral defense. IFN-α downregulates protein synthesis to resist viral replication and upregulates MHC expression to facilitate the recognition of infected cells. It also plays a major role in inactivating antitumor immunity. However, it is not significantly associated with cancer cachexia.
✅ Tumor necrosis factor-α:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ T4 hormone:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are secreted from the thyroid gland, affecting cells throughout the body. They act to increase basal metabolic rate, affect protein synthesis, and increase sensitivity to catecholamines. Hyperthyroidism can lead to weight loss due to increased basal metabolic rate, but it is unlikely to play a role in this specific patient’s malignancy-related cachexia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with fatigue, cough and episodic shortness of breath and wheezing for the past 2 months. She also describes feeling bloated and has several episodes of diarrhea per week. Family history is significant for asthma in her brother. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical exam, bowel sounds are present, the abdomen is soft and nontender, and pulsatile hepatomegaly is noted. Cardiac auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Respiratory auscultation is normal. There is 1+ pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Chest radiography is obtained and shows a central solitary nodule in the left lung. Which of the following tests is most likely to help in establishing the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Periodic acid-Schiff staining on duodenal biopsy

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with episodic shortness of breath and wheezing, diarrhea, pulsatile hepatomegaly, and tricuspid regurgitation most likely has a bronchial carcinoid tumor.

Bronchial carcinoid tumors are an uncommon group of pulmonary neoplasms characterized by neuroendocrine differentiation and a relatively indolent course. The tumor is thought to derive from peptide- and amine-producing neuroendocrine cells. These tumors can arise throughout the body, including the thymus, lung, gastrointestinal tract, and ovaries. Carcinoid tumors often produce serotonin and other bioactive amines, resulting in serotonin syndrome. This condition may present as cutaneous flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm. Long-term sequelae of prolonged exposure to elevated hormone levels include venous telangiectasias, valvular right heart disease, and retroperitoneal fibrosis. 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5‑HIAA), a byproduct of serotonin breakdown, can be found elevated in the urine. It is important to note that serotonin syndrome does not occur if the tumor is limited to the gastrointestinal tract, since serotonin undergoes first-pass metabolism in the liver.

Carcinoid heart disease, which often affects the right heart, is characterized by plaque-like deposits of fibrous tissue in the valvular cusps and leaflets. This patient’s new-onset murmur is likely indicative of tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border), which can lead to right heart failure. Right heart failure often presents with a pulsatile liver and peripheral edema, as seen in this patient.    

Option Analysis

❌ Serum hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B surface antigen can be positive during the acute or chronic stages of infection. Hepatitis B infection can present initially with anorexia, malaise, nausea, and vomiting following with jaundice, hepatomegaly, dark urine, and pale stools. However, it would not explain this patient’s heart murmur or pulsatile hepatomegaly.
❌ Fecal elastase:
Incorrect: The presence of low fecal elastase can help in the diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency. It may present with diarrhea and malabsorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), as well as vitamin B12. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.
✅ Urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Periodic acid-Schiff staining on duodenal biopsy:
Incorrect: Positive staining for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) on duodenal biopsy can be seen in Whipple disease. It is caused by Tropheryma whipplei, an intracellular gram-positive bacteria. Common symptoms include cardiac symptoms, arthralgias, and neurologic symptoms, while diarrhea/steatorrhea occurs later in the disease course. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.
❌ Allergy skin testing:
Incorrect: Allergy skin testing can help in establishing causative agents in allergic conditions (e.g., asthma, food allergy, allergic rhinitis). Although this patient has a positive history of asthma and wheezing, her associated symptoms favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. The parents note recurrent upper and lower extremity muscle spasms. He has had no fever, cough, or runny nose. The patient was born full term via an uncomplicated pregnancy and normal vaginal delivery. Family history is unremarkable. Physical examination demonstrates a neonate with rhythmic jerking movements of the upper and lower of extremities bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is open, pupils are reactive to light, and fundi are normal. Facial examination reveals a small lower jaw, low set ears, and a submucosal cleft palate. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Chest x-ray demonstrates decreased soft tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum. Which of the following immunologic derrangements is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Inability to form membrane attack complex

questions.solution:
This neonate’s presentation with generalized tonic-clonic seizures, abnormal facies, muscular spasms and a heart murmur with absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray is most suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome (DGS).

DGS results from a microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2. This region houses the TBX1 gene, which encodes normal development of the pharyngeal pouches 3 and 4. Normally, the third pharyngeal pouch develops into the thymus and the inferior parathyroid gland, whereas the fourth pouch develops into the superior parathyroid gland.

 


T-lymphocytes are produced in the bone marrow but mature in the thymus, and in patients with thymic hypoplasia, T cells do not mature, resulting in a severely compromised immune system.

The parathyroid gland secretes parathyroid hormone to increase the level of calcium ions in the blood via kidney reabsorption. Thus, parathyroid hypoplasia manifests with hypocalcemia--a known precipitant of seizures and tetany.

In addition, patients with DGS commonly have congenital heart defects (e.g., truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot), facial abnormalities (cleft palate) and a characteristic “facies” (orbital hypertelorism, short palpebral fissures, short philtrum and bifid uvula). These patients are also subject to higher rates of behavioral and mental health conditions.


Reproduced from Wikipedia

The diagnosis of DGS is based upon reduced numbers of CD3+ T cells, combined with either  characteristic clinical findings or a demonstrated deletion in chromosome 22q11.2 (on fluorescence in situ hybridization). Measurement of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels can also be helpful.

Of note, a similar syndrome called velocardiofacial syndrome can also occur with chromosome 22q11.2 deletion and presents with palate (submucous or overt clefts), facial (retrognathia, a long face with a prominent nose), and cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect and right-sided aortic arch).  

Option Analysis

✅ T-cell dysfunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inability to form membrane attack complex:
Incorrect: Inability to form membrane attack complex (C5-C9) is seen in terminal complement deficiency. This disease presents with recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis. Abnormal facies and symptomatic hypocalcemia are atypical.
❌ Insufficient IgA production:
Incorrect: Insufficient IgA production is characteristic of selective IgA deficiency. Most of these patients are asymptomatic; however, some patients develop recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal infections, atopy, autoimmune diseases and/or anaphylactic blood transfusion reactions. Abnormal facies and symptomatic hypocalcemia are atypical.
❌ Ineffective intracellular killing:
Incorrect: Chronic granulomatous disease is an example of ineffective intracellular killing resulting from a defect in NADPH oxidase and impaired respiratory burst. Affected patients are susceptible to infections with catalase positive organisms. Symptomatic hypocalcemia and thymic hypoplasia are atypical.
❌ Impared immunoglobulin gene rearrangement:
Incorrect: Impaired immunoglobulin gene rearrangement characterizes hyper IgM syndrome. In this disease, B cells produce high amounts of IgM but are unable to produce other immunoglobulins due to a defect in class switching. Affected patients present early in life with opportunistic infections.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a high-grade fever and a rash for the past 2 days. The rash first appeared on his face and has now spread over his entire body. Prior to the onset of the rash, the patient had a cough, rhinorrhea and pink eyes. He has not received any vaccinations due to parental preference. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 31/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a tired and restless child with a diffuse, erythematous, maculopapular rash all over the body sparing the palms and soles. Oral examination shows tiny, white round lesions on the buccal mucosa. No pharyngeal exudates are seen. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with measles (rubeola), which is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing the palms and soles).  

Measles affects various organs and can lead to complications such as pneumonia, diarrhea, and, on rare occasions, acute encephalitis, all of which can lead to death. In addition, it can suppress the immune system for up to 6 weeks, contributing to bacterial superinfections (e.g., otitis media and bacterial pneumonia). Pneumonia is the most common cause of measles-associated death in children.  

Another severe and often fatal complication for children under 2 years old is the development of subacutesclerosing panencephalitis, which can happen 7-10 years later. It can lead to dementia, spasticity, epilepsy, and autonomic dysfunction. This complication is thought to be caused by a persistent measles virus infection, possibly due to an abnormal immune response or a mutated strain of the measles virus, which leads to chronic inflammation of the entire brain. Immunocompromised patients have higher rates of pneumonia and encephalitis, which contribute to a higher mortality rate. 

Option Analysis

❌ Aplastic anemia:
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia can complicate parvovirus B19 infection in patients with sickle cell anemia or immunosuppression. Measles does not usually cause or increase the risk of aplastic crises.  
❌ Coronary artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: Coronary artery aneurysm is a life-threatening complication of Kawasaki disease. Such patients usually present with fever, strawberry tongue, a rash, lymphadenopathy and bilateral conjunctival injection. Koplick spots seen in this patient, however, are pathognomonic of measles. 
✅ Encephalitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is a known complication of acute group A streptococcal infection, which can cause scarlet fever and pharyngitis. Patients typically present with a sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure along with fever, malaise and gray white pharyngeal exudates. The presence of Koplik spots in this patient is suggestive of measles.
❌ Orchitis:
Incorrect: Orchitis is a common complication of mumps. Patients usually present with fever, malaise and myalgias followed by the development of parotitis within 48 hours. A maculopapular rash is typically absent.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of an itchy rash on his penis. The rash has been present on the glans of the penis for seven weeks. The patient immigrated from Argentina in his twenties and is unsure of his vaccination status. He has had multiple sexual partners and occasionally uses condoms for protection. Physical examination reveals an uncircumcised penis. A 2-cm velvety, red, well-marginated, painless ulcer is noted on the glans penis. No other penile deformities are observed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This uncircumcised male presents for evaluation of an erythematous painless ulcer on the glans penis. Given the location and character of this lesion, he likely has erythroplasia of Queyrat--a premalignant lesion caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

Premalignant penile lesions include Bowen disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat, and Bowenoid papulosis, which are associated with the high-risk HPV subtypes 16 and 18. Bowen disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat, and Bowenoid papulosis are clinical variants of carcinoma in situ (CIS) and can be differentiated based on appearnace and location:

  •  Bowen disease presents as red, shiny, pigmented patches or plaques on the shaft of the penis or the scrotum. 
  •  Erythroplasia of Queyrat presents as erythroplakia on the glans/prepuce; only the location distinguishes Bowen disease from erythroplasia of Queyrat. 
  •  Bowenoid papulosis presents as multiple warty-like lesions, usually on the penile shaft, which are often pigmented.

Option Analysis

✅ Erythroplasia of Queyrat:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bowen disease:
Incorrect: Bowen disease is characterized by erythroplakia on the shaft of the penis or scrotum. The difference between Bowen disease and erythroplasia of Queyrat is the location--erythroplasia of Queyrat occurs on the glans penis, whereas Bowen disease occurs on the shaft of the penis.
❌ Bowenoid papulosis:
Incorrect: Bowenoid papulosis results in multiple papular lesions on the shaft of the penis. It is most often seen in younger males and is characterized by multiple slightly elevated papules that are red to violet in color.
❌ Lichen sclerosus:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosus is characterized by white atrophic plaques on the glans and prepuce. These plaques grow and coalesce into a sclerotic mass with resultant adhesions, phimosis, and meatal stenosis. Lichen sclerosus is most commonly observed in uncircumcised males.
❌ Peyronie disease:
Incorrect: Peyronie disease is a condition caused by microtrauma and subsequent collagen and scar formation in the tunica albuginea. Patients present with a curved penis, penile pain, and erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the university health center for evaluation of sore throat. The patient has been experiencing worsening sore throat, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes over the past 10-days. In addition, he has been experiencing a mild cough. His symptoms have not been relieved with over the counter tylenol or with the amoxicillin prescribed by his primary care physician, which resulted in the development of an erythematous, maculopapular rash. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/71 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates tender submandibular and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination reveals bilateral tonsillar swelling with exudate. Which of the following clinical features can best help differentiate this patient’s disease process from other causes of pharyngitis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, sore throat, and tender lymphadenopathy. In addition, he underwent a trial of antibiotics that proved unresponsive and resulted in a maculopapular rash. In combination, these findings are suspicious for infectious mononucleosis. Among the patient’s symptoms, the presence of posterior cervical lymphadenopathy has the highest clinical correlation and positive likelihood ratio (LR) for infectious mononucleosis.

Infectious mononucleosis is an acute illness most commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). It is characterized by fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudate with swelling. While evaluating a patient with the aforementioned symptoms, multiple differential diagnoses should also be suspected including streptococcal pharyngitis, viral pharyngitis, acute HIV infection, and lymphoma.

Features that can help distinguish infectious mononucleosis from other causes of pharyngitis include the presence of hepatomegaly (LR 95% CI: 1.4-2.9), splenomegaly (LR 95% CI: 1.9-6.6), palatal petechiae (LR 95% CI: 2.1-13), and posterior cervical adenopathy (LR 95% CI: 1.6-5.9). In contrast, the absence of these symptoms makes the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis less likely. If a patient with infectious mononucleosis is misdiagnosed with streptococcal pharyngitis, administration of amoxicillin can precipitate a diffuse maculopapular rash. 

Option Analysis

✅ Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy is observed in both bacterial and viral pharyngitis, as well as in infectious mononucleosis. As a result, this physical examination finding is non-specific and would not help in distinguishing infectious mononucleosis from other causes of pharyngitis.
❌ Tonsillar exudate:
Incorrect: This patient presents with sore throat, tonsillar swelling with exudate, as well as submandibular and posterior auricular lymphadenopathy. These findings are concerning for infectious mononucleosis. The presence of tonsillar exudate, however, does not reliably distinguish infectious mononucleosis from other causes of pharyngitis.
❌ Fatigue:
Incorrect: Patients with infectious mononucleosis can present with fatigue. However, fatigue is also observed in patients with other causes of pharyngitis (e.g. streptococcal pharyngitis). As a result, this symptom has limited utility in identifying the underlying cause of this patient’s pharyngitis.
❌ Presence of cough:
Incorrect: According to the Centor score, the presence of a cough leans against streptococcal pharyngitis. However, this symptom does not reliably rule in or out infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain and vomiting in school. His parents mention that he had a viral illness two weeks ago, and he has since been drinking and urinating more frequently than usual. Additionally, he has lost weight despite increasing his caloric intake. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5° F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 87/55 mm Hg. The child appears lethargic, he is difficult to rouse, and his breathing appears labored. Physical examination shows reduced skin turgor. Laboratory findings show blood glucose levels of 450 mg/dL and an arterial pH of 7.20. Which of the following additional sets of laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with polyphagia, polyuria, and weight loss following a viral illness two weeks ago. His clinical presentation reveals non-specific abdominal pain, vomiting, altered consciousness, Kussmaul respirations, signs of dehydration (e.g. low blood pressure, reduced skin turgor), and hyperglycemia. These findings reflect the classic presentation of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) secondary to undiagnosed type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM).

DKA can occur due to insulin noncompliance or increased insulin requirements (e.g. infection). The absent/low insulin leads to lipolysis to generate free fatty acids, which are then converted to ketone bodies (e.g. acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate) to meet energy requirements. These ketone bodies lead to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. It is important to note that DKA occurs in T1DM rather than T2DM because the endogenous insulin in T2DM is sufficient to prevent lipolysis.

Laboratory findings supporting DKA include high glucose, hyperkalemia (but decrease in total body K+ due to urine loss), and elevated urine and blood ketone bodies. Arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, including a low pH, low HCO3– (trying to buffer the excess acid), and often a low PaCO2  due to respiratory compensation (Kussmaul respirations to exhale extra CO2 in an attempt to normalize the pH).

To calculate the anion gap, use the following formula: anion gap = Na+ – (Cl-+ HCO3–). This patient's anion gap is 138 - (95+20)= 23, which is above the normal value of 8-12. The anion gap represents the difference between the cations and anions, and the additional ketone bodies in the serum are responsible for this difference.




Option Analysis

❌  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  Na+   (mEq/L)  Cl-  (mEq/L)  52  32  135  95 :
Incorrect: High PaCO2, high bicarbonate high and normal anion gap (135-(95+32)=8) are consistent with respiratory acidosis and metabolic compensation. This patient has diabetec ketoacidosis, which results in an anion gap metabolic acidosis.
❌  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  Na+   (mEq/L)  Cl-  (mEq/L) 3018138110:
Incorrect: Low PaCO2, low bicarbonate and normal anion gap (138-(110+18)=10) are consistent with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This pattern can be seen in diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis.
❌  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  Na+   (mEq/L)  Cl-  (mEq/L) 2525140104:
Incorrect: Findings of low PaCO2, normal bicarbonate and normal anion gap (140-(104+25)=11) are consistent with respiratory alkalosis before metabolic compensation occurred. This pattern can be seen in conditions such as hyperventilation due to panic attack.
✅  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  Na+   (mEq/L)  Cl-  (mEq/L) 2620138 95 :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  Na+   (mEq/L)  Cl-  (mEq/L) 5040143 95 :
Incorrect: These findings of high PaCO2, high bicarbonate and normal anion gap (8) are consistent with respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.
❌  Arterial PaCO2  (mEq/L)  Arterial HCO3–  (mEq/L)  Na+   (mEq/L)  Cl-  (mEq/L) 4024141104:
Incorrect: These findings represent normal findings in a healthy individual.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician's office for evaluation of sore throat and fever for 3 days. He has received all childhood vaccinations. His medical history is unremarkable. He and his family immigrated from Vietnam 2 years ago. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Examination of the patient’s throat is shown below. This patient is at risk for developing which of the following clinical manifestations?

 
Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Myocarditis, membranous pharyngitis, and anterior neck lymphadenopathy

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a sore throat, fever, and tonsillar exudate, a classic presentation of group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) pharyngitis, which is associated with acute rheumatic fever (ARF).

Acute rheumatic fever is an early sequelae that occurs approximately 2 weeks following group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis. Clinical manifestations include arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules. The heart involvement associated with ARF is typically pancarditis, involving the pericardium, epicardium, myocardium, and endocardium (valvulitis). The damage to the valves may become chronic and progressive, leading to mitral (most common), aortic and rarely, tricuspid valves damage. Rheumatic heart disease may manifest acutely or years after the initial illness. Regurgitation is the most common finding but may progress to stenosis. Diagnosis is made via the Jones criteria (shown below). Prevention of ARF involves early diagnosis and antibiotic treatment of GAS infection.



Option Analysis

❌ Myocarditis, mucositis, and conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Kawasaki disease. Other findings include fever, typically above 38.5ºC (101.3ºF), extremity edema, lymphadenopathy, arthritis, polymorphous rash, pericardial effusion, and coronary artery aneurysm. Kawasaki disease develops during the acute illness, unlike rheumatic fever with group A strep infection.
❌ Encephalopathy and myoclonic jerks:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with subacute sclerosing panencephalitis--a known sequelae of measles infection. This childhood viral infection is characterized by prodromal fever accompanied by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis and buccal lesions (Koplik spots). Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis occurs years after the primary infection. This child received all childhood vaccinations, including measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.
✅ Carditis, arthritis, and subcutaneous nodules:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Parotitis and orchitis:
Incorrect: Mumps is a viral infection marked by prodromal fever, headache, myalgias, fatigue, anorexia, and parotid gland swelling. Complications include orchitis, meningitis, and deafness. This child received all childhood vaccinations, including measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.
❌ Myocarditis, membranous pharyngitis, and anterior neck lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Diphtheria is an infectious condition caused by the gram-positive bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Initial symptoms include sore throat, malaise, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (“bulls neck”), and low-grade fevers. The prototypical sore throat manifestation includes gray and white exudate, so-called pseudomembranes. Associated complications include myocarditis, CNS disturbance, and renal disease. This child received all childhood vaccinations, including the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is being evaluated in the cardiac telemetry unit for sudden onset dyspnea. Three days prior, she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention, which demonstrated right coronary artery stenosis. The ECG at that time demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. On physical examination, the following murmur pattern is appreciated over the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s new onset dyspnea?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new holosystolic murmur, hypotension, and dyspnea three days following an inferior wall MI, favoring the diagnosis of acute mitral regurgitation secondary to papillary muscle rupture.

Risk factors for acute mitral regurgitation include both STEMI and NSTEMI (especially of the inferior wall), left ventricular dilatation, mitral valve prolapse, infective endocarditis, blunt chest trauma, and chronic or acute rheumatic heart disease. In the case of inferior wall myocardial infarction, rupture of the posteromedial papillary muscle is by far more common than rupture of the anterolateral papillary muscle. The posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied by the posterior descending artery (most commonly a branch of the right coronary artery), whereas the anterolateral papillary muscle receives dual supply from both the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries.

Clinical manifestations of acute papillary muscle rupture include hypotension, acute pulmonary edema, and a new onset holosystolic murmur best heard over the 5th left midclavicular intercostal space (cardiac apex). Diagnosis is confirmed via echocardiography, and treatment involves administration of afterload reduction agents (e.g. nitroprusside), vasopressors, and emergent surgery.

Option Analysis

✅ Papillary muscle rupture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventricular septal rupture:
Incorrect: Ventricular septal rupture usually occurs in the first 24 hours following infarction. Risk is augmented with left anterior descending artery occlusion or extensive myocardial damage. Patients may present with a variety of symptoms ranging from exertional dyspnea to cardiogenic shock. A new holosystolic murmur is also appreciated, but it is typically at the right lower sternal border.
❌ Left ventricular free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Left ventricular free wall typically occurs within the first five days following myocardial infarction. Complete rupture results in hemopericardium and pericardial tamponade. Clinical findings of tamponade include muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and distended neck veins.
❌ Ventricular arrhythmia:
Incorrect: During the first 24 hours post-myocardial infarction, the most common cause of death is ventricular tachycardia/ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death (SCD). However, a ventricular arrhythmia would not precipitate a holosystolic murmur.
❌ Ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: A true ventricular aneurysm typically develops anywhere from weeks to months following an anterior myocardial infarction. A true aneurysm is defined as an akinetic, fibrotic, and scarred myocardium. An acute-onset holosystolic murmur would be atypical.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes seeking evaluation of upper abdominal pain and recurrent watery diarrhea. The pain is worse after meals. He has tried over-the-counter antacids, but they have been ineffective in controlling his symptoms. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient was adopted, and his family history is unknown. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure of 122/75 mmHg. Physical exam reveals epigastric tenderness and conjunctival pallor. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated serum gastrin level, and fecal occult blood test is positive. Upper endoscopy reveals thickened gastric folds as well as multiple ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. Considering the disorder to be heritable, which of the following conditions is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
In this vignette, the patient’s history of epigastric pain, elevated gastrin levels, and endoscopic findings of multiple ulcers in the gastric and duodenal regions raise concerns for a gastrinoma. When inherited, gastrinomas are usually associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), an autosomal dominant genetic condition which predisposes patients to develop pituitary adenomas, parathyroid adenomas, and pancreatic endocrine tumors (e.g., gastronomas, insulinomas, etc.). Pituitary adenomas are seen in up to 30-40% patients with MEN1.

Pituitary adenomas are classified based on size and hormone-secreting status. When a pituitary adenomas is under one-centimeter in diameter, it is termed a microadenoma. Most microadenomas are asymptomatic. If the tumor is greater than one-centimeter in diameter, it is termed a macroadenoma. Macroadenomas can cause symptoms of mass effect (i.e. headaches, visual field deficits, and hypopituitarism), since the tumor compresses and impairs the function of the normal pituitary gland.

Adenomas are further classified as non-functional, which do not secrete hormones, and functional, which do secrete hormones. Most non-functional adenomas only present with mass effect symptoms. Functional adenomas, on the other hand, can present with varying symptoms depending on the hormone produced. The most common of them is prolactinoma, which secretes prolactin.



Option Analysis

❌ Colorectal cancer:
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer is a long term complication of inflammatory bowel disease, which can present with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. However, the elevated gastrin levels and endoscopic findings suggest an alternate diagnosis.
✅ Pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pheochromocytoma:
Incorrect: Patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2A and 2B are at increased risk of developing pheochromocytoma. However, this patient most likely has gastrinoma, which is associated with MEN1. Patients with MEN1 are not at increased risk of developing pheochromocytoma.
❌ Thyroid cancer:
Incorrect: Patients with MEN2A and MEN2B are at increased risk of developing medullary thyroid carcinoma. However, gastrinomas are associated with MEN1, and it would be atypical for a patient with MEN2A or MEN2B to present with this condition.
❌ Intestinal ganglioneuroma:
Incorrect: Patients with MEN 2B are at risk of developing intestinal ganglioneuromas. However, it would be atypical for a patient with MEN 2B to present with a gastrinoma.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to difficulty keeping up with other children at daycare. Over the last 2 months, the daycare teachers have noticed that the patient cannot walk independently and seems more tired than usual. The parents have noticed that the boy finds it difficult to climb stairs. He has been eating and growing normally, and he has no past medical history except for an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago that resolved on its own. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged and nontender calves bilaterally. When asked to rise from the floor, the boy uses hand support to push himself to an upright position. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Serum creatinine kinase is 14,200 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young boy with progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gower sign (using hand support to push himself to an upright position) and elevated creatinine kinase is most likely suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a frameshift deletion mutation in the dystrophin gene, leading to the production of truncated or absent dystrophin protein. Affected patients present at age 2-3 years with muscle weakness that begins in pelvic girdle muscles and progresses superiorly. Serum creatinine kinase (CK) and aldolase levels are usually elevated, and genetic testing confirms the absence of dystrophin protein.

DMD should be differentiated from Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), which usually manifests later in life (age 5-15 years), with a milder degree of clinical involvement. Patients typically remain ambulatory at least until age 16, and commonly well into adult life. Intellectual disability is less common, and there is relative preservation of neck flexor muscle strength. Cardiac involvement in BMD is often predominant and can manifest early in life. Moreover, in contrast to DMD, patients with BMD,typically have abnormal or low concentration of dystrophin protein resulting from non-frameshift mutations.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Guillain-Barré syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) can occur following a respiratory tract infection. However, GBS presents with ascending muscle weakness, hyporeflexia and neuropathic pain. Moreover, the patient's symptoms began before the respiratory tract infection, making this diagnosis unlikely.
✅ Duchenne muscular dystrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Becker muscular dystrophy:
Incorrect: Although Becker muscular dystrophy can present similar to DMD, the age of onset, however, is later in life, and the muscle weakness is less severe.
❌ Viral myositis:
Incorrect: Viral myositis can present with acute muscle pain and weakness. However, this patient’s prolonged history of proximal muscle weakness and absence of muscle tenderness makes the diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Myasthenia gravis:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. Affected individuals most commonly present with fluctuating weakness and fatigability of ocular muscles. Moreover, it rarely affects children, and isolated proximal muscle weakness is inconsistent with the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of a painless testicular mass. The patient first noticed a nontender lump on the left testicle 2 weeks ago while showering. In addition, he has experienced a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the previous 3 months. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and asthma. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/79 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a nontender nodule on the left testicle that does not transilluminate. The nodule does not decrease in size when the patient lies flat. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated placental alkaline phosphatase level and ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic and homogeneous mass. Which of the following statements best characterizes this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Predisposition for metastases to the lungs

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a painless, non-illuminating testicular mass and an elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) level. These findings are consistent with those of a testicular seminoma, which is characterized by a slow tumor growth rate.

Seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. Gross examination of this tumor typically shows a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopic examination, tumor cells appear large with a central nuclei surrounded by clear cytoplasm; they are thus said to have a “fried egg appearance.” On laboratory testing, patients will have elevated PLAP levels, whereas α-fetoprotein and ꞵ-hCG levels are typically normal.

In regards to prognosis, seminomas exhibit a slow growth rate, metastasize late, respond well to radiotherapy, and overall have an excellent prognosis. In contrast, non-seminoma tumors are more aggressive, metastasize early, have a variable response to treatment, with a subsequently poorer prognosis.

In the case of mixed tumors, such as ones containing elements of both choriocarcinoma and seminoma, the prognosis is based on the worst component.



Option Analysis

✅ Slow rate of nodule growth:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Development of testicular atrophy:
Incorrect: Elevation of scrotal temperature is one of the major factors to impair spermatogenesis and steroidogenesis in a testis with varicocele. This heat stress is shown to be closely associated with oxidative stress, and it is followed by the apoptosis of germ cells. This cell death can be seen clinically as testicular atrophy secondary to loss of germ cell mass. This patient’s solid mass, which does not resolve with laying flat (which is typically seen in varicoceles), is suggestive of another condition.
❌ Development of gynecomastia:
Incorrect: Nonseminomatous testicular tumors (e.g. choriocarcinomas) are associated with elevated ꞵ-hCG levels. Elevated levels of ꞵ-hCG can cause gynecomastia in men. In contrast, this patient has a seminoma, which does not usually cause elevated ꞵ-hCG levels.
❌ Development of hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Nonseminomatous testicular tumors (e.g. choriocarcinomas) are associated with elevated ꞵ-hCG levels. Since ꞵ-hCG and TSH share a common subunit, elevated levels of ꞵ-hCG can cause hyperthyroidism. In contrast, this patient has a seminoma, which does not usually cause elevated ꞵ-hCG levels.
❌ Predisposition for metastases to the lungs:
Incorrect: This patient has a painless, non-illuminating, testicular mass in the setting of an elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP), which is concerning for a seminoma. Seminomas are characterized by late metastases when compared to other testicular tumors. In contrast, aggressive testicular tumors (e.g. choriocarcinoma) are more likely to spread to the lungs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate for evaluation of disorganized behavior. Two days ago, the patient refused to come out of his room claiming, “I have a plan to rid the world of climate change!” The patient has been refusing to eat or sleep. The roommate states, “I’m also missing my prescription for my ADHD.” The patient has a history of major depressive disorder and allergic rhinitis. His current medications include escitalopram and an over the counter nasal decongestant. He does not use tobacco or alcohol. Temperature is 100 °F (37.7 °C), pulse is 110 bpm, and blood pressure is 150/80 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and irritable. On physical examination, the pupils are mydriatic, and the patient is diaphoretic. Oral mucosa appears moist. No clonus is elicited in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with agitation, delusions, insomnia, reduced appetite, and a hyperadrenergic state. In addition, this patient's history is suspicious for amphetamine abuse, especially given his roommate is missing a prescription for attention deficit disorder (these patients are commonly prescribed amphetamine derivatives such as methylphenidate).

Amphetamines are sympathomimetic agents with resultant stimulant effects on the central nervous system. Their mechanism of action involves blockade of the dopamine reuptake and release of monoamine neurotransmitters including dopamine, norepinephrine and serotonin.






Amphetamines may be ingested orally, insufflated, injected, or inhaled and result in the desired effects of euphoria, prolonged wakefulness, and anorexia. When ingested in excess, amphetamines can cause paranoia, psychosis (delusions), and a sympathomimetic toxidrome. As a result, patients may suffer from seizures and/or cardiovascular collapse. 

Option Analysis

✅ Amphetamine intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anticholinergic toxicity:
Incorrect: Anticholinergic toxicity is characterized by dry skin, dry mucous membranes, ileus and acute urinary retention. The presence of moist mucous membranes in this patient makes this toxidrome less likely.
❌ Serotonin syndrome:
Incorrect: Clinical manifestations of serotonin syndrome include psychomotor agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, and clonus in the setting of over ingestion or coingestion of serotonergic agents. Clonus is not appreciated on this patient’s physical exam.
❌ Phencyclidine ingestion:
Incorrect: Phencyclidine (PCP) ingestion manifests with nystagmus, ataxia, and psychomotor agitation. Patients are often incredibly physically aggressive--requiring the use of both chemical and physical restraints.
❌ Brief psychotic episode:
Incorrect: A brief psychotic episode is defined as acute onset of one or more psychotic symptoms for >1 day and less than 1 month. The presence of mydriasis, hypertension, and tachycardia instead suggests an underlying substance-induced psychotic episode.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of decreased vision. She reports that driving has become difficult for her over the last 2 months, and she recently got into a car accident after failing to see a car in her periphery. Over the same time period, she has been feeling fatigued, gained 4.5-kg (10-lbs) and has been having frequent hot flashes. Review of systems is significant for constipation and menstrual irregularity. Her last menstrual period was 4 months ago. She has no significant past medical history, and her family history is negative for cancers. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory testing shows serum prolactin levels within normal limits. MRI of the brain reveals a 1.1-cm well-defined round lesion in the pituitary fossa. Which of the following changes in serum hormone levels are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of restricted peripheral vision in this patient suggests the development of bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm by the pituitary mass. Given the patient’s normal serum prolactin levels, it is most likely a nonfunctional macroadenoma.

Non-secretory macroadenomas can result in destruction of nearby secretory cells, resulting in panhypopituitarism. Destruction of thyrotropes can result in low serum TSH levels that can lead to the development of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, weight gain, menstrual irregularities), whereas that of gonadotropes can result in decreased LH and FSH secretion, leading to amenorrhea and menopausal symptoms (e.g. hot flashes). Since the anterior pituitary can no longer secrete FSH and LH, the hypothalamus synthesizes more GnRH (elevated GnRH levels) due to the lack of negative feedback.

Treatment of a non-functioning macroadenoma, especially the ones that cause severe clinical symptoms such as in this patient, is transsphenoidal resection.

 

Option Analysis

✅  GnRH  TSH  FSH ↑↓↓:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GnRH TSH  FSH ↓↓↓:
Incorrect: Since GnRH is secreted from the hypothalamus, it responds to the decrease in gonadotropins by increasing (not decreasing) its secretion through negative feedback mechanism. This patient most likely has non-functioning macroadenoma that is inhibiting the secretion of pituitary hormones.
❌  GnRH  TSH  FSH ↓ ↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory values can be seen in patients with primary hypothyroidism; thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) acts as a prolactin-releasing hormone, resulting in decreased GnRH and FSH levels. However, this patient has a normal serum prolactin level, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌  GnRH  TSH  FSH ↓↓↑:
Incorrect: This set of laboratory values can be seen in patients with a gonadotropin-secreting pituitary tumor. FSH levels are elevated, resulting in negative feedback inhibition of GnRH secretion. If the tumor is large enough, it can cause mass effect and result in decreased TSH secretion.
❌  GnRH  TSH  FSH Normal ↓↓:
Incorrect: Since GnRH is secreted from the hypothalamus, it responds to the decrease in gonadotropins by increasing its secretion through a negative feedback mechanism. This patient most likely has a non-functioning macroadenoma that is inhibiting the secretion of pituitary hormones.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting for two days. This morning she developed a rash on her lower extremities, prompting her college roommate to bring her to the emergency department. Past medical history includes recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The patient is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms for contraception. Temperature is 40.2 C° (104.4 F°), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 29/min and blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a lethargic female with an erythematous, non-blanching petechial rash on the trunk and lower extremities.  The hips flex when the neck is flexed. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Impaired production of superoxide by phagocytes
Impaired production of the membrane attack complex
Defective adhesion and transmigration of leukocytes
Impaired production of C1 esterase inhibitor

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with meningitis secondary to Neisseria meningitidis. This presentation, in combination with a history of recurrent episodes of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, suggests terminal complement deficiencies (C5-C9) which normally forms the membrane attack complex (MAC).

The complement system helps with three important immune processes: inflammation, phagocytosis, and the creation of MAC.



There are three complement pathways for these purposes:

  •  Classical pathway  
  •  Alternative pathway  
  •  Lectin binding pathway 
All three pathways are initiated by different mechanisms, but terminate with formation of MAC--a protein complex perforates bacterial cell membranes. The function of various components of the complement pathway is demonstrated below.

The deficiencies of complement pathways can be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner or can be acquired secondary to a severe infection or autoimmune conditions. Complement deficiency is divided   into early and late complement deficiency.

Complement deficiencies can also cause hyperactive immune response. For example, C1-inhibitor  normally inhibits the complement system, and its deficiency results in angioedema or non-pitting edema of nondependent areas, due to unregulated activation of kallikrein. C4 levels are characteristically decreased in this condition. Treatment of complement deficiencies include administration of immunosuppressants (in case of overactive immune response) and prophylactic antibiotics (in case of underactive immune response).

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired production of superoxide by phagocytes:
Incorrect: Impaired production of superoxide by phagocytes is seen in chronic granulomatous disease, an immunodeficiency caused by NADPH oxidase deficiency. Affected patients present with recurrent infections with catalase positive organisms. Neisseria is not a catalase positive organism.
❌ Impaired phagosome-lysosome fusion:
Incorrect: Chediak-Higashi syndrome results from a defective LYST gene leading to microtubule dysfunction and imparied phagosome-lysosome fusion. Affected patients present in infancy or early childhood with recurrent infections, progressive neurodegeneration, coagulation defects, silvery hair, lymphohistiocytosis and peripheral neuropathy.
✅ Impaired production of the membrane attack complex:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Defective adhesion and transmigration of leukocytes:
Incorrect: Defective adhesion and transmigration of leukocytes results in leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Affected patients present in infancy or early childhood with recurrent skin and mucosal infections without purulence and delayed separation of the umbilical cord.
❌ Impaired production of C1 esterase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Impaired production of C1 esterase inhibitor causes angioedema or non-pitting edema of nondependent areas due to unregulated activation of kallikrein. Recurrent Neisseria infections are atypical.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute-onset, right-sided eye pain. She was in a movie theater when she suddenly experienced severe pain in the right eye and associated blurry vision. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. She smokes 1-2 cigarettes per day and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Review of the medical record shows the patient’s most recent hemoglobin A1C was 5.7%. Ophthalmologic examination is notable for the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The right pupil is unresponsive to light. Bilateral retina are successfully visualized, and increased optic nerve cupping is observed in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Anatomically shallow anterior chamber with lens enlargement

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute-onset eye pain. Physical examination reveals a dilated right pupil non-reactive to light, with surrounding injection and increased optic nerve cupping. Together, these findings are consistent with acute closed-angle glaucoma, which in the absence of other precipitating factors, is most commonly due to an enlarged lens that gets pushed up against the iris in individuals with an anatomically shallow anterior chamber.

Closed-angle glaucoma is caused by narrowing or closure of the iridocorneal angle. This abnormality leads to impaired aqueous humor outflow, increased intraocular pressure, and ischemia of intraocular structures. Closed-angle glaucoma can be divided into primary and secondary disease.

Primary disease is due to an enlarged lens that gets pushed up against the iris in individuals with an anatomically shallow anterior chamber. The condition often develops when the patient is in a low-light environment, since it triggers pupillary dilation and iris contraction, which crowds the iridocorneal angle. Secondary disease can be due to hypoxia from retinal diseases (e.g., diabetes mellitus, central retinal vein occlusion), which induces neovascularization and causes the iris to be pushed anteriorly. It can also be caused by anticholinergic drugs, which lead to mydriasis and reduced aqueous humor outflow.

Acute closed-angle glaucoma often manifests with increased intraocular pressure on tonometry, a dilated pupil unresponsive to light with surrounding injection, severe pain, blurred vision, as well as nausea and vomiting. Chronic closed-angle glaucoma occurs when the increase in intraocular pressure happens gradually, and it will often present with progressive vision loss due to optic nerve damage.



Option Analysis

✅ Anatomically shallow anterior chamber with lens enlargement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinal vein occlusion:
Incorrect: Retinal vein occlusion is a known cause of secondary acute closed-angle glaucoma. The condition can present with retinal hemorrhage, edema, and retinal vessel dilation on fundoscopic examination. In contrast, this patient’s retinal examination demonstrates only optic nerve cupping.
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Medications with antimuscarinic properties like atropine can precipitate episodes of secondary closed-angle glaucoma. In contrast, amlodipine does not predispose patients to closed-angle glaucoma.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus can result in neovascularization and precipitate secondary closed-angle glaucoma. However, this patient’s hemoglobin A1C is within normal limits, hence making underlying diabetes unlikely.
❌ Opacification of the lens:
Incorrect: Cataracts are characterized by opacification of the ocular lens. However, cataracts are not known to cause closed-angle glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a painful vesicular rash on his face, elbows, and trunk for two days. His parent states the patient had a “flare-up of dryness and itching” in the same region for which high-potency topical corticosteroids were started five days ago. Family history is significant for asthma in his mother. Temperature is 38.05°C (100.5°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows an irritable child with erythematous, scaly, crusted lesions on the extensor surfaces of the elbows and on the trunk. Examination findings of the face are shown:


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The presentation of this patient is most likely a complication of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This child’s presents with a painful vesicular eruption, fever, and a history of recent treatment with an immunosuppressive agent (corticosteroids). This presentation is highly suggestive of eczema herpeticum, a herpes simplex virus 1 infection (HSV-1). This is a rare but severe complication of atopic dermatitis, which is a likely cause of a flare of dryness and itching in this patient.

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is an immune-mediated inflammatory skin condition that commonly affects children, but it is also seen in adults. Major risk factors include a family history of atopy (e.g. asthma) and a loss-of-function mutation in the flaggrin (FLG) gene, which normally helps in maintaining the epidermal skin barrier. The disrupted skin barrier increases the exposure to antigen, resulting in a type I hypersensitivity reaction. The clinical presentation of AD varies among infants and children/adults:

  •  Infants: dry, itchy erythematous scaly, crusted lesions on extensor surfaces (e.g. elbows), trunk, cheeks and scalp; it spares the diaper area. 
  •  Children/Adults: lichenification of plaques in flexural areas.
Diagnosis is made based on history and clinical appearance of the lesions. Laboratory investigations may reveal elevated IgE levels and peripheral eosinophilia. Treatment options include avoiding triggers (excessive bathing, dry environments, stress, overheating) and application of topical emollient, with or without topical corticosteroids.  

Option Analysis

❌ Seborrheic dermatitis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic dermatitis ranges in presentation from mild scaliness (dandruff) in the scalp to involving a wide area of skin with well-demarcated, erythematous, greasy, scaly lesions. Crusting of lesions and the development of painful vesicular eruption is not typically observed.
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is an immune-mediated hyperproliferative skin disorder that can result in well-demarcated erythematous lesions with silver-scaling plaques and pruritus. Although extensor areas of the elbows are involved, it usually does not affect children or complicate into a vesicular eruption.
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratosis usually presents as a waxy, “stuck on” lesion on the face or trunk, mostly in elderly patients. Scaly, erythematous, crusted lesions are unlikely.
✅ Atopic dermatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lichen planus:
Incorrect: Lichen planus presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques. It usually affects the ankles and the volar surface of wrists. Involvement of the trunk and extensor surfaces with erythematous vesicular eruption suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to a primary care physician for evaluation of worsening gynecomastia for three years. The patient smokes marijuana regularly but does not take medications for any underlying medical conditions. Examination reveals a well-appearing male with Tanner IV breast tissue, Tanner V pubic hair and a 5 cm mobile mass superior to the left gonad. The patient’s right gonad is not palpable. The patient noticed the mass one year prior, but thought it was normal and never sought evaluation. An ultrasound is conducted, which reveals a cystic mass with fluid levels. A biopsy is conducted, revealing seminiferous tubules with small round Sertoli cells and both primordial follicles and follicular cells. Which of the following is an additional clinical finding to be expected with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a testicular mass containing follicular cells. This finding is pathognomonic for an ovotesticular disorder – a rare disease arising from errors in gene expression regulating sexual development.

Sexual development occurs in two stages: the initial phase of sex determination, followed by sexual differentiation. Initially, inheritance of the Y chromosome and expression of its genetic content drives development of the gonad towards testicle formation. In the second phase of sexual differentiation, the secretion of growth factors and intercellular paracrine signalling (driven by the genes listed in the above table) drives external genital development and maturation. The secretion of testosterone and anti-mullerian factor by Leydig and Sertoli cells, respectively, induces development of the male sexual organs.

Patients with ovotesticular disorder have formerly been characterized as true hermaphrodites (note that although still widely used, this is now considered a pejorative term). Most patients are found to have ambiguous genitalia at birth. Phenotypic males present with cryptorchidism and hypospadia, later progressing to scrotal pain and gynecomastia during puberty. Phenotypic females present with labial fusion and urogenital sinus, later presenting with primary amenorrhea and infertility.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ambiguous genitalia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Imperforate hymen  :
Incorrect: Imperforate hymen refers to a congenital condition where the hymen completely obstructs the vagina.  
❌ Bifid uterus:
Incorrect: Also known as a bicornuate uterus, this is a congenital condition where the uterus is divided into two separate chambers. This condition is associated with preterm labor, recurrent miscarriage, and fetal malpresentation.  
❌ Labial hypoplasia:
Incorrect: Labial hypoplasia is a developmental abnormality where one labia is smaller or absent compared to the other. Labial hypoplasia is often corrected with cosmetic surgery and is not associated with other disorders of sexual development.  
❌ Testicular cancer  :
Incorrect: Although this patient presents with a lump on the superior pole of his testicle, it’s important to consider the results of the biopsy specimen, which reveals ovarian tissue within the testicle – suggesting an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of worsening abdominal pain over the past three months. He has not had a bowel movement in three days. The patient’s parent reports an 11-lb (5 kg) weight loss and fevers most nights over this same time period. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates abdominal distension and diffuse tenderness to palpation with a positive fluid wave test. A CT scan of the abdomen shows para-aortic and mesenteric lymph node enlargement and a 7cm x 7cm enhancing mesenteric mass. A biopsy of one of the aforementioned lymph nodes is performed, and the histologic findings are demonstrated below.  


Reproduced from: Flickr  
Which of the following chromosomal translocations is most likely present in cells obtained from the lymph node?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with signs of a bowel obstruction secondary to an enlarging abdominal mass and biopsy results confirming the diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma (BL). BL is highly associated with translocations involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 (most commonly to chromosome 14), resulting in overexpression of the MYC transcription factor. MYC is a major regulator of aerobic glycolysis, which is predominantly seen in tumors demonstrating rapid cell growth.

Two distinct clinical forms of BL are seen in children: endemic and sporadic (non-endemic). The endemic variant is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections and typically present as a rapidly growing mandibular mass. Currently, this variant is seen most commonly in regions of Africa where EBV is endemic. In contrast, the sporadic variant typically presents with abdominal symptoms and often involves the ileocecal junction, resulting in bowel obstructions and ascites.

Biopsy of the mass or adjacent lymph nodes is necessary for diagnosis. A tissue sample of BL classically demonstrates a "starry sky” appearance. The “sky” is composed of a large number of medium-sized neoplastic B-cells with minimal cytoplasm. The “stars” are tingible-body macrophages that contain dead neoplastic cells. Upon fixation, the peripheral cytoplasmic space surrounding the phagocytosed debris is washed away, creating round white spaces.  




Option Analysis

✅ t(8;14)   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ t(9;22)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(9;22), also known as the Philadelphia translocation, is associated with the majority of chronic myeloid leukemia cases (CML). CML occurs in older patients (50-60 years old). A peripheral blood analysis reveals a significant leukocytosis with the presence of basophilia and eosinophilia. This young child’s presentation and biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ t(12;21)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(12;21) is the most common chromosomal rearrangement in childhood B-cell acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). The peak incidence of ALL is in children aged 2-5, who usually present with episodes of bleeding (e.g., petechiae, hematoma). This patient’s biopsy findings suggest a different condition.   
❌ t(14;18)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(14;18) is associated with follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which are variants of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma presents as a slowly progressive, painless lymphadenopathy, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma typically presents in adults. This young child’s presentation and biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ t(11;14)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(11;14) is associated with mantle cell lymphoma, which is more common in older men. This young child’s presentation and biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for an annual well-visit. He has no complaints and feels well. His past medical history is significant for diabetes and asthma, for which he takes metformin and inhaled corticosteroids and albuterol as needed. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past forty-five years. Vitals are within normal limits. Oral examination reveals poor dentition with multiple cavities and dark-stained teeth. A thin, white patch with well-defined margins is noted on the left upper palate, as seen in the image below. The physician attempts to scrape it off with a tongue depressor but cannot do so. Which of the following factors is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Ebstein Barr virus infection of squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
Oral leukoplakia is a premalignant lesion that presents as a white patch on the oral mucosa. Risk factors for developing oral leukoplakia are similar to those predisposing to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), including alcohol and tobacco use (smoked and especially smokeless).    

Oral leukoplakia most commonly presents as a uniformly thin, white patch with well-defined margins. The growth can be irregular, flat, nodular, or exophytic in other cases. It is important to note that oral leukoplakia cannot be scraped off, unlike oral thrush. Oral leukoplakia is a premalignant lesion, and biopsy is necessary to determine the extent of dysplasia.    

After exposure to a carcinogen, hyperplasia is the first cellular change, and persistent exposure results in atrophy, or cellular degeneration. Following chronic exposure, irreversible cell damage takes hold, manifesting as either apoptosis or malignant transformation. Thus oral leukoplakia can histologically present at any of these stages of cellular change: hyperkeratosis, mild dysplasia, moderate dysplasia, severe dysplasia, or carcinoma in-situ. 

Option Analysis

✅ History of cigarette smoking:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhaled corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Inhaled corticosteroids are a risk factor for oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush). Although this patient uses inhaled steroids to treat his asthma, oral thrush can be easily scraped off with a tongue depressor.
❌ Inhaled albuterol:
Incorrect: Inhaled albuterol is not a risk factor for the development of leukoplakia. 
❌  Ebstein Barr virus infection of squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: Oral hairy leukoplakia is an Epstein Barr virus-mediated mucocutaneous condition in which the virus most commonly infects the squamous epithelium of the tongue. Hairy leukoplakia presents as a white lesion on the lateral margin of the tongue with “feathery” projections. 
❌ Poor oral hygiene:
Incorrect: Poor oral hygiene can be a risk factor for developing various oral conditions, including oral thrush and leukoplakia. However, cigarette smoking is a more significant risk factor for the development of leukoplakia.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless, enlarging mass on the right side of his face over the past several months. He has no significant past medical history and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a right-sided, non-tender, mobile, preauricular mass extending to the angle of the mandible. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. A biopsy of the mass is scheduled. Pathological examination demonstrates the proliferation of ductal myoepithelial and epithelial cells with a marked increase in stromal components. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed if this patient’s condition remains untreated?

choices.text: Inability to close the right eye

questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenomas are benign tumors consisting of ductal epithelial and myoepithelial cells. The presence of both epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation defines this tumor as “pleomorphic.” Pleomorphic adenomas predominantly affect the parotid gland, although other salivary glands (e.g. submandibular) can be implicated.  

Pleomorphic adenomas typically present as slow-growing, mobile, painless masses. Symptoms and signs depend on the size, location, and potential to undergo malignant transformation. The facial nerve (CN VII) originates in the brainstem and travels through the temporal bone before exiting the stylomastoid foramen. The subsequent branches of the facial nerve emanate from the body of the parotid gland and divide before innervating the muscles controlling facial expression. Therefore, symptoms of facial nerve weakness can occur if the parotid tumor grows or if it undergoes malignant change. With advancing disease, this nerve impingement may result in findings of ipsilateral eyebrow drooping, inability to close the eye, the disappearance of the nasolabial fold, and drooping at the affected corner of the mouth. 

Option Analysis

✅ Inability to close the right eye:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right-sided facial sensation loss:
Incorrect: Facial sensation (ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular divisions) are mediated by the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This patient’s mass is more likely to cause another neurological deficit. 
❌ Right-sided ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis:
Incorrect: Horner syndrome is a condition characterized by ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and facial anhidrosis (loss of sweating) due to a disruption in sympathetic innervation. This syndrome occurs more commonly in the setting of a lung tumor involving the apex (Pancoast tumor). 
❌ Right-sided sensorineural hearing loss:
Incorrect: Although pleomorphic adenoma most commonly occurs in the salivary glands, it can arise in other parts of the head and neck; a rare location of pleomorphic adenomas is the ear canal. Conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss, would occur if present in this location. 
❌ Loss of the gag reflex:
Incorrect: The afferent limb of the gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), whereas the efferent limb is carried by the vagus nerve (CN X). While this patient’s salivary gland tumor (pleomorphic adenoma) can grow and impinge the facial nerve (CN VII), resulting in facial nerve palsy, the gag reflex would remain unaffected.

questions.text: A 50-year-old individual presents to the physician for evaluation of persistent diarrhea and a skin rash for the past week. The patient’s diarrhea began one week ago, is watery, and persists even during fasting. Yesterday, the patient noticed blood in the stool as well. In addition, the patient started experiencing a painful rash on their neck, shoulders, and the palms of their hands. The patient was diagnosed with acute leukemia six months ago and received a bone marrow transplantation two months ago after chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a maculopapular rash is noted on the shoulders, arms, palms, and soles. Oral examination reveals the presence of mouth ulcers. On laboratory tests, serum alkaline phosphatase and serum bilirubin are elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Immune response of graft T-cells against recipient’s cells
Immune response of graft B-cells against recipient’s antigens
Immune response of recipient’s T-cells against graft antigens

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), which is a common complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Although GVHD is mostly seen in bone marrow transplantation, it can also occur in solid organ transplantation with rich lymphocytes (e.g., liver) or even when giving un-irradiated blood.  

Graft-versus-host disease is a systemic disorder that occurs after the graft’s immune cells recognize the antigens of the host cells and induce damage to the recipient’s tissues. For GVHD to occur, three components must be met:  

 1.      The graft (transplanted organ) must contain immunocompetent cells (e.g. bone marrow transplant).  
 2.      The recipient must be immunocompromised and thus incapable of mounting an immune response to eliminate the transplanted immunocompetent cells.
 3.      The transplanted immune cells must recognize the alloantigens of the host cells as foreign or non-self.

GVHD is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that is mediated by T-cells – specifically, both T-helper cells (CD4+) and cytotoxic T-cells (CD8+) cells. It develops when these donor T-cells recognize antigens on the recipient’s cells due to a mismatch between the major and/or minor histocompatibility antigens between the host and recipient. GVHD develops when the donor T-cells recognize the recipient’s MHC proteins as foreign and induce an inflammatory response damaging the host cells.  



Patients with acute GVHD usually present with a pruritic or painful erythematous maculopapular rash. The rash typically involves the shoulders, nape of the neck, palms, and soles. However, in severe cases, the rash may be generalized, and patients may have blisters and ulcers. In addition, patients usually have gastrointestinal manifestations, including secretory watery diarrhea that persists during fasting and may progress to bloody diarrhea if ulcers in the gastrointestinal tract develop. Some patients may also have vomiting and nausea. Finally, the liver is usually involved (unless the transplanted organ is the liver), which manifests as elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin.  

Finally, despite the harmful consequences of GVHD, it can sometimes be used for beneficial effects in leukemia patients, wherein the donor lymphocytes attack the recipient's malignant cells, a process known as graft versus leukemia effect.   



Option Analysis

✅ Immune response of graft T-cells against recipient’s cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Immune response of graft B-cells against recipient’s antigens :
Incorrect: Graft-versus-host disease is due to host T-cells attacking the recipient’s antigens; B cells are not involved in GVHD. 
❌ Immune response of recipient’s T-cells against graft antigens :
Incorrect: In graft-versus-host disease, the graft T-cells attack and damage the antigens in the recipient. 
❌ Infection with cytomegalovirus :
Incorrect: Patients with immunodeficiency (like this patient) are susceptible to CMV infection, which can lead to colitis. However, the constellation of symptoms (elevated liver enzymes, skin rash, and gastrointestinal symptoms) strongly suggest GVHD as the most likely diagnosis in this case. 
❌ Infection with Mycobacterium avium complex :
Incorrect: MAC can lead to colitis in patients with immunodeficiency. However, skin rashes and elevation of liver enzymes are not seen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a fall at a construction site. His colleague who witnessed the event reports that the patient hit his head and lost consciousness. On arrival, the patient is responsive to pain only. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. On physical examination, the skull is intact, and diffuse bruising is noted.
