Neck stiffness is present. Motor examination reveals flaccid paralysis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of hypotension, bradycardia, neck stiffness, and flaccid paralysis suggests tonsillar herniation secondary to intracranial bleeding (e.g. subdural hematoma).

Tonsillar herniation (also called downward cerebellar herniation) is a type of infratentorial herniation in which there is a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum–resulting in compression of the lower brain stem and upper cervical spinal cord. Clinical manifestations include neck stiffness, flaccid paralysis, decreased level of consciousness, disconjugate eye movements, and nystagmus. Abrupt respiratory depression and blood pressure instability occur secondary to the compression of respiratory and cardiac control centers in the brain stem. The flaccid paralysis is the result of a decreased level of consciousness.



Option Analysis

❌ Hypovolemic shock:
Incorrect: While internal bleeding can lead to hypotension, the heart rate is expected to be increased in a compensatory effort. In addition, hypovolemic shock would not explain the patient’s respiratory depression or neck stiffness.  
❌ Central transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Central transtentorial herniation refers to the downward displacement of the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This type of herniation may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Central herniation may also result in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries) known as Duret hemorrhages. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a different type of brain herniation.  
❌ Subfalcine herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation refers to the lateral displacement of the innermost part of the frontal lobe (the cingulate gyrus) under the falx cerebri. This displacement can cause compression of the anterior cerebral artery and infarction of the frontal and parietal lobes. Clinical features of cingulate herniation are not well defined but may include unilateral/bilateral weakness, loss of bladder control, and coma. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a different type of brain herniation.  
✅ Tonsillar herniation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse axonal injury  :
Incorrect: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) refers to the shearing of white matter tracts, seen commonly in motor vehicle crashes with an acceleration-deceleration mechanism. Patients are often comatose without elevated intracranial pressure at presentation. On neuroimaging, DAI is characterized by multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction. While diffuse axonal injury may occur due to falls, it would not explain the respiratory depression, hypotension, and neck stiffness in this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner because of a mild headache, dizziness, fatigue, and nausea. The patient’s partner left their lakeside cabin earlier in the day to collect more firewood for their wood-burning stove. At the time, the patient was asymptomatic, and the symptoms had developed when the partner returned three hours later. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He is confused and oriented only to person and place. The patient’s skin is dry and flushed. His gait is unsteady. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a carboxyhemoglobin level of 11%. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient’s symptoms improve after the administration of 100% supplemental oxygen. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Binding to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin
Inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase
Free radical formation and lipid peroxidation

questions.solution:
This patient with a wood-burning stove presents with nausea, headaches, dizziness, and flushed skin. His symptoms improve with administration of 100% supplemental oxygen. Together, these findings are suggestive of carbon monoxide toxicity.

Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless and odorless gas that has a high affinity for cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain. The binding of CO inhibits this enzyme, resulting in defective oxidative phosphorylation, ATP production, and aerobic metabolism. As a result, cells resort to anaerobic metabolism, resulting in lactic acidosis and eventual cell death. In addition, CO has a significantly higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen and causes a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. The end result is decreased oxygen binding capacity, increased hemoglobin affinity for oxygen, and subsequently decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.

Similarly, cyanide toxicity also inhibits cytochrome c oxidase and prevents oxidative phosphorylation. Furthermore, cyanide can bind to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin, which is unable to transport oxygen, which further exacerbates tissue hypoxia. However, unlike CO poisoning, cyanide poisoning does not affect the oxygen dissociation curve.  

Option Analysis

❌ Binding to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes cyanide poisoning. Cyanide can bind to the ferrous (Fe2+) iron in hemoglobin to form cyanohemoglobin, which is unable to transport oxygen, which leads to tissue hypoxia. Similar to carbon monoxide poisoning, cyanide toxicity also inhibits cytochrome c oxidase and prevents oxidative phosphorylation, leading to further tissue hypoxia. However, this patient has a history of using a wood-burning stove in an enclosed space, which is more concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning.  
❌ Denaturation of globin chains:
Incorrect: This finding can occur in red blood cells deficient in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). In such cells, oxidative stressors can cause hemoglobin to denature. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with carbon monoxide poisoning, which leads to inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase.  
✅ Inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of ATP synthase:
Incorrect: Oligomycin directly inhibits mitochondrial ATP synthase. In contrast, this patient has a history of using a wood-burning stove in an enclosed space, which is more concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning, which leads to inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase.  
❌ Free radical formation and lipid peroxidation:
Incorrect: Iron poisoning can lead to free radical formation and lipid peroxidation; iron toxicity presents with abdominal pain, liver failure, and hemorrhagic gastritis. In contrast, this patient has a history of using a wood-burning stove in an enclosed space, which is more concerning for carbon monoxide poisoning, which leads to inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of left hip pain. The patient’s parent noticed a left-sided limp several weeks ago and initially attributed it to a fall at the playground. The pain has persisted and is minimally relieved with rest or ibuprofen. The patient has no significant past medical history. He takes no daily medications, and immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. The child is in the 50th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows a well-appearing and cooperative child. With internal rotation and abduction of the left hip, range of motion is limited secondary to pain. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. An X-ray of the patient's hip is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
 
Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
Legg-Calvé-Perthes (LCP) disease refers to idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head. The onset of LCP disease usually occurs in children between the ages of 3 and 12 years of age and preferentially affects males.

Patients typically present with gradual, chronically worsening hip pain and/or limp that is aggravated by physical activity. As the disease progresses, the physical examination may reveal limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip. Diagnosis of LCP requires a high index of suspicion as initial radiographs are often normal. Radiographs in the later course of the disease may demonstrate increased density of the femoral head or a crescentic subchondral fracture in the femoral head termed the “crescent sign.” Treatment involves physical therapy and restriction of physical activity. Surgery may be required if conservative management fails.

Option Analysis

✅ Legg-Calvé-Perthes   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Slipped capital femoral epiphysis   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs when the femoral epiphysis is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly relative to the femoral head and neck. This condition most commonly occurs in adolescents with obesity.   
❌ Developmental dysplasia of the hip   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) presents in the first few months of life. Clinical clues include asymmetric gluteal/thigh creases, apparent limb-length discrepancy, as well as positive Barlow or Ortolani maneuvers. This patient’s age, chronic limp, and X-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ Septic arthritis   :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is a surgical emergency that involves infectious arthritis of the joint space. This patient’s presentation, including the chronic nature of his pain and paucity of systemic findings (e.g. fever), suggests a different diagnosis.   
❌ Transient synovitis   :
Incorrect: Transient synovitis, also known as toxic synovitis, is a self-limited inflammatory condition of the hip that occurs following an upper respiratory infection or diarrheal illness. This patient’s x-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 3, is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain that started 3 hours ago. She describes the pain as sharp, constant, and rates it as 7/10 in intensity. Since the pain started, she has been feeling nauseous and has vomited twice. She reports a few episodes of similar abdominal discomfort in the past but says that this time it “feels different.” Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 32 kg/m2. The patient is in acute distress due to pain and points to the upper abdomen. The abdomen is tender to touch. No rebound tenderness or hepatomegaly is present. An abdominal ultrasound is performed and reveals a normal common bile duct with concomitant gallbladder wall thickening and free fluid around the gallbladder. Laboratory results are obtained and shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  15,000 mm3 
 Platelet count    250,000 mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  90 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.8 g/dL 
 BUN  11 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase   18 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase   20 U/L 
 Amylase  55 U/L 
 Lipase  62 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   65 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (right upper quadrant pain, nausea and vomiting), laboratory findings (leukocytosis, normal liver enzymes), and results of the abdominal ultrasound are suggestive of calculous cholecystitis.   

Acute calculous cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder caused by obstruction of the cystic duct. When the cystic duct becomes obstructed by a stone, there is distension and inflammation of the gallbladder, triggering an inflammatory response within the gallbladder. Clinical features typically include intense RUQ pain, fever, and nausea. Additionally, this patient demonstrated a positive Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory pause upon palpation of the RUQ). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate leukocytosis. Marked elevation in the serum total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase concentrations are not common in uncomplicated acute cholecystitis, since obstruction of bile flow is limited to the gallbladder (mild elevations may be present, however).  

Diagnosis relies on a transabdominal ultrasound that helps to visualize the gallbladder. Typical findings in acute cholecystitis include a positive sonographic Murphy sign (sudden inspiratory arrest upon placing the ultrasound probe directly on the gallbladder), gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid (hypoechoic free fluid around the gallbladder). If an ultrasound is inconclusive, a HIDA scan (cholescintigraphy) can be performed, in which a radioactive tracer is injected intravenously; normally, the radioactive tracer would fill the gallbladder, but in cases of cystic duct obstruction, the gallbladder would not be visualized.  

Option Analysis

❌ Choledocholithiasis :
Incorrect: Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of gallstones obstructing the common bile duct. Symptoms of choledocholithiasis include right upper quadrant (RUQ) or epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes jaundice; however, the systemic symptoms and signs seen in this patient (e.g., fever, leukocytosis) would not be seen. Instead, laboratory results may show elevation of ALP, GGT, direct bilirubin, and/or AST/ALT. Additionally, ultrasound of the RUQ in choledocholithasis typically shows dilated biliary ducts.   
❌ Pancreatitis :
Incorrect: Patients with acute pancreatitis typically experience acute epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevation of serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal, and/or characteristic enlargement of the pancreas on CT with contrast. This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.    
✅ Calculous cholecystitis :
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Appendicitis :
Incorrect: Appendicitis is an acute inflammation of the appendix caused by either obstruction from a fecalith (in adults) or lymphoid hyperplasia (in children). Patients usually present with fever, abdominal pain around the umbilicus/right lower quadrant, and nausea. If perforation occurs, peritoneal signs will be seen (e.g., guarding, rebound tenderness). This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Gallstone ileus:
Incorrect: Gallstone ileus is a cause of bowel obstruction due to gallstones that enter the intestines through a cholecystoenteric fistula. It occurs secondary to cholecystitis leading to adhesion of the gallbladder to its surroundings and formation of a fistula between the gallbladder and intestine. Patients often present with intermittent abdominal pain, persistent nausea and vomiting, hematemesis and hyperactive bowel sounds. This patient’s presentation and laboratory results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and productive cough for the past year. The patient has not seen a physician in several years. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a thin woman who breathes through pursed-lip. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing bilaterally. Which of the following parameters is most likely to be increased in this patient?

choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in one second

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has shortness of breath and pursed-lip breathing in the setting of an extensive smoking history. She most likely has emphysema.

Emphysema is one of the obstructive lung diseases, which are a group of conditions characterized by obstruction of airflow and air trapping within the lungs. The underlying cause of air trapping varies based on etiology. Asthma, for example, causes air trapping due to bronchoconstriction, whereas emphysema causes air trapping due to destruction of alveolar and bronchial tissue.  

 Lung function testing in patients with obstructive lung diseases typically shows a small reduction in forced vital capacity (FVC) and significant reduction in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) because these individuals have narrow airways, which hinder how fast air can leave the lungs. Thus, the FEV1/FVC ratio is also reduced.  

Moreover, in this patient with emphysema, there is protease-mediated damage of the extracellular matrix. The loss of elastic tissue causes a two-fold impact. First, there is an increase in lung compliance (change in volume per unit change in pressure). Second, there is increased air trapping, since the loss of elastic tissue surrounding the respiratory bronchioles causes their collapse during expiration.  


Option Analysis

✅ Lung compliance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Forced vital capacity:
Incorrect: Forced vital capacity (FVC) measures the amount of air a person can breathe out forcefully after taking as deep a breath as possible. This parameter is typically decreased in patients with obstructive lung diseases due to impaired elastic recoil of the lungs. 
❌ Forced expiratory volume in one second:
Incorrect: Patients with obstructive lung diseases have a significant reduction in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), which measures the total amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled in the first second of the FVC test.
❌ Lung elastic recoil:
Incorrect: Lung elastic recoil is typically decreased in COPD as a result of destruction of elastic tissue.
❌ Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide:
Incorrect: Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is decreased in patients with emphysema, because alveolar destruction decreases the surface area for gaseous exchange.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department due to persistent vomiting and diarrhea over the past week. His parent states, “He just cannot seem to keep anything down, whenever I feed him he just vomits it right back up.” The patient attends daycare, and his parent is unsure of any sick contacts. He is otherwise healthy, vaccines are up to date, and birth history was uncomplicated. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 84/40 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam the patient is crying but consolable and is noted to have diminished tear production. Which of the following best describes the most likely electrolyte abnormality present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of gastroenteritis, dehydration, and volume loss without adequate repletion. Of the listed metabolic disturbances, hypernatremia with concurrent hypokalemia is most likely to occur due to loss of water and potassium via stool.  

Sodium is primarily found in the extracellular fluid and is the primary driver of tonicity in the human body. Hypernatremia either occurs when more water is lost than sodium or when more sodium is retained compared to water. Most often, hypernatremia results from water losses. This includes losses through the skin, gastrointestinal tract, or kidneys. Common precipitants include heavy exercise without adequate water intake, gastroenteritis, and osmotic diuresis (e.g., mannitol, diabetes mellitus). Over ingestion or increased intake of sodium relative to water is less common but is encountered with massive salt intake or when hyponatremia is corrected too quickly.  

Symptoms of hypernatremia depend on the severity, with minor hypernatremia causing irritability, twitching, and weakness, while severe hypernatremia can result in lethargy, seizures, and coma.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hypernatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia is not a commonly implicated electrolyte abnormality in the setting of gastroenteritis. It is more commonly associated with malignancy and hypoparathyroidism.
❌ Hypermagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypermagnesemia is not commonly implicated in the setting of gastroenteritis. Hypermagnesemia would be more likely in conditions such as tumor lysis syndrome, primary hyperparathyroidism, and overuse of magnesium-containing drugs (e.g., cathartics, laxatives). 
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal fluid loss may activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and result in hypokalemia. In contrast, hyperkalemia is more commonly associated with etiologies that release potassium from cells (e.g., rhabdomyolysis, tumor lysis syndrome) or decrease renal excretion of potassium (e.g., hypoaldosteronism, kidney injury).
❌ Hyponatremia :
Incorrect: Hyponatremia is possible in the context of gastrointestinal losses and diarrhea. However, it is more likely to be observed in patients who are adequately repleting their volume status with free water. This patient has been unable to tolerate oral intake, hence making this answer choice less likely.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old female presents to the emergency department with worsening lower extremity edema. In addition, her urine has appeared more foamy than usual. Past medical history includes HIV, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and intravenous heroin use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 157/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is noted to have 2+ peripheral edema of the lower extremities and acanthosis nigricans over the neck. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. A urinalysis is notable for 4+ protein and negative for blood. The patient subsequently undergoes a renal biopsy with the light microscopy finding as below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia     

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of heroin use and HIV presents with clinical features concerning nephrotic syndrome. The biopsy and light microscopy findings demonstrate segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis due to deposition of lipids and proteins within the glomerulus, which is consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.   

 Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in patients of African-American and Hispanic descent. The underlying cause of the disease is not well-established, but is associated with multiple comorbidities including HIV, sickle cell disease, heroin use, obesity, recent interferon treatment, and congenital malformations.   

The disease only affects some glomeruli and particular segments of the glomeruli, hence the nomenclature. Light microscopy will demonstrate segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis, while immunofluorescence is generally negative but will sometimes stain positive for C3, C1, or IgM. Electron microscopy will typically demonstrate podocyte foot effacement, similar to minimal change disease.  

Treatment consists of a trial of corticosteroid therapy. Unfortunately, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis has an inconsistent response to corticosteroids, and some patients may progress to chronic kidney disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Minimal change disease :
Incorrect: Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and is usually idiopathic. Light microscopy findings in these patients are usually normal, although lipid can sometimes be seen in the proximal convoluted tubule. In contrast, this patient’s biopsy result shows segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.
❌ Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis :
Incorrect: On light microscopy, patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis can present with a crescent moon-shaped glomeruli. The crescent consists of fibrin and plasma proteins. In contrast, this patient’s biopsy result shows segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.
❌ Diabetic glomerulonephropathy :
Incorrect: Light microscopy findings for diabetic glomerulonephropathy include mesangial expansion, glomerular basement membrane thickening, and characteristic Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. No Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules are present on this patient biopsy result.
❌ Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis :
Incorrect: This disease often occurs in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus and demonstrates wire looping on light microscopy.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 4, presents to the clinic for the evaluation of vaginal spotting between menses for the past 2 months. Her cycles were regular before that. She has no history of dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia. Menarche was at age 13 years. Past medical history is significant for breast cancer, generalized anxiety disorder, hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include tamoxifen, paroxetine, amlodipine and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows a normal-sized uterus without tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a pedunculated pearl-shaped mass arising from the uterine body. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface

questions.solution:
This patient with intermenstrual bleeding while on tamoxifen therapy and the ultrasound finding of pedunculated pearl-shaped mass most likely has an endometrial polyp.  

An endometrial polyp is defined as the hyperplastic overgrowth of endometrial glands and stroma from the surface of the endometrium. It can occur in both premenopausal or postmenopausal women and typically presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. Intermenstrual bleeding is the most frequent symptom in premenopausal women with endometrial polyps. However, it may sometimes be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging or abnormal cervical cytology.  

Risk factors include obesity, tamoxifen therapy and hormone replacement therapy, all of which stimulate the endometrial tissue, resulting in its proliferation, which may lead to the development of endometrial polyps, hyperplasia, or cancer. Physical examination is usually normal except in the case of a prolapsed polyp, in which a friable, pedunculated lesion can be seen protruding from the external cervical os. Ultrasound helps in localizing the lesion while definitive diagnosis is established on histologic evaluation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial tissue in the myometrium:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. Although abnormal uterine bleeding is commonly seen, the condition is associated with abdominal pain and an enlarged, boggy and tender uterus on examination.
✅ Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inflammation of the endometrium:
Incorrect: Inflammation of endometrium (endometritis) commonly presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain and fever. The condition is usually associated with recent childbirth, an intrauterine procedure, or a genitourinary infection.
❌ Benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation:
Incorrect: Uterine leiomyoma (fibroids) result from benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation. The condition usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menses, mass-effect symptoms such as constipation and an irregularly enlarged uterus. This patient has a normal-sized uterus.
❌ Ectopic endometrial tissue:
Incorrect: Endometriosis refers to presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. It commonly presents with dysmenorrhea (not intermenstrual bleeding), pelvic pain and deep dyspareunia. The uterus is normal in size but is usually immobile (fixed).

questions.text: A 1-day-old female newborn is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for severe respiratory distress and cyanosis. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman who had minimal prenatal care. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 150/min, blood pressure is 87/55 mm Hg, and respiration rate is 60/min. An electrocardiogram reveals left axis deviation with a superior axis and chest x-ray shows decreased pulmonary markings and a hypoplastic right ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tricuspid valve atresia is a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by congenital agenesis or absence of the tricuspid valve which results in the absence of direct communication between the right atrium and ventricle. If left untreated, tricuspid atresia has a high mortality rate, with a survival rate as low as 10% at 1 year of life.  

The chest radiograph in patients with decreased pulmonary flow will often show decreased pulmonary markings due to decreased bloodflow from the right ventricle to the lungs. Cyanotic heart diseases of the newborn can be divided according to the level of pulmonary flow as follows:  

 


The electrocardiogram (ECG) in healthy newborn infants often shows right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy in the first few days of life. Deviation from this physiologic axis can assist in establishing the diagnosis. In patients with tricuspid valve atresia, surface ECG demonstrates tall P waves and left axis deviation with a superior axis (>30°), indicating LV hypertrophy, and diminished RV forces due to a hypoplastic right ventricle. In a cyanotic infant, the above findings are considered pathognomonic for tricuspid valve atresia.  

Initial management includes cardiorespiratory support and medications for stabilization, followed by surgical correction.    

Option Analysis

❌ D-transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: The initial electrocardiogram (ECG) in infants with D-transposition of the great vessels (D-TGA) is often normal. In addition, despite having marked hypoxemia, D-TGA pulmonary markings on chest x-ray are normal or increased, rather than decreased. D-TGA often presents with classic chest radiograph features of a heart with an “egg on a string” appearance. 
❌ Persistent truncus arteriosus:
Incorrect: The electrocardiogram findings in patients with persistent truncus arteriosus (TA) are often nonspecific and may be normal. In addition, chest radiograph in TA typically shows cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings. 
❌ Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) :
Incorrect: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR), in which all four pulmonary veins return to the right heart instead of the left side, often presents with non-specific findings on electrocardiogram. The chest radiograph can be normal or may show the classic “snowman” sign. 
❌ Tetralogy of Fallot:
Incorrect: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) also causes decreased pulmonary flow; however, the electrocardiogram in TOF typically shows right axis deviation, prominent R waves anteriorly and S waves posteriorly due right atrial enlargement and right ventricular hypertrophy. This patient has a hypoplastic right ventricle, suggestive of a different condition. 
✅ Tricuspid atresia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to academic decline and bizarre behavior for the past 6 months. He used to be a straight-A student, but during the past 2 years, he has been failing exams and repeatedly getting in trouble with teachers. The teachers report that he speaks out of turn, interrupts other students, and makes inappropriate gestures. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is constantly blinking and clears his throat frequently. Occasionally, the patient points the middle finger at the doctor, and doing so appears to cause the patient distress. The parents are embarrassed and concerned about their son's demeanor. Which of the following best describes this patient's behavior?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with academic decline, vocal tics (clears throat), and motor tics (blinking, obscene gestures) that have been present for more than 1 year, all favoring the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome (TS). The disruptive behavior is most likely due to concurrent attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, present in up to 60% of the cases of TS.  

Tics are defined as swift, abrupt, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). Although considered involuntary, tics can temporarily be voluntarily suppressed. Tics can be primary (e.g., Tourette syndrome, transient motor tics) or secondary (e.g., Wilson disease, post encephalitis). Tics can be further divided into simple and complex tics. This vignette’s inappropriate gesture refers to copropraxia, a complex tic manifested by involuntary obscene/forbidden gestures.    

TS is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and phonic tics that occur during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to disturbance in the cortico-striatal-thalamic-cortical (mesolimbic) circuit which results in disinhibition of the limbic system and motor. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition. The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical presentation with onset before age 18.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Echolalia:
Incorrect: Echolalia refers to the involuntary repetition/imitation of another person's vocalizations. 
❌ Echopraxia:
Incorrect: Echopraxia refers to the involuntary repetition/imitation of another person's actions. 
✅ Copropraxia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Coprolalia:
Incorrect: Coprolalia is the involuntary and repetitive use of obscene or socially inappropriate language.
❌ Palilalia :
Incorrect: Palilalia refers to repetition of a word or a phrase with increasing speed.

questions.text: An 85-year-old female is brought to the emergency department due to acute-onset involuntary flinging movements of the right side of her body for the past several hours. The patient has a medical history significant for long-standing hypertension treated with lisinopril but is healthy otherwise. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 155/102 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is orientated and cooperating. Involuntary movements of the proximal and distal muscles on the right side are noted. Motor and sensorial examinations are within normal ranges. Carotid and vertebral artery doppler investigations are normal. Cardiac investigations including echocardiography and electrocardiography are normal. An MRI is obtained, and a diagnosis is made. Aspirin 300 mg and atorvastatin therapies are initiated, and the patient's symptoms resolve gradually in the following 1-day period. This patient’s condition is best characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset of hemiballismus likely due to a lacunar infarct of the basal ganglia as a consequence of long-standing hypertension.  

Ballism refers to involuntary movements of the proximal limbs, characterized by large-amplitude, flinging or kicking motions. Ballism is often unilateral (hemiballism), present at rest, and worsened by activity. Traditionally, hemiballism was pathognomonic of a lesion of the contralateral subthalamic nucleus (STN). However, recent evidence suggests that other locations are often involved, including the caudate nucleus, putamen, thalamus, and globus pallidus. Most stroke lesions causing hemichorea/hemiballism seem to involve a common functional network connected to the posterolateral putamen.    
The basal ganglia system is important in regulating movement. Damage or malfunction of these structures disrupts the balance between the indirect and direct pathways in the basal ganglia circuitry, leading to excessive dopaminergic activity. Disruption to the indirect pathway results in loss of inhibition to the globus pallidus, which in turn allows hyperkinetic movements to occur. Chorea, athetosis, and ballism often coexist in the same patient and are considered to be a part of the choreiform spectrum.    

High-yield note: For the purposes of USMLE examinations, keep in mind the association between the subthalamic nucleus and contralateral hemiballismus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Dystonia :
Incorrect: Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by sustained, involuntary muscle contractions that result in repetitive movements or an abnormal fixed posture. It may be focal or generalized. Writer's dystonia, also known as writer's cramp is an example of task-specific hand dystonia elicited by writing. However, this patient’s acute onset of rapid, large-amplitude movement favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Myoclonus :
Incorrect: Myoclonus is a brief, involuntary, twitch of a muscle or group of muscles caused by muscular contractions or inhibitions. Muscular contractions manifest as positive myoclonus, while muscular inhibitions produce negative myoclonus such as asterixis. Myoclonus is often described as jerks, shakes, or spasms. However, this patient’s acute onset and resolution of rapid, large-amplitude movement favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Chorea :
Incorrect: Chorea is a type of hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by brief, involuntary and unpredictable contractions of the distal limbs and, less commonly, the face and trunk. The movements seen in chorea are non-patterned, and vary in speed, timing, and direction. Although chorea and ballism are thought to be a part of the same choreiform spectrum, ballismus is characterized by proximal and large amplitude movements, in contrast to the distal, low-amplitude movements of chorea.   
✅ Hemiballism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Athetosis :
Incorrect: Athetosis is a neurological condition characterized by slow, writhing movements of the fingers. The term "choreoathetosis" is often used when chorea and athetosis coexist.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her partner due to rapidly progressive paranoia and personality changes for the past month. The partner first noticed that the patient kept forgetting small things, such as the neighbors’ names, but he began to worry when she started becoming paranoid and accusing him of stealing money from her purse. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient looks anxious. When asked if she knows how to use a pen, the patient takes it and tries to blow air through it. Eye examination reveals bilateral nystagmus. During the examination, the patient exhibits random jerking movement of the legs and kicks the table. A lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following would most likely be found in this patient's cerebrospinal fluid?

choices.text: Elevated IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF
Elevated protein levels with normal cell count

questions.solution:
The presence of rapidly progressive (1 month) dementia, memory loss, personality changes and abnormal movements (myoclonus) raises concern for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).  

 CJD belongs to the prion disease family, a group of transmissible, fatal neurodegenerative diseases with long incubation periods and rapid progression once clinical symptoms appear. Prions are small, misfolded, infectious, protein-containing particles (PrPSc) that replicate and replace normal prion proteins (PrPC) over time, resulting in neurotoxicity. CJD can be sporadic (unknown cause) or genetic, due to mutations of the gene encoding the prion protein.    

Diagnosis of CJD involves several different modalities, as follows:

  •  Neuroimaging with MRI is the best initial test for evaluating CJD. Brain MRI excludes other potential causes of dementia and also can suggest CJD as the underlying etiology. On a brain MRI, CJD classically shows enhancement of the basal ganglia and thalamus. 
  •  Periodic sharp wave complexes are the hallmark EEG finding in patients with CJD. The fusion of dendritic membranes of affected neurons result in increased electrotonic coupling and synchronized bursting activity. 
  • Detection of protein 14-3-3 in cerebrospinal fluid is classically seen in patients with CJD; it occurs due to acute neuronal damage.


Option Analysis

✅ 14-3-3 protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF:
Incorrect: Elevated IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF can be seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune neurodegenerative disease characterized by immune-mediated inflammatory demyelination of the central nervous system. Common presenting symptoms include pyramidal signs (e.g., weakness, spasticity), cerebellar syndromes (e.g., diplopia, ataxia), and spinal cord symptoms (e.g., neurogenic bladder, paraparesis).   
❌ S100B protein:
Incorrect: S100B protein is widely used as a measure of glial activity (primarily by astrocytes) or damage. S100B is elevated in cerebrospinal fluid in acute brain injury, such as trauma or stroke, as well as infections. 
❌ Elevated protein levels with normal cell count:
Incorrect: Elevated CSF protein with normal cell count (albuminocytologic dissociation) is characteristic of acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy, the most common subtype of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). The condition is characterized by symmetric ascending muscle weakness/paralysis, facial paralysis (usually bilateral) and respiratory failure. Although the exact cause is unknown, it is often associated with infections (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni).  
❌ Low glucose:
Incorrect: An abnormally low glucose level in the cerebrospinal fluid can indicate possible bacterial infection, fungal infection, a tumor, hypoglycemia, or inflammation of the central nervous system. This patient has no fever or headache, which makes an infection or tumor unlikely.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of daily headaches and blurry vision. These symptoms started two months ago. In addition, the patient reports feeling itchy over his body after bathing or visiting the sauna. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and asymptomatic gallstones were discovered on a recent ultrasound. The patient is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year smoking history. On the physical exam, the patient is observed to have facial plethora and a spleen palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory testing is ordered and the results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  18.1 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  54% 
 Erythrocytes  7.2 million/mm3 
 Leukocytes  12,500/mm3 
 Platelets  470,000/mm3 
 Uric Acid  7.9 mg/dL 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Increased erythrocyte production secondary to hypoxia
Deposition of bile acids in the skin
Autoimmune destruction of myelin in the central nervous system

questions.solution:
This patient has polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative neoplasm most commonly caused by a Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2) gene mutation. The mutation allows myeloid cell lines, most notably erythrocytes, to proliferate in the absence of erythropoietin (EPO). Patients may also present with elevated leukocyte and platelet counts.  

Patients present with a combination of constitutional symptoms and symptoms secondary to increased blood viscosity. Constitutional symptoms include weight loss and fatigue. Hyperviscosity leads to visual changes, facial plethora, and hepatosplenomegaly. Patients will also have elevated mast cell and basophil cell counts due to leukocyte proliferation. This causes pruritus that is exacerbated by hot temperatures.  

Work-up includes getting a complete blood count (CBC), uric acid level, and EPO level. CBC will show significantly elevated RBC counts in combination with mildly elevated leukocyte and platelet counts. Uric acid levels are elevated due to increased cell turnover. EPO levels will be below the normal reference range.  

Phlebotomy is used to reduce RBC count and viscosity. Aspirin can be administered to reduce the risk of thrombosis. Cytoreduction agents such ruxolitinib (a JAK2 inhibitor) can be administered in severe cases to slow down neoplastic cell proliferation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased erythrocyte production secondary to hypoxia:
Incorrect: Hypoxia causes the release of erythropoietin (EPO) and results in increased red blood cell production. This may account for the patient’s elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit. However, hypoxia would not account for the elevated leukocyte and platelet count or the splenomegaly observed in this patient.
✅ Erythropoietin-independent proliferation of erythrocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased blood plasma volume:
Incorrect: This describes relative polycythemia. The condition is often secondary to dehydration or fluid loss via burns, wherein the individual’s blood plasma volume decreases dramatically while the RBC count remains roughly unchanged. The net result is hemoconcentration. However, no part of the patient’s history or physical exam suggests that he is volume depleted.  
❌ Deposition of bile acids in the skin :
Incorrect: Cholestasis can cause pruritis secondary to the accumulation and deposition of bile acids in the skin. This patient’s gallstones may obstruct the common bile duct, cause choledocolithiasis, and impede bile flow. However, patients with choledocolithiasis typically have additional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant tenderness. The patient in this vignette has none of these symptoms.  
❌ Autoimmune destruction of myelin in the central nervous system:
Incorrect: This describes multiple sclerosis, which may cause symptoms including vision impairment, headaches, paresthesias, and impaired coordination. This patient endorses vision changes and headaches. However, multiple sclerosis typically presents between 20-40 years-old. Moreover, multiple sclerosis would not account for the patient’s elevated RBC, WBC, and platelet counts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the labor and delivery triage at 24 weeks gestation due to severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and contractions. Pregnancy has been uneventful other than hypertension of 149/90 during her last visit. She has been compliant with prenatal care and took prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack per day for 10 years which she reduced during pregnancy to half a pack per day. She is otherwise healthy and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears in acute distress due to pain. Pelvic examination shows a rigid and tender uterus. High-frequency and low-amplitude uterine contractions are noted. There is minimal bleeding present in the vaginal vault. There is no change in fetal station. The fetal heart rate is 160 bpm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This primigravida woman is presenting with sudden onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, high-frequency/low-amplitude uterine contractions, and signs of fetal distress (tachycardia), favoring the diagnosis of abruptio placenta.    

Abruptio placenta (placental abruption) is the premature separation of all or a part of the placenta from the uterine wall, resulting in hemorrhage. Placental abruption typically occurs after 20 weeks gestation. The clinical findings are vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, high-frequency/low-amplitude uterine contractions, uterine tenderness, and uterine rigidity. The uterine tachysystole occurs due to blood penetrating the myometrial wall, resulting in irritation and subsequent contractions and rigidity. The vaginal bleeding may be concealed and accumulate between the fetal membranes and decidua. Placental abruption is associated with significant maternal morbidity and neonatal morbidity and mortality. Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation and imaging; typically an ultrasound will show a retroplacental collection of blood. Management depends on the maternal and fetal stability and includes supportive care with/or without emergent cesarean section. Risk factors for the development of placental abruption include maternal hypertension, prior placental abruption, cocaine use, smoking, and trauma.  



Option Analysis

❌ Uterine rupture :
Incorrect: Uterine rupture also presents with abdominal pain with/without hemodynamic changes, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and fetal heart rate changes (most commonly bradycardia). However, loss of fetal station (station refers to the stage of the presenting fetal part; therefore, loss of station means regression of the fetus back into the uterus because of the rupture), cessation of contractions (as opposed to this patient’s high-frequency/low-amplitude contractions), and changes in uterine contour are also expected. Risk factors are previous classical uterine incision and myomectomy.
✅ Placenta abruption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implantation over the internal cervical os that covers all or part of the cervix. The classic presentation is painless late-pregnancy vaginal bleeding. Significant risk factors include previous cesarean deliveries, previous uterine surgery, multiple gestations, and previous placenta previa. The presence of pain and a tender uterus in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Chorioamnionitis :
Incorrect: Chorioamnionitis refers to an acute inflammation of the amniotic membranes and chorion. Chorioamnionitis is typically seen in women with prelabor rupture of membranes (which allows for bacterial migration and colonization) but can also occur with intact membranes. Symptoms include fever, maternal and fetal tachycardia, uterine tenderness, bacteremia, and purulent or malodorous amniotic fluid. Maternal fever is required for diagnosis and is not seen in this patient. 
❌ Placenta accreta:
Incorrect: Placenta accreta refers to a placenta that attaches to the myometrium without penetrating it. Placenta accreta presents as a life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs after delivery when manual placental separation is attempted. This patient has not yet delivered, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old female presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and lethargy. The patient is currently undergoing treatment for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and last received chemotherapy two days ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 92/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. On physical exam, she is pale and ill-appearing, intermittently convulsing, and has tenderness to palpation over the left flank. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Urine  
 Erythrocytes  20/hpf 
 Leukocytes  30/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)   >3%  
 Urine Microscopy  + uric acid crystals 
 
Which of the following metabolic derangements best explains this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has nausea, vomiting, and tetany shortly after receiving chemotherapy for a hematologic malignancy. The urinalysis demonstrates uric acid crystals and a fractional excretion of sodium >3% consistent with acute kidney injury and pre-renal azotemia. This presentation is likely due to tumor lysis syndrome.  

Laboratory derangements associated with tumor lysis syndrome include hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperuricemia. The primary pathologic driver of this process is the rapid lysis of tumor cells and subsequent release of intracellular phosphate, which binds serum calcium. Calcium phosphate, in addition to uric acid, can then deposit in the renal tubules leading to acute kidney injury.  

Phosphate is primarily found intracellularly and is an important determinant of serum pH. Phosphate also plays a key role in the synthesis of nucleotides, ATP, and metabolic intermediates. Serum levels become elevated when the excretory capacity of the kidneys becomes overwhelmed due to endocrinopathies or release from intracellular stores. Etiologies of hyperphosphatemia include hypoparathyroidism, diGeorge syndrome, or increased phosphate load via laxative abuse. Additional causes that release intracellular phosphate include crush injuries, rhabdomyolysis, and tumor lysis syndrome.  

Unlike other metabolic derangements, hyperphosphatemia in and of itself does not cause specific symptoms. Rather, hyperphosphatemia causes symptoms associated with its concomitant electrolyte derangements.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperphosphatemia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperglycemia :
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia may present with lethargy, nausea, and vomiting in the setting of diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. Although hyperglycemia can also be seen as part of the body’s stress response, blood glucose levels under these conditions would not typically be high enough to account for this patient’s symptoms. 
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal losses may present with hyponatremia and manifest clinically with nausea and fatigue. However, hyponatremia is not a primary metabolic derangement observed in tumor lysis syndrome. 
❌ Hypomagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia is a common clinical entity usually due to gastrointestinal or renal losses. Symptoms include seizures, tetany, and ventricular arrhythmias including torsades de pointes. It is not a primary metabolic derangement observed in tumor lysis syndrome. Instead, patients with tumor lysis syndrome are more likely to have hypermagnesemia.
❌ Hypokalemia :
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal losses may result in hypokalemia; however, tumor lysis syndrome presents with hyperkalemia due to the rapid lysis of cells and release of intracellular potassium stores.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old male is transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) after developing acute shortness of breath and cough. He was undergoing chemotherapy when the symptoms emerged. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and multiple myeloma. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. The patient is oriented to self but not place or time. Rales are heard at the right lung base. The patient is subsequently intubated for airway protection, has a central line placed, and initiated on vasopressors. On the second day of ICU stay, the patient is noted to have blood in the foley catheter and diffuse bruising. Coagulation studies are demonstrated below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Prothrombin time  25 seconds 
 Partial thromboplastin time  67 seconds 
 Fibrinogen   90 mg/dL (100-150 mg/dL) 
 Factor VIII  24% (60-100%) 

Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Cancer procoagulant activation of factor X
Trauma to vascular endothelium resulting in exposure of tissue factor
Impaired hepatic synthesis of coagulation factors

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with sepsis in the setting of hospital acquired pneumonia. He later develops bleeding from his urinary catheter, and the laboratory findings demonstrate prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, and low factor VIII levels. Together these findings are consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).  

DIC refers to a widespread consumptive coagulopathy resulting in hemorrhage, thrombocytopenia, and end-organ ischemia. It has multiple triggers including trauma, sepsis (due to lipopolysaccharides found in bacteria), pregnancy related complications, malignancies (acute promyelocytic leukemia, mucinous tumors), and transfusion reactions.   

Regardless of the trigger, DIC causes unchecked activation of the coagulation cascade and deposition of platelet-rich or fibrin-rich thrombi in the microvasculature. Over time, this process consumes all coagulation factors, causing an elevated PT/PTT and decreased fibrinogen levels. DIC also causes fibrinolysis resulting in elevated d-dimer levels, depleted platelets resulting in thrombocytopenia, and schistocytes on peripheral blood smear.  

Clinically, patients will often develop bleeding from catheters, venipuncture sites, or other means of invasive access. Patients often develop petechiae and easy bruising from thrombocytopenia. Signs of end-organ ischemia may also ensue (e.g., renal insufficiency, pulmonary hemorrhage). When suspected, coagulation studies including PT/PTT, d-dimer, and fibrinogen levels should be obtained. Additionally, factor VIII levels can help determine if the coagulopathy is due to DIC (reduced levels) or hepatic dysfunction (normal levels, since factor VIII is made outside the liver).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Lipopolysaccharide induced consumptive coagulopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cancer procoagulant activation of factor X :
Incorrect: Studies have shown that certain malignancies can drive the process of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) via a proteolytic enzyme termed “cancer procoagulant.” However, this protein is primarily found in mucinous tumors and would be unlikely to trigger DIC without additional instigating factors. 
❌ Trauma to vascular endothelium resulting in exposure of tissue factor:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiologic process of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) as a consequence of severe trauma. Damage to the vascular endothelium activates the coagulation cascade via exposure of tissue factor and release of procoagulant enzymes or phospholipids. Placement of a central line may disrupt the vascular endothelium. However, this procedure only results in localized, limited vascular trauma, which would not be enough to induce DIC. 
❌ Impaired hepatic synthesis of coagulation factors :
Incorrect: Distinguishing between disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and liver failure without a clear history is often difficult, as both present with similar laboratory findings. One way to make the distinction would be to check a factor VIII level, which will be normal or elevated in coagulopathy due to liver failure, since it is synthesized outside of hepatocytes. Conversely, this enzyme will be decreased in DIC due to global consumptive coagulopathy. 
❌ Inherited deficiency of ADAMTS13:
Incorrect: Deficiency of ADAMTS13 describes the pathophysiology of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, which results in the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers that generate platelet-rich thrombi. These thrombi then deposit in the microvasculature. In this disease, the coagulation cascade is unaffected, and thus the PT and PTT will be normal (or slightly elevated).

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the cardiologist with a several week history of fatigue, shortness of breath, fever, and chills. The patient underwent catheter-directed ablation for medication resistant atrial fibrillation six days ago. He additionally reports he recently underwent a root canal procedure several weeks ago. Past medical history is significant for rheumatic heart disease, mitral valve prolapse, mitral valve repair, and atrial fibrillation. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 122/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a holosystolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex. A surgical incision site over the patient’s left neck shows no erythema, discharge, or swelling. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40.5% 
 Leukocyte count  14,100/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 ESR                    34 mm/hr 
 CRP  6 mg/L 
Microbiology 
Blood cultures  Gram-positive, coagulase-negative bacteria in 3 consecutive plates  
 Which of the following is the most commonly affected structure in this disease process?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has multiple risk factors for the development of endocarditis including valvular damage, a recent invasive cardiac procedure, and a recent dental procedure without antibiotic prophylaxis.  Of these, the patient likely has endocarditis due to Staphylococcus epidermidis from the recent ablation given the findings of a blood culture positive for a Gram-positive, coagulase-negative bacteria. In these instances of subacute endocarditis, the mitral valve is the most common site of initial infection.  

In contrast, in endocarditis due to a Gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, the tricuspid valve is the most common site of infection. This bacteria is commonly acquired through IV drug use, recurrent hemodialysis, or through a central venous access catheter. Other organisms implicated in tricuspid valve infections include Pseudomonas and Candida.    

Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary veins :
Incorrect: While the pulmonary veins may be implicated in further transmission of vegetations from endocarditis, they are not the most commonly affected site.
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: The tricuspid valve is the most commonly affected valve in endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus in the setting of intravenous drug use, since this valve is the first encountered by bacteria traveling through the venous system. However, this patient’s endocarditis is of a different etiology.
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to S. epidermidis; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.
✅ Mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to S. epidermidis; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up appointment after a core-needle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of breast cancer. The results are sent for further immunohistochemistry analysis. The patient would like to know the prognosis of her condition. Which of the following characteristics, if found, would confer the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer prognosis is dependent on the cancer stage, biological type of tumor, and the availability of treatment modalities. Invasive carcinomas can be classified according to the biologic type as follows: ER-positive/HER2-negative, HER2-positive, and ER/PR/HER2-negative (triple-negative). The biologic classification is important, since each type differs in patient characteristics, grade, mutation profile, metastatic pattern, response to therapy, time to recurrence, and prognosis. For the majority of patients with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, an adjuvant endocrine therapy is recommended. Patients with triple negative tumors tend to have a poorer short-term prognosis (first five to seven years) and higher relapse rates during this period of time compared with ER-positive types. Since triple-negative tumors lack hormone receptors, no targeted therapy is available, making treatment more difficult.  





Option Analysis

❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  +  -  - :
Incorrect: Estrogen receptor (ER) expression is generally associated with a better outcome and prognosis. ER is used to determine if a patient should receive adjuvant endocrine therapy (e.g. tamoxifen).
✅   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression -  -  - :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  +  +  - :
Incorrect: In general, both estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) expression are associated with a better outcome and prognosis. ER is used to determine if a patient should receive adjuvant endocrine therapy. Progesterone receptor (PR)-positive tumors also have better outcomes with endocrine therapy; however, PR status is heavily dependent on ER. Therefore, PR is not an independent predictive value.
❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  - +  - :
Incorrect: Progesterone receptor (PR)-positive tumors have better outcomes with endocrine therapy; however, PR status is heavily dependent on ER. Therefore, PR is not an independent predictive value. 
❌   Estrogen receptor  expression   Progesterone receptor  expression    HER2 receptor overexpression  -  - +:
Incorrect: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) overexpression and/or amplification confers an unfavorable prognosis. Before the introduction of targeted therapy such as molecular inhibitors of HER2 (e.g. trastuzumab), outcomes were similar to patients with triple-negative carcinomas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pelvic pain and inability to conceive during the past year. She stopped taking oral contraceptives a year and a half ago. The patient states that she often has severe pain with defecation and during sexual intercourse. Her menstrual cycle occurs every 28 days, lasts for 5 days, and is accompanied by severe pain and discomfort. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, mild pelvic tenderness is noted, the uterus is soft and normal size. The cervix is normal and slightly immobile. A left adnexal mass is noted upon palpation. The patient’s adnexal mass most likely derived from which of the following tissues?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with infertility, dysmenorrhea, dyschezia (painful defecation), dyspareunia (painful intercourse), and immobile cervix on physical examination, favoring the diagnosis of endometriosis. The adnexal mass is likely an endometrioma, a blood-filled “chocolate cyst” that results from implantation of endometrium within the ovary.  

Endometriosis refers to the implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrial cavity, most commonly in the pelvis, peritoneum, and ovary (may be bilateral). There are several different hypotheses that explain the growth of endometrial glands outside of the uterus, but the most widely accepted one is the retrograde flow of menstruation. Patients often present with cyclic pelvic pain, heavy bleeding, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia (the 3D’s), infertility, and a normal-sized uterus. Physical examination findings are variable and depend upon the size and location of the implants. Findings may include tenderness with a digital exam, nodularity in the posterior fornix, adnexal masses, and immobility of the cervix or uterus (due to inflammation and scarring). Imaging may show ovarian cysts (endometriomas) and rectovaginal or bladder nodules. Definitive diagnosis and treatment are done by histologic evaluation with laparoscopy. During laparoscopy, the appearance of the lesions is variable but sometimes blue/brown lesions have been described as "powder burns” lesions. Treatment includes NSAIDs, oral contraceptives, and laparoscopic removal in refractory cases.  

Endometrioid carcinoma of the ovary is believed to arise from endometriosis. They are usually malignant tumors, but benign and borderline types also exist. On histology, they are composed of tubular glands, similar to that of the endometrium. They often occur bilaterally, and up to 30% of cases have a concomitant endometrial carcinoma.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Endometriosis lesions in the pouch of Douglas



Option Analysis

❌ Ovarian germ cells:
Incorrect: Germ cell tumors include dysgerminoma, teratoma, and yolk sac tumors. This patient, however, is presenting with infertility, dysmenorrhea, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and immobile cervix, which favors the diagnosis of endometriosis.
❌ Sex cord-stroma of the ovary:
Incorrect: Sex cord-stromal tumors include thecoma, granulosa cell tumor, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, and fibromas. This patient, however, is presenting with infertility, dysmenorrhea, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and immobile cervix, which favors the diagnosis of endometriosis.
❌ Surface epithelium of the ovary:
Incorrect: Surface epithelial tumors include serous and mucinous cystadenomas, serous and mucinous cystadenocarcinoma, and Brenner tumor. This patient, however, is presenting with infertility, dysmenorrhea, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and immobile cervix, which favors the diagnosis of endometriosis.
✅ Endometrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Myometrium:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from the myometrium include leiomyomas (fibroids). They are noncancerous monoclonal tumors that arise from the smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts of the myometrium. They are associated with heavy menstrual bleeding, bulk-related symptoms (e.g. pelvic pain) and infertility. Although this patient's symptoms overlap, leiomyomas are not associated with cervical immobility and an adnexal mass. Instead, an enlarged, mobile uterus with an irregular contour would be seen.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of headaches and fatigue. Two days ago, the patient developed an upper respiratory infection. She has not travelled recently. Physical exam shows jaundiced skin and conjunctiva as well as petechiae on the oral mucosa. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mmHg. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hematologic  
 Platelet count  50,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin  9.3 g/dL 
 Reticulocyte count   4.1% 
 Haptoglobin  10 mg/dL 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Total bilirubin  5.1 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  4.2 mg/dL 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)  46 mg/dL 
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  410 U/L 
Coagulation studies  
 Prothrombin time (PT)  11 seconds 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  34 seconds 
 Bleeding time*  16 minutes 
*Reference Range: 2-7 minutes   
ADAMTS13 levels are normal. Schistocytes are seen on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Decreased degradation of von Willebrand factor multimers

questions.solution:
This patient has thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute renal failure in the setting of a recent upper respiratory infection. She most likely has atypical hemolytic-uemic syndrome (HUS).  

Peripheral blood smear showing schistocytes: 

Reproduced from; Wikimedia commons 

There are two types of HUS, typical and atypical. Typical HUS occurs in children following an episode of gastroenteritis caused by Shiga/Shiga-like toxin producing organisms, such as enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli O157:H7 (EHEC) or Shigella dysenteriae. Patients usually have a history of eating undercooked beef, drinking unpasteurized milk, or swimming in contaminated water.  

Atypical HUS is caused by a genetic mutation in factor H, a protein that normally controls the complement system. Without factor H, the complement system is overactivated and unregulated, leading to extensive endothelial cell damage. Atypical HUS can occur at any age and is not associated with Shiga/Shiga-like toxin producing bacteria. However, many cases are triggered by upper respiratory infections or other inflammatory conditions that cause complement activation.  

Eculizumab, an anti-CD5 antibody, can be used for the treatment of atypical HUS.  

Option Analysis

❌ Shiga-toxin producing bacteria:
Incorrect: Shiga-toxin producing bacteria, such as Shigella dysenteriae and Escherichia coli O157:H7, cause typical hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS). Infection by these pathogens can also present with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. In contrast, this patient does not have these symptoms.
✅ Increased complement activation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased degradation of von Willebrand factor multimers:
Incorrect: Decreased degradation of von Willebrand factor multimers is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Laboratory testing would show reduced ADAMTS13 activity. 
❌ Anti-GpIIb/IIIa antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-GpIIb/IIIa antibodies are associated with Glanzmann thrombasthenia. However, the condition would not cause anemia, reduced haptoglobin, or kidney injury.
❌ Defect in platelet adhesion:
Incorrect: A defect in platelet adhesion is associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome. The condition presents with thrombocytopenia and abnormally large platelets. However, it would not cause anemia, reduced haptoglobin, or kidney injury.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic because of progressive fatigue, fevers, and night sweats for the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for 3 episodes of sinusitis in the last 6 months, which all resolved with the use of oral antibiotics. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and purpuric rashes on lower extremities. There is no lymphadenopathy.  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
Complete blood count 
Hemoglobin   8.5 g/dL 
 Platelet count   70,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count   6,000/mm3 
After appropriate workup, bone marrow biopsy reveals the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with symptomatic pancytopenia (fatigue, fever, night sweats, tachycardia) and bone marrow biopsy showing myeloblasts is consistent with leukemia. Leukemia is a myeloid or lymphoid malignancy resulting in widespread involvement of bone marrow. The common types of leukemia include:  

  1.  Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) 
  2.  Chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) 
  3.  Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) 
  4.  Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) 


Several genetic and environmental factors are associated with its development, including trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), chromosomal translocations or deletions, smoking, ionizing radiation, and chemotherapy. Clinical findings include fatigue or dyspnea (secondary to the anemia), petechiae or purpura (thrombocytopenia), and frequent infections (abnormal leukocyte function). Physical examination often reveals enlargement of reticuloendothelial system (lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) and skin changes (leukemia cutis). Definitive diagnosis usually requires bone marrow biopsy or flow cytometry analysis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis usually presents with a triad of fever, pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear reveals atypical lymphocytosis. However, pancytopenia would not be observed, and this patient does not have lymphadenopathy or pharyngitis.
✅ Leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Lymphoma is a malignancy of lymphoid tissue including lymph node, thymus, spleen and bone marrow. It usually presents with a painless lymph node enlargement and “B symptoms” (fever, night sweats, unexplained weight loss). Bone marrow biopsy in any type of lymphoma would not show Auer rods or myeloblasts.   
❌ Aplastic anemia:
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure usually due to immune-mediated injury to hematopoietic stem cells triggered by a drug, virus or chemicals. Although it may also present with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia, bone marrow biopsy would instead show a hypocellular marrow with fat cells and marrow stroma.
❌ Immune thrombocytopenic purpura:
Incorrect: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is an acquired cause of immune-mediated thrombocytopenia that results from autoantibodies against platelet antigens. It is asymptomatic in most patients but may present with petechiae, purpura or hemorrhagic bleeding in severe cases. It results in an isolated thrombocytopenia, as opposed to the pancytopenia seen in this patient.

questions.text:
40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of recurrent epistaxis and ongoing gingival bleeding. She has no history of trauma. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for hemophilia A in her brother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and petechiae on the lower extremities. There is ongoing oozing of blood from the gingiva. Laboratory studies are shown:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   8.6 g/dL 
 Platelets   60,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   3,500/mm3 
 Coagulation profile 
 Prothrombin time (PT)  25 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  50 sec 
 Bleeding time (BT)   11 minutes 
 Plasma fibrinogen  150 mg/dL   (N = 200-400 mg/dL) 
 D-dimer   1200 ng/dL   (N = <500 ng/mL) 

After stabilization and appropriate workup, bone marrow biopsy is performed and is shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Chromosomal analysis of the abnormal cells will most likely show which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of recurrent epistaxis, ongoing gingival bleeding and abnormal coagulation profile (increased PT, aPTT, BT and decreased fibrinogen) suggest disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). In association with pancytopenia and typical bone marrow biopsy findings of myeloblasts with Auer rods, acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is the most likely diagnosis.

Acute myeloid leukemia is a myeloid stem cell malignancy that results in failure of differentiation of myeloid precursors into mature granulocytes, on the basis of which it is divided into 8 types (M0 through M7). APML, the M3 subtype, is due to t(15;17) translocation, which links the retinoic acid receptor α (RARA) gene on chromosome 15 to promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene on chromosome 17, creating a fusion gene PML-RARA. It encodes an abnormal retinoic acid receptor which interrupts the differentiation of promyelocytes, leading to the development of APML.    

Clinically, it can present with anemia (fatigue, dyspnea), thrombocytopenia (easy bruising, epistaxis) and abnormal leukocyte function (infections). DIC is a potential complication of APML. Bone marrow biopsy shows neoplastic promyelocytes with azurophilic granules, bilobed nuclei and pink cytoplasmic rod-like structures called Auer rods (arrows). Definitive diagnosis is established by identifying PML-RARA fusion gene on fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis. APML is treated with all-trans retinoic acid.  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Option Analysis

❌ 13q deletion:
Incorrect: Deletion of 13q is usually seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a B-cell neoplasm, but this patient’s bone marrow biopsy instead shows abnormal myeloid cells.  
❌ t(8;14):
Incorrect: Translocation of chromosome 8 on 14 is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. It usually presents with a mass in the facial or abdominal region.
