Bone marrow biopsy shows uniform neoplastic cells with evenly interspersed reactive tingible-body macrophages, resulting in a characteristic "starry-sky" pattern. It is not associated with DIC.  
✅ t(15;17):
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ t(9;22):
Incorrect: Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22] bcr-abl) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia. It is mostly asymptomatic or presents with nonspecific symptoms (fatigue, weight loss). Coagulation profile is normal. Bone marrow biopsy shows mature neoplastic myeloid cells rather than myeloblasts (immature myeloid cells), as seen in this patient.  
❌ t(14;18):
Incorrect:  t(14;18) is typical of follicular lymphoma (non-Hodgkin lymphoma). It usually presents with waxing and waning courses of lymphadenopathy. This patient’s presentation with immature myeloblast proliferation in bone marrow and DIC is consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to the physician due to back pain. 2 months ago, he started having back pains which he attributed to the strenuous interval training he attended at that time. The patient discloses morning pain and stiffness which improves after his morning exercise routine. The pain often awakes him at night, but he is able to go back to sleep. On physical examination, pain is reproduced with palpation of the sacroiliac joint and spinal flexion is limited. Estimated erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 75 mm/hr. This patient’s condition is also associated with which of the following?

choices.text: Sclerosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion

questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with an insidious onset of progressive back pain, morning stiffness which improves with movement, and night pain. He most likely has ankylosing spondylitis (AS).  

Ankylosing means stiffening, spondylo- refers to the vertebra, and -itis refers to inflammation. AS is a type of seronegative spondyloarthritis (negative rheumatoid factor), a group of autoimmune conditions characterized by arthritis and a strong association with HLA-B27 (MHC class I serotype). These include psoriatic arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis, juvenile spondyloarthropathy, and ankylosing spondylitis. HLA-B27 testing is part of the diagnostic evaluation.  

These conditions share common features including inflammation of the axial joints (especially the sacroiliac joint), asymmetric oligoarthritis, dactylitis (sausage digits), uveitis, and enthesitis (inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone). AS is also associated with increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, including aortic root disease, acute coronary syndrome, stroke, venous thromboembolism, and conduction abnormalities. Patients with AS often have elevated ESR and CRP, as well as characteristic changes in the sacroiliac joint on a plain radiograph (erosions, ankylosis, changes in joint width, and sclerosis). Management includes NSAIDs, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, and other agents.  

According to the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS) criteria, "inflammatory back pain" should be suspected if 4/5 of the following criteria are present:  

  • Age of onset <40 years  
  • Insidious onset  
  • Improvement with exercise  
  • No relief with rest  
  • Pain at night that improves upon arising  


Option Analysis

❌ Recurrent conjunctival inflammation:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis and other seronegative spondyloarthropathies are associated with uveitis, not conjunctivitis. Although both conditions are associated with eye redness, uveitis is an intraocular inflammation while conjunctivitis is superficial (the tissue that lines the inner surface of the eyelid).
❌ Nail pitting:
Incorrect: Nail pitting occurs due to a focal area of abnormal keratinization. It is associated with conditions such as psoriasis, alopecia areata, and eczema.
❌ Sclerosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts:
Incorrect: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with ulcerative colitis (UC). UC is also associated with spondyloarthropathy. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, another type of seronegative spondyloarthritis.
❌ Scoliosis:
Incorrect: Scoliosis refers to the sideways curvature of the spine that occurs most commonly during the growth spurt before puberty. Spinal deformities may be seen in patients with advanced ankylosing spondylitis and include flexion deformity of the neck, thoracic hyperkyphosis, loss of lumbar lordosis, and deformities of the hips. However, it is not associated with scoliosis.
✅ Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the office due to 2 days of sore throat, purulent nasal discharge and facial pain. Past medical history is significant for several sinus infections over the past 6 months, all of which resolved with oral antibiotics. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F), pulse is 80/minute, respirations are 19/minute, and blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema and maxillary sinus tenderness. There is no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results are as follows:    
Laboratory value  Result
Complete blood count 
Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   600,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   100,100/mm3 
 Neutrophils  40% 
 Myelocytes  32% 
 Metamyelocytes  10% 
 Band forms  1% 
 Blast cells  1% 
 Lymphocytes  7% 
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis reveals a bcr-abl fusion gene. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Auer rods on peripheral blood smear
Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration
Flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation (CD20 and CD5)

questions.solution:
This patient with leukocytosis and bcr-abl fusion gene on genetic analysis most likely has chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).  

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of mature granulocytes. It is usually a result of the translocation of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 to the ABL gene on chromosome 9, leading to the formation of the oncogenic BCR-ABL fusion gene on the shortened chromosome 22 (known as Philadelphia chromosome with t[9;22]). Laboratory investigation usually shows leukocytosis (>100,000/mL) with neutrophilia.    

An elevated percentage of myelocytes as compared to mature metamyelocytes (myeloid bulge) and a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score helps differentiate CML from a leukemoid reaction; leukemoid reactions are typically seen in response to infections or drugs (e.g. steroids). A high LAP score is associated with an increased number of mature white blood cells (as in leukemoid reactions), whereas a low LAP score is associated with an increased number of immature white blood cells (as in CML).  
An absolute basophilia is also characteristic of CML. Eosinophil and platelet count may also be elevated. Peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy show granulocyte hyperplasia with more mature forms and are important investigations to determine the phase of disease (chronic, accelerated, or blast crisis). Definitive diagnosis is established by genetic testing demonstrating the bcr-abl fusion gene.




Option Analysis

❌ Auer rods on peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: Auer rods are pathognomonic of acute myeloid leukemia. Peripheral blood or bone marrow blast cells should be ≥20% to establish the diagnosis, unlike the 1% blast cells in this patient.
❌ Elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score:
Incorrect: An elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is typically found in leukemoid reaction, which occurs in response to an infection. Leukocyte count can be as high as 50,000/microL with neutrophilia and marked left shift. The elevated myelocytes as compared to metamyelocytes and the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (bcr-abl) on FISH analysis are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration:
Incorrect: Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is usually seen in hairy cell leukemia, which presents with pancytopenia and massive splenomegaly. Elevated leukocyte counts and the bcr-abl fusion gene are suggestive of a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ Flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation (CD20 and CD5):
Incorrect: Flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation is diagnostic for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. It is asymptomatic in most cases or presents with “B symptoms” (fever, weight loss, night sweats and fatigue). Lymphadenopathy is usually present. This patient’s laboratory and genetic findings are suggestive of a different diagnosis.  
✅ Absolute basophilia:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of a neck lump she noticed while showering. Since it first appeared, it has rapidly increased in size. The patient has also noted some vocal changes and increased difficulty swallowing. Medical history is significant for papillary thyroid cancer in her 20s, for which she underwent thyroid lobectomy. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic mass in the residual left thyroid lobe with increased blood flow. Fine-needle biopsy shows a mixture of large pleomorphic and spindle-shaped cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with a history of papillary thyroid cancer is now presenting with a rapidly enlarging thyroid mass and compression symptoms. Ultrasound shows a mass lesion with internal flow, which is characteristic of malignancy. Finally, histopathology demonstrates a mixture of large pleomorphic and spindle-shaped cells, favoring the diagnosis of anaplastic carcinoma.  

Anaplastic and poorly differentiated thyroid cancers are the most aggressive types of thyroid cancer. Poorly differentiated thyroid cancer is thought to represent an intermediate entity in the progression between well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma to anaplastic carcinoma. Poorly differentiated tumors arise from BRAF-positive differentiated thyroid cancers, while anaplastic tumors arise from RAS mutation-positive differentiated thyroid cancers. Anaplastic thyroid cancers are also associated with p53 mutations.  

Anaplastic carcinoma has a mortality rate approaching 100%. The mean age at diagnosis is 65 years and is more prevalent in women. Approximately 20% of patients with anaplastic thyroid cancer have a positive history of differentiated thyroid cancer, and up to 30% percent have coexisting differentiated cancer. Patients often present with a rapidly enlarging neck mass and compression symptoms due to local invasion (e.g., dyspnea, hoarseness, dysphagia, cough). Constitutional symptoms may be present, including weight loss, anorexia, fatigue, and fever of unknown origin.  

Unfortunately, metastases are usually present at the time of diagnosis. Diagnosis is made by needle or surgical biopsy demonstrating spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, squamoid cells, or a combination of the 3 patterns. Treatment depends on the time of diagnosis, local invasion, and metastases. It may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and palliative care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anaplastic carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Papillary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common cancer of the thyroid. On histology, it is characterized by cells with nuclear clearing (“Orphan Annie eye”), nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.
❌ Follicular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Follicular thyroid cancer is a type of differentiated cancer with histological features that may resemble normal thyroid tissue. To differentiate follicular thyroid cancer from follicular adenoma, capsular and/or vascular invasion should be demonstrated on histological examination after surgery.
❌ Medullary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the parafollicular (C cells) of the thyroid gland. A hallmark of the tumor is calcitonin production. On histology, it is characterized by sheets of polygonal cells immersed in an amyloid stroma that stains positive with Congo red.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fatigue, jaundice, paleness, and difficulty breathing for the past week. He states that the symptoms started suddenly. He denies any recent illnesses, sick contacts, or recent travel. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, rheumatic fever, hypercholesterolemia, and mitral valve regurgitation. Past surgical history includes a mitral valve replacement 2 months ago.  Current medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, and warfarin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 108/66 mmHg. Physical examination shows pallor. Laboratory test findings are shown below:  

 
Laboratory value  Results 
 Hematologic  
 Leukocyte count   9,600/mm3 
 Erythrocyte count   3.2 million/mm3 
 Platelet count  260,000/mm3  
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Hemoglobin  9.4 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   88 fL 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)  34% Hb/cell 
 Reticulocyte count   4.2% 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Haptoglobin  Undetectable 
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  380 U/L 
 Total bilirubin  5 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient with signs and symptoms of hemolytic anemia (hemoglobinemia, jaundice, pallor, fatigue, shortness of breath) along with recent surgical history of prosthetic mitral valve replacement has intravascular macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia caused by mechanical destruction of erythrocytes.  

Extrinsic hemolytic anemia can be differentiated according to the location of the red blood cell destruction by categorizing into intravascular and extravascular hemolysis. Extravascular hemolysis is defined by red blood cell destruction outside of blood vessels, typically in the reticuloendothelial system. Intravascular hemolysis is defined by red blood cell destruction within blood vessels. Intravascular hemolytic anemia can be further characterized based on the size of the blood vessel, categorized into microangiopathic and macroangiopathic hemolysis. In this patient, his microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is likely the result of his recent mitral valve prostheses causing destruction of his erythrocytes.  

  •  Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia results in erythrocyte destruction in the systemic circulation due to mechanical forces applied to the erythrocyte membrane. This can be seen in conditions such as moderate and severe aortic stenosis, prosthetic heart valves, and strenuous exercise. 
  •  Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia results in erythrocyte destruction in the systemic circulation due to microthrombi in small blood vessels. This can be seen in conditions such as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).  
These 2 types of hemolytic anemias are difficult to distinguish based on laboratory findings alone, since the hemolysis results in similar findings (e.g., schistocytes on blood smear, decreased haptoglobin, elevated LDH). However, the clinical scenario can help clarify which hemolytic process is occurring; in patients with chronic anemic signs and aortic stenosis or prosthetic valves, macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia should be suspected. In contrast, in patients with acute anemia and presenting as severely ill (e.g., TTP, HUS, DIC), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia should be suspected.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Extravascular hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Extravascular hemolytic anemia includes autoimmune hemolytic anemia, drug-induced hemolytic anemia, infectious hemolytic anemia, and inherited intrinsic hemolytic anemias. Erythrocytes are typically marked by antibodies for destruction in the reticuloendothelial system. In contrast, this patient likely has an intravascular hemolytic anemia, which can be inferred by his undetectable haptoglobin levels and recent valve replacement, making him at increased risk of macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.  
❌ Drug-induced hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Drug-induced hemolytic anemia is a type of immune-mediated hemolytic anemia that can be either intravascular or extravascular. Some common drugs associated with this type of hemolytic anemia include penicillins, cephalosporins, alpha-methyldopa, L-dopa, ibuprofen, diclofenac, quinidine, hydrochlorothiazide, sulfonamides, and tetracyclines. This patient is not currently taking any medications that would predispose him to drug-induced hemolysis.  
❌ Intravascular microangiopathic hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Intravascular microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), HELLP syndrome, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). These various causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemias typically present acutely, with patient’s appearing severely ill within hours to days. In contrast, this patient’s 1-week history of fatigue, in conjunction with his recent valve replacement, likely suggest a macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.   
❌ Autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is a type of antibody-mediated hemolytic anemia that can be due to warm antibodies (IgG) or cold antibodies (IgM). Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia is an extravascular hemolytic process (i.e. takes place in the spleen), whereas cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia can be either an intravascular or extravascular process. This patient likely has an intravascular hemolytic anemia, which can be inferred by his undetectable haptoglobin levels; in conjunction with his recent valve replacement, this likely suggests a macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.  
✅ Intravascular macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of a three-month history of progressive fatigue, abdominal pain, and darker-than-normal urine, especially in the morning. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Sucrose hemolysis test is positive. The patient's condition is most likely attributed to which of the following?

choices.text: Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis
Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis
Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis
Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis
Positive direct Coombs test with extravascular hemolysis

questions.solution:
This patient with dark urine in the morning, normocytic anemia, decreased haptoglobin, pancytopenia, and positive sucrose hemolysis test has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH is an intrinsic, intravascular hemolytic anemia. Extrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem outside of the erythrocyte and is typically acquired (e.g., autoimmune, infections, microangiopathic), whereas intrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem with the erythrocyte itself and is typically caused by enzyme deficiencies, commonly seen in congenital conditions (e.g., PNH, sickle cell disease, G6PD, hereditary spherocytosis).  

The type of hemolysis can be determined based on symptoms and laboratory findings. In intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobin that is released inside vessels gets bound by haptoglobin, and both molecules are removed together. Therefore, haptoglobin levels decrease. Once the haptoglobin gets overwhelmed, the remainder of the hemoglobin travels via the blood to the kidneys. Here, it is excreted in the urine and causes hemoglobinuria. While passing through the renal tubules, some of the hemoglobin is reabsorbed by the cells lining the tubule. The iron component of the heme is stored in these cells as hemosiderin for a few days. Eventually, these cells slough into the urine and cause hemosiderinuria.  


In extravascular hemolysis, erythrocytes are destroyed outside of the blood vessels, typically in the liver or spleen. Therefore, patients may present with splenomegaly or hepatomegaly. However, haptoglobin levels are normal, and there is no hemoglobinuria or hemosiderinuria.

Option Analysis

❌ Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. Extravascular hemolysis would not cause decreased haptoglobin levels.
❌ Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis is unlikely to cause pancytopenia.
✅ Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis would not cause pancytopenia, decreased haptoglobin, or positive sucrose test.
❌ Positive direct Coombs test with extravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. A direct Coombs test is used to detect autoimmune or drug-induced hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hepatitis C cirrhosis is transferred to the intensive care unit due to hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient was initially admitted for management of a right middle lobe pneumonia, but today the patient was noted to have altered mental status and tachypnea. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 100/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. Physical examination shows a man in moderate respiratory distress with evidence of accessory muscle use. Auscultation reveals bilateral rales throughout the lung fields. The patient is subsequently intubated and sedated for airway protection. Follow up chest x-ray, laboratory results, and cardiovascular studies are demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
 
Laboratory value  Result 
CBC, Serum 
Hemoglobin  12.5  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  37.5% 
 Leukocyte count  17,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  123,000/mm3 
Blood Gases, Serum 
pH  7.50 
 PCO2  25 mmHg 
 PO2  54 mm Hg 
 FiO2  100% 
Transthoracic Echocardiography 
Ejection fraction 62%; No valvular regurgitation or other structural abnormalities noted 
 Which of the following best describes the most likely pathophysiology of this acute disease process?

choices.text: Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar space due to damage of alveolar capillaries
Pulmonary hemorrhage with formation of hemosiderin laden macrophages
Leakage of protein-poor fluid into the alveolar space due to increased hydrostatic pressure
Focal necrosis with an area of surrounding pulmonary hemorrhage

questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) based on the Berlin criteria, with findings of new bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray, a PO2:FiO2 ratio < 300, an identifiable clinical insult of pneumonia, and a normal cardiac ejection fraction. Clinically, patients will present with gradually increasing tachypnea and hypoxia after an inciting event. Laboratory results are generally non-specific, but arterial blood gas will typically reveal hypoxemia accompanied by an acute respiratory alkalosis.  

ARDS is an acute, diffuse, inflammatory lung injury that is associated with a variety of etiologies. Sepsis is the most common cause of ARDS, with trauma, aspiration, drowning, blood product transfusion, pancreatitis, and drugs being common culprits as well.  

Regardless of etiology, the clinical and pathological course of ARDS follows the same trajectory. An insult causes alveolar damage and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor, interleukin (IL)-1, IL-6, and IL-8. These cytokines recruit neutrophils to the lung parenchyma, where they release toxic mediators that damage both the capillary endothelium and alveolar endothelium. Damage to these structures results in leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar space, alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, and decreased lung compliance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar space due to damage of alveolar capillaries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary hemorrhage with formation of hemosiderin laden macrophages :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathologic findings seen in diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). While DAH can precipitate ARDS, it is less likely in this patient with a clinical history of pneumonia as the inciting event. Typically, DAH presents with hemoptysis, which this patient does not have.   
❌ Leakage of protein-poor fluid into the alveolar space due to increased hydrostatic pressure:
Incorrect: Leakage of protein poor fluid into the alveolar space describes cardiogenic fluid overload as the etiology of this patient’s respiratory distress. Given this patient’s normal echocardiography, cardiogenic causes of fluid overload are unlikely.   
❌ Increased bronchoalveolar fluid containing eosinophils:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of eosinophilic pneumonitis or bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. This diagnosis is less likely in this patient, given an absence of volatile exposure or history of asthma with chronic steroid use.   
❌ Focal necrosis with an area of surrounding pulmonary hemorrhage  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of pulmonary vasculitic diseases, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Given this patient’s acute presentation with absence of other systemic findings (e.g., renal disease, nasal polyps), vasculitides are less likely.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath. The patient was at home reading a book when he suddenly developed shortness of breath and left-sided chest pain. Three days ago, he returned from a business trip to China. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 127/94 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a tall thin male in moderate respiratory distress and diminished breath sounds over the left lung. Cardiovascular and abdominal exams are noncontributory. The patient’s D-dimer level is 230 ng/mL (reference range: < 500 ng/mL). Which of the following is the strongest risk factor predisposing this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient developed sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. The vital signs are notable for tachypnea and tachycardia, and physical examination is notable for diminished breath sounds over the left lung. He most likely has a primary spontaneous pneumothorax.  

Primary spontaneous pneumothorax refers to lung collapse in the absence of significant prior lung disease. In these patients, lung collapse occurs when the pleural space is punctured, such as when an apical subpleural bleb ruptures. Air is subsequently able to escape through the puncture site and becomes trapped in the pleural cavity, resulting in lung collapse.  

The strongest risk factor for the development of primary spontaneous pneumothorax is active cigarette smoking. Other notable risk factors include male gender and having a tall-thin body habitus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cigarette smoking :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent drop in atmospheric pressure:
Incorrect: Changes in atmospheric pressure, such as during a plane ride, can potentially trigger the rupture of subpleural blebs and lead to pneumothorax. However, this risk is largely theoretical and has not been well-documented in the medical literature.
❌ Body habitus:
Incorrect: Patients with a tall, thin body habitus are at increased risk of developing a primary spontaneous pneumothorax. This association is thought to be due to increased alveolar stretch at the lung apex in such individuals. However, cigarette smoking is a stronger risk factor for developing a primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
❌ Male gender:
Incorrect: Primary spontaneous pneumothorax occurs 3-6 times more frequently in men. However, it is not the strongest risk factor for the development of a primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
❌ Recent long distance travel:
Incorrect: Long distance travel can cause an individual to remain immobile for prolonged periods of time. This increases an individual’s risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Although a PE can present with tachypnea, tachycardia, and pleuritic chest pain, the patient’s normal D-dimer level makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider seeking evaluation of jaundice. Two days ago, the patient participated in a marathon race. He had a similar episode in college after an episode of binge drinking. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and hepatitis A infection, which he acquired one-year ago while travelling overseas. In the office, his temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse jaundice. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Urinalysis reveals no significant findings. The patient’s blood work reveals the following findings:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.2 mg.dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,800/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  4.1 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  14 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  17 U/L 
Which of the following best explains the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Liver injury secondary to viral proliferation
Impaired excretion of bilirubin from the liver

questions.solution:
This patient has Gilbert syndrome, a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by mildly reduced UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. This enzyme is involved in conjugating bilirubin, and therefore, patients with Gilbert syndrome have hepatocytes that are less effective at conjugating bilirubin. This relative deficiency can result in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Gilbert syndrome is fairly common, and between 4-16% of individuals (depending on the population studied) have the condition.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic. However, they can develop mild jaundice when exposed to triggers that increase hemolysis/bilirubin production. Potential triggers include fasting, febrile illness, fatigue, stress, and physical exertion, all of which induce mild hemolysis.  

Laboratory testing will reveal mildly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels and normal liver function tests.

Option Analysis

✅ Mildly reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Absent UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity:
Incorrect: This answer describes Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1. Patients exclusively present in the neonatal period with markedly elevated bilirubin levels, which often exceed 20 mg/dL. In addition, patients will have persistent jaundice and kernicterus. In contrast, this patient has mildly elevated bilirubin levels, no neurological deficits, and intermittent episodes of jaundice triggered by stressors.
❌ Liver injury secondary to viral proliferation:
Incorrect: Patients with viral hepatitis can develop injury and jaundice. However, this patient’s hepatitis A infection occurred a year ago, and the infection self-resolves. Moreover, this patient has normal liver enzyme levels, making liver injury unlikely.
❌ Impaired excretion of bilirubin from the liver:
Incorrect: This answer describes Dubin-Johnson syndrome and Rotor syndrome. However, both of these conditions will cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
❌ Reduced glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase activity:
Incorrect: Patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency have red blood cells that are vulnerable to hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stress. This hemolysis can lead to increased hemoglobin release and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, patients may also have anemia or increased urine hemoglobin. In contrast, this patient has a normal hemoglobin and urinalysis results.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old Hispanic woman comes to the office because of red-colored urine. She first noticed the change in color 2 days ago. Medical history is significant for several years of joint pains. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral periorbital edema and ulcerative lesions on the palate. Laboratory results are as follows:


After further workup, renal biopsy is performed (shown below).

Reproduced from:

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This woman with nephritic syndrome (hematuria, hypertension, periorbital edema, red blood cell casts) together with biopsy findings of glomerular proliferation and capillary wall thickening most likely has diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN). This patient’s DPGN is likely secondary to an undiagnosed case of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), as indicated by the history of chronic joint pains, ulcerative palatal lesions, and thrombocytopenia.  

DPGN is mostly associated with SLE, an autoimmune condition with higher prevalence in women of Asian, African-Americans and Hispanic descent. Renal involvement (lupus nephritis) is common and is one of the most common causes of death in patients with SLE. It is a result of type III hypersensitivity reaction (HSR), whereby anti-DNA antibodies attack and form immune complexes (ICs) with DNA, the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), and the mesangium. These IC deposits then cause complement activation, inflammation, and glomerular damage, resulting in nephritic syndrome.



Reproduced from:

Lupus nephritis is classified into different types on the basis of histological pattern of glomerular injury. DPGN is the most common and most severe form and is defined as >50% involvement of glomeruli in both kidneys. Histologically, DPGN is characterized by areas of cellular proliferation (arrows) and capillary wall thickening that appears as “wire-looping” (arrowheads). Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular IC deposits. On electron microscopy, it appears as subendothelial IC deposits.



Option Analysis

❌ Normal serum C3 level  :
Incorrect: The subendothelial and mesangial immune complex deposits seen in the biopsy results here result in activation of the complement system, which results in the influx of neutrophils and mononuclear cells, causing inflammation. This utilization leads to decreased serum C3 levels, as the complement activation in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) occurs predominantly via the alternative pathway.
❌ Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies are commonly seen in Goodpasture syndrome. This condition is a pulmonary-renal syndrome that usually presents with hemoptysis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Biopsy findings include crescent shaped deposition in glomeruli (not a wire-looping pattern, as seen in this patient).
❌ Increased eosinophil count:
Incorrect: Eosinophilia is usually seen in acute interstitial nephritis, which is typically associated with fever, rash, sterile pyuria, and white blood cell casts -- none of which are seen in this patient.
✅ Anti-double stranded DNA antibodies (anti-dsDNA):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with certain vasculitides (e.g. granulomatosis with polyangiitis). Their typical renal manifestation is RPGN that is histologically characterized by crescent formation in glomeruli. Though RPGN can also sometimes be seen in other classes of lupus nephritis, the biopsy findings of this patient are diffuse glomerular capillary wall thickening, which is indicative of another condition.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of abdominal pain and fatigue. His symptoms began 4 months ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, he reports a 5 kg (11 lb) unintentional weight loss since symptom onset. The patient often wakes up at night drenched in sweat. Past medical history is notable for peripheral vascular disease and alcohol use disorder. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Physical examination shows jaundice and scleral icterus. Abdominal pain is most prominent in the epigastric region. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Total bilirubin  5.2 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  4.6 mg/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase  96 U/L 
 Aspartate transaminase  110 U/L 
 Alanine transaminase  112 U/L 
 Lipase*  95 U/L 
*Normal range: 12-70 U/L  

Which of the following additional findings will be most likely present on this patient’s physical examination?

choices.text: Tenderness to palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant
Enlarged gallbladder that is nontender to palpation
Diffuse velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has pancreatic cancer, which is typically located at the pancreatic head and can cause jaundice. The most common type is pancreatic adenocarcinoma. It arises from the epithelial cells lining the pancreatic ducts. It is a very aggressive tumor, and individuals often already have metastases at the time of diagnosis. Important risk factors include smoking, high alcohol consumption, and chronic pancreatitis.  

Patients with pancreatic cancer can have epigastric pain, weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. Patients can also have Trousseau syndrome (also known as Trousseau sign of malignancy) and Courvoisier sign. Trousseau syndrome, also termed migratory thrombophlebitis, is characterized by blood clots that appear unexpectedly in superficial veins, and then over time migrate to different locations in the body. Courvoisier sign describes an enlarged, palpable, yet non-tender gallbladder and accompanying jaundice.  

Laboratory testing can show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (due to bile duct obstruction by the tumor), elevated liver enzymes, and alkaline phosphatase. Lipase may also be elevated. A frequently tested fact is that tumor markers associated with pancreatic adenocarcinoma are carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).  



Option Analysis

❌ Flank ecchymosis and discoloration:
Incorrect: This answer describes the Grey-Turner sign, which is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis. Pancreatitis causes epigastric pain that radiates to the back and markedly elevated lipase levels. This patient’s history of alcohol use disorder does put him at greater risk for pancreatitis, but it would be atypical for acute pancreatitis to cause chronic fatigue, weight loss, or night sweats.
❌ Tenderness to palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant:
Incorrect: Murphy’s sign is characterized by tenderness upon palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is associated with cholecystitis, which can cause abdominal pain and hyperbilirubinemia. However, it would not account for the elevated lipase or liver enzymes. 
❌ Periumbilical discoloration and bruising:
Incorrect: This describes Cullen’s sign, which is another physical exam sign found in patients with acute pancreatitis. However, it would be atypical for pancreatitis to cause the chronic fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats seen in this patient.
✅ Enlarged gallbladder that is nontender to palpation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diffuse velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin:
Incorrect: This answer describes malignant acanthosis nigricans, a paraneoplastic phenomenon associated with abdominal malignancies. To be specific, it is most often seen in patients with gastric adenocarcinoma. In contrast, this patient’s elevated lipase, liver enzymes, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia are more consistent with pancreatic cancer.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider’s office for evaluation of recent skin changes. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. She is not currently taking any medications. Her father passed away from a myocardial infarction at 32-years-old, and her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her paternal grandfather passed away from colorectal cancer at 62-years-old. Her vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several subcutaneous nodules found above the Achilles tendon bilaterally. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  141 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.0 mEq/L 
 Serum Glucose (Fasting)  87 mg/dL 
 Triglyceride  144 mg/dL 
 Serum Cholesterol (Total)  325 mg/dL 
Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
This patient has type II familial hyperlipidemia, an autosomal dominant condition caused by defects in low density lipoprotein receptors or apolipoprotein B-100. The condition presents with premature atherosclerosis, early-onset coronary artery disease, and tendon xanthomas. Laboratory findings will reveal markedly elevated cholesterol levels but normal/mildly elevated triglyceride levels.  

The symptoms of hyperlipidemia can vary depending on the type and severity. Skin manifestations include xanthomas, which are deposits of fat under the skin and in the tendons. These occur when extremely high blood levels of lipoproteins or triglycerides leak out of the blood vessels. When these deposits occur around the eyelid, they are called xanthelasma. In addition, lipids can deposit around the cornea, creating a brown ring of fat called a corneal arcus. Lipid deposition in the liver can cause fatty liver disease, also called hepatic steatosis.   

The most worrisome complication of the familial hyperlipidemias is early-onset atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, including coronary artery disease, stroke, peripheral vascular disease and carotid artery stenosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy can be secondary to poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. The patient’s mother has diabetes mellitus, and there is a genetic component to the disease. However, the patient's most recent blood sugar level is within normal range, making diabetes unlikely in this patient.
✅ Premature atherosclerosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinitis pigmentosa:
Incorrect: Patients with abetalipoproteinemia may present with retinitis pigmentosa. The condition manifests in infancy. It causes fat malabsorption and failure to thrive. Patients present with the consequences of deficiency in fat-soluble vitamins, such as easy bruising (vitamin K), osteopenia (vitamin D), and worsening vision (vitamin A). In contrast, the patient in this vignette has none of these symptoms.
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal tract malignancies may cause occult blood loss and iron deficiency anemia. This patient has a family history of colorectal cancer. However, she does not have any other symptoms of the condition such as unexplained weight loss, and her skin and laboratory findings are better explained by another diagnosis.  
❌ Acute pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Patients with type I or type IV familial hyperlipidemia are at increased risk of pancreatitis, in the setting of significantly elevated triglycerides. In contrast, this patient’s family history of early-onset acute coronary syndrome, presence of Achilles xanthomas, and elevated cholesterol raise concerns for type II familial hyperlipidemia. Type II familial hyperlipidemia does not typically cause pancreatitis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations. The patient was in the park jogging when he suddenly felt lightheaded, dizzy, and noted a pounding sensation in his chest. The symptoms resolved prior to arrival, and he now feels back to his baseline. Medical history is otherwise noncontributory, and he does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. The electrocardiogram from triage is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Pre-excitation through the bundle of Kent
Macro-reentrant circuit at the tricuspid annulus
Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents after a near-syncopal event during exertion. The electrocardiogram demonstrated a slurred upstroke of the QRS complex, wide QRS complexes, and a short PR interval. These findings are most consistent with Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome.   

Wolff-Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome refers to an accessory pre-excitation syndrome that arises when electrical signals are able to bypass the AV node. The most common accessory pathway in this disorder is the bundle of Kent, which rests on the infero-lateral aspect of the right atrium. Ventricular pre-excitation via this pathway can result in reentrant tachycardias, since it does not have the same physiologic brakes as the AV node. If these reentrant tachycardias are sustained, they can result in ventricular fibrillation or sudden cardiac death. Definitive treatment involves catheter directed ablation of the bypass tract to facilitate normal conduction through the AV node.  

On electrocardiogram, the disease is characterized by three distinct features: 1) a slurred upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave), 2) wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), and 3) a short PR interval (<120 ms).  

However, one must take care when diagnosing this condition, since electrocardiographically it may not always present at regular rates, but rather with sustained reentrant tachycardias. This phenomenon allows for potential misinterpretation of this deadly arrhythmia as atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response or paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.    



Option Analysis

✅ Pre-excitation through the bundle of Kent :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Macro-reentrant circuit at the tricuspid annulus :
Incorrect: Atrial flutter is defined by atrial depolarization occurring at a rate of 250 to 350 beats/min. It is usually caused by an atrial reentry circuit that runs around the tricuspid annulus. The condition is characterized by "flutter waves", which have a sawtooth appearance, and the presence of multiple P-waves between QRS complexes. 
❌ Multiple atrial micro-reentrant circuits :
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation manifest on electrocardiography with irregularly irregular QRS complexes and absent P-waves. In contrast, the QRS complexes on this patient’s electrocardiograph occur at regular intervals, and P-waves are present.
❌ Enhanced automaticity from atrial non-sinus node sites:
Incorrect: Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is defined by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying intervals and at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies in the same lead. Patients with underlying pulmonary disease are predisposed to this tachyarrhythmia. However, this patient’s rhythm is regular, and the P-waves are of similar morphology. 
❌ Abnormal ventricular repolarization:
Incorrect: Torsades de pointes results from abnormal ventricular repolarization. On electrocardiogram, it is characterized by a ventricular rate greater than 200 beats/min and an undulating QRS axis, with the polarity of the complexes appearing to shift about the baseline. These findings are not present on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with malaise and fatigue. She reports that several months ago, she had an influenza-like illness where she had low-grade fevers, chills, nausea, and vomiting that self-resolved. She reports since that event, she has not felt back to her normal self. She reports she is otherwise healthy and does not use illicit drugs, drink alcohol, or smoke tobacco products. She works as a nurse in a large healthcare facility and recently traveled to Haiti for a medical mission trip. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 132/72 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. She has screening labs performed which are notable for an ALT of 342 U/L and an AST of 221 U/L. She subsequently undergoes a liver biopsy which demonstrates lymphoid aggregates and areas of macrovesicular steatosis. This patient's clinical presentation was most likely the result of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This healthcare professional presents with malaise, fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, and a liver biopsy consistent with hepatitis C infection. Of the answer choices listed, hepatitis C is primarily transmitted parenterally, such as through a needlestick injury.  

Hepatitis C is an enveloped single-stranded RNA flavivirus that is primarily transmitted parenterally (e.g., through needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions). Transmission through blood transfusion used to be a common cause, but due to improved routine screening of blood products, most acquisition now occurs through intravenous drug use.  

Compared to other forms of viral hepatitis, hepatitis C carries a long incubation period, usually on the order of two weeks to six months. Acute infection is typically mild and manifests with malaise, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, low-grade fevers, as well as nausea and vomiting. Chronic infection can be insidious, with the majority of patients experiencing no symptoms until cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma ensues. At this stage of infection, patients may manifest with features such as ascites, jaundice, coagulopathy, and hepatic encephalopathy.  

Clues to diagnosis are often reliant upon risk factors, such as being a healthcare worker or a dialysis patient. Histologically, the disease manifests with lymphoid aggregates and areas of macrovesicular steatosis on liver biopsy, as the virus can replicate in both hepatocytes and lymphocytes.

Option Analysis

✅ Needlestick injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Consumption of raw seafood:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A and E are transmitted via the fecal-oral route, whereas hepatitis C is transmitted via needlestick injury, intravenous drug use, dialysis, or blood transfusions. Hepatitis A, while a potential cause of hepatitis in this patient who recently traveled to an endemic region, would typically present with an acute phase (e.g., fevers, nausea, vomiting) with elevated liver enzymes and a return to baseline following resolution. The chronicity of this patient’s condition raises concern for another hepatitis virus.
❌ Unprotected sexual intercourse:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B and D are transmitted sexually. Hepatitis C has also been documented to occur through sexual intercourse; however, sexual transmission is much less common than parenteral transmission.
❌ Vertical transmission:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B and D can be transmitted vertically from mother to child during pregnancy. Hepatitis C has also been documented to occur through vertical transmission; however, vertical transmission is much less common than parenteral transmission.
❌ Vector borne transmission:
Incorrect: None of the hepatitis viruses are transmitted via vectors such as mosquitos.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old African American woman presents to her primary care physician with burning and redness of her left eye. She reports onset of symptoms approximately one week ago, but on review of systems, she also reports chronic fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. She has no significant past medical history, but she states her mother has an “autoimmune” disorder; she is unsure of the details. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs and has not traveled recently. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 130/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.  Physical examination reveals red, hard, painful lumps over the anterior shins. Ocular examination of the left eye is depicted below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

This patient’s clinical presentation is most likely associated with which of the following pathological features?
questions.solution:
This young, African-American female presents with constitutional symptoms including weight loss, fatigue, shortness of breath and cough. Additional findings include erythema nodosum (tender nodules over the shins) and an image depicting uveitis, or inflammation of the uvea. Together, these findings are concerning for sarcoidosis, a multi-system non-caseating granulomatous disorder.  

Sarcoidosis is more common in African-Americans, and patients often have a family member with the condition as well. While the exact pathophysiology of this disease is still being studied, it is thought to be due to dendritic cell overstimulation in response to a foreign antigen, resulting in multisystem granulomatous disease. Over time, deposition of granulomas results in fibrous scar formation in affected organs—for example, causing restrictive lung disease in the lung or cardiomyopathy in the heart. Less commonly, granuloma formation in the liver can result in cholestatic liver disease and cirrhosis. Nervous system involvement commonly manifests with Bell's palsy.

Most patients with sarcoidosis are completely asymptomatic, but when symptoms do arise, they are usually constitutional. Symptoms include fever, weight loss, fatigue, arthropathy, shortness of breath and coughing. More specific signs and symptoms include erythema nodosum, lupus pernio (a lupus like rash), and uveitis.     

Option Analysis

✅ Non-caseating granulomas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caseating granulomas:
Incorrect:Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection is associated with caseation necrosis and presents with fevers, night sweats, weight loss, as well as risk factors for acquisition such as travel to endemic areas. It is a rare cause of uveitis. 
❌ Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies :
Incorrect: Crohn disease is associated with anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies as well as anterior uveitis. This patient has some clinical features of this condition; however, she is without any gastrointestinal features, making this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ HLA-B27 surface antigen:
Incorrect: HLA-B27 surface antigen is associated with ankylosing spondylitis as well as ulcerative colitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis—all of which are clinically correlated with uveitis. However, aside from uveitis, this patient does not have typical features of these diseases.
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibodies :
Incorrect: Systemic lupus erythematosus is associated with anti-dsDNA antibodies and is rarely associated with uveitis. Additionally, patients with SLE typically present with polyarthralgias, rashes, and/or painless oral ulcers, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old African-American man presents to his primary care physician with shortness of breath and fatigue over the past several months. He complains of diffuse pain in his joints as well as a rash that appeared over his lower extremities. He reports “I’m just not feeling like myself, and I’m starting to wonder if I’m depressed.” His past medical history is notable for obesity, hypertension, and a 20-pack-year smoking history. He works as a construction contractor. Temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 147/94 mmHg. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable for submandibular and axillary lymphadenopathy, as well as red tender lumps on the anterior shins. He subsequently undergoes lymph node biopsy that demonstrates the following pathologic lesion:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

Which of the following laboratory findings is most commonly associated with this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This African-American patient presents with chronic shortness of breath, fatigue, erythema nodosum (red tender lumps on the anterior shins), lymphadenopathy, as well as a histologic image demonstrating asteroid bodies consistent with sarcoidosis. Of the laboratory findings listed, hypercalcemia is most commonly found in patients with sarcoidosis due to increased expression of 1-alpha hydroxylase in alveolar macrophages. Increased 1-alpha hydroxylase results in conversion of vitamin D precursors to calcitriol and increased intestinal absorption of calcium.  


Sarcoidosis refers to a multisystem granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas in involved organs, most commonly the lungs. Diagnosis of the disease is made by confirming compatible clinical and radiographic manifestations, excluding other similar diseases, and tissue biopsy confirming detection of noncaseating granulomas.  

Laboratory findings associated with sarcoidosis include increased serum ACE levels, hypercalcemia, and an increased CD4/CD8 T-cell ratio. Additional clues to the diagnosis include radiographic findings of bilateral hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy, coarse reticular opacities, or a honeycombing pattern in the upper lobes (late finding) on chest CT. Histologic specimens contain noncaseating granulomas with associated asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies, which are calcium and protein inclusions inside of Langhans giant cells. The majority of cases resolve spontaneously without any required treatment; however, more severe cases may require treatment with steroids.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypercalcemia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophilia :
Incorrect: Infections with opportunistic fungal infections, such as Aspergillus, can result in peripheral eosinophilia on a complete blood count and differential; however, opportunistic infections are rarely associated with sarcoidosis. 
❌ Overexpression of calretinin :
Incorrect: Mesothelioma is associated with an overexpression of calretinin. Histologically, it is associated with psammoma bodies. 
❌ Increased plasma 5-HIAA concentration :
Incorrect: Elevated plasma 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) can be seen in patients with carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid tumor cells secrete excessive amounts of serotonin. If the tumor metastasizes to the lungs, patients can present with systemic symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, such as unexplained diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, and/or bronchospasm/wheezing. Although this patient has shortness of breath, this patient lacks the other suggestive symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely.   
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect:Legionella and certain lung malignancies  (e.g. small cell carcinoma) are associated with hyponatremia—the latter due to SIADH. Hyponatremia is not commonly associated with sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. She was found down by her neighbors, who immediately called EMS. Medical history is notable for multiple myeloma, for which she is currently undergoing treatment. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 137/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 89% on room air. Physical exam reveals a cachectic, ill-appearing woman who is moaning and unable to provide further history. She has bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness to palpation as well as warm and perfused peripheral extremities. Subsequent blood cultures grow gram-negative rods. Which of the following is the most likely trigger of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, fever, hypotension, and growth of a gram-negative rod on blood culture. This clinical presentation is consistent with septic shock in the setting of pyelonephritis. Of the triggers listed above, lipid A, a component of gram-negative bacteria, is responsible for the systemic inflammatory response mediating sepsis.  

Lipid A is a heat-stable endotoxin and component of the lipopolysaccharide cell wall in gram-negative bacteria. When gram-negative bacteria are lysed by the immune system, lipid A is released into the bloodstream, inducing macrophages to release TNF, IL-1, and IL-6. These inflammatory cytokines activate and injure the vascular endothelium, leading to nitric oxide release and systemic vasodilation. They also promote tissue factor (thromboplastin) expression, triggering the extrinsic coagulation cascade and potentially resulting in disseminated intravascular coagulation. 

Clinically, septic shock manifests with decreased systemic vascular resistance, decreased venous return, and decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. The heart compensates by increasing cardiac output, producing a high flow state wherein tissues cannot properly extract circulating oxygen. This results in increased anaerobic metabolism, lactic acidosis, and increased mixed venous oxygen saturation.  

If untreated, septic shock portends a high mortality rate due to the body’s inability to perfuse vital organs. Septic shock can result in multi-organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and thrombosis. Treatment involves fluid resuscitation, broad spectrum antibiotics, and vasopressors for hemodynamic support.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lipid A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Histamine and bradykinin:
Incorrect: The primary mediators of anaphylactic shock, which is a subtype of “warm” or distributive shock, are histamine and bradykinin. Triggers for anaphylactic shock include bee stings or other allergens such as peanuts. In contrast, this patient has fever, bilateral costovertebral tenderness, and a positive blood culture, which raises more concerns for septic shock secondary to a urinary tract infection.
❌ Mutation in factor V:
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden is a hereditary clotting disorder that promotes the formation of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, which can lead to obstructive shock. Although this patient is at risk for venous thromboembolism given the history of malignancy, this clinical presentation is more consistent with septic shock.
❌ Thromboplastin:
Incorrect: Tissue thromboplastin is commonly activated in the setting of severe sepsis and can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). While this patient has features of septic shock, she does not display features of DIC, such as oozing from IV sites or ecchymosis.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a protein produced by Streptococcus pyogenes, a gram-positive coccus. This protein degrades cell membranes and lyses red blood cells RBCs. While Streptococcus pyogenes can induce septic shock, this exotoxin is not implicated in its pathogenesis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine visit. He reports that he is otherwise feeling well aside from a chronic cough. He reports that he continues to smoke 10-15 cigarettes per day despite attempting to quit earlier this year. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. He has been working in an underground coal mine for the past twenty years. The patient has a screening chest x-ray performed which is demonstrated below.  

 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology resulting in this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Imbalance in protease-antiprotease activity and enlargement of alveolar space
Calcification and fibrosis of the pleura
Type IV hypersensitivity reaction and granuloma formation

questions.solution:
This patient who works in a coal mine presents with a history of chronic cough and a chest x-ray that demonstrates focal nodular opacities in the upper lobes, consistent with coal workers pneumoconiosis. The underlying pathophysiology of these radiographic findings is related to an aggregation of macrophages laden with carbon.  

Coal workers pneumoconiosis, also known as black lung disease, or coal miners disease, is caused by prolonged inhalation of coal dust—usually over a time period of approximately twenty years. Coal dust that enters the lungs cannot be removed, and the particles are engulfed by resident alveolar or interstitial macrophages. Over time, coal dust provides a sufficient stimulus for the macrophage to release various inflammatory products and fibroblast growth factors, inducing further aggregation of carbon-laden macrophages called coal macules, which are often surrounded by focal emphysema.  These aggregations can cause inflammation and fibrosis, as well as the formation of nodular lesions within the lungs, typically in the upper lobes.    

Most patients with coal workers pneumoconiosis are asymptomatic, and when they do develop symptoms, it is usually in the form of chronic cough, dyspnea, or fleeting chest discomfort. Diagnosis is based on a history of exposure to coal, a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing, as well as a chest x-ray demonstrating small rounded, nodular opacities in the upper lobes. Treatment for this condition is removal from the exposure and supportive care.  



Option Analysis

✅ Aggregation of carbon laden macrophages:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Imbalance in protease-antiprotease activity and enlargement of alveolar space:
Incorrect: An imbalance in protease-antiprotease activity and enlargement of alveolar space is the primary mechanism thought to underlie the development of emphysematous changes in the lung. While this patient does smoke, the chest radiograph does not demonstrate emphysematous changes such as flattened diaphragms, large bullae, or increased retrosternal space.    
❌ Calcification and fibrosis of the pleura:
Incorrect: Calcification and fibrosis of the pleura results in pleural thickening and plaque formation, a feature unique to asbestosis. At risk individuals include those who work in shipbuilding, plumbing, or roofing.
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction and granuloma formation:
Incorrect: Berylliosis is a noncaseating granulomatous disease due to exposure to beryllium—a metal found in computers, electronics, and cars. 
❌ Intraalveolar exudate :
Incorrect: A lobar pneumonia results in intra-alveolar exudate and subsequent lung consolidation, which appears as a lobar opacity on chest x-ray. This patient’s clinical presentation is inconsistent with bacterial pneumonia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the office by her partner due to hand tremors and a clumsy gait, which have progressively worsened over the last 4 months. Past medical history is noncontributory. She lives with her partner, who has noticed that she has become more withdrawn lately. The patient does not drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or use illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her BMI is 20 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. During the physical examination, the patient exhibits a flat affect while speaking. Her liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin and is mildly tender. No palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites is noted. A resting tremor is present in the bilateral hands. Further physical examination of this patient would most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Green-brown rings in the periphery of the iris
Cool, dry skin and hair loss

questions.solution:
This young female has personality changes, tremors, and hepatomegaly and Kayser-Fleischer rings. These findings are suggestive of Wilson disease.  

Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to impaired copper excretion into the bile and subsequent copper accumulation. Normally, the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13 encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase. The protein helps excrete copper into the bile and synthesize ceruloplasmin (carrier protein for copper in the serum). However, these functions are impaired in patients with mutant copies of the gene.  

Initially, copper accumulates in the liver, manifesting as hepatitis, hepatomegaly, and eventually cirrhosis. With disease progression, copper accumulates in other organs as well, such as the brain and cornea. Accumulation in the brain causes extrapyramidal symptoms, such as dysarthria, Parkinsonism (e.g. hand tremors), drooling, and behavioral changes (e.g. depression). Corneal deposition results in Kayser-Fleischer rings, which is a pathognomonic finding for Wilson disease. These green-brown rings are located in the periphery of the iris and can be visualized on slit-lamp examination.  

Laboratory testing may reveal reduced ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper excretion. Treatment consists of chelating agents, such as penicillamine, which increase renal excretion of copper by forming water-soluble compounds.


Image reproduced from



Option Analysis

✅ Green-brown rings in the periphery of the iris:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperresonant lungs on percussion:
Incorrect: α1-antitrypsin deficiency is characterized by uninhibited neutrophil elastase activity, which results in destruction of lung parenchyma and panacinar emphysema. It would clinically manifest as hyperresonant lungs on percussion. Although the accumulation of misfolded α1-antitrypsin protein within hepatocytes can cause hepatocyte destruction and eventually cirrhosis, it would not present with the neurological disturbances seen in this patient.
❌ Diffusely hyperpigmented skin:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis is caused by a genetic mutation resulting in uninhibited small intestinal reabsorption of iron. Over time, the iron accumulates, resulting in widespread deposition into organ tissues. Dermal deposition can present as diffuse hyperpigmentation (bronzing) of the skin. Although hemochromatosis can cause hepatitis and eventually cirrhosis, it would not present with the neurologic manifestations seen in this patient.
❌ Cool, dry skin and hair loss:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis results in iron deposition within various organs. Pituitary deposition can result in hypopituitarism, which can cause secondary hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism can cause cool, dry skin, hair loss, and fatigue. However, it would not lead to a hand tremor or abnormal gait.
❌ Exaggerated startle response:
Incorrect: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative condition caused by misfolded protein particles (prions). Accumulation of prion particles in the brain eventually leads to neuronal degeneration. CJD presents with rapidly progressing dementia, depression, and an exaggerated startle response with myoclonus. It would not, however, present with hepatomegaly, as seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right eye pain and redness. The pain started suddenly, and it is difficult for him to open the right eye in a well lit room. The patient has a history of chronic atraumatic low back pain for which he intermittently takes ibuprofen. Chart review reveals three similar episodes of eye pain requiring emergency department visits; however, the patient failed to follow up with an opthamologist. The patient’s right eye appears injected with associated photophobia.  X-ray of the patient's spine is shown below.  


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons  

Laboratory analysis demonstrates a C-reactive protein level 26 mg/L (normal <10 mg/L). If left untreated, this patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of anterior uveitis, including sudden onset eye pain, redness and photophobia.  Additionally, his x-ray findings of vertebral body fusion suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Other extra-articular manifestations of AS include aortic regurgitation (AR) and restrictive lung disease (RLD).  

AS is a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy that mainly involves spinal and sacroiliac joints, and is associated with multiple extra-articular findings including ocular, pulmonary, cardiac, gastrointestinal, and dermatologic manifestations. The most common extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic regurgitation, restrictive lung disease sans fibrosis, psoriasis, and the inflammatory bowel diseases ulcerative colitis and crohn’s disease.    

In addition, several complications are associated with long term axial AS, including vertebral body fractures, lumbosacral spinal cord compromise,and osteoporosis as a result of abnormal bone metabolism causing loss of trabecular bone in vertebral bodies. It is usually evident within the first 10 years of the disease onset and increases the risk of fragility fractures. No specific guidelines exist regarding the optimal time to start screening for low BMD in patients with AS; however, some authorities recommend screening for low BMD in the first year of diagnosis of AS with continued monitoring every two years, especially in the setting of high disease activity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Osteoporosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Avascular necrosis of femoral head:
Incorrect: Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head results from occlusion of end-arteries supplying the femoral head. Common causes include long-term steroid use, systemic lupus erythematosus, hemoglobinopathies and antiphospholipid syndrome. Ankylosing spondylitis is not associated with avascular necrosis of the femoral head. 
❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with scarring of aortic leaflet cusps which can lead to aortic regurgitation. In contrast, mitral valve stenosis is a complication of rheumatic fever, in which the axial skeleton is not involved. 
❌ Felty syndrome:
Incorrect: Felty syndrome is characterized by painful swelling and stiffness of small joints (metacarpophalangeal joints, interphalangeal joints), neutropenia and splenomegaly as a complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. Involvement of thoracic and lumbar spine is unusual.  
❌ Pulmonary hypertension:
Incorrect: Pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery pressure ≥25 mmHg) can occur as a complication of left sided-heart disease, chronic lung disease, and systemic soft tissue diseases like SLE and sarcoidosis. It is not, however, seen in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to his physician for evaluation of personality changes. At work, he has recently gotten into several heated arguments with colleagues and has missed several deadlines. The patient states, “I just feel more irritable than usual, and even small things get me angry." He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Medical history is notable for a right humeral fracture that occurred 5 years ago while playing soccer. Family history is notable for “liver disease” in his maternal uncle and grandfather, but he is unaware of additional details. Physical examination reveals greenish-brown rings around the iris. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Resting tremors are present in the bilateral hands. Which of the following sets of laboratory values would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has changes in personality, hepatomegaly, Kayser-Fleischer rings, and tremors. In combination, these findings are concerning for Wilson disease.  

Patients with Wilson disease have impaired biliary copper excretion and impaired hepatic incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin. Ceruloplasmin is a protein that is heavily involved in copper transport throughout the body; 90% of copper is bound to ceruloplasmin whereas only 10% is free in the serum. As a result, patients with Wilson disease will have a decreased total serum copper concentration due to decreased ceruloplasmin levels. However, due to copper-overload, there is an increase in free serum copper (i.e. copper not bound to ceruloplasmin). The elevation in free serum copper subsequently leads to increased urinary copper excretion.  

Clinically, symptoms develop due to copper accumulation in various organs. Copper deposition in the liver can cause hepatotoxicity and cirrhosis. The excess copper also deposits in the brain causing Parkinsonism and extrapyramidal symptoms. Disease progression can be slowed by administering copper chelating agents, such as penicillamine or trientine.

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Total serum copper would be decreased, not increased, in patients with Wilson disease. This is because most of the copper in the serum is bound to ceruloplasmin (10% free, 90% ceruloplasmin-bound). As a result, a decrease in ceruloplasmin, as seen in Wilson disease, leads to a decreased total serum copper.
❌ :
Incorrect: Total serum copper is decreased, not increased, in patients with Wilson disease. This is because most of the copper in the serum is bound to ceruloplasmin (10% free, 90% ceruloplasmin-bound). As a result, a decrease in ceruloplasmin, as seen in Wilson disease, causes a decreased total serum copper. Furthermore, patients with Wilson disease have increased, not decreased, urinary copper excretion.
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms consistent with Wilson disease. Laboratory testing would reveal low ceruloplasmin levels. Furthermore, total serum copper would be decreased, not increased, in Wilson disease. This is because most of the copper in the serum is bound to ceruloplasmin (10% free, 90% ceruloplasmin-bound). As a result, a decrease in ceruloplasmin leads to a decreased total serum copper.
❌ :
Incorrect: Patients with Wilson disease have reduced ceruloplasmin levels, which leads to an increase in free serum copper (copper not bound to ceruloplasmin). Since free serum copper is increased, urinary copper excretion would be increased as well.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to bloody vomiting. The patient was at home watching television when he felt nauseated and threw up “a cup full” of bright red blood. He has not experienced any chest pain. The patient has a history of hepatitis C infection that was diagnosed 7 years ago, but he was not treated due to a lack of medical follow-up. He has never consumed alcohol, but smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. He does not consume illicit substances. At arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 98/64 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and palmar erythema. Paraumbilical veins are visible. There is 1+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. This patient’s condition is most likely related to which of the following?

choices.text: Infiltration of eosinophils in the esophagus

questions.solution:
