Untreated hepatitis C infection is a common cause of liver cirrhosis, which can manifest with scleral icterus and jaundice, palmar erythema, caput medusae (visible paraumbilical veins), and fluid accumulation (e.g., pitting edema, abdominal ascites). As blood flow through the liver is impeded due to hepatic fibrosis and scarring, portal hypertension develops. There is subsequently backflow of blood into the portosystemic anastomoses, as well as the spleen, which presents as splenomegaly. This increased backflow of blood into the portosystemic anastomoses results in dilated veins. Prominent areas of anastomosis include the following:  

  • Anterior surface of the abdomen, causing caput medusae  
  • Lower rectum leading to hemorrhoids, which can manifest as hematochezia  
  • Lower end of the esophagus leading to esophageal varices  

Esophageal varices are at a major risk for rupturing and bleeding. Ruptured esophageal varices can cause massive hematemesis and life-threatening hemorrhage. Despite intervention, nearly 50% of patients die from their first bleeding episodes, and amongst those who survive, 20% have recurrent episodes.



Option Analysis

✅ Increased esophageal venous pressures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone:
Incorrect: Decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone can be seen in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which typically present as retrosternal burning pain (heartburn), regurgitation, and cough. However, GERD would not manifest with acute hematemesis.
❌ Rupture of the esophageal wall:
Incorrect: Transmural rupture of the esophageal wall is termed Boerhaave syndrome. It is rare but can occur after repeated episodes of vomiting or after prolonged coughing. Patients have severe retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (described as crepitus on chest auscultation), both of which this patient lacks.
❌ Infiltration of eosinophils in the esophagus:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by infiltration of eosinophils into the esophagus. It is associated with atopy and asthma. Patients can present with dysphagia and food impaction, but they usually do not have hematemesis. Additionally, this patient has symptoms of cirrhosis (e.g., scleral icterus, palmar erythema) and more likely has hematemesis secondary to an esophageal variceal bleed.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with weight loss and fatigue that has been ongoing for several months. The patient has been experiencing “weakness” in his knees and dizziness when rising from a seated to standing position. He also reports, “I don’t feel as sharp as I used to. I’m constantly forgetting things.” The patient traveled to Guatemala several weeks ago to visit his extended family. Past medical history is unremarkable, and family history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus and glioblastoma multiforme in his mother. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination is notable for hyperpigmented palmar creases; neurologic examination is non-focal. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and orthostatic hypotension. Physical examination is notable for hyperpigmented palmar creases, reflective of increased melanin in the setting of augmented ACTH production. Together, his clinical presentation is consistent with primary adrenal insufficiency, of which the most common etiology in the developed world is autoimmune adrenalitis.  

A careful history and physical examination can disclose the etiology and subtype of chronic adrenal insufficiency. In general, chronic adrenal insufficiency presents with non-specific or constitutional symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, muscle or joint pain, and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., impaired memory, depression).  

Differentiating features of chronic primary adrenal insufficiency include hyperpigmentation, salt craving, orthostatic hypotension, as well as hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and metabolic acidosis. Hyperpigmentation stems from increased levels of ACTH, which stimulate melanin stimulating hormone (MSH) production and subsequent melanin synthesis. Loss of aldosterone leaves the kidneys with an inability to adequately retain sodium, excrete potassium, and maintain intravascular volume--leading to salt craving, orthostatic hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and metabolic acidosis. Additional clues to this diagnosis include a family history of autoimmune disorders (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, type I  diabetes mellitus).  

In contrast, chronic secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency is more commonly due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis dysfunction -- and thus does not affect levels of aldosterone. This means that patients with chronic secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency will not develop metabolic derangements. Hyperpigmentation will also be absent since ACTH production is reduced. Important clinical features for secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency include headaches, focal neurologic deficits, and abrupt withdrawal of exogenous glucocorticoids.  



Option Analysis

✅ Autoimmune adrenalitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic mycobacterial infection:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection is the most common etiology of primary adrenal insufficiency in the developing world. Associated clinical features include hemoptysis, fevers, night sweats, and cough, which are absent in this patient.
❌ Pituitary macroadenoma:
Incorrect: Pituitary macroadenomas are common culprits of secondary adrenal insufficiency, which typically present with chronic headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia. In contrast, this patient does not have any such symptoms.
❌ Suprasellar mass:
Incorrect: Suprasellar masses such as glioblastoma multiforme may manifest with clinical features of headache, elevated intracranial pressure, as well as secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency. This patient’s neurologic exam is unremarkable, making this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Intraparenchymal hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage can potentially lead to secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency. However, it is unlikely this patient has an intraparenchymal hemorrhage given the normal neurologic exam and lack of associated risk factors (e.g., hypertension, excess alcohol consumption).

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman is evaluated by the outpatient physician for 5-months of generalized fatigue and diffuse soft-tissue pain. The pain is present in the upper extremities, lower extremities, and back. She feels tired every morning despite getting adequate sleep in the evening. Past medical history is notable for hypertension that is currently managed with propranolol. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 136/88 mmHg, pulse is 61/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination reveals 5/5 strength and full range-of-motion in the upper and lower extremities. Soft-tissue tenderness is elicited at multiple locations across the patient’s body. Laboratory results are as follows:  

 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.8 g/dL 
 Leukocyte  7,800/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)   7 mm/h 
 Serum creatinine kinase  27 U/L 
 Antinuclear antibodies  Negative 

Which of the following additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?

choices.text: Facial rash exacerbated by sunlight exposure
Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine
Improvement of symptoms with medication cessation

questions.solution:
This patient has fibromyalgia, a condition caused by abnormal pain perception. The exact mechanism of abnormal pain perception is uncertain and likely multimodal, but various studies have determined that patients have an exaggerated pain response to pain stimuli, altered brain structure, and altered neurotransmitter function. The condition is most often diagnosed in women between 20-50 years-old. Fibromyalgia often runs in families, so there appears to be a strong genetic component to the disease. Pyschological trauma like child abuse is also linked to fibromyalgia.  

Patients with fibromyalgia present with chronic widespread pain that most often present at points where muscles attach to the bone. These are called “tender points.” The tender points are spread throughout the patient’s body and lack the localized patterns found in conditions such as polymyositis/dermatomyositis (proximal tenderness) or ankylosing spondylosis (spinal tenderness).  

In addition, cognitive disturbances are present in the majority of patients. Patients may present with fatigue, headaches, unrefreshing sleep, and difficulty concentrating. The cognitive disturbances are often referred to as "fibro fog." Patients commonly describe problems with attention and difficulty doing tasks that require rapid thought changes. Psychiatric symptoms are also common in patients with fibromyalgia, with depression and/or anxiety present in 30 to 50% of patients at the time of diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Jaw pain exacerbated by chewing:
Incorrect: Patients with temporal arteritis can have jaw pain that is exacerbated by chewing. Temporal arteritis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica, which causes pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips, as well as elevated ESR levels. In contrast, this patient has diffuse tenderness affecting both proximal and distal joints and normal ESR levels, suggesting a different diagnosis.
❌ Facial rash exacerbated by sunlight exposure:
Incorrect: A malar rash may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis presents with proximal muscle tenderness and weakness. In contrast, this patient has full strength throughout. Moreover, the patient has diffuse pain, as opposed to the localized symptoms observed in dermatomyositis. SLE can also be ruled out due to the negative antinuclear antibodies (ANA) titers.
✅ Difficulty concentrating at work :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: Patients with ankylosing spondylitis often have limited range of motion in the spine. The condition most often affects young men. Pain and tenderness is localized to the affected patient’s back. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to present with the diffuse soft-tissue tenderness noted in this patient.
❌ Improvement of symptoms with medication cessation:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers such as propranolol can cause fatigue and drowsiness as side effects. This phenomenon may potentially explain why the patient reports feeling tired despite getting adequate sleep. However, diffuse soft-tissue/joint pain is not a side effect of beta-blockers. As a result, discontinuing propranolol will likely have little effect on the patient’s symptoms.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for evaluation of multiple prior episodes of sunburn. According to his mother, the patient gets more easily sunburned and has a lighter skin tone as compared with his siblings. The patient’s family immigrated to the United States 2 years ago, and they previously had limited access to healthcare. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 97/68 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination reveals diffuse milky-white hair and skin. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.6 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  47% 
 Leukocytes  7,200/mm3 
 Platelets  190,000/mm3 

Genetic testing reveals reduced tyrosinase activity. Which of the following conditions is the patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient has albinism, which is characterized by a drastic reduction or complete lack of pigmentation in the hair, skin, and eyes. The condition arises due to congenital defects in tyrosinase, the enzyme that produces melanin, or impaired transport of tyrosine and melanosomes.  

Patients can have milky-white hair and skin. In addition, patients can have very light blue or translucent irises, which appear red because of the retinal tissue lining the back of the eye. The absence of melanin in the eyes causes a variety of vision problems, including impaired depth perception, reduced visual acuity, nystagmus, and amblyopia. Moreover, albinism can cause freckles, moles, and lentigines to form on the skin; the lack of melanin and exposure to intense ultraviolet radiation increases the risk of developing skin cancer.  

Albinism is also seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which can cause pancytopenia, recurrent infections, and peripheral neuropathy. Of note, this patient does not have Chediak-Higashi syndrome, since his blood cell counts are normal.  

Treatment involves preventing additional ailments arising from the lack of protection normally conferred by melanin. Prevention includes wearing tinted glasses for eye protection and sunscreen to reduce the risk of skin cancer. Nitisinone, a medication that increases tyrosine levels, can be used to treat certain forms of albinism.


Option Analysis

❌ Recurrent Staphylococcal infections:
Incorrect: This complication would likely develop in patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which is due to a defect in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene. The condition can cause albinism, pancytopenia, recurrent infections, and peripheral neuropathy. In contrast, this patient’s blood count shows normal hemoglobin, platelet, and leukocyte levels, making Chediak-Higashi syndrome unlikely.  
❌ Intellectual disability :
Incorrect: Intellectual disability may develop in patients with phenylketonuria, which occurs due to imapired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Patients can develop a musty odor, eczema, fair complexion, intellectual disability, and seizures. In contrast, this patient’s genetic testing reveals a defect in the tyrosinase enzyme. 
✅  Reduced visual acuity :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Early onset arthritis:
Incorrect: Early-onset arthritis may be a complication of alkaptonuria, which is due to a congenital defect in homogentisate oxidase. As a result, homogentisic acid accumulates in the body and can damage cartilage. Additional symptoms include bluish-black ear cartilage and sclera. 
❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome can develop peripheral neuropathy. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is due to a defect in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene, and it can be a cause of albinism. However, patients with this condition also develop pancytopenia. In contrast, this patient’s hemoglobin, leukocyte, and platelet counts are within normal limits.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of visual changes. She reports having blurry vision that is more pronounced at the end of the day. The symptom started gradually around 3 months ago and has been progressing over time. The patient was recently diagnosed with an anterior mediastinal mass via chest CT. She consumes a diet rich in fresh vegetables and meats. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals weakness in the extraocular muscles. When the patient is asked to look upwards toward the ceiling for 60 seconds, she notes double vision after 40 seconds, which resolves after several minutes of rest. Visual acuity and pupillary reflexes are normal. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.


Which of the following structures at the neuromuscular junction is most likely affected in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has extraocular muscle weakness that worsens with repeated activity and improves with rest. These findings are concerning for myasthenia gravis (MG). MG is often associated with thymic abnormalities (e.g., thymic hyperplasia or thymoma), as seen in this patient with recent diagnosis of mediastinal mass on CT scan.  

MG is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that develops when B-cells begin producing antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors on muscle cells. Myasthenia gravis causes muscle weakness via two mechanisms. First, the antibodies block the binding of ACh to its receptors. Second, the antibodies can activate the classical complement pathway, resulting in destruction of ACh receptors.

Due to the reduced number of available ACh receptors, ACh released at the nerve terminal is unable to generate the postsynaptic potential needed to induce muscle contraction, resulting in muscle weakness. The weakness is more pronounced with the repeated use of a muscle group, since it causes depletion of the ACh store in the neuromuscular junction.  

A minority of people with MG produce another type of antibody against muscle-specific tyrosine kinase (MuSK). This antibody attacks proteins within myocytes and also results in impaired muscle cell activity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Structure A  :
Incorrect: This patient with ptosis, diplopia and extraocular muscle weakness most likely has MG, which occurs due to the formation of auto-antibodies against postsynaptic ACh receptors. In contrast, structure A is a presynaptic mitochondria, which plays no role in the pathogenesis of MG.
❌ Structure B:
Incorrect: Structure B is a presynaptic vesicle containing ACh. Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting extravasation of these vesicles into the synaptic cavity, thereby inhibiting the release of ACh. Clinically, it can manifest as diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, and dyspnea. It is unlikely in this patient without any risk factors (e.g. ingestion of expired canned foods).
✅ Structure C:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Structure D:
Incorrect: Structure D is a presynaptic calcium channel. Patients with Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome develop auto-antibodies against this structure. The condition manifests with muscle weakness that temporarily improves with activity. However, this patient has ptosis that is elicited by prolonged upwards gaze, which suggests that her muscle weakness is worsened with activity. This finding is more consistent with MG.
❌ Structure E:
Incorrect: Structure E is a vesicle that has fused with the cellular membrane and is releasing ACh into the neuromuscular junction. As mentioned before, botulinum toxin impairs this process and can manifest with flaccid muscle paralysis, diplopia, dysarthria, and/or dysphagia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of recurrent bloating and diarrhea over the past 2 months. She has bulky and foul-smelling diarrhea that is often difficult to flush. The patient had a Roux-en-Y reconstruction 5 years ago for morbid obesity that was refractory to diet and lifestyle modifications. Since then, she has lost 45-lbs, which has significantly improved her daily life. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies demonstrate a hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 101 µm3. Serum electrolytes are normal. Stool analysis shows no occult blood and stool culture is negative. The patient is asked to ingest 25 g of D-xylose following an overnight fast. Urine concentration of D-xylose after several hours is 3.0 g (normal ≥4.5 g). The physician prescribes her oral antibiotics, and the test is repeated after 2 weeks. Subsequent urine concentration is 9.2 g. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Microbial overgrowth in the small intestine
Reduced secretion of pancreatic lipase and colipase
Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the small bowel
Villous blunting due to gliadin hypersensitivity

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of malabsorption (e.g., bloating, foul-smelling diarrhea). Taking into consideration her previous history of a Roux-en-Y bypass surgery and abnormal D-xylose test that normalizes after antibiotic therapy, she likely has small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).

SIBO can arise due to blind loop syndrome, which occurs when a portion of the intestines is bypassed and food no longer passes through it. Blind intestinal loops are vulnerable to stasis and bacterial proliferation. In SIBO, intestinal bacteria deconjugate primary bile acids, resulting in impaired dietary fat absorption and subsequent steatorrhea.

The D-xylose test measures the absorptive capacity of the small intestine and is used to determine whether defects in the intestinal mucosa are responsible for malabsorption. In cases of SIBO, increased bacterial proliferation results in impaired D-xylose absorption. Since the elimination of D-xylose is mostly renal, inadequate intestinal absorption leads to low urine D-xylose levels. In patients with SIBO, D-xylose absorption will often increase following a course of antibiotics.  





Option Analysis

✅ Microbial overgrowth in the small intestine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced secretion of pancreatic lipase and colipase:
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis is the most common cause of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency in adults. It can manifest with steatorrhea, diarrhea, and recurrent bloating. However, the D-xylose test in patients with pancreatic insufficiency is normal because the small bowel mucosa is undamaged, and as a result, the monosaccharide can be absorbed and subsequently excreted via urine.
❌ Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the small bowel:
Incorrect: Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the small bowel can be seen in patients with Crohn disease. Although Crohn disease tends to present in young adults with signs of steatorrhea, the D-xylose test would be abnormal even after antibiotic treatment, since the damaged bowel wall would still not be able to absorb the monosaccharide.
❌ Inadequate synthesis of bile acids:
Incorrect: Bile acids are essential for proper lipid digestion in the small bowel. D-xylose is a monosaccharide and can be absorbed by the small intestine even without bile. As a result, conditions that result in inadequate bile synthesis or release into the gastrointestinal lumen (e.g., cirrhosis, choledocolithiasis) would not affect D-xylose absorption.
❌ Villous blunting due to gliadin hypersensitivity:
Incorrect: Celiac disease is characterized by villous blunting secondary to gliadin hypersensitivity. Since celiac disease impairs proper small bowel absorption, it would result in an abnormal D-xylose test. However, antibiotics would be ineffective in treating celiac disease or improving intestinal D-xylose absorption.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old male comes to his outpatient provider’s office for evaluation of fatigue and diffuse muscle aches. His symptoms started about a year ago and have been progressing over time. He also reports having bowel movement once a week with hard, pellet-like stool formation. Past medical history is significant for insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus type 2 and end-stage renal disease. He underwent a kidney transplant two months ago. His medications include insulin and sirolimus. The patient has a 35-pack-year smoking history but is no longer smoking. In the office, his temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 115/74 mmHg. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Serum calcium  11.2 mg/dL 
 Serum phosphate  2.4 mg/dL 
 Parathyroid hormone*  560 pg/mL 
  *Normal range: 10-55 pg/mL  

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Secretion of parathyroid-hormone related peptide by a tumor
Reduced calcitonin secretion by thyroid gland

questions.solution:
This patient with end stage renal disease (ESRD) presents with fatigue, diffuse muscle aches and constipation, with laboratory evidence of hypercalcemia and high serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. He has most likely developed tertiary hyperparathyroidism.   

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is sometimes seen in patients who have had secondary hyperparathyroidism for many years (e.g. patients with ESRD), leading to severe parathyroid hyperplasia, with autonomous secretion of PTH that is no longer adequately responsive to the plasma calcium concentration. The end-result is hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia and markedly elevated serum PTH levels. Even if the underlying cause of the secondary hyperparathyroidism is treated, the parathyroid glands will continue producing PTH independent of calcium levels. In this scenario, the ESRD was treated by a kidney transplant, but PTH secretion remains elevated.  

Patients with tertiary HPTH usually present with clinical features of hypercalcemia, which include, polyuria, bone pain, constipation, muscle weakness, fatigue and psychiatric symptoms. Laboratory findings include elevated PTH and calcium levels. Phosphate levels can vary. If the person still has chronic kidney disease, phosphate will be high. But if the person has had a kidney transplant, then phosphate will be low because the new kidneys will be working properly (as in this patient). 

Option Analysis

❌ Side effect of sirolimus :
Incorrect: Sirolimus is used after transplant surgery to prevent organ rejection. Side-effects include pancytopenia, insulin resistance, and hyperlipidemia. However, sirolimus does not cause excess PTH release or hypercalcemia as side effects. 
❌ End-organ resistance to parathyroid hormone:
Incorrect: End-organ resistance to PTH is observed in patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism 1a. This condition does result in elevated PTH levels. However, since end-organs like the kidneys are unable to respond to PTH, serum calcium levels are low and phosphate levels are high. 
❌ Secretion of parathyroid-hormone related peptide by a tumor:
Incorrect: Parathyroid-hormone related peptide (PTHrP) is sometimes released in certain malignancies (e.g. breast cancer and squamous cell lung cancer) as a paraneoplastic syndrome. Excess PTHrP secretion causes hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia. However, in response to hypercalcemia, PTH levels will be reduced. This patient has elevated PTH levels. 
✅  Calcium-independent secretion of parathyroid hormone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Reduced calcitonin secretion by thyroid gland :
Incorrect: Calcitonin prevents bone reabsorption and helps bring down blood calcium levels. Reduced calcitonin secretion will in turn raise calcium levels, which would decrease PTH release by negative feedback. In contrast, this patient has elevated PTH levels.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of generalized muscle aching, weakness and pain in the left hand. The symptoms started gradually a few months ago and have been progressing over time. Past medical history is notable for uncontrolled hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease. Her medications include amlodipine, hydralazine and insulin glargine. Her last recorded glomerular filtration rate is 20 mL/min, and she has been receiving dialysis three times per week for the past 2 years. A radiograph of the patient’s hands is shown below:


 Routine blood work is performed. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with end stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis for 2 years is now developing muscle aching, weakness and pain in left hand. Hands radiograph shows areas of subperiosteal bone resorption and multiple lytic expansile lesions (i.e. brown tumors (arrows)), making secondary hyperparathyroidism the most likely diagnosis.      

Secondary hyperparathyroidism develops in patients with chronic kidney disease due to decreased renal synthesis of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. Decreased vitamin D production causes hypocalcemia, stimulating parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion by the parathyroid glands. In addition, the hyperphosphatemia seen in patients with chronic kidney disease is another stimulus that increases PTH secretion, thereby increasing serum PTH.

 

Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a resultant skeletal disorder caused by a surplus of PTH in which osteoclastic bone resorption results in a loss of bone mass, peritrabecular fibrosis, and cyst-like brown tumors in and around bone (as seen in this patient). 

Option Analysis

✅   Parathyroid Hormone  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Increased  Decreased  Increased  :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Parathyroid Hormone Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Increased  Decreased  Decreased  :
Incorrect: This pattern is seen in patients with vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is activated to calcitriol in the kidneys and markedly increases intestinal calcium and phosphate absorption. Lack of vitamin D causes a negative feedback response that increases PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands. However, the patient’s history of end-stage kidney disease provides a more likely explanation for her clinical and radiographic findings.
❌   Parathyroid Hormone Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Increased  Increased  Decreased  :
Incorrect: This pattern is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism. In the majority of cases, primary hyperparathyroidism is caused by a benign adenoma of a single parathyroid gland that autonomously secretes PTH, resulting in elevated calcium and decreased phosphate levels. However, the patient’s history of end-stage kidney disease provides a more likely explanation for her clinical and radiographic findings.
❌   Parathyroid Hormone Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Increased  Increased  Increased  :
Incorrect: This pattern is seen in tertiary hyperparathyroidism, which is a state of excessive PTH secretion after a long period of secondary hyperthyroidism, reflecting the development of autonomous parathyroid gland function. It is preemptive to diagnose this patient as tertiary hyperparathyroidism without checking the response to therapy.
❌   Parathyroid Hormone Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Decreased  Increased  Decreased  :
Incorrect: Such set of findings can be seen in patients with humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy that is caused by secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide by malignant tumor cells. The rise in calcium and decline in phosphate levels cause negative feedback inhibition of endogenous PTH production, resulting in low PTH levels.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with worsening gait disturbance. He says, “I feel so unsteady on my feet, I can only get around in a wheelchair now.” In addition, the patient has experienced severe lancinating pain in his back. Past medical history is notable for HIV, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and polysubstance abuse. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 100/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Neurological exam is notable for bilateral dysmetria, a positive Romberg sign, and absent deep tendon reflexes. A screening rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is positive. Which of the following additional neurologic findings is commonly associated with this patient's condition?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a positive Romberg sign, dysmetria, and absent deep tendon reflexes, which are concerning for degenerative changes affecting the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Given his positive RPR test, the most likely etiology is tabes dorsalis secondary to a tertiary syphilis infection.  

Tabes dorsalis arises due to infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by Treponema pallidum, the spirochete that causes syphilis. The condition takes nearly 20 years to develop after initial infection. Infection of the spinal cord leads to demyelination and degeneration of the dorsal column and roots, resulting in findings of gait ataxia and incoordination.  

The most specific finding for tabes dorsalis is the Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is characterized by small bilateral pupils that do not constrict when exposed to bright light, but do constrict when focused on a nearby object. This finding is also termed light-near dissociation. Other common symptoms include lancinating pains, neurogenic urinary incontinence, and signs of dementia. Treatment involves administering intravenous penicillin.


Option Analysis

✅ Pupils that display light-near dissociation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Relative afferent pupillary defect:
Incorrect: Marcus Gunn pupil (MGP) refers to a finding observed during the swinging-flashlight test. Normally, after exposure to bright light, a pupil constricts. A MGP, on the other hand, has a relative afferent pupillary defect. As a result, when light is rapidly transferred from the normal eye to the eye with MGP, the MGP dilates instead of constricting. However, MGP is not typically associated with tertiary syphilis. 
❌ Cranial nerve III palsy:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve (CN) III nerve palsy refers to a “down and out pupil,” wherein the pupil is enlarged and shifted inferolaterally. Etiologies include uncal herniation and microvascular disease. In contrast, this patient has a positive Romberg sign, dysmetria, and absent deep tendon reflexes, which is more consistent with neurosyphilis. Neurosyphillis would not typically cause a CN III palsy. 
❌ Loss of pain and temperature sensation:
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis rarely affects the spinothalamic tract, which is an afferent pathway in the anterior spinal cord that relays pain and temperature sensation. This portion of the spinal cord is more commonly implicated in anterior spinal artery infarction or Brown-Sequard syndrome.  
❌ Saddle anesthesia:
Incorrect: Saddle anesthesia refers to numbness of the perineum and is often implicated in cauda equina syndrome. However, this patient lacks other findings that are worrisome for cauda equina syndrome, such as bowel/bladder incontinence or pain radiating down the legs.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man comes for a follow-up visit after a DEXA scan revealed that he had a T-score of -2.8. The patient is physically active and goes jogging 3-4 times per week. He consumes a diet rich in milk, meats, and fresh vegetables. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  141 mmol/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  25 mmol/L 
 Calcium  9.3 mmol/L 
 Phosphorous  3.7 mmol/L 

The patient is started on a new medication for his condition and educated on its side effects, which include esophagitis and jaw necrosis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this newly-prescribed medication?

choices.text: Activation of calcium sensing receptors in parathyroid glands
Reduction of phosphate uptake from gastrointestinal tract

questions.solution:
This patient has osteoporosis, which can be diagnosed with a T-score ≤ -2.5. The first step in management is to initiate lifestyle changes such as engaging in physical activity as well as ensuring adequate calcium and vitamin D intake.

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, are the first-line drugs to manage osteoporosis. Bisphosphonates are pyrophosphate analogs that bind to hydroxyapatite in the bone and inhibit osteoclast activity. Side effects include jaw osteonecrosis, atypical stress fractures, and, if taken orally, they can cause pill-induced esophagitis. To prevent this last side-effect, patients are advised to take the medication with water and remain upright for 30 minutes afterwards. Bisphosphonates should also be used with precaution in individuals with renal failure, since they are eliminated via the kidneys.  

For advanced cases of osteoporosis, teriparatide, a recombinant parathyroid hormone, can be used. Although parathyroid hormone stimulates bone resorption, it has been found that pulsatile injections with teriparatide activate osteoblasts more than osteoclasts. The net result is increased bone formation. Its side effects include transient hypercalcemia and increased risk of osteosarcoma. Other medications include denosumab, a monoclonal antibody against RANKL that inhibits osteoclasts maturation, and raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator that mimics natural estrogen.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of osteoclast bone resorption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activation of bone estrogen receptors:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of action of selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs). SERMs inhibit osteoclast differentiation and bone resorption. Side-effects include increased risk of venous thromboembolism and endometrial cancer in women. However, SERMs do not typically cause esophagitis or osteonecrosis.  
❌ Promotion of osteoblastic bone deposition:
Incorrect: Teriparatide, a PTH analog, has a similar mechanism of action to endogenous PTH, and therefore, when it is administered in a pulsatile manner, it stimulates osteoblast function, increases gastrointestinal calcium absorption, and increases renal tubular reabsorption of calcium. Side effects include hypercalcemia but not osteonecrosis or esophagitis, which are characteristic of another class of medications used to treat osteoporosis.
❌ Activation of calcium sensing receptors in parathyroid glands:
Incorrect: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic that allosterically activates calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands and other organs. This activation in turn reduces parathyroid hormone secretion, ultimately reducing the rate of bone breakdown. However, it would be atypical for cinacalcet to cause osteonecrosis or esophagitis.
❌ Reduction of phosphate uptake from gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Phosphate binders, such as sevelamer, decrease phosphate absorption from the gastrointestinal tract. Side effects include hypercalcemia and encephalopathy. The latter side-effect is more common among aluminum-containing phosphate binders.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of bone pain and an abnormal gait pattern. The patient and his family recently immigrated to the United States from Southeast Asia and previously had limited access to healthcare. According to the parents, the patient’s past medical history is notable for several episodes of pneumonia and greasy foul-smelling stools. His diet consists of fish, vegetables, and some meats. Vitals are within normal limits. He is below the 10th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination is notable for bowing of the legs and tenderness on palpation of the lower extremities. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  142 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.9 mmol/L 
 Calcium  8.0 mmol/L 
 Phosphorous  2.5 mmol/L 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired absorption of fat soluble vitamins
Intestinal damage secondary to autoimmune response

questions.solution:
This patient has rickets, the inadequate mineralization of the cartilaginous growth plates, secondary to cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis can cause exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, resulting in impaired absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, and K).  

In general, vitamin D deficiency is the most common cause of rickets. Often, it occurs in those with inadequate UV light exposure, since UV light stimulates vitamin D synthesis. Other causes of vitamin D deficiency include intestinal malabsorption, which can be seen with cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease. Of note, in this vignette, it was the patient’s history of recurrent pneumonia and steatorrhea that made cystic fibrosis the most likely underlying cause.  

Moreover, users of medications like phenytoin are also at risk. This is because phenytoin is metabolized by the same liver and kidney hydroxylase enzymes needed for vitamin D synthesis. Likewise, liver and kidney disease can also cause vitamin D deficiency. For example, in liver disease, the organ is unable to turn inactive vitamin D into 25-hydroxy-vitamin D. Likewise, in chronic kidney disease, the kidneys cannot turn 25-hydroxy-vitamin D into 1,25-hydroxy-vitamin D.    

Vitamin D deficiency leads to impaired uptake of calcium and phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract, ultimately causing impaired cartilage and bone mineralization.  

Option Analysis

❌ Genetic defect impairing osteoclast activity:
Incorrect: This answer describes osteopetrosis, which is characterized by impaired bone resorption. However, osteopetrosis presents with normal phosphorus levels. In addition, osteopetrosis would not account for the patient’s bowed legs, recurrent pneumonia, and steatorrhea.
❌ Inadequate dietary vitamin D intake:
Incorrect: Inadequate intake may lead to vitamin D deficiency and present with symptoms of rickets, such as bowed legs, bony pain, and abnormal gait. However, the patient’s history of recurrent pneumonia and steatorrhea raise concerns for cystic fibrosis, which causes vitamin D deficiency via impaired uptake from the intestinal tract. Additionally, this patient’s diet is well-balanced, consisting of fish and vegetables, which are typically high in vitamin D. 
❌ Inadequate dietary calcium intake  :
Incorrect: Inadequate calcium intake can also cause rickets. However, the patient’s history of recurrent pneumonia and steatorrhea raise suggest that cystic fibrosis, which can lead to imapired fat-soluble vitamin absorption, is a more likely explanation.
✅ Impaired absorption of fat soluble vitamins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intestinal damage secondary to autoimmune response:
Incorrect: Conditions such as celiac disease and inflammatory bowel disease can cause impaired absorption of vitamin D and minerals. However, these conditions would not explain the recurrent episodes of pneumonia found in this patient’s history.

questions.text: A 62 year-old man presents to his outpatient provider’s office because of two months of persistent headaches, blurry vision, and numbness in the hands bilaterally. The headache is unresponsive to over the counter pain-killers. He also reports 10 lbs (4.5 kg) weight loss over the same period. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Family history is significant for multiple sclerosis in his mother. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 75/min and blood pressure is 148/97 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is noncontributory. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. On peripheral smear, red blood cells are seen to clump together when placed in a 5°C (41°F) refrigerator. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Neoplastic proliferation of IgM-secreting plasma cells
Erythropoietin-independent proliferation of red blood cells
Autoimmune destruction of myelin in the central nervous system
Malignant proliferation of cells of myeloid lineage
Infection by a double-stranded DNA virus

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, a malignant proliferation of IgM-producing plasma cells. The elevated serum IgM levels result in increased blood viscosity. Many patients with the condition are asymptomatic, However, symptomatic patients present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, fever, weight loss) and symptoms secondary to increased blood viscosity/decreased blood flow (e.g., vision impairment, leg cramps, neuropathy).  

Diagnostic workup involves obtaining a complete blood count, peripheral blood smear, serum protein electrophoresis, and bone marrow biopsy. Cold agglutination, the clumping of red blood cells at low temperatures, can be seen on peripheral smears. A diagnosis of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia can be made if serum protein electrophoresis demonstrates elevated IgM levels and bone marrow biopsy shows greater than 10% plasma cells.  

Asymptomatic patients do not need treatment but should be followed closely. Patients with symptoms secondary to elevated blood viscosity should undergo plasmapheresis, which filters out the excess IgM. Chemotherapeutic agents such as rituximab and fludarabine can be utilized to destroy malignant plasma cells.  

Option Analysis

✅ Neoplastic proliferation of IgM-secreting plasma cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Erythropoietin-independent proliferation of red blood cells :
Incorrect: This answer describes polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by elevated red blood cell mass. Patients with the condition may present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss) and symptoms secondary to increased blood viscosity (e.g., visual disturbances, headaches, thrombosis). While the patient in this vignette has some of the aforementioned symptoms, it would be atypical for polycythemia vera to cause rouleaux formation on peripheral smear. 
❌ Autoimmune destruction of myelin in the central nervous system :
Incorrect: This answer describes multiple sclerosis, which may cause symptoms including vision impairment, incontinence, paresthesia, and impaired coordination. The patient presents with vision changes and has a family history of multiple sclerosis. However, the disease typically affects young adults between 20-40 years-old. Moreover, multiple sclerosis would not explain the cold-agglutination of RBCs. 
❌ Malignant proliferation of cells of myeloid lineage :
Incorrect: Malignant proliferation of cells of myeloid lineage (e.g. acute or chronic myeloid leukemia) can present with constitutional symptoms, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. However, it would be uncommon for either AML or CML to present with headaches, visual impairments, and peripheral neuropathy. In addition, peripheral smear finding of rouleaux formation cannot be accounted for by AML or CML. 
❌ Infection by a double-stranded DNA virus :
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus can present with fatigue, pharyngitis, and hepatosplenomegaly. In addition, the infection may cause elevated antibody levels and a positive cold-agglutinin test, which are seen in this patient. However, EBV infections most often occur in teens and young adults. Moreover, an EBV infection would not explain the patient’s visual findings or paresthesias.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of joint pain and stiffness. Her symptoms are worse in the morning and subsequently improve after two-hours of physical activity. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she is currently taking metformin. She has a 40-pack-year smoking history and currently smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes daily. The patient lives in rural Maryland and recalls several insect bites while hiking a few weeks ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for swelling and pain on passive motion in the bilateral metacarpophalangeal, wrist, and metatarsophalangeal joints. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints
Degenerative disorder of the joint articular cartilage
Deposition of uric acid in the joint space

questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the joint cartilage. It presents with symmetrical pain and swelling most frequently affecting the metacarpophalangeal (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP), and metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints.



Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with environmental risk factors, such as infections and smoking, and genetic predisposition, such as female gender and having the HLA-DR1/DR4 alleles. It is hypothesized that environmental risk factors modify normal articular proteins in the synovial joints. The modified proteins are targeted by the immune system, since it fails to recognize them as part of the normal body, causing the proteins to become self-antigens. Antigen presenting cells then pick up the self-antigens and activate CD4+ T-cells. T-helper cells then stimulate nearby B-cells to produce autoantibodies.

T-cells eventually enter the joints and secrete inflammatory cytokines. Likewise, autoantibodies bind to their targets and trigger the complement cascade. The inflammation causes synovial cells to proliferate. This increase in synovial and immune cells creates a pannus, a layer of granulation tissue and inflammatory cells. Over time, cytokines released in the pannus start to break down the articular cartilage, exposing the underlying bones, leading to bone erosion.





Option Analysis

✅ Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection by tick-transmitted spirochete:
Incorrect: This answer describes Lyme disease, which is prevalent in the Northeastern and upper Midwestern United States. The infection can cause a migratory arthritis that spreads from one large joint to another. However, it would be atypical for Lyme disease to affect the small joints of the hands and feet.
❌ Inflammatory damage of the muscles:
Incorrect: This answer describes polymyositis and dermatomyositis. Both conditions can cause proximal muscle weakness and most often affects the shoulders. However, it would be atypical for either condition to cause symmetric arthritis affecting the hands and feet.
❌ Degenerative disorder of the joint articular cartilage:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disorder wherein wear and tear destroys the articular cartilage. It most commonly affects large weight bearing joints and causes pain that worsens with activity. In contrast, this patient has pain that improves with activity.
❌ Deposition of uric acid in the joint space:
Incorrect: Gout is caused by the deposition of uric acid in the joint space. It usually causes acute pain in a single joint, classically the metatarsophalangeal joint of the big toe. In contrast, it would be atypical for gout to cause symmetric arthritis.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. The symptoms are most prominent in the hands. Stiffness is worse in the morning and gradually improves after 1-2 hours of activity. In addition, the patient endorses fatigue and a decreased appetite. She immigrated to the United States from Ireland 5 years ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 147/83 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Imaging of the patient’s hands reveals the following findings:


Reproduced from: Radiopedia  

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints
Deposition of uric acid in the joint space
Overuse of the joint articular cartilage

questions.solution:
This patient's radiograph shows erosion, joint space narrowing, and ulnar deviation most prominent in the metacarpophalangeal joints. Prominent erosion is also seen at the ulnar-carpal joint. These findings, in combination with the patient’s history of joint stiffness that improves with activity and constitutional symptoms, are most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis.   

Rheumatoid arthritis can present with the following imaging findings:  

1) Juxta-articular osteopenia, which is decreased bone density around the affected joint. It is seen as areas of increased transparency on x-ray.  

2) Soft tissue swelling, which is seen as a thick halo around the bone. However, swelling around small joints can be difficult to visualize on x-rays.    

3) Joint space narrowing   

4) Bone erosions, which look as if someone bit into the bone.  

5) Subchondral cysts, which are sacs of hyaluronic acid that form in the subchondral bone, the layer of bone just under the cartilage. On imaging, subchondral cysts look like dark, round, and fairly well-delineated areas inside the bone.

Figure 1: Hand radiograph with annotations

Caption: 1) Juxta-articular osteopenia, 2) bony erosions, 3) joint space narrowing.  



Option Analysis

❌ Bone loss secondary to hypercortisolism:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome, which is characterized by cortisol overproduction, can lead to osteoporosis secondary to decreased bone formation and increased bone absorption. Imaging would reveal increased radiolucency but would not show ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints, joint space narrowing, or bony erosions.
✅ Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Deposition of uric acid in the joint space:
Incorrect: This answer describes gout, which can cause acute joint pain. However, the condition generally causes monoarthritis. In contrast, it would be atypical for gout to cause the symmetrical joint space narrowing and ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints seen in this radiograph.
❌ Iron overaccumulation within the body:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis can cause arthritis secondary to iron deposition in the joints. The metacarpophalangeal joints are often affected. Imaging can reveal joint space narrowing and cyst formation. However, ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints is atypical for hemochromatosis.
❌ Overuse of the joint articular cartilage:
Incorrect: This answer describes osteoarthritis, which affects large weight-bearing joints and causes pain that is worse with activity. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph shows involvement of the small joints of the hand. Moreover, the patient’s joint symptoms improve with movement.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is referred to a cardiologist for evaluation for intermittent cyanosis and exercise intolerance. Symptoms began around half-a-year ago, and they have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for a congenital heart defect, which was diagnosed shortly after birth. However, he was subsequently lost to follow-up and was not treated for this condition. The patient smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. Physical exam is notable for cyanosis of the lips and clubbing of the fingers. Cardiac catheterization is performed, and oxygen saturation in the cardiac chambers and outflow tracts are shown below:  

 Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?

choices.text: Impaired growth of the septum primum
Impaired closure of the foramen ovale
Fluid accumulation in the lung parenchyma

questions.solution:
This patient has Eisenmenger syndrome, which is when an uncorrected left-to-right shunt reverses direction and becomes a right-to-left shunt. In this patient’s case, the condition most likely arose secondary to an uncorrected ventricular septal defect, given catheterization finding of decreased saturation in the left ventricle.  

Eisenmenger syndrome occurs as a result of the constant shunting of blood to the right heart, which increases pulmonary blood flow. This high flow state triggers vascular remodeling in the lungs, which is characterized by increased proliferation of vascular smooth muscle and narrowing of pulmonary artery lumen. As a result, the right heart must pump against greater resistance, so it too undergoes remodeling in the form of right ventricular hypertrophy. This growth causes the pressure in the right heart to increase and exceed that of the left heart, ultimately switching the shunt’s direction.    

Clinically, Eisenmenger syndrome presents with cyanosis, hypoxia, and clubbing of the fingers and toes. In addition, patients can develop polycythemia, since hypoxia increases kidney erythropoietin production.  

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired growth of the septum primum :
Incorrect: This pathology would result in an atrial septal defect (ASD). ASDs are a type of left-to-right shunt. Cardiac catheterization will show increased oxygen saturation in the right atrium, ventricle, and pulmonary artery. Even with Eisenmenger syndrome, ASD would lead to decrease in saturation in the left atrium (not the ventricle). 
❌ Impaired closure of the foramen ovale :
Incorrect: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) can cause transient right-to-left shunting of blood. Cardiac catheterization may show reduced oxygen saturation in the left atrium, ventricle, and aorta. In contrast, this patient’s catheterization does not demonstrate this finding. 
✅ Reversal of long-standing left-to-right shunt :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Hyperplasia of bronchial mucus-secreting glands :
Incorrect: This answer describes chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD). COPD can result in a productive cough, barrel chest, cyanosis, and nail clubbing. Patients with a smoking history are at increased risk. Although this patient has a smoking history, he is relatively young and lacks the history of cough characteristic to COPD. 
❌ Fluid accumulation in the lung parenchyma :
Incorrect: This answer describes pulmonary edema. The accumulation of fluids in the lung parenchyma can reduce oxygen exchange and cause cyanosis. However, blood in this patient’s left atrium has high oxygen saturation, suggesting that gas exchange is normal.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining the effects of different genetic mutations and changes in molecular signalling on colonic polyps. One specific colonic polyp she is examining is a sessile serrated polyp obtained from a 65-year-old patient. Biopsy of the polyp is shown below:

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Immunostaining for MLH1 and MSH2 proteins are negative. Which of the following best describes the underlying abnormality that enabled this polyp to grow?

choices.text: Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions
Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor

questions.solution:
This sample shows a serrated polyp. It likely arose due to CpG island hypermethylation and subsequent impaired synthesis of DNA repair proteins MLH1 and MSH2.  

Serrated polyps are one of two neoplastic polyps, with the other being adenomatous polyps. Serrated polyps are often flat or sessile and characterized by a “sawtooth” appearance on histology. A characteristic finding of these polyps is instability (hypermutability) in microsatellite regions, which are tandem repeats of nucleotides found throughout the genome. This finding arises due to hypermethylation of CpG islands located in DNA repair-genes. Since methylation leads to gene silencing, these changes result in reduced production of DNA repair proteins and an increased risk of developing mutations in microsatellite regions. Overtime, these mutations accumulate, enabling the polyp to grow and eventually progress to cancer.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased B-catenin synthesis:
Incorrect: The APC gene encodes a cytoplasmic protein that functions to promote the degradation of B-catenin. Mutations in the APC gene typically result in the development of adenomatous polyps, not serrated polyps. 
❌ Loss of serine-threonine kinase activity:
Incorrect: Mutations in the serine/threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene are present in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. These genes encode a tumor suppressor protein involved in cell signaling and apoptosis. As a result, mutations in this gene result in uncontrolled cellular growth. However, another answer choice is more commonly implicated in the pathogenesis of serrated adenomatous polyps.
❌ Impaired production of p53 protein:
Incorrect: A mutation in the TP53 gene results in reduced production of the tumor suppressor protein p53. Mutations in TP53 is a major contributor to the growth of adenomatous polyps. In contrast, serrated polyps have a different underlying genetic defect. 
❌ Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor:
Incorrect: A mutation in the RB gene results in impaired production of the protein retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma inhibits the transcription factor E2F. However, abnormalities in the RB gene or E2F protein regulation are not involved in the pathogenesis of serrated polyps.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her sister due to worsening memory loss. The patient has had difficulty balancing her checkbook and has forgotten the names of her grandchildren on several occasions. According to the sister, the patient recently got lost while walking her dog in a park that she has been visiting daily for the past 10 years. She also requires assistance with daily activities, such as housekeeping and purchasing groceries. However, the patient brushes off these concerns, stating “it is merely part of normal aging.” Family history is notable for declining cognitive function in the patient’s father and grandfather when they were in their 70s. Laboratory testing is ordered as part of the work-up. Which of the following will most likely be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient is presenting with significant cognitive impairment and has a family history notable for dementia. She likely has late-onset Alzheimer disease (AD), which can arise due to an increased number of epsilon 4 (ε4) alleles of the apolipoprotein E gene.

AD is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that can be classified into two forms: 1) late-onset sporadic Alzheimer disease, and 2) early-onset familial Alzheimer disease. Late-onset AD makes up the majority of cases and manifests after the age of 65. It is due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Currently, the most firmly established genetic risk factor for late-onset disease is having increased copies of the apolipoprotein E ε4 allele (ApoE4-ε4). Apolipoprotein E is found in the brain and is involved in the removal of amyloid-beta (Aβ). The ApoE4-ε4 isoform, however, is not as efficient at transferring Aβ to the bloodstream, and therefore it causes increased Aβ deposition. Environmental risk factors for late-onset AD include obesity, reduced physical activity, smoking, and history of traumatic brain injury.

In contrast, early-onset AD typically occurs between the ages of 30-65 and makes up 5-10% of cases. It can be due to mutations in the PSEN1 and PSEN2 gene or by having an extra copy of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (e.g. trisomy 21).  

Option Analysis

✅ Apolipoprotein E epsilon 4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Apolipoprotein E epsilon 2:
Incorrect: The genetic variant apolipoprotein E epsilon 2 (ApoE2) has actually been shown to be protective against developing Alzheimer disease. Although the exact mechanism is still unclear, it is hypothesized that this ApoE isoform reduces the generation of Aβ plaques and may even aid in the clearance of such plaques.
❌ CAG trinucleotide repeats:
Incorrect: CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions are seen in patients with Huntington disease (HD). Patients typically present with abnormal body movements (chorea), behavioral changes (e.g., aggression, irritability, depression), and dementia. Moreover, patients typically develop symptoms starting in their 40s.
❌ Free serum copper :
Incorrect: Wilson disease is caused by impaired copper excretion into bile and failure to incorporate copper into ceruloplasmin. Copper accumulates in tissues, such as the brain, resulting in neurological symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, Parkinsonism, tremor), behavioral changes (e.g. depression), and cognitive impairment. Patients typically manifest with symptoms in early adulthood, making the diagnosis unlikely in this individual.
❌ Amyloid A protein:
Incorrect: Amyloid A protein (AA amyloidosis) is seen in patients with underlying conditions that cause chronic inflammation, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Patients typically present with widespread amyloid deposition, such as in the kidneys (e.g. nephrotic syndrome), as well as in the liver and spleen, resulting in hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. AA amyloidosis does not typically cause neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to her physician for a routine preventative examination. The patient gets regular exercise and does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She states she has been feeling fine for the past year. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable. The patient expresses concern about undergoing colonoscopies because of the procedure’s invasiveness, and she wants to know when it is necessary to have one done. Which of the following risk factors, if present in this patient’s history, would warrant early screening for colorectal cancer?

choices.text: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis diagnosed at age 33.
The patient’s father developed colorectal cancer at age 70.
The patient has a history of irritable bowel syndrome.
The patient’s aunt was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 50.
The patient consumes a low-fiber diet.

questions.solution:
Screening for colorectal cancer (CRC) is essential in identifying premalignant lesions and detecting asymptomatic early-stage malignancy. Screening for colorectal cancer in low-risk individuals begins at the age of 50. Screening includes visualization methods, such as colonoscopy (the gold standard) and flexible sigmoidoscopy. In addition to direct visualization, laboratory testing can be used (such as fecal occult blood test), although these modalities are not as specific as direct visualization techniques.    

Some patients are at an increased risk of developing CRC and warrant screening at an earlier age. The age of beginning CRC screening varies, depending on the patient’s risk factors and family history. Patients who have a first-degree relative diagnosed with colon cancer before the age of 60 should begin screening at the age of 40 or 10 years prior to their relative’s diagnosis, whichever is earlier. In all patients with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., ulcerative colitis, Crohn disease) a screening colonoscopy should be performed eight years after disease or symptom onset. Additionally, patients with hereditary syndromes, such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC), require screening starting at an early age.
   

Option Analysis

✅ The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis diagnosed at age 33.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The patient’s father developed colorectal cancer at age 70.:
Incorrect: Patients with a family history of colorectal cancer (CRC) in a first-degree relative are at increased risk of developing the condition. This is the case regardless of the age at which the relative was diagnosed. However, early colonoscopy screening is warranted only if the first-degree relative was diagnosed at less than 60 years of age. 
❌ The patient has a history of irritable bowel syndrome.:
Incorrect: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is not associated with an increased risk of developing colorectal cancer. In contrast, inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, are associated with a higher risk of CRC, and therefore, these patients require earlier screening. 
❌ The patient’s aunt was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 50.:
Incorrect: Patients who have a first-degree relative with colorectal cancer diagnosed before the age of 60 should undergo earlier colonoscopy screening. The first colonoscopy should be performed at age 40 or 10 years prior to their relative’s diagnosis, whichever is earlier. However, the patient’s aunt is not a first-degree relative, and as a result, early colonoscopy testing is not necessary.
❌ The patient consumes a low-fiber diet.:
Incorrect: Although a low-fiber diet is associated with increased risk of developing colorectal cancer, earlier screening is not warranted based on diet alone.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her partner for involuntary movements of the hands and face. The symptoms began 6-months ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, she has been experiencing personality changes over the past 2 months. According to the partner, the patient has withdrawn from activities she previously enjoyed, such as attending weekly book clubs with her friends. Moreover, the patient has had a decreased appetite and is sleeping less than before. Past medical history is noncontributory. Her father experienced similar motor symptoms and commited suicide at the age of 47. In the office, her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 126/80 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. During the physical exam, the patient makes repeated writhing movements using the fingers and arms. Imaging of the head is ordered. MRI of the brain is most likely to demonstrate which of the following?

choices.text: Loss of neuronal volume in the striatum
Lesion in the left subthalamic nucleus
Hyperintense signal within the basal ganglia
Hyperintense signals within the periventricular white matter

questions.solution:
This patient has choreoathetosis (involuntary writhing movements), psychiatric symptoms (e.g. depressed mood), hyperreflexia, and a history of similar symptoms in her father. These findings are consistent with the presentation of Huntington disease (HD).  

HD is a neurodegenerative movement disorder that is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. The condition arises due to an increased number of CAG trinucleotide repeats in the huntingtin gene, which leads to the production of a dysfunction protein that impairs subcortical motor circuits.  

The diagnosis of HD is based upon the presence of associated clinical features (e.g., chorea, dementia, depression), a family history of the disease, and genetic confirmation of the trinucleotide gene expansion. Gene expansion can be tested using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Head imaging, although not commonly done for diagnostic purposes, would demonstrate characteristic atrophy of the striatum, which is a term collectively referring to the caudate and putamen. Atrophy is most pronounced in the caudate nucleus (red outline) and leads to concomitant enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow outline).  

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
 


Option Analysis

✅ Loss of neuronal volume in the striatum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lesion in the left subthalamic nucleus :
Incorrect: Lesions in the subthalamic nuclei, such as after a hemorrhagic or ischemic stroke, can result in the movement disorder known as hemiballismus. The condition is instead characterized by involuntary, violent, large-amplitude movements of the extremities (e.g., arm flinging, kicking). 
❌ Hyperintense signal within the basal ganglia:
Incorrect: Patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) will have enhancement of the basal ganglia (most notably the caudate and putamen) and thalamus on brain MRI. Patients with CJD typically present with rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus. This patient’s family history and constellation of symptoms are more suggestive of a different etiology. 
❌ Diffuse cortical and hippocampal atrophy:
Incorrect: On imaging, patients with Alzheiemer disease (AD) typically demonstrate generalized cerebral atrophy with disproportionate atrophy of the hippocampus and/or medial temporal lobe. AD has an insidious, progressive course, and typically presents in elderly patients. 
❌ Hyperintense signals within the periventricular white matter:
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis (MS) typically demonstrates multiple sclerotic plaques in the periventricular white matter. Although MS typically affects young females, the condition has a relapsing-remitting course, wherein there are acute exacerbations followed by complete remission of symptoms. In contrast, this patient is exhibiting progressively worsening symptoms.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother due to excessive fatigue over the past 2 months. The mother has occasionally noticed blood in the toilet bowl after the patient defecates. There is no significant family history of cancers. The patient's temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. No abnormal skin pigmentation is noted. Laboratory results are as follows:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.7 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  35% 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  74 μm3 
 
Colonoscopy is performed and reveals seven polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract; subsequent biopsy reveals hamartomatous mucosal polyps. Genetic testing is performed and reveals a mutation in the BMPR1A gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS) is caused by mutations in the BMPR1A and SMAD4 genes. The condition can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with incomplete penetrance or arise due to de novo mutations. These genes are involved in regulating the growth factor-beta (TGF-β) signaling pathway, and therefore, mutations can result in uncontrolled cellular proliferation.    

In JPS, affected individuals are typically symptomatic by age 20, with polyps often appearing in the first decade of life. This syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomas, which are composed of abnormal collections of tissue elements normally found within the intestinal tract. Most of these hamartomas are found in the colon and rectum. Patients commonly present with hematochezia and iron-deficiency anemia. Importantly, they are not only at risk for developing colorectal cancer but also for cancers in other areas of the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach, small intestine, pancreas).   

Diagnosis is made by endoscopic studies (e.g. colonoscopy) followed by biopsy. A patient meeting one of the below criteria can be diagnosed with JPS:  
1) More than five juvenile polyps in the colon or rectum  
2) Multiple juvenile polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract  
3) Any number of juvenile polyps in a person with a family history of juvenile polyposis syndrome 

Option Analysis

✅ Juvenile polyposis syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Peutz-Jegher syndrome:
Incorrect: Peutz-Jegher syndrome can also present with gastrointestinal bleeding and hamartomatous polyps in young children. However, this patient lacks the mucosal hyperpigmentation typically seen in Peutz-Jegher syndrome. Furthermore, the condition is usually caused by a mutation in the STK11 gene, as opposed to the BMPR1A gene.
❌ Familial adenomatous polyposis:
Incorrect: Familial adenomatous polyposis is caused by a mutation in the APC gene and results in hundreds of adenomatous polyps on colonoscopy. This patient’s hamartomatous polyps and genetic testing results suggest a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ Lynch syndrome:
Incorrect: Lynch syndrome is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2). Patients with Lynch syndrome are at increased risk of colorectal cancer. However, it would be unusual for the condition to cause multiple hamartomatous polyps or arise secondary to a BMPR1A gene mutation.
❌ Cronkhite-Canada syndrome:
Incorrect: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is a nonfamilial condition that also results in polyposis in the gastrointestinal tract. Patients typically present with alopecia and cutaneous hyperpigmentation. This patient’s symptoms and genetic testing results make another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty hearing. The patient's partner states “The TV is so loud at home, I can barely hear myself think! I have told him multiple times that he needs hearing aids.” The patient’s past medical history is notable for hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia. He is retired but used to work as an accountant. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. An otoscopic examination is performed and reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Audiometric screening demonstrates bilateral high-frequency hearing loss. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons
Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes
Benign growth of keratinized squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
This elderly patient has bilateral hearing loss, a normal otoscopic examination, and audiometric testing demonstrating high-frequency hearing loss. These findings are consistent with presbycusis.

Presbycusis is an age-related condition that affects approximately two-thirds of adults over 70. Globally, it is the most common cause of hearing loss. Multiple factors contribute to the disease. However, it is considered primarily a disease of aging of the inner ear structures and is characterized by a loss of cochlear hair cells, stria vascularis cells, and spiral ganglion neurons. These changes result in an inability to effectively convert sound information into neural signals that can be processed by the brain.

Clinically, presbycusis will be seen in elderly patients with progressively worsening bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Patients may describe difficulty hearing and understanding conversations in a crowded or noisy environment. Audiometric testing will demonstrate difficulty hearing high frequency sound (typically those above 2000 Hz). As the disease progresses, middle and lower frequency sounds can be lost as well.    

Option Analysis

✅ Age-related changes in hair cells, stria vascularis, and afferent spiral ganglion neurons:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes:
Incorrect: Otosclerosis reflects bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes, which presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss with a normal appearing tympanic membrane. Unlike presbycusis, otosclerosis more commonly presents in the 2nd to 3rd decade of life.
❌ Mechanical damage of cochlear structures   :
Incorrect: Noise-induced hearing loss is characterized by mechanical trauma to stereociliated cells within the cochlea. It tends to affect individuals with a history of exposure to loud noises (e.g., musicians, construction workers). In contrast, this patient has no such history.  
❌ Infiltration by polygonal squamous cells :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the histopathology of squamous cell cancer of the ear, which is a rare neoplasm. Physical examination would likely demonstrate associated lymphadenopathy, nerve palsy, and significant ear pain.
❌ Benign growth of keratinized squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: This answer describes the underlying pathophysiology of a cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas are abnormal, noncancerous accumulations of keratinized squamous epithelium that most commonly develop behind the tympanic membrane. On physical examination, they often appear as a brown, irregular mass. In contrast, this patient has a normal tympanic membrane.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman comes to her physician due to progressive weight gain and fatigue over the last 2 months. She is no longer able to do her job as a warehouse worker because of difficulty lifting heavy boxes. Past medical history is noncontributory. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scattered ecchymoses.
