There is symmetric proximal muscle weakness of the upper and lower extremities. 24-hour urine free-cortisol concentration is markedly elevated, and ACTH level is reduced. Abdominal CT shows a tumor in the right adrenal gland. Which of the following sections in the contralateral adrenal gland is most likely to show the greatest atrophy?



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with easy bruising, central obesity, hypertension, and muscle weakness. When combined with the abdominal CT results, these findings are concerning for Cushing syndrome secondary to an autonomous cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma.

An adrenal adenoma is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland that most commonly is non-functioning and therefore does not cause excess hormone production. However, in some cases, the adenoma can be functioning and result in increased hormone levels.

In this patient, the adenoma is producing excess cortisol. The high cortisol levels trigger negative feedback on the hypothalamus, which suppresses corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) production. This response subsequently suppresses adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production by the anterior pituitary. With no stimulation from ACTH, the normal tissue in the zona fasciculata of the uninvolved adrenal gland shrinks and atrophies.



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This answer choice is the fibrous adrenal capsule, which surrounds the adrenal cortex and keeps the organ mechanically stable. It is not involved in cortisol synthesis and therefore would not be affected in this patient.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This answer choice is the zona glomerulosa, which is heavily involved in the synthesis of mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone. The cells of the zona glomerulosa are stimulated by angiotensin II, not ACTH, and therefore would unlikely exhibit atrophy.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This answer choice is the zona reticularis, which is heavily involved in the synthesis of androgens. It would not show significant atrophy in this patient, who likely has hypercortisolism secondary to a cortisol-secreting adrenal mass.
❌ E:
Incorrect: This answer choice is the medulla of the adrenal gland and is involved in the production of catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine, epinephrine). The adrenal medulla is stimulated by cholinergic sympathetic preganglionic nerve fibers. As a result, this region would be unaffected in spite of the patient’s low ACTH levels.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician due to bloody vaginal spotting. She has not visited a doctor in 15 years. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years and drinks 2 beers per day and 5 on the weekends. She has no history of abnormal Pap smears. The patient has had multiple sexual partners and used condoms inconsistently. The patient’s last menstrual cycle was 3 years ago. Family history includes breast cancer in the patient’s mother at age 65. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 142/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals 2 foci of polypoid masses on the anterior wall of the vagina. A biopsy is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for developing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with abnormal bleeding and polypoid masses on the anterior vaginal wall. The biopsy results show a lesion that infiltrates the vaginal wall and cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, favoring the diagnosis of clear cell adenocarcinoma.   

Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero is associated with the development of clear cell vaginal adenocarcinoma. DES is a synthetic form of estrogen that was prescribed to pregnant women between 1940-1971 to prevent miscarriage, premature labor, and other complications of pregnancy. Exposure can result in both cervical and vaginal clear cell adenocarcinomas.    

In contrast, risk factors for developing squamous cell vaginal cancer are similar to those associated with cervical carcinoma, including cigarette smoking, multiple sexual partners, early age at first intercourse, and immunodeficiency.    

Patients with vaginal cancer typically present with abnormal bleeding. Some patients may note a vaginal mass. Other possible manifestations are related to an extension of the disease to adjacent tissues and include urinary symptoms (e.g., dysuria, hematuria), or gastrointestinal complaints (e.g., tenesmus, constipation).  

Option Analysis

❌ Cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for developing cervical and vaginal squamous cell carcinoma. However, this patient lesion and biopsy favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Alcohol:
Incorrect: Excessive alcohol consumption is associated with squamous carcinoma of the esophagus, breast cancer, and hepatocellular carcinoma. However, it is not associated with cervical or vaginal cancer.  
❌ Family history:
Incorrect: A positive family history of breast cancer is not associated with increased risk for vaginal or cervical cancer. Families with BRCA mutations are at increased risk of developing breast and/or ovarian cancer.  
✅ Exposure to diethylstilbestrol in utero:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lack of barrier contraception:
Incorrect: Lack of barrier contraception (e.g. condoms) increases the risk for sexually transmitted diseases including HPV infection. HPV types 16,18, 31 are often associated with cervical and vaginal squamous cell carcinomas. However, this patient’s lesion and biopsy results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician’s office due to progressive finger pain and ulceration for the past 3 weeks. He describes sharp pain at the fingertips followed by dark color changes and ulceration. His medical history is unremarkable. The patient reports smoking 2 packs of cigarettes per day for the past 10 years. He does not use illicit drugs. The patient is from Israel. Vital signs are within normal limits. On cardiac auscultation, no murmurs are heard, but peripheral pulses are diminished. Examination of bilateral hands reveals superficial tender nodules parallel to the radial vein. Examination of the blood glucose level, hemoglobin A1C, and lipid panel are within normal limits. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Focal granulomatous inflammation of the media
Transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with fibrinoid necrosis
Segmental vasculitis extending to adjacent veins and nerves

questions.solution:
This patient with a heavy smoking history, skin nodules, and finger pain and ulceration most likely has thromboangiitis obliterans (previously known as Buerger disease).    

Thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO) is a nonatherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory vasculitis that commonly affects small to medium-sized arteries, veins and nerves of the extremities. Patients are often young individuals with a smoking history who present with distal ischemia, ischemic digit ulcers, and digit gangrene. The disease is strongly associated with smoking, and smoking cessation is essential to decrease the risk for amputation.    

Although the pathophysiology of the disease is still not clear, the condition is distinguished from other forms of vasculitis by a highly cellular, inflammatory luminal thrombus with relative sparing of the vessel wall. In contrast to atherosclerosis, which involves the intima and media, thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by the infiltration of inflammatory cells in all 3 layers of the arterial wall.  



Option Analysis

❌ Focal granulomatous inflammation of the media:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in giant cell (temporal) arteritis, which commonly affects branches of the carotid artery. Patients are typically >50 years of age with characteristic symptoms of unilateral headache, jaw claudication and visual disturbances.  
❌ Transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with fibrinoid necrosis:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in polyarteritis nodosa, a medium-vessel vasculitis which commonly affects visceral arteries (but spares the lungs). Patients are usually middle-aged men who present with constitutional symptoms, hypertension, abdominal pain, melena, renal damage, and neurologic dysfunction. The condition is often associated with underlying hepatitis B infection.  
❌ Granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilia:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss), a small-vessel vasculitis. Patients typically have an atopic history (e.g., allergy, chronic asthma) and present with skin lesions, peripheral neuropathy, and possible involvement of the heart, GI and kidneys.  
❌  Fibrous-fatty intimal plaque :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with atherosclerosis. Although this patient is at risk of atherosclerosis, his history of episodic Raynaud phenomenon, as well as superficial thrombophlebitis (painful nodules that follow a venous distribution), suggests a different diagnosis. In contrast to atherosclerosis, which involves the intima and media, thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by the infiltration of inflammatory cells in all 3 layers of the arterial wall. 
✅ Segmental vasculitis extending to adjacent veins and nerves:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ “Onion-skin” thickening of the arterial wall:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with severe hypertension, which is characterized by hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis of the arterioles due to the proliferation of smooth muscle cells (“onion skinning”). 
❌ Calcification of the media:
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in Mönckeberg sclerosis (medial calcific sclerosis), an uncommon condition that affects medium-sized arteries. It is characterized by calcification of the internal elastic lamina and media of arteries, resulting in vascular stiffening without the obstruction of blood flow (intima not involved).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain for the past 3 months. He states that he defecates a small volume of stools 3-4 times a day, even after which he gets a sensation of incomplete bowel emptying. The stools are semi-solid, admixed with a small amount of blood. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the abdomen shows mild distension and left-sided tenderness. Colonoscopy reveals edematous rectum, sigmoid and descending colon with loss of vascular markings and multiple pseudopolyps throughout the involved region. The mucosa is erythematous and friable, with spontaneous bleeding on contact. The remainder of the colon and small intestines are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent episodes of small-volume, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and tenesmus (sense of incomplete bowel evacuation). Colonoscopy findings of continuous bowel inflammation with pseudopolyps and friable mucosa are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).  

UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Clinically, it presents with recurrent small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may also have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Macroscopic features typical of UC include:    

  •  Continuous involvement of the colon (Figure A): Unlike Crohn disease (which can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract with relative rectal sparing), UC commonly involves the rectum and may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve other parts of the colon 
  •  Loss of vascular markings (Fig. B): Due to engorgement of the mucosa, the bowel has an erythematous appearance. 
  •  Formation of pseudopolyps (Figure C): When the ulceration destroys significant portions of the mucosa, the residual mucosa protrudes above the surface of the ulcers in the form of polyps. Since these are not true neoplastic polyps, they are called pseudopolyps. 
  •  Friable mucosa (Fig D): Characterized by nodular thickening, with deep linear or serpiginous ulcers.  

Figure A


Figure B (Retrieved from: flickr.com)


Figure C (Retrieved from: flickr.com)


Figure D (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)  

Option Analysis

❌ Crohn disease:
Incorrect: Clinically, Crohn disease can present similarly; however, gross morphology usually reveals skip lesions (focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa) that result in a cobblestone appearance. Moreover, grossly bloody stools are uncommon until late in the disease course.  
✅ Ulcerative colitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranous colitis is a manifestation of C. difficile infection that clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. The infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins), and typical colonoscopy findings include pseudomembranes on the inflamed colonic mucosa. Bloody diarrhea and pancolitis are unlikely.
❌ Ischemic colitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic colitis can be secondary to embolic or thrombotic occlusion of mesenteric vessels; the condition typically presents with postprandial pain or the classic finding of abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. This patient with long-standing diarrhea, abdominal tenderness and contiguous inflammation of the colon likely has a different diagnosis.
❌ Diverticulitis:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis is defined as inflammation of diverticula, which are small, flask-like outpouchings containing only mucosa and submucosa. The presence of such diverticula is common in patients with long-standing constipation. Although diverticulitis can cause left-sided abdominal pain, tenderness and tenesmus, the onset is acute and is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting and low-grade fever.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the office because of an ulcerating lesion on his right elbow. The lesion is painless and nonpruritic but has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. He works as a farmer and spends most of his time outdoors. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes per day for the past 8 years. Past medical history is significant for hepatitis C virus infection 10 years ago. Family history is significant for nodular basal cell carcinoma in his father. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm indurated plaque with ulceration on the right elbow. Biopsy of the lesion shows dysplastic keratinocytes with keratin pearls involving the full thickness of the epidermis. Which of the following factors most increased his risk of developing this lesion?

choices.text: History of hepatitis C virus infection

questions.solution:
This patient with an indurated plaque with ulceration on his right elbow, a history of excessive sunlight exposure (as a farmer), and biopsy findings of dysplastic keratinocytes with keratin pearls has cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC).

cSCC is the second most common type of skin cancer that arises from keratinocytes (with basal cell carcinoma being the most common). The most important risk factor in the development of cSCC is excessive sunlight exposure. Sunlight is mainly ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation that, when absorbed by DNA, can result in DNA damage. If the damage is not repaired adequately by DNA repair mechanisms (e.g. nucleotide excision repair), a series of mutations can ultimately lead to malignant transformation. The point mutation in tumor suppressor gene p53 has especially been associated with damage caused by cumulative exposure of UVB radiation over several years. Other risk factors associated with the development of cSCC include inherited disorders (e.g. xeroderma pigmentosum), exposure to ionizing radiations, immunosuppression (e.g. HIV), chronic wounds (e.g. Marjolin ulcer), and arsenic exposure.

Option Analysis

❌ Tobacco smoking:
Incorrect: Tobacco smoking has been strongly associated with increased risk of developing various malignancies, such as lung cancer. However, it is only weakly associated with the development of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.
✅ Excessive ultraviolet light exposure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of hepatitis C virus infection:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C virus infection is associated with lichen planus, which usually presents with purple, polygonal, pruritic plaques or papules. A solitary indurated plaque with ulceration is suggestive of a different diagnosis.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: The incidence of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) increases with age and is up to 100 times higher for those over 75 than for those under 45. At 44, this patient’s age is not a risk factor for the development of cSCC.
❌ Family history:
Incorrect: Family history of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) has not been associated with increased risk of developing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man presents to the office for the evaluation of a lesion on his right forearm. He first noticed the lesion 9 months ago, and it has gradually increased in size since then. He has worked on various construction sites for the past 45 years. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for skin cancer in his father. Physical examination shows a 1.5 cm nodule with a thick and rough surface on his right forearm. Biopsy of the lesion is shown below.



Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons

Which of the following additional features is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Pinpoint bleeding on scraping off the lesion (Auspitz sign)

questions.solution:
The examination findings of a hyperkeratotic nodule in the setting of prolonged sunlight exposure (construction worker), together with biopsy findings of atypical keratinocytes with keratin pearls and deep dermal invasion, are characteristic of invasive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC).

cSCC is the second most common skin cancer, and it frequently affects fair-skinned individuals with a history of prolonged sun exposure, immunosuppression, chronic non-healing wounds, and/or chronic arsenic exposure. It commonly involves sun-exposed areas including face, lower lips, ears and hands. The lesion appears as 0.5-1.5 cm indurated or firm plaque or papule with scaling, crusting or ulceration. Less commonly, it appears as an enlarging pink nodule with surface keratinization (as in this patient) or ulceration. It is a locally invasive tumor, which may result in early perineural invasion presenting as regional numbness and paraesthesias, pain, and muscle weakness. Trigeminal and facial nerves are most commonly affected by local nerve invasion. It can also metastasize to head and neck lymph nodes, which usually presents as enlarged submental and submaxillary nodes. Diagnosis is established on punch, shave, or excisional biopsy of the lesion.



Option Analysis

❌ Elevated serum IgE levels:
Incorrect: Elevated serum IgE levels are found in association with atopic dermatitis. It usually presents in adults as pruritic lichenified plaques on flexural surfaces with a background history of other atopic conditions (e.g., asthma, allergic rhinitis). A slowly enlarging keratinized nodule is atypical.
❌ History of tick bite:
Incorrect: A tick bite history is significant in Lyme disease, which usually presents with erythema migrans (an erythematous blanching rash with a “Bull’s eye” appearance). A slowly enlarging keratinized nodule is unlikely.
❌ Pinpoint bleeding on scraping off the lesion (Auspitz sign):
Incorrect: Pinpoint bleeding on scraping off the scaly lesion (Auspitz sign) is characteristic of psoriasis, which clinically presents as scaly plaques or papules. A keratinized nodule with atypical keratinocytes on histology is unlikely.
❌ Insulin resistance:
Incorrect: Insulin resistance is commonly associated with acanthosis nigricans, which is an epidermal hyperplasia that presents with a hyperpigmented skin thickening on the neck or axilla. A nodule with keratinization is atypical.
✅ Regional numbness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the physician due to productive cough, bloody sputum and unintentional weight loss. During the past 2 months, his cough has progressively worsened. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Chest radiograph shows a single nodule in the right lower lobe. Biopsy is obtained, and malignancy is confirmed, as shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Following the results, the doctor would like to provide the patient with as much information as possible regarding the prognosis and favorable treatment options of this type of cancer. Assuming the tumor has not spread, which of the following is the best response by the doctor based on these findings?

choices.text: Prognosis and Treatment informationGood prognosis; highly responsive to chemotherapy
Prognosis and Treatment informationPoor prognosis; poorly responsive to chemotherapy
Prognosis and Treatment informationGood prognosis; surgery +/- chemotherapy
Prognosis and Treatment informationGood prognosis; no treatment is needed

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation and histopathologic findings support the diagnosis of malignancy. The patient's extensive smoking history, and tumor characteristics (e.g. peripheral location, pathology showing giant cells) support the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. Large cell carcinomas are highly anaplastic, undifferentiated, malignant epithelial tumors that lack the cytologic characteristics of neuroendocrine carcinoma and show no indication of glandular or squamous differentiation.

Predicting the prognosis of lung cancer is a complex process and depends mainly on the tumor type and the extent of disease (stage) at presentation. Certain types of cancers tend to be more aggressive and poorly responsive to treatment. Large cell carcinomas specifically carry a poor prognosis and are poorly responsive to chemotherapy. As with other types of non-small cell lung cancer, surgical resection offers the best opportunity for long-term survival and cure, if the tumor is indeed resectable. Depending on the cancer staging, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiation, and immunotherapy may be followed or used instead.




Option Analysis

❌  Prognosis and Treatment informationGood prognosis; highly responsive to chemotherapy  :
Incorrect: Small cell lung cancer is typically highly responsive to chemotherapy, and prognosis is good if the tumor has not spread (low stage). This patient’s results favor the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma.
✅  Prognosis and Treatment informationPoor prognosis; poorly responsive to chemotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prognosis and Treatment informationGood prognosis; surgery +/- chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Bronchial carcinoid tumor carries an excellent prognosis, and treatment includes surgery +/- chemotherapy. This patient’s results favor the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma.
❌  Prognosis and Treatment informationGood prognosis; no treatment is needed:
Incorrect: Pulmonary hamartomas are benign neoplasms composed of connective tissue, cartilage, muscle, fat, and bone. It is one of the most common benign tumors of the lung and is often recognized as an incidental mass on a chest x-ray. If the nodule is stable over 2 years, and the location causes no symptoms, generally no treatment is required. This patient’s results favor the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for the evaluation of abdominal pain. The pain started approximately 6 months ago and has progressively worsened over time. It recurs every month around the same time and lasts for 2-3 days. The patient has not had a menstrual period yet but is otherwise healthy.  She has never been involved in vaginal, digital or oral sexual activity. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a well-appearing female of normal stature with Tanner stage III breast and pubic hair growth. Pelvic and rectal examination reveal a palpable mass anterior to the rectum which is obstructing the vagina. Pregnancy test is negative; thyroid stimulating hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are normal. The uterus and ovaries appear normal on ultrasound.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s abdominal pain?

choices.text: Failed canalization of external vaginal membrane

questions.solution:
This patient with monthly cyclical abdominal pain, normal secondary sexual characteristics in the absence of menstruation, in combination with a vaginal bulge, most likely has an imperforate hymen.

An imperforate hymen is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to failed canalization of the hymen, the membrane covering the vaginal opening, during embryological development. The condition can sometimes be diagnosed at birth, when the vaginal secretions stimulated by maternal estrogen cause a mucocolpos in the infant. However, it may remain undiagnosed or asymptomatic until after menarche, when the patient reports cyclic abdominal or pelvic pain in the absence of menses. The collection of blood (hematocolpos) and mucous behind the vaginal introitus, can cause back pain and difficulty with defecation. The patients have normal internal reproductive organs and secondary sexual characteristics. Physical examination shows a vaginal bulge or a palpable anterior rectal mass.



Option Analysis

❌ Failed follicle maturation:
Incorrect: The imbalance of LH/FSH ratio in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can result in the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. PCOS is characterized by hyperandrogenic characteristics (e.g. acne and hirsutism) and/or elevated testosterone levels. Menstrual irregularities and infertility can also be seen. Ovaries appear polycystic on ultrasound.
❌ Severe calorie restriction and deficiency:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs in females with severe calorie restriction and nutrient deficiency due to the suppression of hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. FSH and LH are low in this condition. This patient’s FSH and LH are within normal limits.
✅ Failed canalization of external vaginal membrane:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Failed development of Müllerian duct:
Incorrect: Müllerian agenesis results from the failure of Müllerian duct development. The uterus, cervix and upper two-thirds of vagina are absent in these patients. This patient has a normal uterus.
❌ Obstruction of Bartholin gland duct:
Incorrect: Obstruction of the Bartholin gland duct can present as a unilateral, palpable mass in the posterior vaginal introitus. The cyclical abdominal pain in this patient, however, is suggestive of imperforate hymen.

questions.text: A 2 year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of recurrent infections including otitis media, pneumonia, and erysipelas. He recently recovered from a prolonged course of diarrhea due to infection with Giardia. Temperature is 38.7 C° (101.7 F°), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 55/min and blood pressure is 100/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows small bilateral tonsils and rales in the right lower lobe of the lung. The patient is at 25th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Intraepidermal injection of Candida antigens results in the appearance of a large indurated nodule within 48 hours. Flow cytometry of the patient’s peripheral blood smear demonstrates absence of CD19+ cells. Impairment of which of the following immunoprotective mechanisms is most likely contributing to this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent bacterial and enteroviral infections in the setting of intact T lymphocyte function and absence of CD19+ B cells (specific B cell surface protein)--suggestive of X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia (XLA).

This X-linked recessive disorder results from a mutation in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, manifesting with failure of pre-B cell maturation to mature B cells in the bone marrow. People with XLA lack or have far fewer B cells in peripheral blood and lymphoid tissue, and thus they subsequently lack circulating antibodies of all classes (panhypo-gammaglobinemia). Normal or decreased levels of IgM containing pre-B cells are typically found in the bone marrow.

 


 XLA almost exclusively occurs in males, though the mutation can sometimes develop sporadically rather than being inherited from a parent. Newborns are typically asymptomatic until after 6 months of age, when the mother’s transplacental immunoglobulins diminishes. Without immunoglobulins, children with XLA are at increased risk of viral and parasitic infections (e.g. enterovirus and Giardia lamblia) due to the paucity of opsonizing and neutralizing antibodies. T-cell mediated immunity remains intact, allowing for the clearance of some viral, fungal and protozoal infections. Live attenuated vaccines (e.g. polio vaccine) should be avoided in these patients.

Treatment for XLA includes lifelong intravenous infusion of immunoglobulin as well as prophylactic antibiotics.



Option Analysis

❌ Complement production:
Incorrect: Terminal complement deficiency (deficiency of complements C5-C9) results in an aberrant membrane attack complex--predisposing patients to recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or meningitidis.
✅ Antibody production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interferon signaling:
Incorrect:  Interferon gamma (INF-ɣ) is responsible for enhanced mycobacterial intracellular killing via phagolysosomes. Autosomal recessive deficiency of the INF-ɣ receptor can result in disseminated mycobacterial disease in infancy or childhood.
❌ Isotype switching:
Incorrect: Isotype switching is dependent on the interaction of CD40 with its ligand and occurs in naive B cells.
❌ Leukocyte adhesion:
Incorrect: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency results from a defect in CD18, which mediates leukocyte adherence and transmigration through endothelial walls. It presents in infancy with delayed separation of umbilical cord, poor wound healing, and recurrent apustular infections.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of recurrent pulmonary infections and failure to thrive. Since birth, the parents report the patient has had two episodes of pneumococcal pneumonia and five episodes of otitis media. He recently recovered from a diarrheal illness caused by Cryptosporidium parvum. His vaccinations are up to date, and he does not take any medications. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s brother, who died from pneumococcal pneumonia last year. Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a child who is small for his age. Laboratory results are shown below.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  12  g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
 Immunoglobulins 
 IgG  250 mg/dL 
 IgA  24 mg/dL 
 IgM  700 mg/dL 
 IgE  undetectable 
 CD4/CD8 ratio  2 (normal, 1-4) 

This patient’s condition is most likely caused by a failure of which of the following processes?

choices.text: Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class I
Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class II
Costimulatory signal between B7 and CD28
Costimulatory signal between helper T-cells and CD40
Release of IFN-γ and IL-2 cytokines

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent pulmonary infections from encapsulated organisms (e.g. S. pneumoniae), opportunistic (Cryptosporidium) infections, and otitis media. In addition, the laboratory findings demonstrate high IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins, indicating a diagnosis of hyper IgM syndrome. This X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder is most commonly caused by a defective CD40 ligand (CD40L) on CD4+ helper T-cells, which is required for B-cell class switching.

B-cell activation and class switching is a multistep process wherein foreign antigens are endocytosed by B-cells and presented to CD4+ helper T-cells via MHC II on the B-cell surface. Consequently, a costimulatory signal occurs upon binding of the CD40 receptor on B-cells to CD40 ligand (CD40L) on CD4+ helper T-cells. This binding results in the release of cytokines from helper T-cells to induce the B-cell to undergo immunoglobulin class switching. B-cells can then undergo affinity maturation by creating germinal centres within lymph nodes, and they then begin the production of the appropriate antibody to fight off the infection.

This process remains defective in patients with hyper IgM syndrome, and patients are thus prone to recurrent sinopulmonary, pyogenic, and opportunistic infections. Growth retardation can result from high energy expenditure and poor intake during recurrent illnesses. Laboratory findings demonstrate increased IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to this inability for B-cells to undergo class switching.


 

Option Analysis

❌ Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class I:
Incorrect: Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class I is a component of CD8+ cytotoxic T-cell activation. When nucleated cells are infected, the foreign antigen (e.g. viral or cytosolic proteins) is processed in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and loaded onto MHC class I. Later, T-cell receptors on CD8+ cytotoxic T-cell interact with the antigen, leading to its activation and killing of the infected cell. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.  
❌ Recognition of antigens presented on MHC class II:
Incorrect: Recognition of antigens presented on MHC II is a part of CD4+ helper T-cell activation.  Exogenous antigens (e.g. bacterial proteins) are processed within the endosome and loaded onto MHC class II of antigen presenting cells. This step is followed by an interaction between MHC class II and T-cell receptors on CD4+ helper T-cells, leading to its activation. Helper T-cells then mobilize and recruit other immune cells to fight the infection. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.
❌ Costimulatory signal between B7 and CD28:
Incorrect: This step is part of T-cell activation, not B-cell activation. T-cells interact with antigen presenting cells via two signals. First, in order for T-cells to be activated, the T-cell receptor has to recognize an antigen presented on the MHC molecule. Second, a costimulatory signal leads to T-cell proliferation and survival via interaction of B7 protein (CD80/86) on dendritic cells and CD28 on naive T-cells. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.
✅ Costimulatory signal between helper T-cells and CD40:
Correct: See Main explanation.
❌ Release of IFN-γ and IL-2 cytokines:
Incorrect: IFN-γ and IL-2 cytokines are released by helper T-cells in order to recruit macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells to kill phagocytosed microbes. This process is not affected in hyper IgM syndrome.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute-onset shortness of breath and chest pain that began three hours ago. The patient reports poorly-localized chest pain worse with inspiration. He is a business executive and recently returned from an overseas trip. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, blood pressure is 142/71 mmHg, and respirations are 21/min. Breath sounds are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Examination of the lower extremities reveals swelling and erythema in the right calf. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are 3+ bilaterally. A chest CT is ordered and reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

An arterial blood gas is pending. Which of the following findings will most likely be present on laboratory analysis?

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with superimposed respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with superimposed respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
Figure 1: Chest CT with annotations



Caption: Filling defects due to pulmonary embolism are observed in the patient’s right lung (arrows).

This patient has findings of a right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and a CT-angiogram with evidence of pulmonary embolism. Given his hyperventilation, more CO2 is eliminated through the lungs, and as a result, PaCO2 decreases, resulting in a respiratory alkalosis.

In general, a respiratory alkalosis occurs secondary to conditions that result in hyperventilation. For instance, when an individual is at high altitudes, oxygen levels decrease, causing hypoxemia, which triggers hyperventilation. Increased ventilation can also be an abnormal response that happens with panic attacks or in the early phases of salicylate overdose (due to direct stimulation of central respiratory centers). Tumors in the brain can also stimulate respiratory centers, leading to hyperventilation.

Over time, the body compensates for this respiratory alkalosis by decreasing renal HCO3− reabsorption. Given this patient’s symptoms have been present for only four hours, renal compensation would not yet occur.



Option Analysis

❌ Pure metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A massive deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism may cause a lactic acidosis; however, this patient has normal vitals and strong peripheral pulses, suggesting adequate tissue perfusion.
❌ Pure respiratory acidosis:
Incorrect: This patient is hyperventilating, suggesting a low PaCO2, and is thus more likely to have a respiratory alkalosis.
❌ Metabolic acidosis with superimposed respiratory alkalosis:
Incorrect: This patient is hyperventilating, suggesting a low PaCO2, and is thus more likely to have a respiratory alkalosis. He does not have an etiology that would suggest a metabolic acidosis.
✅ Pure respiratory alkalosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Metabolic alkalosis with superimposed respiratory alkalosis:
Incorrect: This patient is hyperventilating, suggesting a low PaCO2, and is thus more likely to have a respiratory alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis can be triggered by a loss of H+ ions (e.g., vomiting, hyperaldosteronism) or gain HCO3−  ions (e.g., antacid use, loop diuretic use). In contrast, there is little history to suggest that the patient experienced any of these etiologies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of fatigue, chills, and anorexia for one week. The patient is undomiciled and has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 132/87 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears disheveled and has multiple track marks noted on the upper extremities bilaterally. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiovascular examination reveals a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with inspiration. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a new systolic murmur that increases in intensity with inspiration--suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation (TR) due to infective endocarditis. Tricuspid valve endocarditis is associated with IV drug use, and it is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus. Other causes of TR include pulmonary hypertension, rheumatic heart disease, congenital anomalies, carcinoid syndrome, and ischemic heart disease.

TR refers to insufficient closure of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole, resulting in backflow of blood into the right atrium. As a compensatory mechanism, the right ventricle undergoes eccentric hypertrophy and dilation in an attempt to improve right ventricular ejection fraction, which only worsens the regurgitation as the right heart fails. Regurgitant volume backs up into the venous system, resulting in jugular venous distention, hepatosplenomegaly (hepatic congestion), ascites and lower extremity edema. The characteristic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is holosystolic and best heard over the 4th left intercostal space (tricuspid area). During inspiration, negative pressure increases the preload to the heart and increases the intensity of the murmur--a phenomenon known as the Carvallo sign.



Option Analysis

❌ Head bobbing:
Incorrect: Head bobbing (de Musset sign) can be observed in patients with aortic regurgitation. This patient's clinical history is more indicative of tricuspid regurgitation.
✅ Jugular venous distension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hoarseness:
Incorrect: Hoarseness is associated with mitral stenosis, due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve from left atrial enlargement. This patient has a systolic murmur.
❌ Syncope:
Incorrect: While not a specific sign, syncope is often associated with aortic stenosis, due to left ventricular outflow obstruction. Aortic stenosis is more often seen in older patients due to age-related calcification of the aortic valve.
❌ Brachial-femoral pulse delay:
Incorrect: Brachial-femoral pulse delay refers to hypertension in upper extremities and  weak, delayed pulses in lower extremities--a finding often seen in patients with coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of headaches that began five-months ago. The patient reports that the headaches are worse in the morning and improve over the day. In addition, the patient endorses reduced body hair. He does not use any medications. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg. Physical exam is notable for restricted peripheral vision and white watery discharge from the nipples. Further review of the patient’s history will most likely reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has prolactinoma (also termed lactotroph adenoma), a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. In men, it can cause infertility, erectile dysfunction, reduced facial and body hair, and galactorrhea. Patients may also experience symptoms secondary to mass effect. These include headache, vomiting, and bitemporal hemianopsia, due to compression of the optic chiasm by the mass.

Women with prolactinomas also experience galactorrhea, infertility, and mass effect. However, women may also develop amenorrhea, vaginal dryness, and osteoporosis because prolactin suppresses hypothalamic production of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). Reduced GnRH production reduces the secretion of estrogens, ultimately resulting in impaired ovulatory cycles and increased osteoclast bone resorption.



Option Analysis

❌ Skin hyperpigmentation:
Incorrect: Hyperpigmentation is usually seen in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency, in which deficiency of cortisol increases the secretion of ACTH by the negative-feedback mechanism. ACTH and melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) are derived from the same precursor molecule. As a result, increased ACTH production will also lead to increased MSH production. However, adrenal insufficiency does not typically cause white nipple discharge.
❌ Kidney stones:
Incorrect: Patients with hyperparathyroidism often develop hypercalcemia and kidney stones. Severe hypercalcemia can cause headaches. However, the findings of reduced body hair, nipple discharge and bitemporal hemianopsia make prolactinoma more likely.
✅ Erectile dysfunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Diffuse muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Muscle atrophy is usually seen in patients with hypercortisolism. Although an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma would explain the headaches and visual deficits, the condition is usually associated with ecchymosis, abdominal striae, fat redistribution, and/or hypertension, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Enlarged head with frontal bossing:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with acromegaly, a condition caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. Though it can present with headaches and visual disturbances due to mass effect, patients with acromegaly also have macrognathia, widened hands and feet and/or osteoarthritis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette lacks any of these findings.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of myoclonic epilepsy. The patient’s seizure episodes last for 30 seconds typically and are triggered by startle. Past medical history is significant for occipital infarction leading to partial loss of vision. Family history is significant for chronic intermittent muscle weakness in the patient's mother and hemiplegia in her maternal uncle. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows proximal muscle weakness. Skeletal muscle biopsy of the patient shows ragged muscle fibers. Further evaluation confirms the presence of the same inherited disease in all the affected family members. Which of the following pedigrees best describes the mode of inheritance of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with myoclonic epilepsy, a positive maternal family history of myopathies, and muscle biopsy findings demonstrating ragged muscle fibers has a presentation consistent with mitochondrial myopathy.

Mitochondrial myopathy is a rare genetic disorder that occurs when there are mutated mitochondria in muscle cells, especially skeletal muscle cells. The abnormal fibers have irregular size and shape on the cross-section, and thus the condition is known as “ragged fiber disease.” Mitochondria are cellular organelles that have their own mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), and offspring inherit the mitochondria from the mother with no paternal contribution (maternal inheritance). All offspring of affected females may show signs of disease, whereas transmission never occurs through males.

Each cell in the human body has hundreds of mitochondria, and the defects can occur in any number of mitochondria within a cell. This feature results in the presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA, resulting in variable expression in mitochondrial-inherited diseases. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy, and it can be seen in this patient’s family: the mother has mild symptoms of myopathy, the maternal uncle has more severe symptoms with hemiplegia, and the patient has severe symptoms manifesting with epilepsy.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents autosomal dominant inheritance, which can affect 50% of the children of one affected parent. Moreover, both male and females can have the disease and can pass it on to their children; mitochondrial disorders, in contrast, can only be passed on by the mother.
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents X-linked dominant inheritance, wherein the affected father transmits the disease to all daughters and none of his sons, while the affected mother can transmit to 50% of daughters and sons (e.g., fragile X syndrome and hypophosphatemic rickets)
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents X-linked recessive transmission. Male offspring of carrier mothers have a 50% chance of being affected, whereas the female offspring have a 50% chance of being carriers. There is no male-to-male transmission, and the disease can often skip generations.
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents autosomal recessive transmission. With 2 carrier (heterozygous) parents, 25% of children will be affected (homozygous), 50% of children will be carriers, and 25% of children will be neither affected nor carriers. Autosomal recessive conditions tend to skip generations.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of painful lesions on the forehead. The lesions appeared approximately one week ago and started off as small fluid filled sacs. Over the past few days, the lesions have become more red and painful. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and asthma. She does not consume tobacco or alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

If untreated, this patient is at highest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient has unilateral erythema and vesicular lesions in the V1 distribution, which is concerning for herpes zoster (also termed shingles). Given the distribution of these lesions, lack of treatment may result in herpes zoster ophthalmicus, keratitis, and subsequent blindness.

Shingles is due to reactivation of latent varicella zoster virus (VZV), which is the virus responsible for chickenpox in children. After the initial chickenpox has resolved, VZV remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia or sensory ganglia of cranial nerves and is subject to reactivation. During reactivation, the virus replicates and spreads within the ganglion to involve sensory neurons and spreads antegrade along the sensory nerve to cause cutaneous infection.

Clinically, shingles manifests with a rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single or multiple contiguous dermatomes. Over the next several days, the rash develops into small vesicles. As this process occurs, the involved sensory ganglion exhibits intense inflammation and hemorrhagic necrosis of nerve cells, resulting in the most common complication of post-herpetic neuralgia.

Specific complications depend on the dermatome involved. When reactivation occurs in the V1 distribution, ocular involvement may occur. If cranial VII is involved, patients may experience Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of hearing loss, facial paralysis, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. Rarer complications include meningitis, encephalitis, myelitis, or bacterial superinfection in immunocompromised hosts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Keratitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis is a known complication of shingles; however, it is a less common complication. This patient is at higher risk of keratitis, and potentially blindness, given the proximity of the lesions to her eye.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Actinic keratoses are premalignant lesions that have a rough, sandpaper-like appearance. If untreated, actinic keratosis can lead to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). However, this patient has multiple vesicular lesions that are consistent with the presentation of herpes zoster, which is not associated with SCC.
❌ Cavernous sinus thrombosis:
Incorrect: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not a well-established complication of herpes zoster. It is more commonly implicated in chronic bacterial sinus infections and hypercoagulable states.
❌ Unilateral facial paralysis:
Incorrect: Bell palsy may occur if there is reactivation of the varicella zoster virus in the cranial nerve VII distribution. Patients with cranial nerve VII involvement will likely have lesions in the auditory canal or external ear. In contrast, this patient’s vesicular lesions are located on the forehead, which is more consistent with a cranial nerve V in the V1 branch distribution.

questions.text: A 1-day old boy is evaluated in the neonatal ICU for preterm birth and low birth weight. The patient was born via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 35-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation. The neonate has passed urine and is breastfeeding. He has not passed stool. The mother had a normal pregnancy with regular antenatal care. During her pregnancy, she had two upper respiratory tract infections and a urinary tract infection that was treated. She did not use illicit drugs or consume alcohol during her pregnancy. She did consume caffeinated energy drinks and smoked a pack of cigarettes on the weekends throughout her pregnancy. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 70/30 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and respiratory rate is 55/min. His weight, length and head circumference are at the 40th percentile for gestational age. Birth weight was 1500g. Abdomen is soft and nontender. Normal heart sounds are heard on cardiovascular auscultation. Which of the following intrauterine processes is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with low birth weight, preterm birth and a maternal history of tobacco use.  Smoking leads to the formation of reactive oxygen species, which can negatively affect placental function. Specifically, nicotine can cause vasospasm of the placental vessels and structural changes to the villous membrane resulting in abnormal gas exchange across the placenta. Carbon monoxide formed from smoking combines with hemoglobin to form carboxyhemoglobin. Competitive inhibition with oxyhemoglobin reduces tissue oxygenation and impairs fetal oxygen delivery.

As a result, cigarette smoking is associated with complications such as preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, abruptio placenta and spontaneous pregnancy loss. Neonatal complications include sudden infant death syndrome, respiratory tract infections and bronchiolitis. 

Option Analysis

✅ Carboxyhemoglobin formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cell migration failure:
Incorrect: Hirschsprung disease results from the absence of aganglionic cells in the distal rectum due to failure of migration of neural crest cells. Neonates present with intestinal obstruction and failure to pass stool within the first 48 hours of life. The absence of bilious emesis and abdominal distention makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Abnormal rotation of the gut:
Incorrect: Malrotation of the gut can lead to the formation of an intestinal volvulus and intestinal obstruction. The absence of bilious emesis and abdominal distention makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Recanalization failure:
Incorrect: Failure of recanalization can cause duodenal atresia, which manifests with bilious emesis. Low birth weight alone is not an indication of underlying atresia.
❌ Placental prostaglandin E2 production:
Incorrect: Patency of the ductus arteriosus is maintained in utero by placental prostaglandin production. The persistence of the ductus arteriosus can occur in preterm infants and is associated with elevated levels of PGE2. This patient does not have evidence of a murmur on cardiac auscultation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of anxiety and paranoia. The patient was at a party where he started screaming at a girl because he believed she was going to harm him. Several minutes later, he felt restless and stated he felt like “the world was closing in on him.” Temperature is 37.2C (98.96F), heart rate is 115/minute, blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg, and respirations are 18/minute. Oxygen saturation is 99%. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious. Pupils are 3 mm and reactive to light bilaterally. The conjunctiva appears injected, and his coordination is slow. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of a panic attack likely secondary to cannabis intoxication. Cannabis (marijuana) is one of the most commonly used drugs in the United States and contains the active substance delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). This molecule exerts its effects by binding to the cannabinoid binding receptor 1 (CB1) and cannabinoid binding receptor 2 (CB2).

Cannabis can be used via inhalation (most commonly) or ingestion (in the form of edibles). If inhaled, effects take hold within minutes and include euphoria, abnormal time perception, decreased concentration, impaired short-term memory, and increased appetite. In cases of overdose, marijuana may cause panic attacks, paranoia, social withdrawal, and dysphoria.



Physical examination findings associated with cannabis intoxication include tachycardia, hypertension and hyperventilation. The most common physical exam feature is conjunctival injection, which is due to enlargement of the conjunctival vessels that results in a red appearance of the eyes. In addition, patients usually have dry mouth and impaired motor coordination.


People that use cannabis for prolonged periods may experience withdrawal symptoms if they abruptly stop its use. Symptoms of cannabinoid withdrawal include dysphoria, decreased appetite, inability to concentrate, and low mood.


Option Analysis

✅ Cannabis intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phencyclidine intoxication:
Incorrect: Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication is associated with combative and aggressive behavior, paranoia, and dysphoria. Vital signs show increased blood pressure, heart rate and temperature, which may be severe. On physical examination, nystagmus is usually apparent. Conjunctival injection is not commonly observed with PCP intoxication.
❌ Panic disorder:
Incorrect: Although this patient’s presentation is consistent with a panic attack, panic disorder is not secondary to an underlying intoxication.
❌ Lysergic acid diethylamide intoxication:
Incorrect: Although LSD intoxication can lead to panic attacks, the presence of conjunctival injection is more suggestive of cannabis intoxication.
❌ Cocaine intoxication :
Incorrect: Cocaine intoxication can lead to panic attacks, hypertension, and tachycardia; however, it is commonly associated with mydriasis (this patient’s pupils are normal in size).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with painless worsening of vision. Over the past five months, his vision has become more blurry. He has also experienced difficulty driving at night, since light from incoming cars causes an unbearable glare. Medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient does not use glasses or contact lenses. Visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye and 20/100 in the left eye. A fundoscopic examination reveals a reduced red reflex in the left eye. No conjunctival erythema is present, and pupillary response is intact bilaterally. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with blurry vision and increased sensitivity to glare, and ocular examination demonstrates a reduced red reflex. He likely has a cataract, which is due to lens opacification.

Cataracts most commonly develop in adults in the fifth or sixth decades of life. In rare cases, cataracts can be congenital or arise in pediatric patients. The condition is caused by degenerative processes that denature and coagulate proteins within the ocular lens, resulting in opacification, which imapirs transmission of light onto the retina.

Clinically, cataracts present with gradual, unilateral or bilateral, painless visual changes. Visual changes often include blurred vision, colored halos around lights, sensitivity to light/glare, as well as fading or yellowing of objects. On physical examination, patients will demonstrate decreased visual acuity, opacification of all or part of the lens, as well as reduced red reflex. In both children and adults, cataracts may also present with leukoria, which is an abnormal white reflection from the retina of the eye.



Option Analysis

✅ Opacification of the lens:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inflammation of the uvea:
Incorrect: Uveitis refers to inflammation of the uvea and can manifest with ocular pain, conjunctival injection, and imapired vision. In contrast, this patient presents with painless reduction of visual acuity, increased glare, and a reduced red reflex, which are more concerning for a cataract.
❌ Abnormal curvature of the cornea:
Incorrect: Astigmatism refers to an abnormal curvature of the cornea that results in difficulty seeing both near and far objects. However, astigmatism would not account for the reduced red reflex or increased sensitivity to glare.
❌ Optic disc atrophy:
Incorrect: Glaucoma manifests as optic disc atrophy in the setting of elevated intraocular pressures. The condition typically causes progressive peripheral vision loss. Glaucoma would not, however, lead to a reduced red reflex.
❌ Malignant proliferation of retinal cells:
Incorrect: Retinoblastoma is primarily diagnosed in children, and over 95% of cases are diagnosed before the age of 5. It commonly manifests with leukoria, which is an abnormal white reflection from the retina of the eye. Given this patient’s age, his symptoms are more likely due to cataract formation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to her family physician with concerns regarding delayed sexual development. The patient states that she has never had a menstrual cycle. Her temperature is 98.6 F° (37C°), blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and heart rate is 90/min. On pelvic examination, the patient is found to have absence of pubic hair, bilateral intra-labial masses, and a blind-end vaginal pouch. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient who identifies as a female presents with a blind-ended vaginal canal, intra-labial testicles, and a lack of pubic hair. These findings are indicative of a hormonal deficiency during development, specifically of androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS).

AIS is a disorder that arises secondary to defective androgen receptors. Androgens are created in the testes and adrenal gland and subsequently enter systemic circulation. They are then internalized into multiple cell types throughout the body via androgen receptors where they execute transcriptional activities that promote phenotypic masculinization. A mutation of the androgen receptor silences this process, arresting phenotypic masculinization, resulting in de-facto development of female phenotypic characteristics. An important component of management of this condition involves gonadectomy, as retained undeveloped testes carry a risk of malignant transformation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Defective androgen receptors  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chromosomal mosaicism  :
Incorrect: Chromosomal mosaicism is characteristic of Turner syndrome, which results in females lacking an X chromosome. Clinical features include short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, heart defects, and learning disabilities.  
❌ Deficiency of placental aromatase  :
Incorrect: Placental aromatase deficiency results in an accumulation of circulating androgens in both the maternal and fetal circulation. In the female fetus, excess circulating androgens result in the development of ambiguous female genitalia.  
❌ 5-alpha-reductase deficiency  :
Incorrect: 5-alpha-reductase deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder of sexual development caused by a mutation in the SRD5A2 gene. 5-alpha-reductase deficiency results in the inability to convert testosterone to its more potent form, dihydrotestosterone.  
❌ Aberration of GnRH neuronal migration  :
Incorrect: Kallmann syndrome, a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, is characterized by anosmia and lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to aberrant neuronal migration of GnRH-releasing neurons in the olfactory placode.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her physician due to weight loss and fatigue for two months. The patient reports night sweats and high fevers, stating that she has been “soaking the bed sheets through” at night. The patient has no significant past medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following clinical features favors a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma over non-Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of localized lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (e.g., fever, night sweats, weight loss) raises concern for Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). HL encompasses a group of neoplasms histologically characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, which are bilobed tumor giant cells (“owl-eye”). HL arises from germinal center B-cells and has a bimodal distribution; the first peak occurring in patients aged 25-30, while the second peak occurs in patients aged 50-70.  

Unlike most non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs), HL arises in a single lymph node and spreads in a stepwise fashion to anatomically contiguous nodes. Extranodal involvement is uncommon in HL, whereas it is more commonly seen in NHL. Definitive diagnosis, however, still relies on the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in lymph node biopsy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Contiguous lymph node spread   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Presence of constitutional symptoms   :
Incorrect: Constitutional symptoms (fevers, night sweats, weight loss) are common to both Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   
❌ Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase   :
Incorrect: As malignant cells proliferate and outgrow their vascular supply, they release their intracellular contents–including lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Thus LDH can be elevated in both Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   
❌ Elevated serum calcium   :
Incorrect: Paraneoplastic production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D and subsequent hypercalcemia is common to both Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   
❌ Involvement of multiple peripheral nodes   :
Incorrect: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma involves multiple peripheral nodes. Hodgkin lymphoma, in contrast, is commonly localized to a single axial group of nodes (e.g., cervical, mediastinal, paraaortic).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a sudden onset, severe headache. The headache began abruptly one hour ago with associated emesis. Her medical history is remarkable for migraines, for which she takes sumatriptan as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 170/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and in pain. Nuchal rigidity is present on physical exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy woman presents with a sudden onset, severe generalized headache, with associated hypertension and neck stiffness; this presentation is consistent with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

SAH refers to the pooling of blood in the subarachnoid space. Major causes include rupture of a pre-existing saccular “berry” aneurysm (most common) or, less commonly, bleeding from an arteriovenous malformation, tumor or traumatic injury. Patients often present with the “worst headache of my life” (thunderclap headache) or a headache that reaches maximum intensity within seconds to minutes.

Common findings include a brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain/stiffness, and focal neurologic deficits. Diagnosis is performed with a non-contrast CT-brain that will reveal blood in the subarachnoid space. If inconclusive, a lumbar puncture is indicated, which may show bloody or yellow cerebrospinal fluid called xanthochromia (as a result of the broken down blood products in the CSF). Treatment of SAH involves surgical clipping or coiling of the ruptured aneurysm.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Subdural hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Rupture of the bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas, which may be acute due to high energy trauma (e.g. motor vehicle accident) or chronic from low energy trauma (e.g. as seen in cases of brain atrophy, secondary to older age or chronic alcohol use). The CT in a subdural hematoma shows a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines. This patient's presentation occurs outside the setting of trauma.  
❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis typically presents with the classic triad of fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status. Patients often complain of photophobia. The majority of patients have high fevers, typically greater than 38°C (100.4°F). This patient’s presentation is more concerning for a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which also commonly presents with nuchal rigidity.  
❌ Migraine:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by unilateral, throbbing/pulsatile pain that usually lasts 4 to 72 hours. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, or noise sensitivity. While this patient has a history of migraine headaches, the presence of neck stiffness, generalized headache and hypertension suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage.  
✅ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intracerebral hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Intracerebral hemorrhage may present with headache, vomiting, and altered mentation that develops when the hemorrhage becomes large. However, intracerebral hemorrhage typically develops more gradually than subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a fall during a climbing trip. Her partner, who accompanied her, reports that the patient fell from a 4-meter height and hit her head. En route to the hospital, the patient is comatose and unresponsive. Glasgow Coma Score is 3. She is sedated and intubated. On arrival, her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 43/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/70 mmHg. On physical examination, her arms are stiff and bent, with clenched fists and outstretched legs. Both pupils are fixed and dilated. A non-contrast CT is obtained and shows a large biconvex-shaped lesion. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction.

questions.solution:
This patient with an epidural hematoma presents in a coma with fixed and dilated pupils, decorticate posturing, and the Cushing triad of hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration. She has suffered a severe traumatic brain injury and now exhibits signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and impending cerebral herniation. A characteristic finding of elevated ICP is papilledema (i.e. swelling of the optic disk).

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a cardinal cause of disability and mortality. The severity of TBI is commonly graded by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). Severe TBI is defined by a GCS score <9, moderate as 9-12, and mild as 13-15.

Prehospital management is aimed to prevent and treat hypotension and hypoxia because the brain is vulnerable to secondary insults, especially in the first 24 hours. This treatment is usually done via intubation and fluid resuscitation. In patients like this case who present to the emergency department with signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and impending cerebral herniation, such as unilateral or bilateral fixed and dilated pupils, decorticate or decerebrate posturing, and the "Cushing triad" (hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration), prompt endotracheal intubation, head elevation, and hyperventilation should commence immediately. Hyperventilation reduces the PCO2 levels, causing vasoconstriction of the cerebral vessels and thus decreasing the brain blood flow and ICP. Intravascular injection of hyperosmolar agents such as hypertonic saline or mannitol can also be considered.



Option Analysis

✅ Swelling of the optic disk:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Xanthochromia in cerebrospinal fluid  :
Incorrect: Xanthochromia is found in the setting of subarachnoid, not epidural, hemorrhage. The presence of a large biconvex-shaped lesion on CT suggests the later diagnosis.  
❌ Rupture of bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas. CT findings of subdural hematomas show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.  
❌ Multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction.  :
Incorrect:  While diffuse axonal injury (DAI) may occur due to falls, patients with DAI specifically present in a coma without evidence of elevated intracranial pressure. This patient has evidence of cerebral edema.  
❌ Unilateral facial paralysis:
Incorrect: Unilateral facial paralysis, or any focal neurologic deficit, is more likely to be found in ischemic or embolic stroke. This patient presents with evidence of cerebral edema and impending herniation, which is characterized by a global decreased level of consciousness and coma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion and agitation. Past medical history is unknown. The patient is undomiciled and currently resides in a homeless shelter. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for mild epigastric tenderness. Fundoscopic examination shows optic hyperemia. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following agents was most likely ingested?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with confusion and epigastric pain. Laboratory testing reveals an increased osmolal gap (equation can be found below) and anion gap metabolic acidosis, while the physical examination is notable for optic disc hyperemia. These findings are suggestive of methanol poisoning.
 
 
Methanol toxicity usually develops when methanol is consumed as a substitute for ethanol. The condition initially manifests with altered mental status, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Over time, more serious complications such as vision loss and coma may develop since methanol is broken down by alcohol dehydrogenase to its toxic metabolites: formaldehyde and formic acid. Patients may have mydriasis and optic disc hyperemia or swelling secondary to optic nerve injury on physical examination. Other common findings include bradycardia, bradypnea, hypotension, and hyporeflexia.

Laboratory testing will reveal metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap, and increased osmolal gap (since methanol is osmotically active).

Treatment options include fomepizole, a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, or ethanol, which has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Both treatment options prevent the further breakdown of methanol into its toxic metabolites. Furthermore, sodium bicarbonate can be administered to alleviate the acidosis, and some patients may require hemodialysis.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 
 

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Patients with over-ingestion of acetaminophen present with relatively nonspecific symptoms of nausea, vomiting, malaise, and abdominal pain, which can progress to liver damage. Acetaminophen overdose does not cause anion gap metabolic acidosis, and ocular involvement is not usually seen.  
❌ Organophosphate:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning presents with symptoms of cholinergic hyperactivity such as bradycardia, miosis, bronchorrhea, salivation, and lacrimation. This patient’s symptoms are inconsistent with those of organophosphate poisoning.  
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Patients with benzodiazepine overdose can present with nervous system depression and occasionally respiratory depression. However, benzodiazepine overdose would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, increased osmolal gap, or ocular hyperemia.  
❌ Lead:
Incorrect: Patients with lead poisoning present with anemia, headaches, abdominal pain, and encephalopathy. Lead poisoning would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, increased osmolal gap, and ocular hyperemia.  
✅ Methanol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office due to ankle swelling and abdominal discomfort for the past three weeks. He also has shortness of breath and wheezing on exertion, but he denies orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Patient history is significant for a 50 pack-year smoking history, and he drinks approximately 7-8 units of alcohol per week. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9° F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities, tenderness of the right upper quadrant, and prominent jugular veins. Cardiac examination shows a loud pulmonic component of S2 (P2) on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking history is presenting with peripheral edema, hepatic congestion, jugular venous distension, as well as a loud P2 on auscultation. These characteristics, in the absence of features of left sided heart failure (e.g., orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea) all favor the diagnosis of cor pulmonale. Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure (RHF) secondary to a pulmonary condition. For example, this patient most likely has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to chronic smoking, which is contributing to his dyspnea on exertion. COPD causes hypoxia, leading to vasoconstriction in the pulmonary vasculature. This elevation in pulmonary arterial pressure causes a backup of pressure into the right ventricle that eventually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.  The loud P2 heard on cardiac auscultation reflects the increased closing pressure of the valve against pulmonary hypertension secondary to lung disease. As the condition progresses, it can lead to isolated RHF. It is important to note that the most common cause of RHF is left heart failure (LHF).    Since the right side of the heart cannot overcome the pressure in the pulmonary circulation, backward pressure leads to jugular venous distention, increased portal blood pressure, and peripheral edema. Increased pressure in the portal system presents with hepatosplenomegaly, hepatic pulsation, ascites and, in severe cases, cardiac cirrhosis (i.e., liver cirrhosis due to cardiac causes). On gross morphology, the congested liver is called a nutmeg liver due to congested centrilobular areas surrounded by paler, non-congested parenchyma.  


It is important to distinguish RHF and LHF based on the causes, history, clinical examination, and diagnostic investigations:  




Option Analysis

❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Prolonged hypertension can result in left ventricular concentric hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction (the heart can not fill properly) due to reduced compliance. This can eventually lead to left-sided heart failure. Symptoms of left-sided heart failure include dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea due to pulmonary edema. This patient has clinical features of right-sided heart failure. Although this patient has dyspnea, this is most likely due to a primary lung condition, such as COPD, secondary to smoking.  
❌ Chronic alcohol use:
Incorrect: Chronic alcohol use is a cause of dilated cardiomyopathy. This results in eccentric hypertrophy of the heart and systolic dysfunction (the heart can not pump blood out), which leads to left-sided heart failure. This diagnosis is unlikely as the patient is presenting with right-sided heart failure. In addition, he is drinking a moderate level, and a S3 (sign of volume overload) would be expected as opposed to a loud P2 on auscultation.
