✅ Cor pulmonale:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is an autosomal dominant condition most commonly caused by a mutation in genes which encode sarcomeric proteins. This mutation leads to asymmetric septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve which results in outlet obstruction. Presentation is variable and may include dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, palpitations, syncope, sudden cardiac death. This condition usually affects younger athletes. 
❌ Tuberculosis   :
Incorrect: Tuberculosis is a cause of constrictive pericarditis, which can eventually lead to diastolic dysfunction and right heart failure. Constrictive pericarditis can present with signs of right heart side failure as seen in this patient. However, other signs of tuberculosis would also be expected (e.g., cough, hemoptysis, fever, and night sweats).   
❌ Mitral insufficiency:
Incorrect: Mitral insufficiency can cause left sided failure. However, mitral insufficiency (i.e. regurgitation) will present with a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex, not a loud P2.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female comes to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of fatigue, weakness, and 8 kg (17.6 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past two-months. In addition, the patient reports having a decreased appetite. Her medical history is notable for a viral upper respiratory tract infection that self-resolved six weeks ago. Physical exam reveals oral mucosal pallor. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Abdominal exam reveals an enlarged liver and spleen. A fecal occult blood test is negative. Complete blood count reveals a leukocyte count of 3,700/mm3 and platelet count of 98,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear is ordered and the results are as follows:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following findings would help confirm this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy showing fibrosis and increased megakaryocyte count
Bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity and fatty infiltration
Colonoscopy revealing a neoplasm of the large intestines
Serum protein electrophoresis showing increased immunoglobulin levels
Iron studies revealing reduced serum iron and ferritin levels

questions.solution:
This patient has primary myelofibrosis, a condition that causes uncontrolled megakaryocyte proliferation. It is often secondary to mutations in the Janus Kinase 2, MPL, or Calreticulin genes. The mutated megakaryocytes produce large quantities of platelets and cytokines, one of which is fibroblast growth factor (FGF). FGF activates fibroblasts and causes scar tissue deposition. Over time, hematopoietic stem cells are crowded out of the bone marrow by scar tissue. Some of the stem cells migrate to other organs and proliferate there, resulting in extramedullary hematopoiesis.  

Patients present with symptoms secondary to decreased RBC count (e.g., fatigue, mucosal pallor) and decreased WBC count (e.g. recurrent infections). In early stages of the disease, patients have platelet overproduction and this increases their risk of thrombotic events. In later stages, when the bone marrow is fibrosed, patients develop thrombocytopenia and are at increased bleeding risk. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can cause hepatosplenomegaly.  

Work-up includes a complete blood count, peripheral blood smear, bone marrow biopsy, and genetic testing. Peripheral blood smear will show dacrocytes (teardrop-shaped RBCs that managed to squeeze out of the bone marrow). Bone marrow biopsy will show extensive fibrosis with few cells (dry tap) and genetic testing will likely confirm the presence of a mutation (e.g. JAK2).  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Bone marrow biopsy showing fibrosis and increased megakaryocyte count  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity and fatty infiltration:
Incorrect: This finding would suggest aplastic anemia. Viral infections can cause aplastic anemia. However, aplastic anemia secondary to a viral infection typically self-resolves within a few days to weeks. Moreover, it would be atypical for aplastic anemia to cause hepatosplenomegaly or dacrocytes (tear drop cells).  
❌ Colonoscopy revealing a neoplasm of the large intestines:
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer can cause anemia due to occult blood loss. This would account for the fatigue, weakness, and red blood cell (RBC) pallor. However, patients with colorectal cancer generally test hemoccult positive. Moreover, a GI malignancy would not account for the dacrocytes seen on peripheral smear.  
❌ Serum protein electrophoresis showing increased immunoglobulin levels  :
Incorrect: This would be seen in patients with multiple myeloma, which is characterized by the neoplastic proliferation of plasma cells. Multiple myeloma presents with the CRAB symptoms (hyperCalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, and Bone Lesions). While this patient likely has anemia, she has none of the other symptoms. Moreover, an increased number of plasma cells would be expected on the peripheral smear of patients with multiple myeloma.  
❌ Iron studies revealing reduced serum iron and ferritin levels  :
Incorrect: This describes iron deficiency anemia, which can present with fatigue, weakness, and red blood cell pallor. However, it would be atypical for iron deficiency anemia to present with hepatosplenomegaly or dacrocytes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of recurrent, pulsating headaches and transient vision changes for the past week. She initially gained relief from taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications, but they are no longer sufficient due to the worsening of her symptoms. Her current medications include the combined oral contraceptive pill and a tetracycline for acne. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Her BMI is 32 kg/m2. A focused neurological examination shows papilledema during fundoscopy, and testing of visual fields reveals some peripheral constriction. Magnetic resonance imaging is obtained and shows flattening of the posterior sclera and reduced soft tissue occupying the sella turcica. The brain parenchyma and ventricles appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young patient with multiple risk factors (i.e. female gender, obesity, use of tetracyclines) presenting with headache and visual disturbance most likely has idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). IIH, commonly called pseudotumor cerebri, typically affects women of childbearing age, with other risk factors including obesity, vitamin A excess, and use of tetracyclines and danazol.  

IIH is a disorder characterized by clinical features of increased intracranial pressure, including headache, papilledema, visual disturbances, and tinnitus. As the name implies, the cause of the increase in intracranial pressure is unclear. Lumbar puncture typically demonstrates elevated opening pressure with normal cerebrospinal fluid composition, and imaging reveals no evidence of other causes of intracranial hypertension.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hydrocephalus ex vacuo:
Incorrect: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo, also called ex vacuo ventriculomegaly, is characterized by an increased size of cerebrospinal fluid-containing spaces due to degeneration of the brain parenchyma. It is often seen in Alzheimer disease, advanced HIV, Pick disease, and Huntington disease. This patient’s age, symptoms, and MRI findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune inflammatory condition which leads to demyelination of CNS axons (brain and spinal cord). It can present with optic neuritis, cerebellar syndromes (e.g., diplopia, ataxia), pyramidal tract signs (e.g., weakness, spasticity) and spinal cord symptoms (e.g. neurogenic bladder). MRI will likely show lesions in specific white matter areas, including periventricular, juxtacortical regions, corpus callosum, infratentorial regions, and the spinal cord. This patient’s symptoms and MRI findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Normal pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a condition that commonly affects the elderly and is characterized by periodical increase in CSF pressure and expansion of the ventricles. Compression and distortion of the fibers of the corona radiata leads to the classic presentation of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia (magnetic gait), and cognitive dysfunction. MRI shows enlargement of the ventricles. This patient’s age, symptoms and MRI findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Chronic migraine  :
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by unilateral pain that is throbbing and pulsatile in quality, usually lasting 4 to 72 hours. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, and photosensitivity or noise sensitivity. Although this patient has some of the features of migraine headache, her physical exam and MRI findings and her vision changes favor a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the office due to hearing loss, a persistent “buzzing” in his ears, and the feeling of unsteadiness on his feet for the past 2 months. Physical examination shows reduced hearing bilaterally and an ataxic gait. An MRI is obtained and shown below:  


Credit: Radiopaedia

This patient's condition is most likely related to a mutation involving which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with bilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and ataxia, with imaging that shows bilateral masses at the cerebellopontine angle, most likely has bilateral vestibular Schwannomas (acoustic neuromas).  

 Schwannomas arise from Schwann cells, which are a subtype of glial cells. When they arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VII and VIII) at the cerebellopontine angle, they are called vestibular Schwannomas or acoustic neuromas. Bilateral vestibular Schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) occur specifically in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).   

NF2 is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a mutation of the NF2 tumor suppressor gene  on chromosome 22. The NF2 gene produces merlin, also called schwannomin, a cell membrane-related protein that serves as a tumor suppressor. Manifestations of NF2 include bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas), juvenile cataracts, meningiomas, and ependymomas.   



Option Analysis

❌ Neurofibromin :
Incorrect: Loss of neurofibromin protein is the cause of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Mutation of the NF1 gene on chromosome 17 leads to absent/reduced production of neurofibromin protein, resulting in the classic presentation of diffuse cutaneous neurofibromas, intellectual disability, Lisch nodules, optic gliomas, and pheochromocytomas. Neurofibromin belongs to a family of guanosine triphosphate hydrolase (GTPase)-activating proteins that are involved in signaling pathways. This patient's presentation however, is consistent with neurofibromatosis type 2, not type 1.  
✅ Merlin:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ PTEN:
Incorrect: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene is a negative regulator of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway, which is critical for cell proliferation, cell cycle progression, and apoptosis. Loss of function of this gene contributes to breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer development.   
❌ Hamartin:
Incorrect: Hamartin protein is the gene product of the TSC1 gene on chromosome 9, which is widely expressed in normal tissues. Hamartin forms a complex with the tuberin protein that is encoded by the TSC2 gene. It is hypothesized that loss of tuberin (or a functional tuberin-hamartin complex) results in the loss of inhibitory regulation on the cell cycle, leading to tuberous sclerosis, not neurofibromatosis type 2.  
❌ WT1:
Incorrect: WT1 gene is located on chromosome 11. The WT1 gene product is a transcription factor expressed in the developing kidney, testis, and ovary, and it appears to play a role in the development of genitourinary tissues. Mutations of the WT1 gene and its product are associated with Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine physical exam. The patient has no chronic medical conditions. The patient has had multiple sexual partners and takes oral contraceptives. She was previously uninsured and has not seen a physician for several years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 123/71 mmHg. A Pap smear is performed and results are notable for high-grade squamous epithelial dysplasia. Subsequent colposcopy with biopsy confirms the presence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade II. Which of the following best describes the portion of the cervix that is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
When assessing a cervical lesion, it is important to determine the degree of dysplasia and the depth of involvement. A Pap smear can determine the former, whereas colposcopy with biopsy can determine the latter.  

There are two main grades of dysplasia: low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) correspond to low-grade dysplasia, whereas high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) correspond to moderate or high-grade dysplasia. If a Pap smear shows abnormal results, a biopsy can be subsequently performed to determine the depth of involvement.  

There are three grades of cervical epithelial neoplasia, which are divided based on the thickness of the epithelium that is affected. Grade 1 (also termed CIN I) affects the lower one-third of the epithelium, grade 2 (also termed CIN II) affects the lower two-thirds, and grade 3 (also termed CIN III) affects almost all of the epithelium. Finally, carcinoma in situ (CIS) affects the entire thickness of the epithelium.  

Option Analysis

❌ Basal 33% of epithelium:
Incorrect: Patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 1 (CIN I) have disease that affects only the basal one-third of the cervical epithelium. However, this patient has CIN II, which affects the basal two-thirds of the epithelium.  
❌ Apical 33% of epithelium:
Incorrect: Patients with CIN II have disease that affects only the basal two-thirds of the cervical epithelium, because the lesion originates from the basal side (i.e. the portion facing the basement membrane), thus sparing the apical one-third of the epithelium.  
✅ Basal 67% of epithelium  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Apical 67% of epithelium:
Incorrect: This patient has CIN II, which affects two-thirds of the cervical epithelium. However, the lesion originates from the basal side (i.e. the portion facing the basement membrane) and progresses towards the apical side (portion facing cervical surface). As a result, only the basal two-thirds would be affected.   
❌ Near full-thickness epithelial involvement:
Incorrect: Near full-thickness epithelial involvement is seen in CIN III. However, this patient has CIN II and only two-thirds of the epithelium is involved.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for a routine wellness visit. The patient has no acute complaints. However, he does recall having jaundice and abdominal pain 3 weeks ago, after completing a marathon. The symptoms self-resolved after a few days. Laboratory testing reveals a total bilirubin level of 4.8 mg/dL and a conjugated bilirubin level of 4.2 mg/dL. Urine testing is positive for elevated coproporphyrin I levels. Which of the following additional findings will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Dubin-Johnson syndrome, a benign genetic condition characterized by the absence of a biliary transport protein found on the canalicular membrane of hepatocytes. This transport protein is called multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2). As a result, less conjugated bilirubin is transported out of hepatocytes into the bile canaliculi. Eventually, this deficiency leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with total bilirubin levels between 2-5 mg/dL. Of note, in rare instances, individuals with this condition can develop elevated bilirubin levels ranging between 20-25 mg/dL.  

Most individuals are asymptomatic. However, some can develop mild jaundice during illness, pregnancy, after exercise, or after using certain medications (e.g. oral contraceptives). In addition, individuals can have nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, abdominal pain, and weakness.  

Patients will have elevated total and conjugated bilirubin levels with normal liver function tests. Urine testing will reveal high coproporphyrin I levels. Liver histopathology will show normal hepatocytes with lysosomes filled with a dense pigment composed of epinephrine metabolites. This buildup causes the liver to have a black appearance on gross examination. Note that in contrast, individuals with Rotor syndrome (a similar but milder condition) have normal urine coproporphyrin I levels and normal-colored livers.  

Option Analysis

❌ Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency:
Incorrect: Conditions that obstruct bile flow, such as gallstones or malignancies, can lead to this finding. However, this patient’s urine testing reveals elevated coproporphyrin levels, a finding suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Dubin-Johnson syndrome does not cause bile outflow obstruction or subsequent fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption.  
❌ Extraocular muscle palsy:
Incorrect: Extraocular muscle palsy is found in patients with kernicterus, which occurs when fat-soluble unconjugated bilirubin deposits in the brain and causes neurological sequelae. It typically occurs in patients with markedly elevated bilirubin levels. In contrast, this patient has mildly elevated bilirubin levels, and most of it is conjugated bilirubin, which is water-soluble and unlikely to deposit in the brain.   
❌ Splenomegaly:
Incorrect: Patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency or hereditary spherocytosis can develop splenomegaly. These conditions can cause jaundice secondary to increased erythrocyte hemolysis. However, this hemolysis would cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In contrast, this patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Enlarged non-tender gallbladder:
Incorrect: This answer describes Courvoisier sign, which is an enlarged, palpable, yet non-tender gallbladder and accompanying jaundice. Courvoisier sign is found in patients with pancreatic cancer. However, it would be atypical for pancreatic cancer to cause intermittent jaundice or present in a young patient without risk factors (e.g., smoking, chronic alcohol use).  
✅ Blackened liver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a several day history of a swollen and painful left leg. The patient recently had a total hip arthroplasty due to debilitating arthritis. She is currently on estrogen-only replacement therapy for perimenopausal symptoms. Her BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows an edematous left leg below the knee with mild erythema; the right leg is normal. Upon dorsiflexion of the left ankle, the patient winces in pain. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which classically presents as a unilateral, swollen, painful lower extremity. Virchow's triad summarizes the pathophysiology leading to venous thromboembolism: endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and venous stasis.  

Endothelial injury can arise from chronic inflammation or trauma to vessels, such as in cancer patients, infection, or trauma/surgery. Hypercoagulability can be congenital (e.g. Factor V Leiden), acquired (e.g. nephrotic syndrome), or due to medications that induce hypercoagulability like hormone replacement therapy. Venous stasis occurs during periods of extended immobility, including plane flights, hospital stays, post-operation, or sedentary lifestyles.  

Of all the risk factors this patient has, recent major surgery is the strongest risk factor with a relative risk 5-200. Other major risk factors that confer a high relative risk include inherited thrombophilic disorders, history of DVT,  age >70 years, and pregnancy. Other known risk factors listed include obesity and estrogen replacement therapy, however these carry a lower relative risk of 1-3.  

All of the major risk factors for DVT can be summarized using the mnemonic “THROMBOSIS”:     



Option Analysis

❌ Estrogen replacement therapy:
Incorrect: Hormone therapy (whether OCPs or estrogen replacement) is a risk factor for the development of DVTs; however, it has a lower relative risk of DVT development compared to recent surgery.  
✅ Total hip arthroplasty:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of breast cancer:
Incorrect: A remote history of breast cancer itself is a less likely cause for DVT. However, the patient in this vignette does have a provoked DVT, more likely from the prolonged immobility after recent surgery, but it would be worth raising the question of a recurrence of this patient’s cancer.  
❌ Obesity :
Incorrect: Obesity carries a small increased risk of DVT, with a relative risk of 1-3, but it is not the strongest risk factor for the patient listed in this vignette.   
❌ Age:
Incorrect: An age of 55 is not a risk factor for the development of venous thromboembolism. Older age (70) is a minor risk factor for DVT.

questions.text:
A 3-hour-old male newborn delivered at 28 weeks gestation is being evaluated for increased work of breathing. The patient was born to a mother with a history of diabetes and inconsistent prenatal care. His temperature is 38 °C (100.4°F), pulse is 219/min, respirations are 81/min, blood pressure is 64/41 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. Physical exam shows a mildly cyanotic infant with tachypnea, nasal flaring, and subcostal retractions. Auscultation demonstrates diminished breath sounds bilaterally.  A chest x-ray is shown below:  




Reproduced from: Radiopaedia 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is a premature infant who presents with signs of respiratory distress and a chest x-ray significant for ground glass opacities, low volumes, and a bell-shaped thorax, all of which are concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). This condition is caused by an insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant in developing lungs.  

The diagnosis of neonatal respiratory distress is based on clinical findings of progressive respiratory failure shortly after birth and chest radiography. Typically, chest radiographs for NRDS will demonstrate low lung volumes, diffuse reticulogranular ground glass appearance with air bronchograms, which stem from alveolar atelectasis side-by-side with aerated bronchi. The ground glass appearance typically results from surrounding pulmonary edema.    

Option Analysis

✅ Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transient tachypnea of the newborn:
Incorrect: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a self-limited condition due to delayed resorption of alveolar fluid. It presents with an increased work of breathing minutes to hours after birth, but it requires little to no oxygen or ventilatory support. It can be differentiated by chest radiograph, which will typically demonstrate flattened diaphragms due to hyperinflation and mild pulmonary edema.  
❌ Bacterial pneumonia:
Incorrect: Neonatal bacterial pneumonia is a serious complication of early life and can be difficult to differentiate from NRDS due to similar radiographic findings. However, patients with neonatal bacterial pneumonia will typically have signs of sepsis, including lethargy, poor tone, tachycardia/bradycardia, or temperature instability.   
❌ Air-leak:
Incorrect: Barotrauma is a common complication of neonatal respiratory distress, usually from mechanical hyperventilation of poorly developed lungs in intubated patients. While the patient in this vignette has decreased breath sounds bilaterally, he has no evidence of a substantial pneumothorax on his chest x-ray, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Tetralogy of fallot :
Incorrect: Cardiac anomalies should always remain in the differential diagnosis of a cyanotic neonate, including tetralogy of Fallot. However, patients with tetralogy of Fallot do not typically present immediately after birth. Additionally, patients will typically have an audible murmur on chest auscultation and a boot-shaped heart on chest radiograph.

questions.text: An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from a nearby skilled nursing facility with confusion and vomiting for the past day. According to the nursing staff, the patient was in her usual state of health before the last 24 hours, during which she was complaining of nausea. She is normally alert and oriented to person, place and time. She has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension, and she was recently discharged from the hospital after having an obstructed kidney stone removed and a postoperative course complicated by recurrent urinary retention. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 121/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over her left flank. A Foley catheter is in place and draining dark brown urine. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient’s current clinical condition?

choices.text: Bacterial ascent up a short urethra

questions.solution:
This elderly female patient presents with signs and symptoms of pyelonephritis, including nausea, vomiting, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Of the risk factors listed, her strongest predisposing risk factor is Foley catheter placement, which likely served as a nidus for her current infection and should be removed promptly for adequate source control. Both cystitis (bladder infection) and pyelonephritis (kidney infection) have multiple risk factors, but the mechanism of transmission is largely related to ascending bacterial infection.  

Bacteria are constantly moving into the urethral tract from the periurethral area, vaginal cavity, and perianal area; further transmission of these bacteria may occur when host defense systems fail, allowing bacteria to grow to substantial numbers before spontaneous clearance. One such example is a failed vesicoureteral reflux mechanism, which then allows retrograde propulsion of urine, enabling bacteria to ascend the ureter.  

Additional risk factors for the development of urinary tract infections are divided into those that expose the host to potential uropathogens and those that enhance colonization by those uropathogens:  

  •  Increased exposure to uropathogens: Foley catheter, frequent sexual intercourse, trauma or surgical manipulation of the urinary tract 
  •  Enhanced colonization of uropathogens: Female gender (due to a shorter urethra), Foley catheter placement,, diabetes, obesity, pregnancy, and obstructive processes (benign prostatic hyperplasia, neurologic conditions) 

Option Analysis

✅ Indwelling urinary catheter  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Impaired urine flow:
Incorrect: Chronic obstructions due to nephrolithiasis or anatomic variability (e.g. posterior urethral valves) may impede flow of urine, allowing bacteria to migrate more easily. This patient has evidence of continued urine output, making this etiology unlikely.   
❌ Bacterial ascent up a short urethra:
Incorrect: Women in general are more likely to sustain urinary tract infections due to shorter urethras; however, in the setting of a Foley placement, the former risk factor becomes inconsequential by comparison.   
❌ Hematogenous bacterial spread  :
Incorrect: Hematogenous bacterial spread is unlikely in this patient without additional evidence of pneumonia, bacteremia, endocarditis, or an additional inciting infectious process.  
❌ Antimicrobial suppression of endogenous flora:
Incorrect: Recent antimicrobial use may precipitate pyelonephritis with more fastidious bacteria, but this patient has not recently taken antimicrobials.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after experiencing crushing substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm for the past hour. The patient reports experiencing nausea and diaphoresis during this time. An ECG is performed, which shows sinus rhythm with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III and aVF. Before cardiac catheterization could be performed, the patient develops ventricular tachycardia with subsequent hemodynamic instability. Despite appropriate life-saving measures, the patient dies. Autopsy shows yellow lipid plaques on the intimal surface of the right coronary artery with an overlying, completely occlusive thrombus. Examination of several other coronary arteries demonstrate similar lipid plaques. Which of the following locations is most likely to show similar lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm and ST-segment elevations in the inferior leads likely had a myocardial infarction. Subsequent autopsy showed yellow lipid plaques in the coronary arteries, suggestive of atherosclerosis.    

Atherosclerosis is a pathologic process that affects arteries throughout the body, including the aorta, coronary, cerebral, and peripheral arteries. Atherosclerosis is the hardening of any artery (but usually medium-large arteries) which is caused by the buildup of plaques (termed “atheromas”). Atherosclerosis can begin as early as childhood with the development of fatty streaks and advances with aging.

In descending order, the most common arteries affected by atherosclerosis are: 
  1.  Abdominal aorta 
  2.  Coronary artery 
  3.  Popliteal artery  
  4.  Carotid artery 
Risk factors for atherosclerosis can be divided into modifiable and nonmodifiable risk factors. Modifiable risk factors include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking and dyslipidemia, (particularly an increase in LDL levels or a decrease in HDL levels). Non-modifiable risk factors include age, family history, and being of African-American descent.  
 






Option Analysis

❌ Femoral artery:
Incorrect: Atherosclerotic occlusion of the common femoral artery can result in claudication in the thigh and/or calf. Although atherosclerosis of this artery can occur, another location is more commonly affected.   
❌ Subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Stenosis or partial occlusion of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery can result in subclavian steal syndrome. Other causes of subclavian artery thrombosis include vasculitic diseases, such as Takayasu arteritis. Although atherosclerosis of this artery can occur, another location is more commonly affected.   
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the radial artery is rare but can occur in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) via the radial artery. However, the radial artery is not a common site of atherosclerosis, and another location is more commonly affected.   
✅ Abdominal aorta:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal carotid artery:
Incorrect: Atherosclerosis of the internal carotid artery can result in strokes due to atheroemboli and occlusion of cerebral vessels. However, another location is more commonly affected.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine eye examination. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes diagnosed 15 years ago, as well as hypertension and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. Up until 6 months ago, the diabetes had been controlled on metformin and liraglutide, but since then, the patient’s physician switched to monotherapy with insulin, due to increasing capillary blood glucose measurements and hemoglobin A1c. The patient’s temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Visual acuity testing shows a score of 20/60 in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to be found on an ophthalmoscopic examination?

choices.text: Leakage of lipid and proteinaceous materia

questions.solution:
All patients with diabetes should be screened annually for diabetic retinopathy (DR). DR is caused by damage to the retina from the tissue-damaging effects of chronic hyperglycemia, including non-enzymatic glycosylation, altered retinal blood flow, and aberrant growth factor activation (VEGF, TGF-beta), all culminating in retinal hypoxia.  

As the majority of patients with type 2 diabetes will have diabetic retinopathy after 20 years of diabetes, this patient is likely to exhibit signs of DR on examination, which has likely accelerated her vision loss, as seen by her decreased visual acuity. Additionally, DR is known to increase during the year after starting intensive insulin therapy, as enhanced blood sugar control lowers the plasma blood volume and puts small vessels at risk of infarct. In patients with type 1 diabetes, DR occurs earlier, 3-5 years after diagnosis, attributable to longer durations of hyperglycemia without an endogenous insulin buffer.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

DR is divided into two types, nonproliferative and proliferative, each with characteristic findings on ophthalmoscopic examination. Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) shows cotton wool spots (nerve-fiber layer infarcts), intraretinal hemorrhages (“flame” hemorrhages), and microaneurysms. “Hard” exudates occur early in the course of DR, caused by leakage of lipids and proteinaceous material, and appear as small white or yellowish white deposits on the retina with sharp margins. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), which can include the findings of NPDR or can be found in isolation, refers to the finding of retinal neovascularization, where ischemia causes growth factor release, leading to new, unstable blood vessels that can bleed or cause retinal detachment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Retinal macroaneurysms:
Incorrect: Retinal pericytes and microvascular endothelial cells die relatively early on in the setting of uncontrolled diabetes, predisposing to retinal MICROaneurysms, which are hypercellular outpouchings of retinal capillaries with weakened walls that can bleed and cause acute blindness (retinal hemorrhage). Retinal arterial MACROaneurysms are rare, occur at the arteriole level, and result from hypertension rather than diabetes.  
✅ Leakage of lipid and proteinaceous materia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Proliferation of retinal pericytes:
Incorrect: Retinal pericytes and microvascular endothelial cells die relatively early on in the setting of uncontrolled diabetes. The word “proliferative” in “proliferative diabetic retinopathy” refers to the presence of neovascularization (new, tortuous blood vessels) growing from the optic disc and retinal vessels.    
❌ Retinal vein endothelial atrophy:
Incorrect: Retinal pericytes and microvascular endothelial cells die relatively early on in the setting of uncontrolled diabetes. This process is followed by repeated cycles of endothelial growth and cell death, eventually culminating instead in retinal vein endothelial cell proliferation, which is seen as tortuous loops at risk of leakage and rupture.   
❌ Thinned retinal basement membrane  :
Incorrect: Similar to the thickened glomerular basement membrane seen in diabetic kidney disease, the retina in patients with diabetes grows thicker over time. This phenomenon is caused by capillary leakage and edema. If this process occurs near the macula (macular edema), loss of visual acuity will occur.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to progressively worsening headaches over the past year. Medical history is unremarkable, other than mild scoliosis. Over the past year, he has been experiencing dull, diffuse headaches, especially in the morning. He also noted occasional blurry vision but did not seek care. Vital signs are normal. On physical examination, mild bilateral papilledema is noted. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. A brain MRI is obtained and shown below. This patient’s condition is also associated with which of the following findings?  


Retrieved from: Radiopaedia

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation in upper extremities
Herniation of the spinal cord via a vertebral defect
Progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, spastic limb weakness, and normal sensation

questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy boy is now presenting with progressive headaches which are more pronounced in the morning, raising concerns for an intracranial process. The brain MRI reveals a classic picture of cerebellar tonsillar herniation, favoring the diagnosis of Chiari type I malformation, which is associated with syringomyelia.   

Chiari I malformation is characterized by the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils inferior to foramen magnum (mnemonic: type 1 includes 1 structure). This finding is indicated by the red circle, showing caudal displacement of the cerebellar tonsils on head MRI. The condition is usually asymptomatic during childhood and manifests in adolescence and adulthood with occipital headaches, elevated intracranial pressure, and neck pain. The condition often occurs in conjunction with syringomyelia, which is a cavitation within the central canal of the spinal cord that results in a bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities (“cape like” distribution).  

In contrast, Chiari II malformation is marked by herniation of both the cerebellar vermis and tonsils (mnemonic: type 2 includes 2 structure) via the foramen magnum, leading to aqueductal stenosis, and noncommunicating hydrocephalus. Chiari II is often seen with myelomeningocele and is more likely to present early in life.  

 


Option Analysis

✅ Loss of pain and temperature sensation in upper extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Herniation of the spinal cord via a vertebral defect:
Incorrect: This answer describes a myelomeningocele, a congenital open neural tube defect typified by herniation of the meninges and the spinal cord through a vertebral bony defect. The presentation depends upon the level of the lesion and usually involves sensory, motor and bowel and bladder deficits. This condition, however, is associated with Chiari type II, rather than type I. Also, it is more likely to present in infancy, and this patient has a normal medical history.   
❌ Progressive symmetric ascending muscle paralysis:
Incorrect: This answer depicts Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy), an autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of Schwann cells. It is often associated with gastrointestinal infections, such as Campylobacter jejuni.  
❌ Progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, spastic limb weakness, and normal sensation  :
Incorrect: This answer depicts amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a neurologic condition characterized by both upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs. Patients often present with bulbar palsy (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia) and flaccid or spastic limb weakness. This condition is not associated with Chiari malformations.   
❌ Progressive sensory ataxia:
Incorrect: This answer depicts tabes dorsalis, a condition seen in patients with tertiary syphilis. It is characterized by degeneration and demyelination of dorsal columns that carry proprioceptive coordination. Patients present with progressive sensory ataxia, positive Romberg sign and absent deep tendon reflexes.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the clinic with low-grade fevers, fatigue, paleness, shortness of breath, and a nonproductive cough for the past 2 weeks. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Chest auscultation reveals mild wheezing and crackles bilaterally. Chest X-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates. Direct Coombs test is positive. Which of the following classes of antibodies is most likely implicated in this disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient with 2 weeks of low-grade fevers, shortness of breath, and nonproductive cough likely has a form of atypical “walking” pneumonia. Given the positive Coombs test, the most likely cause of pneumonia is Mycoplasma pneumoniae, which can cause a cold (IgM-mediated) autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). This occurs as a result of the production of cold agglutinins, which are autoantibodies that target erythrocyte membranes, resulting in clumping of erythrocytes. This may be visualized on peripheral blood smear, and diagnosis is confirmed by a positive direct Coombs test.  

There are two types of AIHA: cold (IgM-mediated) and warm (IgG-mediated). Cold AIHA is mediated by cold agglutinins and warm AIHA is mediated by warm agglutinins. Cold agglutinins bind erythrocytes in areas of the body at lower temperatures, and warm agglutinins bind erythrocytes in areas of the body at higher temperatures. Both are associated with extravascular hemolysis. Common causes of IgG-mediated AIHA include chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Non-hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), and other non-lymphoid malignancies. Common causes of IgM-mediated AIHA include Mycoplasma pneumoniae, mononucleosis, and Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Immunoglobulin A (IgA):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) acts by inhibiting infectious organisms from attaching to the mucous membranes. It primarily protects against gastrointestinal infections such as Giardia.   
✅ Immunoglobulin M (IgM)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immunoglobulin G (IgG):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin G (IgG) is associated with warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which is commonly due to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), and some drugs such as alpha-methyldopa.  
❌ Immunoglobulin E (IgE):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is associated with type I hypersensitivity (HS) reactions and activates eosinophils in response to parasitic infections.   
❌ Immunoglobulin D (IgD):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin D (IgD) is found on B cells and in the blood, but its function is unclear.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a one-week history of joint pains in both of the hands, which he describes as being achy and stiff. The patient also feels fatigued and feverish at times, and he has recently started noticing chest pains when he sneezes. Medical history includes hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and plaque psoriasis. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and etanercept. The patient’s temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows salmon-colored, scaly plaques over both elbows, and mildly tender proximal interphalangeal joints in both hands. Normal heart sounds are heard on auscultation of the heart, and normal breath sounds are heard without egophony or tactile fremitus. The chest is non-tender on palpation. Which of the following will most likely be found in this patient’s blood?
questions.solution:
This patient has the typical symptoms of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE): the abrupt onset fever, arthralgias, and pleuritis. As compared to idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), DILE has a 1:1 male to female prevalence (vs. 1:9), is more likely to occur over 50 years of age (vs. reproductive years), and is less likely to cause a rash (20% vs. 60%). Also, DILE typically does not affect the oral mucosa, CNS, or kidneys.  

DILE is characterized by lupus-like symptoms with positive anti-histone antibodies found in the serum. Drugs metabolized by N-acetylation in the liver are most commonly implicated in DILE, including procainamide, hydralazine, methyldopa, and minocycline; therefore, genetically predisposed individuals who are slow acetylators are at risk for drug-induced lupus. Additional culprits include sulfa drugs and etanercept. These drugs induce antinuclear auto-antibody (anti-histone) formation and cause systemic symptoms at least one month after starting, but most commonly after months or years of exposure. You can remember the drugs that cause DILE by the following mnemonic:  

 


Diagnosis is made through identification of anti-histone antibodies in the blood in the absence of SLE-specific antibodies (anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith). Importantly, up to 80% of patients with SLE may have anti-histone antibodies in addition to SLE-specific antibodies. Removal of the offending agent leads to resolution of symptoms in most cases.  

Option Analysis

❌ Anti-Sm antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Sm (anti-“Smith”) antibody is specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.  
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibody is specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.  
✅ Anti-histone antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lupus anticoagulant:
Incorrect: Lupus anticoagulant is a pro-thrombotic immunoglobulin that binds to phospholipids and cell surface proteins. It may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but it does not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.  
❌ Anticardiolipin IgG antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticardiolipin antibodies bind cardiolipin, a macromolecule that makes up 20% of the total lipids in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM) may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but they do not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty swallowing for the past 2 months. The patient describes intermittent difficulty swallowing solids which improves with water or by chewing her food more. She also reports feeling more tired during this time period. Medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva. Which of the following may be seen on further evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, which presents with a classic triad of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, tachycardia, pale conjunctiva), esophageal webs, and dysphagia. Among the answers options above, only koilonychia (spoon nails) is associated with iron deficiency.  

An esophageal web is a thin, mucosal, noncircumferential membrane that grows within the esophageal lumen and may cause dysphagia. It is usually located in the proximal esophagus. Diagnosis is made by endoscopy and/or barium swallow test. An esophageal web can be seen as part of Plummer-Vinson Syndrome or as a separate entity.  

Plummer-Vinson Syndrome is a rare disorder caused by chronic iron deficiency. It is typically seen in white women between 40-70 years old, but it has also been described in children and adolescents. Other signs and symptoms include glossitis, angular cheilitis, koilonychia (as seen in this patient), splenomegaly, enlarged thyroid, and symptoms of iron deficiency anemia (e.g. fatigue). Diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome is important due to the increased risk for developing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment consists of iron repletion, which often leads to rapid resolution of the dysphagia. However, in patients with significant dysphagia, esophageal dilation may also be required.  

Option Analysis

✅ Koilonychia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Scaly skin:
Incorrect: Scaly skin is associated with vitamin A deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of vitamin A deficiency include corneal degeneration, immunosuppression and night blindness.   
❌ Swollen gums:
Incorrect: Swollen gums are associated with vitamin C deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of vitamin C deficiency include easy bruising, petechiae, “corkscrew” hair, hemarthrosis, anemia, poor wound healing, perifollicular and subperiosteal hemorrhages, and weakened immune response.  
❌ Delayed wound healing:
Incorrect: Delayed wound healing is associated with zinc and vitamin C deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of zinc deficiency include suppressed immunity, male hypogonadism, reduced adult hair (axillary, facial, pubic), dysgeusia (taste abnormality), and anosmia.   
❌ Subacute combined degeneration:
Incorrect: Subacute combined degeneration is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. Other signs and symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency include megaloblastic anemia and paresthesias.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female comes to the office for a follow-up appointment. Two weeks ago, the patient fell during a college basketball game on an overstretched arm. Since then, she has experienced tenderness around the snuffbox of the right hand. An x-ray obtained following the injury failed to demonstrate a scaphoid fracture. However, imaging did show a circular lucent lesion with central irregular calcifications at the metaphysis of the base of the 5th proximal phalanx. The cortex appears intact. Vital signs are within normal limits. Family history and medical history are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has chondroma, a benign tumor of hyaline cartilage that typically develops in the medullary cavity (enchondroma) or on the cortical surface (juxtacortical chondroma). It occurs typically in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. It appears as a metaphyseal lesion of the tubular bones in the hands and feet. While it is usually a solitary lesion, multiple enchondromas are associated with Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome.  

Most enchondromas are asymptomatic and are detected incidentally, as in the case of this patient. Occasionally, they may cause pain or pathologic fracture. On imaging, chondromas are characterized by a well circumscribed lucent lesion with central irregular calcifications, a sclerotic rim, and an intact cortex. Macroscopically, they are usually < 3 cm, gray-blue in color, and translucent. Histologically, they are composed of benign cartilage with central calcifications and peripheral ossification. Solitary lesions rarely undergo sarcomatous transformation, but with enchondromatosis syndromes, the risk is higher. Treatment may include observation or curettage, depending on the clinical course.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Osteoid osteoma:
Incorrect: Osteoid osteoma (OO) is a type of bone-producing tumor which commonly occurs at the cortex of the distal femur or proximal tibia. On histology, the tumor is well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. On x-ray, OO appears as a central nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim. Patients often present with pain which responds to NSAIDs. While this patient’s lesion has similar radiological features, the absence of pain, the tumor’s location, and the presence of irregular calcifications all favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Osteoid blastoma:
Incorrect: Osteoid blastoma (OB) is a type of bone-producing tumor which commonly occurs at the vertebrae. On histology, the tumor is well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. On x-ray, OB can have variable appearance and may manifest as a central nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim. Patients often present with pain which does not respond to NSAIDs (thus distinguishing it from osteoid osteoma). This patient tumor location and the absence of pain favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Chondroma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chondrosarcoma :
Incorrect: Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilage-producing tumors which are subclassified into conventional (hyaline cartilage–producing), dedifferentiated, clear cell, and mesenchymal types. Chondrosarcomas usually arises in the bone of the pelvis or shoulder and rarely involves the distal extremities. On imaging, it appears as a foci with calcifications or flocculent densities that may destroy the cortex. Clinically, it usually presents as a painful and progressively enlarging mass.   
❌ Osteochondroma :
Incorrect: Osteochondroma (exostosis) is a benign overgrowth of cartilage that can be sessile or pedunculated. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones close to the growth plate. The cap consists of benign hyaline cartilage that undergoes endochondral ossification, with new bone-forming at the inner part. This patient’s radiographic findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of progressively worsening fatigue, dyspnea, and lightheadedness for the past 6 months and leg swelling for the last month. She has not had any prior episodes of syncope or chest pain with exertion. Past medical history includes anorexia nervosa. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Body mass index is 14.5 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a thin woman in respiratory distress and neck examination shows jugular venous distention. Cardiac auscultation shows a holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates to the axilla and an S3 heart sound that is best heard at the apex in early diastole. A chest x-ray is obtained, and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s findings on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: Increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve
Increased blood flow during ventricular filling
Forceful atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle

questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, dyspnea, an S3 heart sound, enlarged heart shadow on X-ray, past medical history of anorexia nervosa, and low BMI likely has dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to a thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency resulting in wet beriberi. Thiamine is heavily involved in energy generation, especially during oxidative metabolism. Since cardiac tissue relies on oxidative metabolism, deficiency of vitamin B1 can lead to dysfunction and eventually dilated cardiomyopathy. The S3 heart sound is best heard in early diastole and is due to increased blood flow during ventricular filling.  

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), which is defined as dilation of all four chambers of the heart, is the most common cause of cardiomyopathy and makes up about 90% of cardiomyopathy cases. The dilation of the heart chambers leads to thinning of the walls of the heart and decreased strength of contraction. Therefore, the patient has systolic dysfunction and normal diastolic function.  

 


The majority of dilated cardiomyopathy is idiopathic, but there are many possible causes that must be ruled out. Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy include: 
  •  Genetic mutations: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), hemochromatosis 
  •  Systemic conditions: Thyrotoxicosis, peripartum cardiomyopathy, wet beriberi (caused by thiamine deficiency) 
  •  Infectious: Myocarditis, Coxsackievirus B, Chagas disease 
  •  Toxic: Chronic alcoholism, chemotherapy (doxorubicin, daunorubicin), cocaine abuse 
 Diagnosis of dilated cardiomyopathy is achieved via radiographic examination with x-ray and echocardiography. X-ray may show cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, and pleural effusion. Echocardiography shows ventricular dilation and decreased ejection fraction.  

Possible complications of dilated cardiomyopathy include systolic heart failure, arrhythmias, and valve regurgitation.    

An angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), or beta blocker may be used to help slow disease progression, but a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) may be necessary, and the most severe cases require heart transplant.   

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased mitral valve leaflet motion:
Incorrect: Decreased mitral valve leaflet motion is associated with the opening snap characteristic of mitral stenosis. It would not be observed in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.   
❌ Increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: Increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve results in fixed splitting of the S2 heart sound. Fixed splitting is associated with left-to-right shunts, such as atrial septal defect (ASD). It would not be observed in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.   
✅ Increased blood flow during ventricular filling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delayed right ventricular emptying:
Incorrect: Delayed right ventricular emptying results in wide splitting of the S2 heart sound. Wide splitting is associated with pulmonic stenosis and right bundle branch block. It would not be observed in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.   
❌ Forceful atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle  :
Incorrect: Forceful atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle causes an S4 heart sound, which is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and best heard in late diastole.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, at 20 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for routine prenatal ultrasonography. She reports no recent changes in her health. The fetal ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index of ≤ 5 cm (normal 8-18 cm), as well as bilateral deformities of the upper and lower extremities. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following associated conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ultrasound shows a low amniotic fluid index, indicating oligohydramnios, and bilateral limb deformities, which suggests Potter sequence. Any cause of low amniotic fluid can lead to Potter sequence, including placental insufficiency, bilateral renal agenesis, and posterior urethral valves (in males).  

During the first trimester, amniotic fluid volume is derived from the maternal compartment, fetal secretions, and placenta. During the second trimester, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid. A urinary tract anomaly can lead to anuria/oliguria, which causes oligohydramnios.    

The lack of amniotic fluids causes the fetus to become compressed in utero. The result is Potter sequence, which is characterized by severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia. Lung hypoplasia occurs because the fetus needs to aspirate a certain amount of amniotic fluid in order to expand and develop its lungs.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Cleft palate:
Incorrect: Cleft palate occurs when there is a lack of a connection between the roof of the mouth and the nose. It is caused by failed fusion of the two lateral palatine shelves or failed fusion of the lateral palatine shelf with the nasal septum/median palatine shelf. It is not associated with renal agenesis or oligohydramnios.  
✅ Lung hypoplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Macrosomia :
Incorrect: Macrosomia is defined as a birth weight exceeding 4 kg (8.8 lb), regardless of gestational age. Macrosomia is associated with gestational diabetes, which would instead result in polyhydramnios, since the elevated maternal blood glucose leads to osmotic diuresis in the fetus.   
❌ Spina bifida occulta:
Incorrect: Spina bifida occulta is a type of neural tube defect. It is characterized by failed closure of the spinal canal but no herniation of neural tissues. Neural tube defects are often associated with low folic acid intake during pregnancy or use of certain medications (e.g. valproate). Spina bifida is not associated with oligohydramnios.  
❌ Urachal fistula:
Incorrect: A urachal fistula occurs when there is failure of the urachus to degenerate, resulting in open communication between the bladder and umbilicus. Patients may have excretion of urine via the umbilicus. The condition is not a cause of oligohydramnios.  
❌ Duodenal atresia:
Incorrect: Duodenal atresia occurs when the duodenum fails to recanalize properly. This results in the inability to swallow amniotic fluid and leads to polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male comes to the office for a follow-up appointment due to bloody urine and flank pain. He generally feels well, and medical history is unremarkable. The patient mentions that his father had high blood pressure and died at the age of 50 from cardiac complications. The patient does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 147/90 mmHg. A CT of the abdomen is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons 
This patient’s condition follows which of the following inheritance patterns?
questions.solution:
This has hypertension, hematuria, flank pain, and abdominal CT showing bilateral cystic masses. He has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).  

ADPKD, as the name suggests, is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 (85% of cases) or PKD2 gene on chromosome 4 (15% of cases). The age of presentation is variable, though most patients become symptomatic in adulthood and develop end-stage renal disease (ERSD) at age 50-70 years old. Of note, patients with PKD2 mutations usually have a less severe phenotype and develop ESRD later than patients with PKD1 mutations.  

Flank pain is the most common complaint and occurs due to renal hemorrhage, calculi, or urinary tract infection. Patients can also have hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, and impaird kidney function. Bilateral flank masses can sometimes be palpated. ADPKD is associated with some extra-renal manifestations, including berry aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, benign hepatic cysts, and diverticulosis.    

Interestingly, the majority of patients with ADPKD die from cardiac causes, more specifically cardiac hypertrophy and coronary artery disease. Diagnosis can be made by obtaining a detailed family history and confirming via imaging. Genetic testing is generally not required.  

Option Analysis

✅ Autosomal dominant: chromosome 16:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autosomal recessive: chromosome 6:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6. However, patients with ARPKD typically develop symptoms in utero or immediately after birth. Also, ARPKD is associated with liver disorders such as liver fibrosis and portal hypertension, which are not seen in this patient. This patient presentation is more consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which most frequently involves chromosomes 16.   
❌ Autosomal recessive: chromosome 7  :
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive condition caused by defects in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7, most commonly due to a deletion of Phe508. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which most frequently involves chromosome 16.   
❌ Autosomal dominant: chromosome 3:
Incorrect: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a deletion of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. It is associated with the development of tumors, ranging from the renal cell carcinoma to hemangioblastoma. However, this patient has hypertension, hematuria, and bilateral cystic masses, which is more consistent with the presentation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.  
❌ X-linked dominant:
Incorrect: Fragile X is an X-linked dominant condition caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. Symptoms include cognitive impairment, long faces, and macroorchidism. In contrast, this patient has hypertension, hematuria, and bilateral cystic masses, which is more consistent with the presentation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, end-stage kidney disease on dialysis, diabetes, and hypertension presents to the emergency department with a two day history of fever, chills, and dyspnea on exertion. The patient reports he receives dialysis 3 times/week and has not missed any of his scheduled appointments. He last received dialysis two days ago. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On physical examination the patient is ill-appearing. There are erythematous lesions noted on the chest and arms bilaterally, as well as a fistula with a palpable thrill in the left arm without evidence of overlying erythema, discharge, or excoriation. A holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the lower left sternal border. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Subacute deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves
Rapid bacteremia and acquisition of large vegetations on previously normal valves
Subacute bacteremia and acquisition of small vegetations on previously damaged valves
Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the urologic tract
Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the gastrointestinal tract

questions.solution:
Acute endocarditis is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus due to its high virulence.  It classically presents with the rapid development of fever, chills, shortness of breath, and signs of septic shock following inoculation. The infection leads to deposition of large vegetations on previously normal heart valves. The patient with a history of dialysis likely obtained the organism from a recent dialysis session where proper aseptic technique was not performed while accessing the fistula. Other patients at high risk for acute endocarditis include patients with IV drug use and those with central venous catheters that are frequently accessed.  

In contrast, subacute endocarditis most commonly occurs due to viridans group streptococci following dental procedures, as this group of organisms is highly prevalent as oral flora. This group of bacteria typically form smaller vegetations on previously damaged or prosthetic valves. Additionally, subacute endocarditis tends to have a slow, indolent presentation, causing fatigue, weakness, chills, and a new murmur over weeks to months. Other bacteria implicated in subacute endocarditis include Enterococcus faecalis, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Coxiella burnetii.   

Option Analysis

❌ Subacute deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves:
Incorrect: This answer is the pathogenesis that describes Libman-Sacks endocarditis, or marantic endocarditis, which commonly occurs in patients with underlying lupus or malignancy. This form of endocarditis, while possible in this patient given the history of lupus, tends to progress slowly over weeks, in contrast to the rapid onset of symptoms as seen in this patient.  
✅ Rapid bacteremia and acquisition of large vegetations on previously normal valves:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subacute bacteremia and acquisition of small vegetations on previously damaged valves:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis of subacute endocarditis, which commonly occurs due to infection with viridans streptococci following dental procedures, Staphylococcus epidermidis following invasive cardiac procedures, or Enterococcus faecalis following indwelling catheter placement. This form of endocarditis tends to progress over weeks to months, as opposed to days as in this patient.   
❌ Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the urologic tract:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis of endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis, which results after invasive urologic or abdominal procedures. It presents with the typical features of subacute endocarditis including malaise, fatigue, and a new murmur over a period of weeks to months.   
❌ Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: This describes the pathogenesis of endocarditis due to Streptococcus gallolyticus, also known as Streptococcus bovis, which has a high association in patients with underlying colorectal cancer. It presents with the typical features of subacute endocarditis including malaise, fatigue, and a new murmur over a period of weeks to months.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after exhibiting disorganized behavior and vomiting. Per EMS, the patient was yelling and smoking marijuana on the street, after which she began vomiting large amounts of non-bilious non-bloody emesis. She was given several doses of ondansetron and haloperidol prior to arrival, which improved the symptoms. Past medical history is notable for cyclic vomiting syndrome, schizophrenia, and hypothyroidism for which she takes metoclopramide, risperidone, and levothyroxine, respectively. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and uses marijuana several times per week. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a disheveled woman who is sleeping comfortably in bed. While the nurses are attempting to place an IV, telemetry displays the following finding:  

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s telemetry finding?
questions.solution:
This patient has received multiple anti-dopaminergic medications (e.g., metoclopramide, haloperidol, risperidone), which are known to prolong the QT interval. The telemetry strip demonstrates torsade de pointes, a subtype of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.  

Torsade de pointes means “twisting of the points” and is a subtype of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia defined by a ventricular rate >200 beats per minute, undulating QRS axis, and paroxysms of < 90 seconds. The major risk factor for developing torsade de pointes is QT interval prolongation, of which there are numerous causes.  

The most common causes include electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia and medications such as class IA and IC antiarrhythmics, antidepressants, antidopaminergics, antiemetics, and anticonvulsants. Less commonly, acquired conditions such as Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (associated with deafness, autosomal recessive) or Romano-Ward syndrome (normal hearing, autosomal dominant) can cause QT prolongation. Treatment of torsade de pointes involves empiric intravenous magnesium sulfate or cardioversion and overdrive pacing for patients with sustained torsade de pointes and unstable vital signs.  

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonism of D2 receptors:
Correct: See main explanation  
❌ Hypomagnesemia :
Incorrect: Alcoholism and gastrointestinal losses can result in hypomagnesemia and subsequent QT prolongation, resulting in torsade de pointes. However, this patient has no history of significant alcohol use, and hypomagnesemia is more likely to occur due to diarrhea than vomiting. Given this patient’s clinical history, overuse of anti-dopaminergic drugs is a more likely precipitant of this patient’s telemetry findings.   
❌ Autosomal recessive QT prolongation syndrome:
Incorrect: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is an autosomal recessive QT prolongation syndrome associated with sensorineural hearing loss. This patient has no history of hearing deficits.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Severe untreated hypothyroidism, usually in the setting myxedema coma, can lead to torsade de pointes. This is unlikely given the patient is being treated with levothyroxine and lacks clinical findings of severe hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, weakness, dry skin).   
❌ Marijuana use:
Incorrect: Marijuana use, in and of itself, is not associated with QT prolongation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe burns on his body sustained in a house fire about an hour ago. His left lower leg was trapped under a burning beam, and as a result, he could not immediately escape from the house. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/55 mmHg. He is conscious but is moaning in pain. There is no singed hair on his face or nostrils, and he is breathing spontaneously. Physical examination shows 2nd-degree burns to the anterior chest, abdomen, and entire left leg. Which of the following most likely represents the total percentage of his whole body surface area involved in the burn according to the rule of nines?
questions.solution:
This patient has sustained 2nd-degree burns on different parts of his body (anterior chest and abdomen, left leg) after being trapped in a house fire. His vitals are unstable (increased body temperature, tachycardia, hypotension) due to fluid loss through the damaged skin and widespread cytokine activation. He needs urgent medical attention to avoid possible complications (e.g., infection, lactic acidosis) and death.

Management of burn patients (e.g., fluid resuscitation, antibiotics) depends on the severity of the burns and the total body surface area (TBSA) involved. Different methods are employed to assess the TBSA of a patient with burns (e.g., Lund-Browder charting, Palm method, etc.). One such method is known as the “Rule of Nines.” It is one of the most expeditious methods to estimate TBSA in adults. It attributes 9% of the TBSA to each of the following areas: head, anterior chest, posterior chest, anterior abdomen, posterior abdomen, right arm, left arm, and anterior and posterior parts of the right and left legs each. The perineum is assigned 1% of the TBSA. Therefore in the above patient, his anterior chest (9%) and abdomen (9%), together with anterior (9%) and posterior (9%) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% (9+9+9+9) involvement of the TBSA.  



Option Analysis

❌ 27%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9=36%)  
✅ 36%  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 45%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9= 36%)  
❌ 54%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9= 36%)  
❌ 63%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9= 36%)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to his family physician for a routine school physical. The patient appears anxious and uneasy during the encounter. During the physical exam, the patient confesses that he feels insecure about his body. During gym practice, the patient has noticed that his genitalia appears different from his peers. There is no history of a disorder of sexual development within the family. The patient’s height and weight are at the 56<sup>th</sup> and 45<sup>th</sup> percentile for his age, respectively. On physical examination, ambiguous genitalia are present with a bifid scrotum, undescended testicles and hypospadias. Laboratory testing reveals an increased testosterone to dihydrotestosterone ratio. Which of the following is likely true regarding this patient’s parents?

choices.text: The patient’s father is homozygous recessive.
Neither parent possesses an allele for the disease.
The patient’s mother is homozygous dominant.

questions.solution:
On exam, this patient is found to have ambiguous genitalia, a bifid scrotum, hypospadias, and undescended testicles, which point to a disorder of sexual development (DSD). While DSDs encompass a large family of conditions, this patient’s elevated testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) level is indicative of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.

The ratio of increased testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) indicates this patient’s inability to convert testosterone to its more potent form, DHT. The enzyme responsible for this conversion is 5-alpha reductase. A mutation of this enzyme is caused by a mutation of the SRD5A2 gene, which is inherited in an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.  

Option Analysis

❌ Both parents are homozygous recessive.  :
Incorrect: The vignette states that there is no history of a disorder of sexual development in the family. If both parents were homozygous recessive, the father would present with symptoms of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.  
✅ Both parents are heterozygous.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The patient’s father is homozygous recessive.  :
Incorrect: The vignette states that there is no history of a disorder of sexual development in the family. If the patient's father were homozygous recessive, he would present with symptoms of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.  
❌ Neither parent possesses an allele for the disease.  :
Incorrect: This patient is suffering from 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, which is an autosomal recessive disease.  
❌ The patient’s mother is homozygous dominant.  :
Incorrect: 5-alpha-reductase deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder. If one parent is homozygous dominant, it would be impossible for him to inherit the disease.

questions.text: A 57-year-old individual is brought to the emergency department by their spouse due to an episode of vomiting blood several hours ago. The patient has a history of chronic alcohol use and was diagnosed with liver cirrhosis two years ago. The patient vomits blood twice in the emergency department. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 108/minute, and blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg. The patient appears to be disoriented. Two intravenous lines are secured, and the patient is started on a blood transfusion. Thirty minutes later, the patient begins experiencing chills and flank pain. In addition, the patient’s urine appears red. The patient’s temperature is now 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 130/minute, and blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Transfusion is immediately stopped, and aggressive hydration is started. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with hematemesis, and given the patient’s history of liver cirrhosis, the most likely cause of the hematemesis is ruptured esophageal varices: a life-threatening complication of liver failure and the most common cause of death in patients with liver cirrhosis. Patients with ruptured varices lose a significant amount of blood and must therefore be stabilized; blood units are given as needed. Upon receipt of this necessary transfusion, this patient developed chills, flank pain, red urine, fever, and hypotension within 30 minutes.
