Patients (especially on examination questions) typically present with the sensation of light flashes or floaters described as fine dots, veils, cobwebs, clouds, or strings, followed by sudden visual field loss in the affected eye. As the retina detaches, it may create a mechanical depolarization of the axons running through the nerve fiber layer of the retina, resulting in the sensation of flashing bright lights. Vision loss typically begins in the periphery and progresses toward the central visual axis over hours to weeks like a “curtain drawn down.” Diagnosis is based on a fundoscopic examination, which may visualize crinkling of retinal tissue or changes in blood vessel direction. Retinal detachment is an emergency and requires urgent surgery to restore sensory function.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retinal detachment   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Choroidal rupture   :
Incorrect: Choroidal rupture occurs in the setting of blunt trauma to the eye. Ophthalmoscopic examination reveals white or yellow streaks concentric to the optic disc.   
❌ Central retinal vein occlusion   :
Incorrect: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) can also present with sudden-onset, painless, monocular vision loss. Fundoscopic findings demonstrate engorged retinal veins and a “blood and thunder” appearance.   
❌ Proliferative diabetic retinopathy   :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of diabetes, her clinical and fundoscopic presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis. Fundoscopic findings of proliferative diabetic retinopathy include a net of neovascularization over the surface of the optic disc.   
❌ Central retinal artery occlusion   :
Incorrect: Central retinal artery occlusion results in sudden, painless monocular vision loss as well--often secondary to the carotid or cardiogenic embolism. Fundoscopy typically reveals a “cherry-red” spot overlying the fovea and a pale ischemic retina.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate facial lesions for one week (detailed in the image below). The patient notes significant weight loss and chronic diarrhea. Two weeks ago, he was initiated on an antiepileptic agent. The patient is sexually active with men and women and uses condoms inconsistently. He uses intravenous drugs, including heroin, and consumes alcohol daily. He has a pet cat at home. Temperature is 38.11°C (100.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the skin lesion reveals lymphocytic infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
 

Wikimedia commons
By M. Sand, D. Sand, C. Thrandorf, V. Paech, P. Altmeyer, F. G. Bechara - M. Sand, D. Sand, C. Thrandorf, V. Paech, P. Altmeyer, F. G. Bechara: Cutaneous lesions of the nose. In: Head & face medicine Band 6, 2010, S. 7, ISSN 1746-160X. doi:10.1186/1746-160X-6-7. PMID 20525327. (Review). Open Access, CC BY 2.0

choices.text: Vasculitis following inoculation of a bloodborne pathogen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple features consistent with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) with evidence of associated Kaposi sarcoma. HIV is an enveloped RNA virus transmitted via vaginal or anal sexual intercourse, bloodborne exposure (needle sticks, intravenous drug use, blood transfusions), or transmitted from mother to fetus in the perinatal period. Urine, saliva, and tears are considered to carry a low to nearly zero risk of transmission. The presence of concurrent sexually transmitted infections in an exposed individual increases the risk of transmission.

Once exposure occurs, HIV targets dendritic cells, CD4 T lymphocytes, and macrophages. Glycoprotein 120 (gp120) encoded by the viral env gene binds to chemokine receptors present on the surface of T lymphocytes (CXCR4) and macrophages (CCR5). Individuals with a homozygous deletion of the gene coding for CCR5 have relative resistance to HIV infection. Once bound, gp120 undergoes a conformational change that reveals the viral gp41 receptor, allowing membrane fusion with the host cell membrane. Upon viral entry, reverse transcriptase converts the two viral single-stranded RNA molecules to double-stranded DNA and integrates with the host genome using the enzyme integrase.

Polyproteins are transcribed from the newly integrated viral genome, cleaved, and released from the cell using the enzyme protease from the cell. The infected cell eventually undergoes apoptosis, resulting in a decline of CD4 lymphocytes and viremia leading to systemic disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV drug use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exposure to cats:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that completes a portion of its life cycle in feline feces. Transmission can occur through consuming contaminated fruits and vegetables and can result in fulminant infection in those with untreated AIDS and a CD4 count of fewer than 100 cells/microL. Infected patients present with features of meningoencephalitis and space-occupying lesions.  
❌ Contact with infected saliva:
Incorrect: HIV is not transmitted through saliva. It is primarily transmitted through bloodborne and sexual contact.  
❌ Vasculitis following inoculation of a bloodborne pathogen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis viruses can be transmitted through blood and manifest with dermatologic findings such as livedo reticularis. This rash appears as reddish-blue skin discoloration, with the legs most often affected. This patient has a different dermatologic finding suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Drug-induced reaction:
Incorrect: Lamotrigine, an antiepileptic agent, can cause Steven-Johnson syndrome. However, the rash is typically tender, ill-defined erythematous macules and is accompanied by fever and epidermal sloughing.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate blurry vision and dizziness. Her symptoms started around an hour ago. In addition, she is sweating and feels “as if my heart were racing”. While in the emergency room, the patient faints and collapses. Finger dipstick glucose level is measured to be 50 mg/dL. The patient is immediately given glucose. She regains consciousness, and her symptoms subsequently improve. The patient has had several similar episodes over the past month. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 120/81 mmHg, and pulse is 97/min. Serum analysis reveals elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient's history is notable for palpitations, blurry vision, dizziness, loss of consciousness, and hypoglycemia. These symptoms resolve after glucose administration. Furthermore, her serum insulin and C-peptide levels are elevated. In combination, these findings are concerning for insulinoma.  

Insulinomas are rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that arise from ꞵ-cells within the islets of Langerhans. Most cases are sporadic, although the condition can sometimes be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome.    

Insulinomas secrete insulin inappropriately and irrespective of serum glucose levels. As a result, patients with insulinomas are at risk of developing Whipple triad, which consists of hypoglycemia, hypoglycemic symptoms, and resolution of symptoms with glucose administration. Symptoms of hypoglycemia can include blurry vision, confusion, and in severe cases, seizures and coma. Moreover, patients may develop symptoms of adrenergic activation such as palpitations, sweating, and tremulousness.      

Insulinomas must be differentiated from excess exogenous insulin administration. While both conditions present with similar symptoms, a C-peptide level can be used to differentiate the two. C-peptide is a protein produced from ꞵ-cells in conjugation with insulin. Since patients with exogenous insulin use have low endogenous insulin production, C-peptide levels will be low. In contrast, patients with insulinomas will have high endogenous insulin production and elevated C-peptide levels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Insulinoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Exogenous insulin use:
Incorrect: Exogenous insulin use can cause hypoglycemia and associated symptoms, including dizziness, blurry vision, palpitations, and anxiety. However, serum C-peptide levels would be low in patients who inject exogenous insulin. 
❌ Glucagonoma:
Incorrect: Glucagonoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with increased glucagon production. These patients are at risk for hyperglycemia instead of hypoglycemia. 
❌ VIPoma :
Incorrect: VIPoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with increased vasoactive inflammatory peptides (VIP) production. Patients can develop the triad of hypokalemia, secretory diarrhea, and achlorhydria. It is not associated with hypoglycemia.
❌ Somatostatinoma :
Incorrect: Somatostatinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with increased somatostatin production. Somatostatin inhibits the synthesis of gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP), which promotes insulin release. As a result, a somatostatinoma would decrease insulin production and elevate blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician due to midline abdominal pain that has been ongoing for several months. The pain is described as a burning sensation and worsens after meals. As a result, the patient has been eating less and has experienced a 5 kg (11 lb) weight loss. She has a history of peptic ulcer disease, which was diagnosed last year. She was prescribed omeprazole but has not noticed an improvement in symptoms after initiating therapy. Medical history is also notable for low back pain. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastric region. An endoscopy is performed and shows multiple ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. A urea breath test is negative. Administration of intravenous secretin is followed by an increase in serum gastrin levels by 200 pg/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has peptic ulcer disease refractory to treatment. In addition, a secretin test returns positive. These findings suggest that Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES) is secondary to gastrinoma, a type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor.  

Most gastrinomas arise in either the duodenum or pancreas. Gastrinomas can arise sporadically, with a median age between 20-50, or as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome.  

The pathophysiology of gastrinomas is related to the oversecretion of gastrin, which stimulates gastric parietal cells to produce excess acid. The acid causes gastric and duodenal ulcers that are usually multiple, recurrent, and refractory to treatment. Since so much acid is produced, ulcers can even form in areas of the gastrointestinal tract far from the stomach (e.g. jejunum).    

Moreover, the increase in duodenal acidity deactivates pancreatic enzymes and damages epithelial cells. These changes impair food absorption, causing chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss.    

The diagnosis of ZES can be challenging. Patients will often have elevated serum gastrin levels and increased stomach acidity. In addition, a secretin stimulation test can be used to assist with diagnosis. Secretin normally inhibits gastrin and gastric acid release. However, secretin administration leads to paradoxical elevations in gastrin levels in patients with gastrinomas.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ NSAID use  :
Incorrect: NSAIDs can prevent the release of prostaglandins, which have a protective effect on the gastric mucosa, and cause gastric ulcers. However, a positive secretin test is indicative of gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.   
❌ Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: The infection of Helicobacter pylori (H.Pylori) is the most common cause of peptic ulcer disease. However, a negative urea breath test and a positive secretin test are more suggestive of gastrinoma than H.pylori infection.
❌ Stress ulcer:
Incorrect: Stress ulcers are seen in severely ill patients (e.g. ICU patients). Stress ulcers are related to decreased blood flow to the stomach, increasing mucosal injury risk.
❌ Cushing ulcer:
Incorrect: A Cushing ulcer is a gastric ulcer that develops in the setting of elevated intracranial pressure. The increase in intracranial pressure causes vagal nerve overactivation, which results in acid oversecretion. However, a secretin test would be negative in patients with Cushing ulcers.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife to evaluate his altered mental status. The wife states her husband complained of headache and blurry vision earlier that morning with associated nausea and vomiting. He tried taking acetaminophen with minimal relief. His past medical history includes hypertension and a 35 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 158/98 mmHg. There is spontaneous flexion of the hips with passive flexion of the neck. Which of the following findings on fundoscopy contraindicates the performance of a diagnostic lumbar puncture?

choices.text: Edematous optic disc with blurred margins
Enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio
Extensive retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, and a positive Brudzinski sign--concerning meningitis. Unless contraindicated, every patient with suspected meningitis should undergo lumbar puncture (LP). Suppose a lumbar puncture is performed in the setting of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In that case,  a cerebral herniation may ensue due to the rapid change in intracavitary pressure as cerebrospinal fluid is removed for analysis. Any diagnostic physical exam findings that suggest elevated ICP (e.g., papilledema) prohibit the performance of this procedure.  

Papilledema refers to swelling of the optic disc and has multiple etiologies. Meningitis may cause elevated ICP via obstructive hydrocephalus or impaired cerebrospinal fluid absorption due to  inflammation at the level of arachnoid granulations. Fundoscopic findings of papilledema demonstrate an enlarged blind spot and an elevated, edematous disc, with blurred disc margins and engorged blood vessels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Edematous optic disc with blurred margins   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio   :
Incorrect: This finding suggests open-angle glaucoma, which typically presents as progressive peripheral vision loss with findings of an enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio (“cupping” of the optic disc) on fundoscopy.   
❌ Extensive retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement   :
Incorrect: This fundoscopic finding is often observed in patients with retinal vein occlusion. Patients typically present with sudden onset, painless, monocular vision loss.   
❌ Retinal neovascularization   :
Incorrect: Formation of new blood vessels (neovascularization) is often seen in the advanced stages of diabetic retinopathy. This finding occurs secondary to retinal ischemia and subsequent upregulation of pro-angiogenic cytokines, namely, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Neovascularization is not a contraindication to the performance of a lumbar puncture.   
❌ Crinkling of retinal tissue   :
Incorrect: Retinal detachment typically presents as flashes or floaters followed by sudden, painless visual field loss in the affected eye. Vision loss typically begins in the periphery and progresses toward loss of the central visual axis over hours to weeks. A fundoscopic examination may demonstrate wrinkling/crinkling of retinal tissue or changes in blood vessel direction. These fundoscopic findings do not suggest papilledema and hence do not contraindicate the performance of a lumbar puncture.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist after his primary care doctor noted ocular malalignment. He was born at full term without complications. The patient has been growing well along with the 50th percentile for height and weight. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals malalignment of the right eye. Examination with an ophthalmoscope reveals a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. Dilated fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown below. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor
Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions

questions.solution:
This young child presents with strabismus, leukocoria, and fundoscopy findings consistent with retinoblastoma. This retinal tumor of childhood is caused by a mutation in both alleles of the retinoblastoma or RB1 gene on chromosome 13. Retinoblastomas can be hereditary, in which case the individual inherits a mutation in one of the alleles of the RB1 gene; however, random mutations in this gene may also lead to the development of retinoblastoma. Hereditary retinoblastomas are typically bilateral and are associated with an increased risk of developing additional malignancies, including osteosarcoma, sarcomas, and melanoma. Sporadic retinoblastomas tend to be unilateral.  

Clinical features of retinoblastoma include leukocoria or “white pupil” with red reflex testing. Typically, reflected light from the fundus appears red; however, a tumor that grows over the fundus blocks reflected light such that the pupil appears white. Other common symptoms include strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), nystagmus, or ocular inflammation. Metastases to the brain are common, presenting with findings of vomiting, headaches, or neurologic deficits. Diagnosis of retinoblastoma begins with a red reflex testing, followed by a fundoscopic examination. Characteristic findings on fundoscopy include the presence of a chalky, off-white retinal mass with a soft, friable consistency. A biopsy is not necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Definitive treatment depends on the extent of disease progression, but in early stages typically consists of enucleation or complete removal of the eye.  

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions   :
Incorrect: Patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)  inherited germline mutations in DNA-repair genes, resulting in hypermethylation of these crucial repair proteins.   
❌ Increased B-catenin synthesis   :
Incorrect: The APC gene encodes a cytoplasmic protein that promotes the degradation of B-catenin. Mutation in the APC gene develops colonic polyps, not retinoblastoma.   
❌ Loss of serine-threonine kinase activity   :
Incorrect: Mutations in the LKB1 or STK11 gene are present in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. These genes encode a tumor suppressor protein involved in cell signaling and apoptosis. Loss of kinase activity of STK11 is associated with deranged growth suppression function. Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome characteristically have a hyperpigmented perioral area, along with an increased risk for gastrointestinal cancers.   
❌ Impaired production of p53 protein   :
Incorrect: A mutation in the TP53 gene reduces the production of the tumor suppressor protein p53. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a rare cancer-predisposition syndrome caused by autosomal dominant mutations in the TP53 gene. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is also known as sarcoma, breast, leukemia, and adrenal gland (SBLA) cancer syndrome.
